From harbour@lists.harbour-project.org  Thu Mar  1 00:24:01 2001
From: harbour@lists.harbour-project.org (Ron Pinkas)
Date: Thu Mar  1 00:24:01 2001
Subject: [Harbour] MEMVARs problem (Ryszard)
In-Reply-To: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKOEPMDJAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>
Message-ID: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKOEPODJAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>

Ryszard,

This is getting more interesting...

In Clipper, if the var is created with __QQPUB() __MRelease() will not
release it but MXRelease() will! Same is true for the PUBLIC command.

For PRIVATES neither __MRelease() nor __MXRelease() releases the var,
instead it just becomes NIL.

Both PRIVATE and PUBLICS will get release with __MClear()

In Harbour, __MXRelease() *should* release publics but it does not.

Ron

> Sorry for the wrong subject line.
>
> Correction, in Harbour even __MRelease() does not release the var as it
> should.
>
> > Ryszard,
> >
> > In Clipper releasing a PUBLIC render the var undefined in Harbour
> > it remains
> > valid and becomes NIL. Please note, than in both Clipper and
> Harbour this
> > will be true with PRIVATEs.
> >
> > Also note that RELEASE uses __MXRelease(). If you manually use
> > __MRelease()
> > then both Harbor and Clipper do release the var rendering it undefined.
> >
> >    //----------
> >    //PRIVATE x // works differently.
> >    PUBLIC x
> >
> >    ? x
> >
> >    RELEASE x
> >
> >    ? x // In Harbour NIL, in Clipper RT Err.
> >
> >    //__MCLEAR( "x" )
> >    //----------
> >
> > Ron


From harbour@lists.harbour-project.org  Thu Mar  1 01:24:02 2001

   * contrib/dot/pp.prg
     * Improved management of variable scoping.

   /* Appears to work correctly when compiled with Clipper, but is incorrect
under Harbour, because
      __MXRelease() is not releasing memvars as it should. */

> [mailto:harbour-admin@lists.harbour-project.org]Namens Ron Pinkas

> Aan: clipper@gospelcards.com.br; abc@ibm.com; root@cartesis.com;
> jvtecheto@iname.com
> CC: Harbour@Lists. Harbour-Project. Org
> Onderwerp: [Harbour] Harbour Project VIRUS warning
>
>
> Dear Harbour users,
>
> Server logs indicate that you downloaded the recent MSVC SimpLex
> BUILD 0.36
> of Harbour.
>
> This message is to inform you that this zip file contains executables
> infected with a virus.
>
> I would like to offer my personal apology, and some instructions on how to
> rid your system, from this Virus.
>
> I successfully cleaned my system by performing the following:
>
> 1. Use FREE HouseCall from
> http://housecall.antivirus.com/housecall/start_corp.asp
>
> 2. Choose Auto Clean, which will successfully clean most files on your
> system, but will fail to clean executables currently in use. This
> in my case
> included files like:
>
>    \windows\
>             explorer.exe
>             taskmon.exe
>             \system\
>                     ddhelp.exe
>                     mprexe.exe
>                     rnaapp.exe
>                     spool32.exe
>                     tapisrv .exe
>                     ssdpsrv.exe
>
>    \Program Files\Internet Explorer\iexplore.exe
>
> 3. Record a list of all these files and copy them to any temp
> folder on your
> system.
>
> 4. Run HouseCall again, this time pointing it to just that temp folder.
> HouseCall will successfully clean these copies.
>
> 5. Create a DOS Boot disk, or reboot your system into DOS mode. If you did
> create a BOOT disk, scan this disk by HouseCall, though in my case, there
> was no such infection.
>
> 6. After rebooting in DOS mode, copy all clean copies from step 4. onto
> their original location recorded in step 3.
>
> 7. Reboot your system, into Windows, and perform full scan of your system
> again. All should be clean!
>
> Again please accept my apologies.
>
> Ron Pinkas
>

> Harbour mailing list
> Harbour@lists.harbour-project.org
> http://www.matrixlist.com/mailman/listinfo/harbour

> http://www.Harbour-Project.org

From harbour@lists.harbour-project.org  Thu Mar  1 02:49:02 2001
From: harbour@lists.harbour-project.org (Dave Pearson)
Date: Thu Mar  1 02:49:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Our current GPL license probably won't do what we want it to do.
In-Reply-To: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKAEPLDJAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>; from Ron@Profit-Master.com on Wed, Feb 28, 2001 at 04:56:05PM -0800
References: <200102282324.f1SNOK524504@thor.parrett.net> <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKAEPLDJAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>
Message-ID: <20010301074534.F8427@hagbard.davep.org>

On Wed, Feb 28, 2001 at 04:56:05PM -0800, Ron Pinkas wrote:

> The LGPL is too complex for me to explain the problems, but those
> interested should carefully read sections 5 and 6, to understand the
> problems.

<URL:http://www.harbour-project.org/faq/harbour-2.html#ss2.12> is the
"nutshell" explanation of why we didn't use the LGPL for any part of
harbour.

> 1. The code generated by the Harbour Compiler (either in source or object
> form), is not subject to the Harbour License Agreement, as long as it is
> being linked with the HVM, and HRTL to form an Executable. Or  being
> provided in a object/lib form to serve as a linkable "library" to be linked
> with Harbour Compiler Generated Output (either in source or object form),
> and the HVM and HRTL to form an executable.

I don't like these restrictions at all. I don't think there should be any
restriction on what people do with the output from the harbour compiler.
This seems very unfree to me.

> 2. Linking the HVM code, into an application, does not subject the
> application to the Harbour License Agreement, as long as it is being linked
> with an Harbour Compiler Generated Output (either in source or object form)
> and the HRTL to form an executable.

This effectively stops anyone building alternative compilers that make use
of the HVM and HRTL, I'm not sure this is what is wanted.

> 2. Linking the HRTL code, into an application, does not subject the
> application to the Harbour License Agreement, as long as it is being linked
> with an Harbour Compiler Generated Output (either in source or object form)
> and the HVM to form an executable.

This also seems to have the same restriction against people building
alternative compilers.

-- 
The Harbour Project: A free software Clipper compatible compiler
Home Page..........: http://www.harbour-project.org/
FAQ................: http://www.harbour-project.org/faq/harbour.html
My harbour page....: http://www.davep.org/harbour/

From harbour@lists.harbour-project.org  Thu Mar  1 02:49:06 2001
From: harbour@lists.harbour-project.org (Dave Pearson)
Date: Thu Mar  1 02:49:06 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Our current GPL license probably won't do what we want it to do.
In-Reply-To: <200102282324.f1SNOK524504@thor.parrett.net>; from dholm@jsd-llc.com on Wed, Feb 28, 2001 at 06:24:13PM -0500
References: <200102282058.f1SKwuh11637@thor.parrett.net> <200102282058.f1SKwuh11637@thor.parrett.net> <20010228220219.T7328@hagbard.davep.org> <200102282213.f1SMDb518505@thor.parrett.net> <200102282213.f1SMDb518505@thor.parrett.net> <20010228221929.A8427@hagbard.davep.org> <200102282225.f1SMPp519627@thor.parrett.net> <200102282225.f1SMPp519627@thor.parrett.net> <20010228223922.B8427@hagbard.davep.org> <200102282324.f1SNOK524504@thor.parrett.net>
Message-ID: <20010301073821.E8427@hagbard.davep.org>

On Wed, Feb 28, 2001 at 06:24:13PM -0500, David G. Holm wrote:
> ** Reply to message from Dave Pearson <davep@davep.org> on Wed, 28 Feb
> 2001 22:39:22 +0000
> 
> > Interestingly we'd have none of these problems (modulo the GETSYS and
> > friends issue) if it were possible to LGPL the harbour VM and RTL.
> 
> After looking at ancient Harbour mailing list messages, I find that I
> originally argued for using LGPL for the HRL and HVM, with GPL for
> everything else. But the group elected to use the Harbour Exception, due
> to claims that the LGPL was too ambiguous for commercial use of programs
> created from Harbour.

For the purposes of clarification (of the situation, not the historical
discussions): not using the LGPL has nothing to do with allowing commercial
software (harbour can be used commercially, all free software can) and
everything to do with recognising that many people will want to distribute
non-free software where their code, the HVM and the RTL will be combined
into one monolithic file.

The LGPL is clear about the licence requirements for a person's code if they
decide to distribute binary versions of LGPL'd code in that way.

See <URL:http://www.harbour-project.org/faq/harbour-2.html#ss2.12> for my
explanation of why we didn't go for the LGPL.

>                       The intent of the Harbour Exception is *clearly* to
> allow commercial programs that include bug fixes and/or enhancements to
> Harbour without the commercial programs coming under the GPL, but with the
> requirement that the bug fixes and/or enhancements be freely available. 

Again, to clarify, strike "commercial" from the above and insert "non-free".

>                                                                         So
> if the Harbour Exception, as currently worded, does not accomplish this,
> then it needs to be corrected.

I think the harbour exception is ambiguous at best. I'm currently wondering
if we should keep it as it is and perhaps have a short document that
clarifies the *intent* of the exception (or, more importantly, the *intent*
of the copyright holders who use that licence).

The likes of GETSYS and friends should probably still have their licences
relaxed though. I see no point in requiring people who develop non-free
applications with harbour, and who need to fiddle with GETSYS or ERRORSYS,
make an offer to supply the source of those parts of harbour.

-- 
The Harbour Project: A free software Clipper compatible compiler
Home Page..........: http://www.harbour-project.org/
FAQ................: http://www.harbour-project.org/faq/harbour.html
My harbour page....: http://www.davep.org/harbour/

From harbour@lists.harbour-project.org  Thu Mar  1 04:43:02 2001
From: harbour@lists.harbour-project.org (Dave Pearson)
Date: Thu Mar  1 04:43:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Some observations on the harbour web pages
Message-ID: <20010301094200.K8427@hagbard.davep.org>

Just a small observation about the harbour download page (perhaps this
effects other pages too, I don't know). It speaks a lot about "16 bits" and
"32 bits" and the like. Ideally it should be "16 bit" and "32 bit". That is,
generally, you don't use the plural in this case.

The download page does actually have examples of the singular usage in one
or two of the comment fields.

One other question about the downloads page, is there really any point in
still having the "DevCenter" on there?

On the opening page I noticed:

,----
| MemoEdit() for 95% complete
`----

which doesn't parse very well. Perhaps:

,----
| MemoEdit() is now almost complete
`----

would work better?

On the links page the "Guide to Lex and Yacc" link appears to have moved.
It's no longer at <URL:http://members.nbci.com/thomasn/y_man.htm> but
instead appears to be at <URL:http://epaperpress.com/y_man.html>.

On <URL:http://www.harbour-project.org/doc/index.htm> the title:

,----
| Alphabetical list of functions by Categorie
`----

should read:

,----
| Alphabetical list of functions by category
`----

Is <URL:http://www.harbour-project.org/doc/overview.htm> anyone's
responsibility? The reason I ask is that it's got interesting statements
like:

,----
| Very important: The preprocessor functionality is not built in yet. So you
| may test only Clipper language without preprocessor commands, etc.
`----

I'd forgotten that there was a time when harbour didn't have a
pre-processor. ;>

I'd be happy to write and maintain an overview if nobody "owns" that
document and if nobody has a burning desire to write it instead. That said,
I think the FAQ probably serves exactly the purpose of that document
(thoughts anyone)?

Also, on <URL:http://www.harbour-project.org/doc/index.htm> I'd probably
change the text of the link called "GNU licence" to "The GNU General Public
Licence". There is no "GNU licence", there are many GNU licences (GPL, LGPL,
and GFDL).

On <URL:http://www.harbour-project.org/mailinglist.htm> the description for
the harbour talk list talks about the harbour "cominity", that should be
"community". Also, the trailing part that says "fits in Harbour Talk" will
probably read better if it starts with "fit", not "fits".

On <URL:http://www.harbour-project.org/crew.htm> it would appear that a
number of country pointers still ain't quite right. For example, Brian Hays'
entry says that he lives in the US but if you follow the link for the US you
get <URL:http://www.worldtime.org/cgi-bin/wt.cgi?cnt=53478&ID=761452251a&land=223>.

<URL:http://www.worldtime.org/cgi-bin/wt.cgi?cnt=53478&ID=761452251a&land=191>
isn't Spain, at least, I don't think it is <g>>

<URL:http://www.worldtime.org/cgi-bin/wt.cgi?cnt=53478&ID=761452251a&land=174>
doesn't look much like Russia.

<URL:http://www.worldtime.org/cgi-bin/wt.cgi?cnt=53478&ID=761452251a&land=168>
makes Poland look a little wet.

That might not be all of them, the above were a random sample.

-- 
The Harbour Project: A free software Clipper compatible compiler
Home Page..........: http://www.harbour-project.org/
FAQ................: http://www.harbour-project.org/faq/harbour.html
My harbour page....: http://www.davep.org/harbour/

   * harbour/include/hbapi.h
     + New function ISOBJECT() added.

As you may be aware, a Harbour object is also an array,
this is why it is needed a new function to distinct those 
different types.

Antonio

From harbour@lists.harbour-project.org  Thu Mar  1 05:54:02 2001
From: harbour@lists.harbour-project.org (John Skelton)
Date: Thu Mar  1 05:54:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Our current GPL license probably won't do what
 we want it to do.
Message-ID: <200103010540_MC2-C738-718C@compuserve.com>

Dave,

| /* As a special exception, when this file is copied by Bison into a
|    Bison output file, you may use that output file without restriction.=

|    This special exception was added by the Free Software Foundation
|    in version 1.24 of Bison.  */

"IOW, it's under the GPL but the GPL doesn't apply when bison produces
output. If you decide to modify bison.simple for your own purposes then t=
he
exception no longer applies."

So don't modify bison.simple.  Instead, modify the output file it was
copied into. :-)

John.

From harbour@lists.harbour-project.org  Thu Mar  1 07:31:05 2001
From: harbour@lists.harbour-project.org (Dave Pearson)
Date: Thu Mar  1 07:31:05 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Our current GPL license probably won't do what we want it to do.

Message-ID: <20010301114402.M8427@hagbard.davep.org>

On Thu, Mar 01, 2001 at 05:39:43AM -0500, John Skelton wrote:
> Dave,
> 
> | /* As a special exception, when this file is copied by Bison into a
> |    Bison output file, you may use that output file without restriction.
> |    This special exception was added by the Free Software Foundation
> |    in version 1.24 of Bison.  */
> 
> "IOW, it's under the GPL but the GPL doesn't apply when bison produces
> output. If you decide to modify bison.simple for your own purposes then the
> exception no longer applies."
> 
> So don't modify bison.simple.  Instead, modify the output file it was
> copied into. :-)

Keeping in mind that you're allowed to do that (if I'm reading it right) but
that the output file has nowhere near the same utility as the input file (in
the context of the intended utility of the input file).

From harbour@lists.harbour-project.org  Thu Mar  1 07:36:01 2001
From: harbour@lists.harbour-project.org (John Skelton)
Date: Thu Mar  1 07:36:01 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Our current GPL license probably won't do what
 we want it to do.
Message-ID: <200103010540_MC2-C738-718A@compuserve.com>

Ron,

"clear that the LGPL is far to restrictive for the
defacto understanding of what we want for Harbour."

Don't its "restrictive" issues also cause problems with non-free
software on Linux?  (Pretty much every C app uses the GNU libc.)
I wonder how so many people/companies deal with that, if so.

Your suggested licence looks a good start, but what bothers me is
that creating licences which accurately and unambiguously allow and
prevent the desired things appears to be very hard.  The FSF/RMS have
had several attempts...

BTW, it's one thing to have a license but entirely another to enforce
it.  Costs loadsa money!  Who's providing it?

"1. ... as long as it is being linked with the HVM, and HRTL to form
an Executable. Or being provided in a object/lib form to serve as a
linkable "library" to be linked with Harbour Compiler Generated Output
(either in source or object form), and the HVM and HRTL to form an
executable."

Would that allow a DLL made using harbour.exe?  Is a DLL an
"Executable"?

John.

From harbour@lists.harbour-project.org  Thu Mar  1 07:38:02 2001
From: harbour@lists.harbour-project.org (Alexander S.Kresin)
Date: Thu Mar  1 07:38:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Re: Some questions
In-Reply-To: <9413346403.20010224115209@orel.ru>
References: <9413346403.20010224115209@orel.ru>
Message-ID: <15717073843.20010301132715@belacy.belgorod.su>

On 24.02.2001 11:52, Alex Shashkov <shashkov@orel.ru> wrote:

AS> 1. What do you think about nation support of such functions as:
AS> UPPER(), LOWER(), ISALPHA(), ISDIGIT(), ISLOWER(), ISUPPER() and
AS> character compare?

 I think, that we should do it :). If you want - go for it.

AS> 2. When creating the index tag the sorting of all the keys is
AS> performed in the memory and only then it is recorded to the index
AS> file (for DBFCDX).

 For DBFNTX it isn't so currently, but I have in mind to rewrite the
 indexing algorithm.
 
AS>  For that purpose the memory is allocated by the
AS> function hb_xgrab(). For very big .dbf files the physical memory may
AS> not be enough and the application terminates errors. Maybe OS swaps
AS> automatically on the disc and hb_xgrab() will work without errors?
AS> (Though it doesn't seem to me that it will be so.)

  I don't think so, too.
  
AS> There is another way to solve that problem. When there is no free
AS> memory left, we just need to write all the keys to the index file and
AS> then to continue the sorting. In order to realize that way we are to
AS> know beforehand how much of the free memory is left. Now the function
AS> MEMORY() works only under OS Windows. We may use the function hb_xalloc()
AS> instead of hb_xgrab() and react to the error ourselves.
AS> To cut the long story short, does it make sense for me to write the
AS> support in order to make this work: when there is not enough memory, all
AS> the keys should be written to the index file and then the sorting will
AS> continue and in the end the correction of the index file takes place?

  Yes, definitely.
  But, probably, it's better firstly to fix some other DBFCDX
  problems:
   - it don't build proper indexes under other than Win32/BCC
   platforms,
   - it GPF's while indexing if the index file already exist (
   building second tag, for example ).
   
   Of course, it's your choice, what to do.

AS> 3. Maybe someone can describe the work of FOR CONDITION, ORDSCOPE(),
AS> ORDCONDSET(), custom order and ORDKEYADD(), ORDKEYDEL() to me? Maybe
AS> you will send a sample on Clipper to me?

  I'll send you what you need.


Best regards,
 Alexander
http://members.xoom.com/alkresin/



From harbour@lists.harbour-project.org  Thu Mar  1 08:31:02 2001
From: harbour@lists.harbour-project.org (Dave Pearson)
Date: Thu Mar  1 08:31:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Our current GPL license probably won't do what we want it to do.
In-Reply-To: <200103010540_MC2-C738-718A@compuserve.com>; from John_Skelton@compuserve.com on Thu, Mar 01, 2001 at 05:39:42AM -0500
References: <200103010540_MC2-C738-718A@compuserve.com>
Message-ID: <20010301131046.P8427@hagbard.davep.org>

On Thu, Mar 01, 2001 at 05:39:42AM -0500, John Skelton wrote:

> Don't its "restrictive" issues also cause problems with non-free software
> on Linux? (Pretty much every C app uses the GNU libc.) I wonder how so
> many people/companies deal with that, if so.

No, the likes of glibc don't cause problems because glibc is generally used
within the terms of the LGPL. Think about shared libraries (DLLs if you
like) and you'll see why LGPLd code on Unix/Linux doesn't suffer from such a
"restriction".

> BTW, it's one thing to have a license but entirely another to enforce it.
> Costs loadsa money! Who's providing it?

Enforcement is down to the individual copyright holders. Sure, chances are
that it can't and won't be enforced. The licence speaks to honest people,
not dishonest people.

--

From harbour@lists.harbour-project.org  Thu Mar  1 10:52:02 2001
From: harbour@lists.harbour-project.org (Ron Pinkas)
Date: Thu Mar  1 10:52:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Our current GPL license probably won't do what  we want it to do.
In-Reply-To: <200103010540_MC2-C738-718A@compuserve.com>
Message-ID: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKAEACDKAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>

John

> "1. ... as long as it is being linked with the HVM, and HRTL to form
> an Executable. Or being provided in a object/lib form to serve as a
> linkable "library" to be linked with Harbour Compiler Generated Output
> (either in source or object form), and the HVM and HRTL to form an
> executable."
> 
> Would that allow a DLL made using harbour.exe?  Is a DLL an
> "Executable"?

Yes, DLL is either a linkable library, and or an executable.

Ron 


From harbour@lists.harbour-project.org  Thu Mar  1 11:09:02 2001
From: harbour@lists.harbour-project.org (Ron Pinkas)
Date: Thu Mar  1 11:09:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Our current GPL license probably won't do what we want it to do.
In-Reply-To: <20010301074534.F8427@hagbard.davep.org>
Message-ID: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKKEACDKAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>

Dave,

> > 1. The code generated by the Harbour Compiler (either in source
> or object
> > form), is not subject to the Harbour License Agreement, as long as it is
> > being linked with the HVM, and HRTL to form an Executable. Or  being
> > provided in a object/lib form to serve as a linkable "library"
> to be linked
> > with Harbour Compiler Generated Output (either in source or
> object form),
> > and the HVM and HRTL to form an executable.
>
> I don't like these restrictions at all. I don't think there should be any
> restriction on what people do with the output from the harbour compiler.
> This seems very unfree to me.

Could you please provide an example of what *desired* (from Harbour stand
point) freedom will be restricted by the above. I can't think of any thing
we would *want* to allow, that does not fall within the above.

> > 2. Linking the HVM code, into an application, does not subject the
> > application to the Harbour License Agreement, as long as it is
> being linked
> > with an Harbour Compiler Generated Output (either in source or
> object form)
> > and the HRTL to form an executable.
>
> This effectively stops anyone building alternative compilers that make use
> of the HVM and HRTL, I'm not sure this is what is wanted.

That's exactly the purpose of the above! Unless I'm mistaken, I 'm not the
only one who does *not* want to see his hard work, used by some other
free/non free software labeled as someone else's compiler. I believe we
would like our work to remain FREE in the context of Harbour, and *only* in
the context of Harbour.


> > 2. Linking the HRTL code, into an application, does not subject the
> > application to the Harbour License Agreement, as long as it is
> being linked
> > with an Harbour Compiler Generated Output (either in source or
> object form)
> > and the HVM to form an executable.
>
> This also seems to have the same restriction against people building
> alternative compilers.

Ditto.

Ron


From harbour@lists.harbour-project.org  Thu Mar  1 11:57:03 2001
From: harbour@lists.harbour-project.org (Dave Pearson)
Date: Thu Mar  1 11:57:03 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Our current GPL license probably won't do what we want it to do.
In-Reply-To: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKKEACDKAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>; from Ron@Profit-Master.com on Thu, Mar 01, 2001 at 08:06:37AM -0800
References: <20010301074534.F8427@hagbard.davep.org> <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKKEACDKAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>
Message-ID: <20010301165602.F19820@hagbard.davep.org>

On Thu, Mar 01, 2001 at 08:06:37AM -0800, Ron Pinkas wrote:
> Dave,
> 
> > I don't like these restrictions at all. I don't think there should be
> > any restriction on what people do with the output from the harbour
> > compiler. This seems very unfree to me.
> 
> Could you please provide an example of what *desired* (from Harbour stand
> point) freedom will be restricted by the above. I can't think of any thing
> we would *want* to allow, that does not fall within the above.

One obvious example is that I may wish to link the harbour output with a HVM
that I've written for myself from scratch, say, a HVM for the Palm or
something. Such a VM might be so different that it couldn't reasonably be
considered to be a HVM. The restriction regarding the output would stop this
from happening.

> > > 2. Linking the HVM code, into an application, does not subject the
> > > application to the Harbour License Agreement, as long as it is being
> > > linked with an Harbour Compiler Generated Output (either in source or
> > > object form) and the HRTL to form an executable.
> >
> > This effectively stops anyone building alternative compilers that make
> > use of the HVM and HRTL, I'm not sure this is what is wanted.
> 
> That's exactly the purpose of the above! Unless I'm mistaken, I 'm not the
> only one who does *not* want to see his hard work, used by some other
> free/non free software labeled as someone else's compiler. I believe we
> would like our work to remain FREE in the context of Harbour, and *only*
> in the context of Harbour.

If that's the case harbour won't be free software after all. Think about it
for a moment, if all free software authors felt that way hardly any of the
tools that are employed in the production of harbour would be available.
DJGPP, for example, could never have existed, neither could Ming32 and the
like.

Where's the freedom in attempting to stop other free software authors from
building on harbour while, at the same time, supporting and allowing the
production of non-free software that makes use of harbour or is built with
harbour?

Why would you want to stop people building free software on top of free
software? Also, why would you want to stop people building non-free software
that makes use of free software?

I find it disturbing that the likes of Clip4Win and FiveW*n would be allowed
to exploit harbour but I wouldn't be allowed to write my own free software
(or even non-free) alternative to the harbour compiler.

-- 
The Harbour Project: A free software Clipper compatible compiler
Home Page..........: http://www.harbour-project.org/
FAQ................: http://www.harbour-project.org/faq/harbour.html
My harbour page....: http://www.davep.org/harbour/

From harbour@lists.harbour-project.org  Thu Mar  1 12:55:04 2001
From: harbour@lists.harbour-project.org (David G. Holm)
Date: Thu Mar  1 12:55:04 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Our current GPL license probably won't do what we want it to do.
In-Reply-To: <3A9D7BE5.20248.95021EE@localhost>
References: <20010228203633.R7328@hagbard.davep.org> <200102282058.f1SKwuh11637@thor.parrett.net>
Message-ID: <200103011753.f21Hrw501972@thor.parrett.net>

** Reply to message from "Phil Barnett" <midnight@the-oasis.net> on
Wed, 28 Feb 2001 22:29:57 -0500

> And, I can tell you right now, every time I want to modify errorsys, I 
> don't want to reapply it to the original source and rebuild Harbour. I 
> can't believe that this is what you are really suggesting...

I'm not suggesting this. I'm claiming that this is what the Harbour
Exception allows one to do, whereas Dave claims that even reapplying the
change to the original source and rebuilding Harbour qualifies as a
derivative work and forces your application to be under GPL, should you
release a binary-only distribution of it. I can't believe that you
missed the part where I agreed with Dave's suggestion that certain files
that developers frequently modify, such as ERRORSYS.PRG, be released to
the public domain.
-- 
David G. Holm, Set Captain and all around
Harbour Project Clipper Compatibility fanatic.

From harbour@lists.harbour-project.org  Thu Mar  1 13:06:02 2001
From: harbour@lists.harbour-project.org (Dave Pearson)
Date: Thu Mar  1 13:06:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Our current GPL license probably won't do what we want it to do.
In-Reply-To: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKKEACDKAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>; from Ron@Profit-Master.com on Thu, Mar 01, 2001 at 08:06:37AM -0800
References: <20010301074534.F8427@hagbard.davep.org> <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKKEACDKAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>

On Thu, Mar 01, 2001 at 08:06:37AM -0800, Ron Pinkas wrote:

>                                                            I believe we
> would like our work to remain FREE in the context of Harbour, and *only*
> in the context of Harbour.

One other thought occurs. If what you say here really is representative of
the desires of any harbour copyright holder, let alone all of them, why
would they ever have applied the GPL (with or without exception) to their
code in the first place.

Any copyright holder who has applied the current licence (GPL only in some
places, GPL plus exception in others) to their code can't agree with the
view expressed above because it is incompatible with the GPL.

The Harbour Project: A free software Clipper compatible compiler

From harbour@lists.harbour-project.org  Thu Mar  1 13:07:02 2001
From: harbour@lists.harbour-project.org (Ron Pinkas)
Date: Thu Mar  1 13:07:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Our current GPL license probably won't do what we want it to do.
In-Reply-To: <20010301165602.F19820@hagbard.davep.org>
Message-ID: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKIEADDKAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>

Dave,

> > Could you please provide an example of what *desired* (from
> Harbour stand
> > point) freedom will be restricted by the above. I can't think
> of any thing
> > we would *want* to allow, that does not fall within the above.
>
> One obvious example is that I may wish to link the harbour output
> with a HVM
> that I've written for myself from scratch, say, a HVM for the Palm or
> something. Such a VM might be so different that it couldn't reasonably be
> considered to be a HVM. The restriction regarding the output
> would stop this
> from happening.

1. It can't be "so different" if it is designed to run *the* Harbour
Generated Output.

2. Regardless, it will still be considered, HVM because a derivative of the
HVM is allowed as long as it includes the "unmodified portions" of the HVM.

> > > This effectively stops anyone building alternative compilers that make
> > > use of the HVM and HRTL, I'm not sure this is what is wanted.
> >
> > That's exactly the purpose of the above! Unless I'm mistaken, I
> 'm not the
> > only one who does *not* want to see his hard work, used by some other
> > free/non free software labeled as someone else's compiler. I believe we
> > would like our work to remain FREE in the context of Harbour, and *only*
> > in the context of Harbour.
>
> If that's the case harbour won't be free software after all.

Not true. This will leave Harbour and its use as Harbour as FREE as we
always wanted it. It will not allow a Harbour disguised as something else.

> Think about it
> for a moment, if all free software authors felt that way hardly any of the
> tools that are employed in the production of harbour would be available.
> DJGPP, for example, could never have existed, neither could Ming32 and the
> like.

I find the above false and misleading! DJGPP, Ming32, and the like, are
*derivative* of GCC/GLIBC, and are allowed because they are derivative work.
This is also allowed in my suggestion. None of the above pretend to be
anything other then a derivative work. I am confident I wouldn't be allowed
to produce a package including a GCC and GLIBC derivative as RPC, without
having to comply with the GCC and GLIBC GPL and LGPL respectively.

> Where's the freedom in attempting to stop other free software authors from
> building on harbour while, at the same time, supporting and allowing the
> production of non-free software that makes use of harbour or is built with
> harbour?

1. There are no limitations on producing, FREE Harbour derivative work
(other then specified in GPL).

2. There are no limitations on producing, FREE or NON FREE Harbour add-ons.

3. There are no limitations on producing, FREE or NON FREE applications,
using Harbour or Harbour Derivative, as a Compiler and RT environment.

Anything outside of that is not freedom, but rather abuse.

> Why would you want to stop people building free software on top of free
> software? Also, why would you want to stop people building
> non-free software
> that makes use of free software?

Please stop misleading! You are effectively attributing to me invented
intentions! The above is a fiction of your imagination!

> I find it disturbing that the likes of Clip4Win and FiveW*n would
> be allowed
> to exploit harbour but I wouldn't be allowed to write my own free software
> (or even non-free) alternative to the harbour compiler.

You are free to develop a Harbour derivative compiler. You should not be
allowed to "adopt" any portion of Harbour, to be included in a package
disguised as an Harbour alternative, where it is actually Harbour itself*.

*To make this perfectly clear, any one of Harbour 3 core sub systems, the
Complier, the HVM, and the HRTL, is substantial enough entity deserving
protection from being "BORROWED" to serve as a core subsystem of any
"alternative" to Harbour. But can be freely used in the context of a Harbour
derivative (which based on the GPL will have to be a FREE software).

Ron


From harbour@lists.harbour-project.org  Thu Mar  1 13:08:01 2001
From: harbour@lists.harbour-project.org (x)
Date: Thu Mar  1 13:08:01 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Bad ideas?
References: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKIEPMDJAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>
Message-ID: <008c01c0a27a$bc9a1be0$eeb49cc3@detti.hu>

I am very new to this list, but as usual I already have "ideas".  Please
forgive me for that rude behaviour and let me explain shortly:

I am a Clipper developer nowadays working in C++ on U*X systems... and I
miss Clipper and decided to somehow help the Harbour project.  However, I
have veeery limited free time, which I try to spend, hmmm., productively.  I
have subscribed few days ago to this list and started to "monitor" the
messages, as it is asked by the FAQ.  It has stated: this is a Harbour
developer mailing list.  I expected to see - mainly at least - task ideas,
guidelines, questions about development issues etc.  What I have found is
that more is going on here, namely:

- discussion of legal (licensing) issues
- reports (which are usually sent to webmaster@xxx.org) about the web pages
- mails with totally different subject than their content (subject about
LGPL, content about releasing variables)

I don't want to seem to be a stupid (did nothing yet, but already
complaining) guy, but I guess this "chaos" could be made a bit less chaotic.
Let me word the idea(s):

- First of all: if you change the subject, pls do change the _subject_ to
help others to fast find those topics they need/can deal with.  It is
something very little and U can save time for people trying to follow
discussions etc.

- Second: while license issues _are_ very important, I guess this project
has reached a size where those "management-like" issues could (should?) be
discussed on a separate mailing list, since they usually have a light
connection to actual coding, and need a different talent/knowledge - they
have they own area, rights etc.  Of course: anyone interested in those
issues could subscribe to that list.  But I could for example set up more
easily a filter, which takes those issues into a separate mail folder here,
not to mix things.

- Third is the same for the Web pages.  They have their own right, too.
Making them is a separate full task and can easily justify the presence of a
separate list.

- +1: of course, announcements of starting important discussions, seek for
help etc, could be posted on every/any list (could even have its own :-))

Clipper, Harbour... in ship terms: with a small ship U can have the
"commands" and discussions just being "shout" to everyone.  This ship seems
to be big enough now to start separate "threads" for the separate issues.

Practical reason: I guess I am not alone being very busy all the time.
Every/any little automated task and the help with changing the subject can
help me to waste less time on digging and spend more on Harbour.

And again: excuse me by being a newborn here and immediately start something
which may easily feel like criticism.  It is not meant to be.  However
probably being new also means that I had a fresh look onto something which
you have just lived with and got used to.  Remember the frog being cooked
slowly :-)))

Please don't take me wrong and consider my 2 cents as my first contribution
to the Harbour project.  I hope it is and it feels to be constructive.

Finally: Thanx for all the work you have done so far.  You have taken a
great job and a great responsibility and have shown a great deal of
unselfishness as well as dedication.  I honor you all, and I whish that I
will have the opportunity to contribute useful help to this project myself.

BR,
FA


From harbour@lists.harbour-project.org  Thu Mar  1 13:33:02 2001
From: harbour@lists.harbour-project.org (David G. Holm)
Date: Thu Mar  1 13:33:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Our current GPL license probably won't do what we want it to do.
In-Reply-To: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKAEPLDJAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>
References: <200102282324.f1SNOK524504@thor.parrett.net>
Message-ID: <200103011832.f21IWS505942@thor.parrett.net>

** Reply to message from "Ron Pinkas" <Ron@Profit-Master.com> on Wed,
28 Feb 2001 16:56:05 -0800

All of your sections are at odds with section 2 of the aims for the
Harbour license. Your section 3 omits the requirements of section 4 of
the aims for the Harbour license. All of the sections are too
restrictive.

Please note that not a single Harbour developer objected to these aims
for the license and not one developer provided an alternate list of
aims. These aims were used as the guidelines from which the Harbour
license was developed. And I can't imagine that our aims have changed
since then.

> From: "David G. Holm" <dholm@jsd-llc.com> -- Sat, 19 Jun 1999 05:13:30 EST
> Subject: [harbourtalk] Aims for Harbour License
>
> Third draft
> 
> My aims for the Harbour License:
>
> 1) It must allow the compiler and library source to be distributed
> freely.
> 
> 2) It must not place any restrictions on the use of the output from the
> compiler.
> 
> 3) It must require that distribution of the compiler or library
> binaries includes the source or an offer to supply the source.
> 
> 4) It must require that distribution of the output from a modified
> compiler includes the modified compiler and library source or an offer
> to supply the source.
> 
> David G. Holm, Set Captain and all around
> Harbour Project Clipper Compatibility fanatic.

It had been my understanding that the GNU GPL and the Harbour Exception
accomplished those aims. It was certainly my *intent* when I adapted the
Harbour Exception from the Guile Exception that Dave provided.
-- 
David G. Holm, Set Captain and all around
Harbour Project Clipper Compatibility fanatic.

line.

** Reply to message from Dave Pearson <davep@davep.org> on Thu, 1 Mar
2001 07:38:21 +0000

> See <URL:http://www.harbour-project.org/faq/harbour-2.html#ss2.12> for my
> explanation of why we didn't go for the LGPL.

Thanks for the pointer. I had tried to find the discussion of why we
abandoned going with the LGPL in my mailing list archives, but had no
success.

> I think the harbour exception is ambiguous at best. I'm currently wondering
> if we should keep it as it is and perhaps have a short document that
> clarifies the *intent* of the exception (or, more importantly, the *intent*
> of the copyright holders who use that licence).

When I adapted it from the Guile exception, the intent was to fulfill
the aims for the Harbour license that I developed (I quoted them in
another message, so I won't quote them again).

> The likes of GETSYS and friends should probably still have their licences
> relaxed though. I see no point in requiring people who develop non-free
> applications with harbour, and who need to fiddle with GETSYS or ERRORSYS,
> make an offer to supply the source of those parts of harbour.

I don't see how making someone include or make available the source to
a modified GETSYS or ERRORSYS is a hardship, but if their developers
wish to relax theor licensing requirements, I won't make any effort to
stop them.
-- 
David G. Holm, Set Captain and all around
Harbour Project Clipper Compatibility fanatic.

From harbour@lists.harbour-project.org  Thu Mar  1 13:55:03 2001
From: harbour@lists.harbour-project.org (Ron Pinkas)

Subject: [Harbour] Our current GPL license probably won't do what we want it to do.
In-Reply-To: <200103011832.f21IWS505942@thor.parrett.net>
Message-ID: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKGEAFDKAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>

David,

> All of your sections are at odds with section 2 of the aims for the
> Harbour license. Your section 3 omits the requirements of section 4 of
> the aims for the Harbour license. All of the sections are too
> restrictive.

I think we all agree with your aim #2. I believe that having to ultimately
link the compiler output to the HVM and HRTL is not a restriction in the
context of violating aim #2.

2. My sections do not address aim #4 because it is already covered by GPLing
the compiler.

> Please note that not a single Harbour developer objected to these aims
> for the license and not one developer provided an alternate list of
> aims. These aims were used as the guidelines from which the Harbour
> license was developed. And I can't imagine that our aims have changed
> since then.

I still agree with those general aims.

Ron

From harbour@lists.harbour-project.org  Thu Mar  1 14:15:02 2001
From: harbour@lists.harbour-project.org (Ron Pinkas)
Date: Thu Mar  1 14:15:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Our current GPL license probably won't do what we want it to do.
In-Reply-To: <200103011836.f21Iak506384@thor.parrett.net>
Message-ID: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKEEAGDKAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>

David,

> Sorry! I was too quick on the trigger and I take that back. I neglected
> to read the entire context of your statement and failed to notice that
> it was in reply to Ron's erroneous claim that the Harbour developers
> only want Harbour output to be used with Harbour.

It is not clear that my thought (it was never a claim) was erroneous. In any
event, the core of my concern, and proposal is with protecting the HVM and
HRTL. The inclusion of the Compiler Output, just seemed to offer a more
complete view.

I will not "fight" to "protect" the Complier Output. But I most certainly
will do my best to protect the HVM and HRTL.

Here is the core of my concern, if we allow any portion of the HVM, and or
the HRTL to be included in *any* application, without subjecting such to any
Harbour Licensing, we effectively allow any company, say Alaska, to develop
just the Compiler, include our HVM and HRTL (modified or not) in a form of
executable (such as a Linker), and thus being able to provide say xBase++ II
(2/3 Harbour), without having to respect any Harbour Licensing issue.

I think most of us would consider the above scenario un-acceptable. But in
effect we might very well allow it, based on the current ideas.

Ron


From harbour@lists.harbour-project.org  Thu Mar  1 15:03:02 2001
From: harbour@lists.harbour-project.org (David G. Holm)
Date: Thu Mar  1 15:03:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Our current GPL license probably won't do what we want it to do.
In-Reply-To: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKEEAGDKAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>
References: <200103011836.f21Iak506384@thor.parrett.net>
Message-ID: <200103012002.f21K2D514415@thor.parrett.net>

** Reply to message from "Ron Pinkas" <Ron@Profit-Master.com> on Thu, 1
Mar 2001 11:12:55 -0800

> ...without having to respect any Harbour Licensing issue.

Nonsense! Here's the full text of the Harbour Excption:

> The exception is that if you link the Harbour Runtime Library (HRL)
> and/or the Harbour Virtual Machine (HVM) with other files to produce
> an executable, this does not by itself cause the resulting executable
> to be covered by the GNU General Public License. Your use of that
> executable is in no way restricted on account of linking the HRL
> and/or HVM code into it.

Which means that your example would run afoul of the GPL, because the
exception applies to linking the HRL and/or HVM for the purpose of
producing an executable and does not apply to linking them for the
purpose of distributing them for use by other programs.
-- 
David G. Holm, Set Captain and all around
Harbour Project Clipper Compatibility fanatic.

From harbour@lists.harbour-project.org  Thu Mar  1 15:46:07 2001
From: harbour@lists.harbour-project.org (Dave Pearson)
Date: Thu Mar  1 15:46:07 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Our current GPL license probably won't do what we want it to do.
In-Reply-To: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKEEAGDKAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>; from Ron@Profit-Master.com on Thu, Mar 01, 2001 at 11:12:55AM -0800
References: <200103011836.f21Iak506384@thor.parrett.net> <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKEEAGDKAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>
Message-ID: <20010301203311.J21816@hagbard.davep.org>

On Thu, Mar 01, 2001 at 11:12:55AM -0800, Ron Pinkas wrote:

> Here is the core of my concern, if we allow any portion of the HVM, and or
> the HRTL to be included in *any* application, without subjecting such to
> any Harbour Licensing, we effectively allow any company, say Alaska, to
> develop just the Compiler, include our HVM and HRTL (modified or not) in a
> form of executable (such as a Linker), and thus being able to provide say
> xBase++ II (2/3 Harbour), without having to respect any Harbour Licensing
> issue.

Excellent, this is *exactly* the protection we've always wanted for the
various parts of harbour. However, the text you proposed also would prohibit
the use of code from any part of harbour in other related or unrelated free
software projects.

Note that we have *exactly* this kind of protection right now and have had
it since the moment the GPL was applied to all the files in harbour. The
text you proposed would tighten up this protection where it isn't necessary,
it would do it in a way that makes harbour less than free and it would
penalise free software developers who want to make use of parts of harbour
without adding anything to the current level of protection.

--

My harbour page....: http://www.davep.org/harbour/

Subject: [Harbour] Bad ideas?

Message-ID: <20010301204117.L21816@hagbard.davep.org>

On Thu, Mar 01, 2001 at 08:06:53PM +0200, x wrote:

> - Second: while license issues _are_ very important, I guess this project
> has reached a size where those "management-like" issues could (should?) be
> discussed on a separate mailing list, since they usually have a light
> connection to actual coding, and need a different talent/knowledge - they
> have they own area, rights etc. Of course: anyone interested in those
> issues could subscribe to that list. But I could for example set up more
> easily a filter, which takes those issues into a separate mail folder
> here, not to mix things.

The problem with this is that licensing is an issue for copyright holders
and copyright holders are more or less the same set as developers. Licensing
is also a development issue.

Licensing actually makes for a very small part of the content of this list.
It just so happens to be the focus of the list at the moment because we're
heading for a more beta-oriented phase and we want harbour to be useful to
everyone and we want the licence details to be as unambiguous as possible.

The *only* people who can make that happen are the copyright holders. It's
not possible to have a "licensing team" work on this on their own list.

> And again: excuse me by being a newborn here and immediately start
> something which may easily feel like criticism. 

It is criticism, that's good, criticism is healthy.

>                                                           Remember the
> frog being cooked slowly :-)))

LOL!

It was, IIRC, in harbour talk and I've got that going back to the moment I
subscribed. If you like I could probably hunt for it for you (although I
think the entry in the FAQ gives a useful nutshell explanation of the
reasoning I gave).

> > The likes of GETSYS and friends should probably still have their
> > licences relaxed though. I see no point in requiring people who develop
> > non-free applications with harbour, and who need to fiddle with GETSYS
> > or ERRORSYS, make an offer to supply the source of those parts of
> > harbour.

> relax theor licensing requirements, I won't make any effort to stop them.

Well, yes, you're right, it's not a hardship in any physical sense. I'm
thinking more that it's a legal requirement that people could probably do
well without. I know that I'd prefer not to have to worry about it too much.

From harbour@lists.harbour-project.org  Thu Mar  1 15:46:26 2001
From: harbour@lists.harbour-project.org (Dave Pearson)
Date: Thu Mar  1 15:46:26 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Our current GPL license probably won't do what we want it to do.
In-Reply-To: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKIEADDKAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>; from Ron@Profit-Master.com on Thu, Mar 01, 2001 at 10:04:06AM -0800
References: <20010301165602.F19820@hagbard.davep.org> <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKIEADDKAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>
Message-ID: <20010301202809.H21816@hagbard.davep.org>

On Thu, Mar 01, 2001 at 10:04:06AM -0800, Ron Pinkas wrote:
> Dave,
> 
> > One obvious example is that I may wish to link the harbour output with a
> > HVM that I've written for myself from scratch, say, a HVM for the Palm
> > or something. Such a VM might be so different that it couldn't
> > reasonably be considered to be a HVM. The restriction regarding the
> > output would stop this from happening.
> 
> 1. It can't be "so different" if it is designed to run *the* Harbour
> Generated Output.

I could be totally new code, written from scratch. IOW, it wouldn't be a
derived work and wouldn't be related to the HVM (you may recall that in the
early days such a beast existed, it was a Java based version of the HVM).

> 2. Regardless, it will still be considered, HVM because a derivative of
> the HVM is allowed as long as it includes the "unmodified portions" of the
> HVM.

If you're talking about a derived work you're not talking about a VM written
from scratch.

> > If that's the case harbour won't be free software after all.
> 
> Not true. This will leave Harbour and its use as Harbour as FREE as we
> always wanted it. It will not allow a Harbour disguised as something else.

How is using harbour, as per the terms of the GPL, "disguised"?

> > Think about it for a moment, if all free software authors felt that way
> > hardly any of the tools that are employed in the production of harbour
> > would be available. DJGPP, for example, could never have existed,
> > neither could Ming32 and the like.
> 
> I find the above false and misleading! DJGPP, Ming32, and the like, are
> *derivative* of GCC/GLIBC, and are allowed because they are derivative
> work.

Wrong. DJGPP is a port of GCC to DOS which a written, from scratch, CRTL.

> This is also allowed in my suggestion. None of the above pretend to be
> anything other then a derivative work. I am confident I wouldn't be
> allowed to produce a package including a GCC and GLIBC derivative as RPC,
> without having to comply with the GCC and GLIBC GPL and LGPL respectively.

Of course you'd have to comply with those the GPL and the LGPL. Likewise,
the GPL allowed DJ Delorie to take GCC and mix it with his own, written from
scratch, CRTL.

Given this, what would be wrong about taking the harbour compiler and mixing
it's use with a written, from scratch, HVM and HRTL?

> > Where's the freedom in attempting to stop other free software authors
> > from building on harbour while, at the same time, supporting and
> > allowing the production of non-free software that makes use of harbour
> > or is built with harbour?
> 
> 1. There are no limitations on producing, FREE Harbour derivative work
> (other then specified in GPL).

That's not what you've suggested. You've already said that you don't want
people using the harbour compiler with non-harbour derived VMs and RTLs.
You've also said that you don't want the HVM or RTL used with code that
wasn't produced by the harbour compiler.

> > Why would you want to stop people building free software on top of free
> > software? Also, why would you want to stop people building non-free
> > software that makes use of free software?
> 
> Please stop misleading! You are effectively attributing to me invented
> intentions! The above is a fiction of your imagination!

Wrong Ron, I'm pointing out to you the loopholes in your suggested licensing
scheme. Why bother asking for feedback if you're simply going to shout it
down when it isn't fully in your favour?

You're telling me I'm wrong yet your reasons come from ignorance. Go and
actually look at the DJGPP situation and you'll see exactly what I'm talking
about.

> > I find it disturbing that the likes of Clip4Win and FiveW*n would be
> > allowed to exploit harbour but I wouldn't be allowed to write my own
> > free software (or even non-free) alternative to the harbour compiler.
> 
> You are free to develop a Harbour derivative compiler. 

Am I free to develop a free compiler that borrows no code from the harbour
compiler at all but makes use of the HVM and HRTL? What about a non-free
compiler?

>                                                        You should not be
> allowed to "adopt" any portion of Harbour, to be included in a package
> disguised as an Harbour alternative, where it is actually Harbour itself*.

The GPL says otherwise.

> *To make this perfectly clear, any one of Harbour 3 core sub systems, the
> Complier, the HVM, and the HRTL, is substantial enough entity deserving
> protection from being "BORROWED" to serve as a core subsystem of any
> "alternative" to Harbour.

Such protection would mean that harbour ceases to be free software and,
quite possibly, open source software (as per the OSD) too. I'm not sure
that's what you really want.

>                           But can be freely used in the context of a
> Harbour derivative (which based on the GPL will have to be a FREE
> software).

You seem to be suggesting that the smallest or largest part of harbour can't
be taken and used in other free software projects. Is this really what
you're suggesting?

--

My harbour page....: http://www.davep.org/harbour/

From harbour@lists.harbour-project.org  Thu Mar  1 17:14:02 2001
From: harbour@lists.harbour-project.org (John Skelton)
Date: Thu Mar  1 17:14:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Our current GPL license probably won't do what
 we want it to do.
Message-ID: <200103011712_MC2-C75C-B966@compuserve.com>

Ron,

"Unless I'm mistaken, I 'm not the only one who does *not* want to see
his hard work, used by some other free/non free software labeled as
someone else's compiler. I believe we would like our work to remain
FREE in the context of Harbour, and *only* in the context of Harbour."

I don't have any interest in doing that, OTOH wouldn't a Clip-4-Win32
using Harbour be doing something (arguably) somewhat similar?  Anyone
could argue that I couldn't sell such a C4W without Harbour's existence
and thus that I was making money out of (because of) Harbour.  Without
getting into whether that would be an accurate description, I'm not
sure I see why it would be OK to sell an add-on but not OK to sell the
compiler, RTL, etc.

I can see it might be questionable behaviour - I just wonder why
people might be so keen to prevent it.  I'm not sure who the people
are who'd be willing to _buy_ such a thing, either!  My guess is that
most wouldn't - unless it also included significant added value, in
which case wouldn't that be a good thing?

However, what _really_ worries me is that at the moment the license
apparently isn't open enough.  Shouldn't we err on the side of being
too open rather than not open enough?

John.

From harbour@lists.harbour-project.org  Thu Mar  1 17:14:07 2001
From: harbour@lists.harbour-project.org (John Skelton)
Date: Thu Mar  1 17:14:07 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Our current GPL license probably won't do what
 we want it to do.
Message-ID: <200103011713_MC2-C75C-B967@compuserve.com>

David,

"whereas Dave claims that even reapplying the change to the original
source and rebuilding Harbour qualifies as a derivative work ..."

I believe Dave's correct: any change (no matter how small or why it's
made) creates a derivative work.

"I agreed with Dave's suggestion that certain files that developers
frequently modify, such as ERRORSYS.PRG, be released to the public
domain."

I also agree.

(It doesn't affect me in that I'd be happy to release Clip-4-Win32's
ERRORSYS.PRG to the Harbour project, but the basic idea of various
files being completely PD does look sensible.)

John.

From harbour@lists.harbour-project.org  Thu Mar  1 17:45:04 2001
From: harbour@lists.harbour-project.org (Dave Pearson)
Date: Thu Mar  1 17:45:04 2001
Subject: [Harbour] linux version
In-Reply-To: <20010301221940.925.qmail@web12712.mail.yahoo.com>; from timur4work@yahoo.com on Thu, Mar 01, 2001 at 02:19:40PM -0800
References: <20010301221940.925.qmail@web12712.mail.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <20010301224403.T21816@hagbard.davep.org>

On Thu, Mar 01, 2001 at 02:19:40PM -0800, Timur Kh wrote:

> Is here anybody, who is busy with linux version of the Harbour?
> 
> As I understood you have own rtl for every OS/compiler. Library, which is
> linked under linux, gtstd, is almost empty. Is here any other library for
> linux under development? If no, I can try to write after some
> consultations.

GTCRS is the library you want to be looking at for terminal IO under
GNU/Linux.

If you're running a RedHat based system there's an RPM of 0.36 available for
download on the harbour web site. If you don't like binary builds but do
have an RPM based system you can grab the SPRM and build it yourself, it'll
do the "right thing" in regards to including the right libraries.

--

FAQ................: http://www.harbour-project.org/faq/harbour.html
My harbour page....: http://www.davep.org/harbour/

From harbour@lists.harbour-project.org  Thu Mar  1 18:54:02 2001
From: harbour@lists.harbour-project.org (Dave Pearson)
Date: Thu Mar  1 18:54:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Our current GPL license probably won't do what we want it to do.
In-Reply-To: <20010301203311.J21816@hagbard.davep.org>; from davep@davep.org on Thu, Mar 01, 2001 at 08:33:11PM +0000
References: <200103011836.f21Iak506384@thor.parrett.net> <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKEEAGDKAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com> <20010301203311.J21816@hagbard.davep.org>
Message-ID: <20010301235338.Y21816@hagbard.davep.org>

On Thu, Mar 01, 2001 at 08:33:11PM +0000, Dave Pearson wrote:
> On Thu, Mar 01, 2001 at 11:12:55AM -0800, Ron Pinkas wrote:
> 
> > Here is the core of my concern, if we allow any portion of the HVM, and or
> > the HRTL to be included in *any* application, without subjecting such to
> > any Harbour Licensing, we effectively allow any company, say Alaska, to
> > develop just the Compiler, include our HVM and HRTL (modified or not) in a
> > form of executable (such as a Linker), and thus being able to provide say
> > xBase++ II (2/3 Harbour), without having to respect any Harbour Licensing
> > issue.
> 
> Excellent, this is *exactly* the protection we've always wanted for the
> various parts of harbour. However, the text you proposed also would
> prohibit the use of code from any part of harbour in other related or
> unrelated free software projects.

Just to clarify what I say here, there should be no reason for stopping a
company like the above from doing what you say, the important point being
that they *must* respect the harbour licence. If they wrote their own
compiler that targeted the HVM and HRTL that should be fine as long as they
distribute the HVM and HRTL within the terms of the GPL and the harbour
exception.

The less desirable situation would be if they modified the HVM or HRTL and
distributed that without making the source available. Seeing as how the
licence of that code is the GPL with an exception and seeing as how they
would have "invalidated" the exception they'd *have* the make the source
available or they would be breaking the terms of the licence.

If it really is the desire of all the harbour copyright holders that such a
freedom not exist then a whole new licence needs to be designed because I
don't see how you can usefully stop such use of the code while using the GPL
as the basis of the harbour licence. At least, not without trying to write
an exception that makes harbour less free (as opposed to the current
exception which seeks to make it more free).

Any copyright owner who never wanted to allow such a use of harbour's code
should never have applied the GPL plus exception to their code in the first
place.

-- 
The Harbour Project: A free software Clipper compatible compiler
Home Page..........: http://www.harbour-project.org/
FAQ................: http://www.harbour-project.org/faq/harbour.html
My harbour page....: http://www.davep.org/harbour/

From harbour@lists.harbour-project.org  Thu Mar  1 19:43:03 2001

From harbour@lists.harbour-project.org  Thu Mar  1 20:37:02 2001
From: harbour@lists.harbour-project.org (Ron Pinkas)
Date: Thu Mar  1 20:37:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Our current GPL license probably won't do what we want it to do.
In-Reply-To: <200103012002.f21K2D514415@thor.parrett.net>
Message-ID: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKIEAJDKAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>

David,

> > Here is the core of my concern, if we allow any portion of the HVM, and
or
> > the HRTL to be included in *any* application, without subjecting such to
any
> > Harbour Licensing, we effectively allow any company, say Alaska, to
develop
> > just the Compiler, include our HVM and HRTL (modified or not) in a form
of
> > executable (such as a Linker), and thus being able to provide say
xBase++ II
> > (2/3 Harbour), without having to respect any Harbour Licensing issue.
>
> Nonsense! Here's the full text of the Harbour Excption:
>
> > The exception is that if you link the Harbour Runtime Library (HRL)
> > and/or the Harbour Virtual Machine (HVM) with other files to produce
> > an executable, this does not by itself cause the resulting executable
> > to be covered by the GNU General Public License. Your use of that
> > executable is in no way restricted on account of linking the HRL
> > and/or HVM code into it.
>
> Which means that your example would run afoul of the GPL, because the
> exception applies to linking the HRL and/or HVM for the purpose of
> producing an executable and does not apply to linking them for the
> purpose of distributing them for use by other programs.

Sadly this is far from nonsense! Please re-read my scenario.

1. Based on the current exception I *can* certainly *link* compiled HVM and
HRTL into my *executable*(1). My resulting *exe*(1) is *not* covered by the
Harbour License.

2. This executable(1) can easily be a linker application.

3. This linker, in-turn *can* link the HVM and HRTL segments of self, along
with Harbour compatible compiled code, thus producing the User Application
executable(2).

4. In this scheme both the HVM and HRTL have been linked into executables
not once, but twice, and both times such linking is covered and "excused" by
the current exception.

The above means my fictitious scenario above is 100% valid, and would *not*
be in violation of our license, because it falls neatly under the current
exception.

There is nothing that subject executable(1), or executable(2), to any
Harbour License, because there only relationship to Harbour is the "mere"
link inclusion of the HVM and HRTL which is *completely* excused.

Hope this does clarify the problem.

Ron


From harbour@lists.harbour-project.org  Thu Mar  1 20:48:02 2001
From: harbour@lists.harbour-project.org (Ron Pinkas)
Date: Thu Mar  1 20:48:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Our current GPL license probably won't do what we want it to do.
In-Reply-To: <20010301203311.J21816@hagbard.davep.org>
Message-ID: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKOEAJDKAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>

Dave,

<<<<
Here is the core of my concern, if we allow any portion of the HVM, and or
the HRTL to be included in *any* application, without subjecting such to any
Harbour Licensing, we effectively allow any company, say Alaska, to develop
just the Compiler, include our HVM and HRTL (modified or not) in a form of
executable (such as a Linker), and thus being able to provide say xBase++ II
(2/3 Harbour), without having to respect any Harbour Licensing issue.
>>>>

> Note that we have *exactly* this kind of protection right now and have had
> it since the moment the GPL was applied to all the files in harbour. The
> text you proposed would tighten up this protection where it isn't
> necessary,
> it would do it in a way that makes harbour less than free and it would
> penalise free software developers who want to make use of parts of harbour
> without adding anything to the current level of protection.

Current exception *allows* the above scenario, and offers absolutely *no*
protection against such.

Please explain, how would GPL protect us against my pretend scenario, when
it is clear that this scenario falls perfectly under our exception?

Ron

From harbour@lists.harbour-project.org  Thu Mar  1 21:35:04 2001
From: harbour@lists.harbour-project.org (Ron Pinkas)
Date: Thu Mar  1 21:35:04 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Our current GPL license probably won't do what we want it to do.
In-Reply-To: <20010301202809.H21816@hagbard.davep.org>
Message-ID: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKCEALDKAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>

Dave,

> > 1. It can't be "so different" if it is designed to run *the* Harbour
> > Generated Output.
>
> I could be totally new code, written from scratch. IOW, it wouldn't be a
> derived work and wouldn't be related to the HVM (you may recall
> that in the
> early days such a beast existed, it was a Java based version of the HVM).

>From GPL section 0:

,-------------
|The "Program", below, refers to any such program or work, and a "work based
on the Program" |means either the Program or any derivative work under
copyright law: that is to say, a work |containing the Program or a portion
of it, either verbatim or with modifications and/or |translated into another
language. (Hereinafter, translation is included without limitation |in the
term "modification".)
`-------------

Translations like you describe, are still a derivative work. The JHVM is
100% derivative work.

> > 2. Regardless, it will still be considered, HVM because a derivative of
> > the HVM is allowed as long as it includes the "unmodified
> portions" of the
> > HVM.
>
> If you're talking about a derived work you're not talking about a
> VM written
> from scratch.

If you wanted to bring the HVM into a new non supported environment, you can
and should consider it derivative work.

> > Not true. This will leave Harbour and its use as Harbour as FREE as we
> > always wanted it. It will not allow a Harbour disguised as
> > something else.
>
> How is using harbour, as per the terms of the GPL, "disguised"?

It would not be under GPL, or I would have had no concern. It is excused
from being covered by the GPL by falling under the Harbour Exception.

> > I find the above false and misleading! DJGPP, Ming32, and the like, are
> > *derivative* of GCC/GLIBC, and are allowed because they are derivative
> > work.
>
> Wrong. DJGPP is a port of GCC to DOS which a written, from scratch, CRTL.

Again, please read the GPL, you'll find that "port" is still derivative
work.

> > Please stop misleading! You are effectively attributing to me invented
> > intentions! The above is a fiction of your imagination!
>
> Wrong Ron, I'm pointing out to you the loopholes in your
> suggested licensing
> scheme. Why bother asking for feedback if you're simply going to shout it
> down when it isn't fully in your favour?

Now you also "know" the scope of my logic? Try this, I asked you to stop
miss-stating my intentions, because you did exactly that. I do *not* want to
"stop non free software that makes [valid] use of free software". It is our
reasonability to provide clear license so that every one can tell, what
is/isn't [valid].

> You're telling me I'm wrong yet your reasons come from ignorance. Go and
> actually look at the DJGPP situation and you'll see exactly what
> I'm talking
> about.

Apparently, ignorance is not discriminating, and when combined with
arrogance becomes quiet difficult to deal with.

Ron


From harbour@lists.harbour-project.org  Thu Mar  1 21:43:02 2001
From: harbour@lists.harbour-project.org (Ron Pinkas)

Subject: [Harbour] Our current GPL license probably won't do what  we want it to do.
In-Reply-To: <200103011712_MC2-C75C-B966@compuserve.com>
Message-ID: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKMEALDKAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>

John,

> "Unless I'm mistaken, I 'm not the only one who does *not* want to see
> his hard work, used by some other free/non free software labeled as
> someone else's compiler. I believe we would like our work to remain
> FREE in the context of Harbour, and *only* in the context of Harbour."
>
> I don't have any interest in doing that, OTOH wouldn't a Clip-4-Win32
> using Harbour be doing something (arguably) somewhat similar?  Anyone
> could argue that I couldn't sell such a C4W without Harbour's existence
> and thus that I was making money out of (because of) Harbour.  Without
> getting into whether that would be an accurate description, I'm not
> sure I see why it would be OK to sell an add-on but not OK to sell the
> compiler, RTL, etc.

1. It wouldn't be similar! To "qualify", you would have to pretend you
developed a full fledge compiler, when in actuality, you only developed a
small portion, and then "borrowed" the rest from Harbour, without having to
give it any credit.

2. I never attempted to stop anyone from making money off of Harbour. This
is 100% legitimate when *not* in violation of a license which the copyright
holders agree with.

Ron


From harbour@lists.harbour-project.org  Thu Mar  1 21:50:03 2001

Dave,

> Just to clarify what I say here, there should be no reason for stopping a
> company like the above from doing what you say, the important point being
> that they *must* respect the harbour licence. If they wrote their own
> compiler that targeted the HVM and HRTL that should be fine as
> long as they
> distribute the HVM and HRTL within the terms of the GPL and the harbour
> exception.

But the Harbour Exception *does* allow them to link the HVM and HRTL into
*any* executable, *without* submitting such executable to the Harbour
License. So *no*, as it stands now, they do *not* have to respect
*anything*, other than our naive generosity.

Ron

----- Original Message -----
From: "Phil Barnett" <midnight@the-oasis.net>

> On 28 Feb 2001, at 11:59, David G. Holm wrote:
>
> > ** Reply to message from Dave Pearson <davep@davep.org> on Wed, 28 Feb
> > 2001 16:47:44 +0000
> >
> > > The point and the intent of the GPL with harbour exception
> >
> > Then you have misunderstood the intent of the Harbour Exception. The
> > intent of the Harbour Exception is that regardless of what you do with
> > the RTL and/or VM, your executable can remain non-free software, should
> > you so desire, even though you must include or make available the source
> > code for any of the RTL and/or VM source modules that you modified, when
> > you distribute your software.
>
> The license excludes the RTL and or VM, not the code they are
> made from, which holds copyrights from various people.
>
> Until the licensing of that code is dealt with, it can't be mixed into a
> commercial application or it is a derivative work and remains the
> copyright of the original author. This alone will drive off intelligent
> business users.

To Phil. Dave, David, Ron and all.

Just imagine what can I do in agree with the Harbour License terms:

1. I made some modification to errorsys.prg (like logging option) and
getsys.prg (calculator-like number input). This code is GPL-ed, so I will
send it to the Harbour developers to add it to the project.
2. Then I will wait for your decision what to do with my code. You can put
it into the Harbour core or maybe into some contribs.
3. In the same time I can make my own distribution of Harbour, OK?
And my Alias Harbour distribution will include my code and the rest of the
Harbour both with the Harbour License terms.
4. Now I have a new HVM/HRTL ready to use with my commercial applications.

So it is just much longer way to have what I want, but I can do it. Or am I
missing/misunderstanding something?
(
--
Regards from the Harbour mirror in Poland
Andrzej P. Wozniak
alias@polnet.cc   harbour@harbour.pl.eu.org
