> > > Then you have misunderstood the intent of the Harbour Exception. The
> > > intent of the Harbour Exception is that regardless of what you do with
> > > the RTL and/or VM, your executable can remain non-free software, should
> > > you so desire, even though you must include or make available the source
> > > code for any of the RTL and/or VM source modules that you modified, when
> > > you distribute your software.
> >
> > The license excludes the RTL and or VM, not the code they are
> > made from, which holds copyrights from various people.
> >
> > Until the licensing of that code is dealt with, it can't be mixed into a
> > commercial application or it is a derivative work and remains the
> > copyright of the original author. This alone will drive off intelligent
> > business users.
> 
> To Phil. Dave, David, Ron and all.
> 
> Just imagine what can I do in agree with the Harbour License terms:
> 
> 1. I made some modification to errorsys.prg (like logging option) and
> getsys.prg (calculator-like number input). This code is GPL-ed, so I will
> send it to the Harbour developers to add it to the project.
> 2. Then I will wait for your decision what to do with my code. You can put
> it into the Harbour core or maybe into some contribs.
> 3. In the same time I can make my own distribution of Harbour, OK?
> And my Alias Harbour distribution will include my code and the rest of the
> Harbour both with the Harbour License terms.
> 4. Now I have a new HVM/HRTL ready to use with my commercial applications.
> 
> So it is just much longer way to have what I want, but I can do it. Or am I
> missing/misunderstanding something?

Yes, you can do this, but I think this is exactly why we are trying 
to tie down the exception and where it stops, making this a 
frivolous exercise.

Forking the code for such a trivial thing is silly and nobody here 
wants that to happen.

We will find another way.


-- 
              Phil Barnett  mailto:midnight@the-oasis.net
                       WWW  http://www.the-oasis.net/
                  FTP Site  ftp://ftp.the-oasis.net

From harbour@lists.harbour-project.org  Fri Mar  2 02:44:02 2001
From: harbour@lists.harbour-project.org (Ron Pinkas)
Date: Fri Mar  2 02:44:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Our current GPL license probably won't do what we want it to do.
In-Reply-To: <3A9EDD8C.16645.EB595A8@localhost>
Message-ID: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKGEAODKAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>

Phil,

> > There is nothing that subject executable(1), or executable(2), to any
> > Harbour License, because there only relationship to Harbour is
> the "mere"
> > link inclusion of the HVM and HRTL which is *completely* excused.
> >
>
> So, if some group wanted to fork the code base and create Harbour
> for dBase or Harbour for Fox or Harbour for xBase, that would be
> ok or not ok?

I'm not sure I understand the question. It is my understanding that any and
all derivative kind of work is allowed in the GPL. The Exception we discuss
is not designed to limit any aspect of the GPL, but rather loosen it. !!!
Light Bulb !!!

****************************************************************************
* Dave, please re-read my proposal, it does *not* take away any of the GPL *
* rights, it simply *allows* you to dismiss any of the GPL liabilities by  *
* meeting the specified conditions. But these are the conditions for the   *
* *exception*, which means if these conditions are not met, what ever you  *
* do with Harbour falls back to the GPL arena, with all its rights and     *
* liabilities!!!                                                           *
****************************************************************************

My concern is with the Harbour Exception:

1. The current Exception does not explicitly cover modified versions of the
HVM/HRTL. This means that even the smallest of changes, like ErrorSys or
GetSys, effectively renders the exception void. This is way to strict.

2. OTOH, the Exception, allows any 3rd party, to provide any executable form
of the HVM and HRTL, without enforcing any bit of the Harbour License. This
opens the door, to possible "abuse". Yet it would not be abuse because we
"allowed" it. (Read my pretend Alaska scenario for an example). This is way
too liberal.

3. How do we address #1. above without making #2. even worse? By allowing
such 3rd. party to modify any portion of the HVM or HRTL, and still be
covered by the current exception would have almost the same effect as
donating the HVM and HRTL to public domain (because in executable form, they
are 100% free (excluded) of any license.

I therefore believe that in order to allow complete freedom, to modify the
HVM and HRTL, and further allow the HVM and HRTL to be *excluded* from the
GPL when linked into executable, we must introduce some additional condition
before the Exception take effect. My idea was that this additional
condition, will require that this excluded executable is indeed an Harbour
application (which is what we intended the exception for, but never exactly
defined).

Ron


From harbour@lists.harbour-project.org  Fri Mar  2 03:16:00 2001
From: harbour@lists.harbour-project.org (Ron Pinkas)
Date: Fri Mar  2 03:16:00 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Clarification, (Dave, David)
In-Reply-To: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKGEAODKAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>
Message-ID: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKAEAPDKAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>

Dave, David,

It just occurred to me when responding to Phil, that you have been reading
my proposed Exception Condition as if they no longer allowed the rights
granted by the GPL license.

The moment we GPLed Harbour it is *guaranteed* to offer *at* *minimum*, all
of the rights granted by the GPL to any and all Harbour users.

Our exception (current or proposed) is only describing when will the user's
rights *escalate* to allow anything and everything he/she wishes to do with
the software.

By describing when the GPL will *not* take effect, the user learns when
he/she are given *infinite* rights beyond the GPL, without having any
License liability.

So as long as you don't claim that the GPL is intending to "stop people
building free software on top of free software" or, intending to "stop
people building non-free software that makes use of free software", my
proposal can not be described as such either, because it only add rights
without removing any!!!

Ron


From harbour@lists.harbour-project.org  Fri Mar  2 03:48:03 2001
From: harbour@lists.harbour-project.org (Dave Pearson)
Date: Fri Mar  2 03:48:03 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Our current GPL license probably won't do what  we want it to do.

On Thu, Mar 01, 2001 at 11:38:52PM -0500, Phil Barnett wrote:

> My question is: How will we identify which parts of the VM and RTL some
> programmer will want to modify and include in the next n years?

The quick and obvious answer is those parts which people used to be able to
modify as part of CA-Clipper.

All other parts of harbour can be modified also but you only get to use
those modifications if you yourself and seeking to build free software with
those modifications. I guess this "cost" is the cost of seeking to use free
software to build non-free software.

From harbour@lists.harbour-project.org  Fri Mar  2 03:48:17 2001
From: harbour@lists.harbour-project.org (Dave Pearson)
Date: Fri Mar  2 03:48:17 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Our current GPL license probably won't do what we want it to do.
In-Reply-To: <082001c0a2d1$a9496d00$05684cd5@andrzejw>; from alias@polnet.cc on Fri, Mar 02, 2001 at 05:10:11AM +0100
References: <200102281659.f1SGxoh18571@thor.parrett.net> <3A9D7BE5.7160.950228E@localhost> <082001c0a2d1$a9496d00$05684cd5@andrzejw>
Message-ID: <20010302083939.D21816@hagbard.davep.org>

On Fri, Mar 02, 2001 at 05:10:11AM +0100, Andrzej P. Wozniak wrote:

> 1. I made some modification to errorsys.prg (like logging option) and
> getsys.prg (calculator-like number input). This code is GPL-ed, so I will
> send it to the Harbour developers to add it to the project.
> 2. Then I will wait for your decision what to do with my code. You can put
> it into the Harbour core or maybe into some contribs.
> 3. In the same time I can make my own distribution of Harbour, OK?
> And my Alias Harbour distribution will include my code and the rest of the
> Harbour both with the Harbour License terms.
> 4. Now I have a new HVM/HRTL ready to use with my commercial applications.

Right now, as the licence details stand, if you decided to make your own
distribution of harbour and in doing so modify part of the RTL, GETSYS.PRG,
in your example, GETSYS.PRG falls squarely under the GPL, no exception,
which means that your distribution of harbour as a whole falls under the
GPL, which means that anyone using that distribution can't enjoy the
exception and any application they build must comply with the GPL and the
GPL only.

From harbour@lists.harbour-project.org  Fri Mar  2 03:48:23 2001
From: harbour@lists.harbour-project.org (Dave Pearson)
Date: Fri Mar  2 03:48:23 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Our current GPL license probably won't do what we want it to do.
In-Reply-To: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKGEAMDKAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>; from Ron@Profit-Master.com on Thu, Mar 01, 2001 at 06:47:31PM -0800
References: <20010301235338.Y21816@hagbard.davep.org> <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKGEAMDKAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>
Message-ID: <20010302083541.C21816@hagbard.davep.org>

On Thu, Mar 01, 2001 at 06:47:31PM -0800, Ron Pinkas wrote:
> Dave,
> 
> > Just to clarify what I say here, there should be no reason for stopping
> > a company like the above from doing what you say, the important point
> > being that they *must* respect the harbour licence. If they wrote their
> > own compiler that targeted the HVM and HRTL that should be fine as long
> > as they distribute the HVM and HRTL within the terms of the GPL and the
> > harbour exception.
> 
> But the Harbour Exception *does* allow them to link the HVM and HRTL into
> *any* executable, *without* submitting such executable to the Harbour
> License. So *no*, as it stands now, they do *not* have to respect
> *anything*, other than our naive generosity.

The exception, as it stands, does open harbour up to possible abuse, of this
there is no doubt (I think we've discussed this possibility before). The
moment you seek to add an exception to the GPL (and probably most free
software licences) it does become horribly complicated. This is an
unfortunate side effect of having an exception that absolves people of their
duties to free software when they are building non-free software.

I'm not certain there is a useful way of stopping this with the licence
details becoming horribly complicated and without it compromising
free-software use of any and all parts of harbour.

This is what I've been trying to get over to you about the text you
proposed. Said text is an exception to make harbour less free, unlike the
current exception which seeks to make it more free. While your proposed
exception would most probably stop BigEvilCorp from playing out your
scenario it also stops NiceFreeSoftwareGroup from making use of parts of
harbour too.

Personally, I'd sooner allow your scenario than stop NiceFreeSoftwareGroup
from doing wonderful things for the world of free software using parts taken
from harbour. Besides, in the above scenario I'd apply Hanlon's Razor,
chances are such an application would be correct and they'd "do the right
thing" once politely asked. If not they'd probably not actually play nice no
matter the licence details of harbour, probably working on the assumption
that they've got more money to fight a legal battle than any one of us have.

-- 
The Harbour Project: A free software Clipper compatible compiler
Home Page..........: http://www.harbour-project.org/
FAQ................: http://www.harbour-project.org/faq/harbour.html
My harbour page....: http://www.davep.org/harbour/

From harbour@lists.harbour-project.org  Fri Mar  2 03:48:31 2001
From: harbour@lists.harbour-project.org (Dave Pearson)
Date: Fri Mar  2 03:48:31 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Our current GPL license probably won't do what we want it to do.
In-Reply-To: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKCEALDKAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>; from Ron@Profit-Master.com on Thu, Mar 01, 2001 at 06:32:19PM -0800
References: <20010301202809.H21816@hagbard.davep.org> <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKCEALDKAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>
Message-ID: <20010302082239.B21816@hagbard.davep.org>

On Thu, Mar 01, 2001 at 06:32:19PM -0800, Ron Pinkas wrote:
> Dave,
> 
> > I could be totally new code, written from scratch. IOW, it wouldn't be a
> > derived work and wouldn't be related to the HVM (you may recall that in
> > the early days such a beast existed, it was a Java based version of the
> > HVM).
> 
> >From GPL section 0:
> 
> ,-------------
> |The "Program", below, refers to any such program or work, and a "work based
> on the Program" |means either the Program or any derivative work under
> copyright law: that is to say, a work |containing the Program or a portion
> of it, either verbatim or with modifications and/or |translated into another
> language. (Hereinafter, translation is included without limitation |in the
> term "modification".)
> `-------------
> 
> Translations like you describe, are still a derivative work. The JHVM is
> 100% derivative work.

The GPL can't and doesn't say what is a derivative work. Copyright law
dictates that. The text above says so. If I sit down and write a work-a-like
from scratch it isn't a derivative work.

If what you claim *is* true that means that harbour is a derivative work of
CA-Clipper and that you should all be thinking of handing copyright over to
CA and that harbour should be using CA's licence.

Are you going to keep trying to find ways of ignoring the point I'm raising
or are you going to acknowledge that it is entirely possible for totally
independent VM and RTL implementations to exist?

> > If you're talking about a derived work you're not talking about a VM
> > written from scratch.
> 
> If you wanted to bring the HVM into a new non supported environment, you
> can and should consider it derivative work.

Unless it isn't a derivative work.

> > > I find the above false and misleading! DJGPP, Ming32, and the like,
> > > are *derivative* of GCC/GLIBC, and are allowed because they are
> > > derivative work.
> >
> > Wrong. DJGPP is a port of GCC to DOS which a written, from scratch, CRTL.
> 
> Again, please read the GPL, you'll find that "port" is still derivative
> work.

I've read the GPL once or twice Ron, I first read it in the early 90s and
have read it many times since. I've also GPLd many items of code that I've
released as free software and have actually signed over to the FSF so I
think I know what's in there. I won't claim to have a perfect knowledge of
the GPL but I know it well enough that having total knowledge of it would
tell me nothing about how DJGPP's RTL isn't a derived work of GLIBC.

However, have you actually read about DJGPP's CRTL? You said:

,----
| DJGPP, Ming32, and the like, are *derivative* of GCC/GLIBC, and are allowed
| because they are derivative work.
`----

which is partly wrong (totally wrong when you look at what I was saying in
total). As I point out above (and you seem not to notice) the CRTL of DJGPP
has nothing to do with GLIBC in terms of actual code, it isn't a derived
work of GLIBC and it isn't under the GPL in normal circumstances (I seem to
recall that making a derived work if it places it under the GPL but that's a
totally unrelated matter, that's simply it doing more or less what we're
doing with the VM nd RTL).

Have you read about the DJGPP RTL Ron? Can you see why I mentioned it as an
example of mixing a derived work compiler with a totally fresh
implementation of a RTL that isn't a derived work and isn't ordinarily under
the GPL?

Why do you think the GPL speaks about this situation when it isn't the GPL
you should be looking at to understand how DJGPP came to be?

> > Wrong Ron, I'm pointing out to you the loopholes in your suggested
> > licensing scheme. Why bother asking for feedback if you're simply going
> > to shout it down when it isn't fully in your favour?
> 
> Now you also "know" the scope of my logic? Try this, I asked you to stop
> miss-stating my intentions, because you did exactly that. I do *not* want
> to "stop non free software that makes [valid] use of free software". It is
> our reasonability to provide clear license so that every one can tell,
> what is/isn't [valid].

Get a clue Ron. I never misstated your intentions, I provided the feedback
you desired. Either you can't see why what I say is the case, in which case
you're after clarification, feel free to ask for it, or you don't want to
see what I'm saying in which case you're simply being argumentative.

> > You're telling me I'm wrong yet your reasons come from ignorance. Go and
> > actually look at the DJGPP situation and you'll see exactly what I'm
> > talking about.
> 
> Apparently, ignorance is not discriminating, and when combined with
> arrogance becomes quiet difficult to deal with.

What is your problem Ron Pinkas? Why do you always try and bully people who
provide the feedback you request but which doesn't provide totally positive
feedback? If you stop your bullying and arrogance for just one moment and
actually go and check on the examples I've given you'll see what I'm saying
and why the text you posted *does* prohibit the development of free software
based around the code in harbour.

Do you understand that, even though it wasn't your *intention* that the text
you propose stops the development of free software, the *implementation* of
those directions would? Do you understand that I've said everything I've
said because I care about free software and that I care about *your* free
software and that none of what I've said has been said out of ignorance or
arrogance?

Accept the feedback I've given you with the same spirit in which it was
given and you'll find that there's an important point in it.

Or, alternatively, you can try and represent my feedback as ignorant
arrogance and be none the wiser despite asking for it. It's your choice Ron.

--

From harbour@lists.harbour-project.org  Fri Mar  2 04:55:03 2001
From: harbour@lists.harbour-project.org (Dave Pearson)
Date: Fri Mar  2 04:55:03 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Our current GPL license probably won't do what we want it to do.
In-Reply-To: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKGEAODKAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>; from Ron@Profit-Master.com on Thu, Mar 01, 2001 at 11:41:56PM -0800
References: <3A9EDD8C.16645.EB595A8@localhost> <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKGEAODKAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>
Message-ID: <20010302093646.G21816@hagbard.davep.org>

On Thu, Mar 01, 2001 at 11:41:56PM -0800, Ron Pinkas wrote:

> I'm not sure I understand the question. It is my understanding that any
> and all derivative kind of work is allowed in the GPL. 

Yes, the GPL is used to provide anyone with a licence to make a derivative
work as long as that work retains the same licence.

>                                                        The Exception we
> discuss is not designed to limit any aspect of the GPL, but rather loosen
> it. 

Correct.

>     !!! Light Bulb !!!
> 
> ****************************************************************************
> * Dave, please re-read my proposal, it does *not* take away any of the GPL *
> * rights, it simply *allows* you to dismiss any of the GPL liabilities by  *
> * meeting the specified conditions. But these are the conditions for the   *
> * *exception*, which means if these conditions are not met, what ever you  *
> * do with Harbour falls back to the GPL arena, with all its rights and     *
> * liabilities!!!                                                           *
> ****************************************************************************

This is useful, I think it will take more thinking about but that's a route
to ponder.

From harbour@lists.harbour-project.org  Fri Mar  2 04:55:12 2001
From: harbour@lists.harbour-project.org (Dave Pearson)
Date: Fri Mar  2 04:55:12 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Clarification, (Dave, David)
In-Reply-To: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKAEAPDKAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>; from Ron@Profit-Master.com on Fri, Mar 02, 2001 at 12:14:05AM -0800
References: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKGEAODKAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com> <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKAEAPDKAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>
Message-ID: <20010302094314.H21816@hagbard.davep.org>

On Fri, Mar 02, 2001 at 12:14:05AM -0800, Ron Pinkas wrote:

> It just occurred to me when responding to Phil, that you have been reading
> my proposed Exception Condition as if they no longer allowed the rights
> granted by the GPL license.

Well, not quite that way, I was speaking about and in response to the
absolute terms it used. It didn't seem to suggest anywhere that it was
talking about non-free use and only non-free use. It was ambiguous enough to
introduce the confusion I was highlighting.

> Our exception (current or proposed) is only describing when will the
> user's rights *escalate* to allow anything and everything he/she wishes to
> do with the software.

Hmm, I'm not sure this is the right way to express the purpose of the
exception. The exception is only there to allow people to distribute binary
renderings of GPLd code in a non-free way. That might not seem like a
significant difference from what you say above but it is quite important.

> By describing when the GPL will *not* take effect, the user learns when
> he/she are given *infinite* rights beyond the GPL, without having any
> License liability.

Again, you need to be very cautious with your wording here. The exception
doesn't absolve the user from observing the GPL in it's entirety, only in
how they can licence their own work when making use of harbour and what they
need to do in terms of distributing binary renderings of harbour code when
it is part of their application.

--

From harbour@lists.harbour-project.org  Fri Mar  2 05:52:08 2001
From: harbour@lists.harbour-project.org (Phil Barnett)
Date: Fri Mar  2 05:52:08 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Our current GPL license probably won't do what   we want it to do.
In-Reply-To: <200103020516_MC2-C755-1836@compuserve.com>
Message-ID: <3A9F34DF.27210.100AB344@localhost>

On 2 Mar 2001, at 5:16, John Skelton wrote:

> Here's a possible problem, too: say 2 years from now "we" (Harbour
> community) want to make file XXX more free (PD, maybe) but we can no
> longer contact its author.  We're stuck.  Maybe we could start _now_
> by having all copyright owned by the Harbour team (of captains, say), so
> that any such decisions would be possible.
> 
> (If so, the wording better state that the team members can change and how
> the actual members are to be identified from time to time.)

This is why a lot of people donate thir copyright to the FSF.

One alternative would be to form a non-profit corporation to 
administer and hold the copyright(s), with the board of directors 
being formed from Harbour Developers and contributors, as defined 
by the corporations bylaws.

I've built such a corporation in the last two years in our Linux User 
Group, and it's been a LOT of work.

That's not to say that I wouldn't do it, as I already know many 
paths to go down to make it easier, but we'd all have to make that 
kind of decision collectively, and we'd all have to chip in some 
cash. That's one thing I've found. Any corporation, even a non-profit, 
has expenses. For our LUG, we've found that 16 members paying 
$35 a year is enough to keep it afloat. (just opening a bank 
account, which is mandatory, costs $15 a month, and there are 
yearly filing fees with the state of $87.50. Filing for federal 501(c)3 
status costs as much as $500 and I don't know if there is a yearly 
fee after that, but I suspect there is.)

This way, the copyrights could be held by a legal entity instead of 
by individuals, thus giving us an instrument to carry on past 
individual lifetimes or periods of participation.

Also, finding a benefactor to set up a trust to pay for it all would be 
another goal.

But, the FSF has already done all of this...


-- 
              Phil Barnett  mailto:midnight@the-oasis.net
                       WWW  http://www.the-oasis.net/
                  FTP Site  ftp://ftp.the-oasis.net

From harbour@lists.harbour-project.org  Fri Mar  2 06:31:02 2001
From: harbour@lists.harbour-project.org (Dave Pearson)
Date: Fri Mar  2 06:31:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Our current GPL license probably won't do what we want it to do.
In-Reply-To: <200103020516_MC2-C755-1836@compuserve.com>; from John_Skelton@compuserve.com on Fri, Mar 02, 2001 at 05:16:19AM -0500
References: <200103020516_MC2-C755-1836@compuserve.com>
Message-ID: <20010302111258.M21816@hagbard.davep.org>

On Fri, Mar 02, 2001 at 05:16:19AM -0500, John Skelton wrote:

> Here's a possible problem, too: say 2 years from now "we" (Harbour
> community) want to make file XXX more free (PD, maybe) but we can no
> longer contact its author. We're stuck. Maybe we could start _now_ by
> having all copyright owned by the Harbour team (of captains, say), so that
> any such decisions would be possible.

For this to work wouldn't we need a "harbour foundation", some form of
non-profit organisation to actually hold the copyright? I'm not sure that
copyright can be assigned to an entity like "a bunch of people who might
change over time". Doesn't it need to be something more concrete?

Then, if we did want a non-profit organisation we'd have to decide *where*
it was created, who ran it, how it was funded, how, who, where, why...

<shudder>

I'd advise talking to the FSF about them taking on the copyright before
anyone think about having some harbour oriented entity allow copyrights to
be signed over.

From harbour@lists.harbour-project.org  Fri Mar  2 06:31:10 2001
From: harbour@lists.harbour-project.org (Dave Pearson)
Date: Fri Mar  2 06:31:10 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Our current GPL license probably won't do what we want it to do.
In-Reply-To: <200103020516_MC2-C755-1833@compuserve.com>; from John_Skelton@compuserve.com on Fri, Mar 02, 2001 at 05:16:17AM -0500
References: <200103020516_MC2-C755-1833@compuserve.com>
Message-ID: <20010302110801.L21816@hagbard.davep.org>

On Fri, Mar 02, 2001 at 05:16:17AM -0500, John Skelton wrote:

> "The above means my fictitious scenario above is 100% valid, and would
> *not* be in violation of our license, because it falls neatly under the
> current exception."
> 
> Fictitious, OK, but what would be the harm? Someone would've written a
> linker - no small task. They'd be benefitting from Harbour. Why's it
> different to me with a Clip-4-Win32 using Harbour? Why do we care? Er...
> do we? I don't think I do (but it's not my decision).

I think "we" do care and should care. Ron is highlighting the fact that the
current exception leaves the harbour code open to the kind of "abuse"[1]
that the GPL attempts to stop. That is, it's not desired that someone can
make minor changes to parts of harbour and release a new compiler based
around harbour without releasing it as free software.

The harbour exception allows (and is designed to allow) someone to build
non-free software that includes free software. Ron is talking about a
possible loophole that would allow someone to get around the wishes of
many/all of the harbour copyright holders.

Ron's example is highly contrived, granted, but that's actually the point.

> Hmm... I just read some of the other messages about code already under
> GPL. In that case isn't the above (fictious or otherwise) scenario already
> allowed and indeed something there's no point in debating because we
> cannot prevent it (GPL can't be revoked IIRC)?

If we didn't have the exception then such a situation could not happen
without breaking the terms of the licence. The harbour exception allows
people to "break" the licence (the GPL) for the purposes of building their
own non-free applications[2]. Ron is pointing out that any sufficiently
deceitful MegaEvilNastyPeopleCorpIncPLCGmbH could twist and turn their way
between the GPL and the exception to come up with a non-free harbour when
the whole point and intent of harbour is that it is first and foremost free
software.

-----
[1]  Actually that's putting the cart before the horse. The behaviour in
question is only "abuse" because a licence like the GPL is in place, if the
licence was a "more free" one it wouldn't be "abuse" because such actions
would be permitted. Think BSDL or (not that it's really a "licence") PD.

[2]  Note that I ran all of this by RMS (for those who don't know, the
founder of the FSF and the author of the GPL) and he agreed that, given our
particular set of licensing problems, we had chosen a sensible route to a
solution. Note that it's also the same solution chosen by at least one other
item of free software (guile) which, as it happens, is also part of the GNU
project.

-- 
The Harbour Project: A free software Clipper compatible compiler
Home Page..........: http://www.harbour-project.org/
FAQ................: http://www.harbour-project.org/faq/harbour.html
My harbour page....: http://www.davep.org/harbour/

From harbour@lists.harbour-project.org  Fri Mar  2 08:59:03 2001
From: harbour@lists.harbour-project.org (Dave Pearson)
Date: Fri Mar  2 08:59:03 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Our current GPL license probably won't do what   we want it to do.
In-Reply-To: <000801c0a312$b7cedc20$0f2aa8c0@antonio>; from alinares@fivetech.com on Fri, Mar 02, 2001 at 01:17:15PM +0100
References: <3A9F34DF.27210.100AB344@localhost> <000801c0a312$b7cedc20$0f2aa8c0@antonio>
Message-ID: <20010302133559.U21816@hagbard.davep.org>

On Fri, Mar 02, 2001 at 01:17:15PM +0100, Antonio Linares wrote:
> Phil,
> 
> > This is why a lot of people donate thir copyright to the FSF.
> 
> That sounds a very good solution.
> 
> Are there any problems for using that way ?

That depends on what you consider to be a problem. For starters, you need to
sign over your copyright, some people might see that as a problem. Also, if
you have a copyright you want to sign over you've got to be sure that, even
as the sole copyright owner, you've got the permission of every major
contributer to the code you've got copyright on.

On top of that some people might not "trust" the FSF to do the right thing
in the future.

Of course, there's the chance that the FSF might not want to accept the
copyright unless *all* of harbour is signed over. That would be quite a
large undertaking (as would signing over copyright to any entity).

You may recall that, in the early days of harbour, I suggested that people
keep track of who had made major contributions to their copyrighted work, it
was for this very reason what I made that suggestion.

-- 
The Harbour Project: A free software Clipper compatible compiler
Home Page..........: http://www.harbour-project.org/
FAQ................: http://www.harbour-project.org/faq/harbour.html
My harbour page....: http://www.davep.org/harbour/

From harbour@lists.harbour-project.org  Fri Mar  2 11:14:02 2001
From: harbour@lists.harbour-project.org (David G. Holm)
Date: Fri Mar  2 11:14:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Our current GPL license probably won't do what we want it to do.
In-Reply-To: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKIEAJDKAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>
References: <200103012002.f21K2D514415@thor.parrett.net>
Message-ID: <200103021613.f22GDY502973@thor.parrett.net>

** Reply to message from "Ron Pinkas" <Ron@Profit-Master.com> on Thu, 1
Mar 2001 17:34:40 -0800

> 1. Based on the current exception I *can* certainly *link* compiled HVM and
> HRTL into my *executable*(1). My resulting *exe*(1) is *not* covered by the
> Harbour License.

Total and utter nonsense! It is *impossible* to create an executable
from Harbour that is not covered by the Harbour License!

> 2. This executable(1) can easily be a linker application.

Which is perfectly legal. There is nothing wrong with writing a
non-free linker using Harbour!

> 3. This linker, in-turn *can* link the HVM and HRTL segments of self, along
> with Harbour compatible compiled code, thus producing the User Application
> executable(2).

Which would mean that the program is *not* just a linker, but a linker
that is bound to two libraries, with the two bound libraries qualifying
as binary distributions, which are covered by the GPL, but *not* by the
Harbour Exception.

> 4. In this scheme both the HVM and HRTL have been linked into executables
> not once, but twice, and both times such linking is covered and "excused" by
> the current exception.

Wrong! See #3.

> The above means my fictitious scenario above is 100% valid, and would *not*
> be in violation of our license, because it falls neatly under the current
> exception.

Wrong! See #3.

> There is nothing that subject executable(1), or executable(2), to any
> Harbour License, because there only relationship to Harbour is the "mere"
> link inclusion of the HVM and HRTL which is *completely* excused.

Wrong! The "relationship" from program #1 to program #2 is a *binary
distribution* of the HVM and HRL (please note that it is *not* proper to
refer to the HRL as the HRTL), which means that while program #1, by
itself, is covered by the Harbour Exception, what it does with the HVM
and HRL is *not* and falls *exclusively* under the GPL.
-- 
David G. Holm, Set Captain and all around
Harbour Project Clipper Compatibility fanatic.

From harbour@lists.harbour-project.org  Fri Mar  2 11:36:07 2001
From: harbour@lists.harbour-project.org (David G. Holm)
Date: Fri Mar  2 11:36:07 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Our current GPL license probably won't do what we want it to do.
In-Reply-To: <200103021130_MC2-C778-64FC@compuserve.com>
Message-ID: <200103021635.f22GZc505183@thor.parrett.net>

** Reply to message from John Skelton <John_Skelton@compuserve.com> on
Fri, 2 Mar 2001 11:30:17 -0500

> "This is why a lot of people donate thir copyright to the FSF."
> 
> But we probably can't because we the Harbour exception (or something
> like it).

Yes, we can. Dave has mentioned that the Guile project has a similar
exception and that it *is* a GNU project.
-- 
David G. Holm, Set Captain and all around
Harbour Project Clipper Compatibility fanatic.

From harbour@lists.harbour-project.org  Fri Mar  2 11:37:01 2001
From: harbour@lists.harbour-project.org (Ron Pinkas)
Date: Fri Mar  2 11:37:01 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Our current GPL license probably won't do what we want it to do.
In-Reply-To: <200103021613.f22GDY502973@thor.parrett.net>
Message-ID: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKCEBEDKAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>

David,

> > 1. Based on the current exception I *can* certainly *link*
> compiled HVM and
> > HRTL into my *executable*(1). My resulting *exe*(1) is *not*
> covered by the
> > Harbour License.
>
> Total and utter nonsense! It is *impossible* to create an executable
> from Harbour that is not covered by the Harbour License!

You might have intended such, but this is no more than wishful thinking,
because the Exception *does* say:

"Your use of that executable is in *no* way restricted on
account of *linking* the HRL and/or HVM code into it."

> Which would mean that the program is *not* just a linker, but a linker
> that is bound to two libraries, with the two bound libraries qualifying
> as binary distributions, which are covered by the GPL, but *not* by the
> Harbour Exception.

No both executables are in "no way restricted on account of linking the HRL
and/or HVM code into them"!!!

> > There is nothing that subject executable(1), or executable(2), to any
> > Harbour License, because there only relationship to Harbour is
> the "mere"
> > link inclusion of the HVM and HRTL which is *completely* excused.
>
> Wrong! The "relationship" from program #1 to program #2 is a *binary
> distribution* of the HVM and HRL (please note that it is *not* proper to
> refer to the HRL as the HRTL), which means that while program #1, by
> itself, is covered by the Harbour Exception, what it does with the HVM
> and HRL is *not* and falls *exclusively* under the GPL.

Every time you link the compiled HVM/HRTL it is be definition is a "binary
distribution". The Exception specifically excuse this kind of distribution
from being covered by our License.

Ron

The harbour exception is based on the guile exception and I think (I'll have
to double check) that guile is copyright the FSF. Also, RMS has seen and
checked the harbour exception and he was happy with it, he did this by proof
reading section 2 of the harbour FAQ for me:

,----[ <URL:http://www.harbour-project.org/faq/harbour-8.html#ss8.4> ]
| Revision 1.11  2000/01/10 16:55:43
| 
| Improved some of the language regarding the GPL (thanks to RMS for his
| input on this subject).
`----

I doubt that the harbour exception would be an impediment to such a course
of action.

From harbour@lists.harbour-project.org  Fri Mar  2 12:11:02 2001
From: harbour@lists.harbour-project.org (FA)
Date: Fri Mar  2 12:11:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Our current GPL license probably won't do what we want it to do.
References: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKIEAJDKAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>
Message-ID: <008001c0a33c$0ef55be0$1bb49cc3@detti.hu>

> 1. Based on the current exception I *can* certainly *link* compiled HVM
and
> HRTL into my *executable*(1). My resulting *exe*(1) is *not* covered by
the
> Harbour License.
>
> 2. This executable(1) can easily be a linker application.
>
> 3. This linker, in-turn *can* link the HVM and HRTL segments of self,
along
> with Harbour compatible compiled code, thus producing the User Application
> executable(2).
>
> 4. In this scheme both the HVM and HRTL have been linked into executables
> not once, but twice, and both times such linking is covered and "excused"
by
> the current exception.


I gues, (excuse me for mambling) that even _having_ a license forbiding this
would not prevent people form actually doing it if they want.  I guess all U
can do against it to make Harbour _very_well_ known so people cannot be
cheated this way. :-((

Suppose someone copies a stable version of the Harbour sources, changes few
things to (eg) C++, starts a grep and changes function names etc.  In many
country (law system) you will not be able to proove it is the same code.
:-(((  Said, but true!  I mean it, I just know 2 lost cases like this. :-(

FA


From harbour@lists.harbour-project.org  Fri Mar  2 12:20:03 2001
From: harbour@lists.harbour-project.org (David G. Holm)
Date: Fri Mar  2 12:20:03 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Fwd: [HarbourUsers] Harbour license restrictions
Message-ID: <200103021719.f22HJ2509262@thor.parrett.net>

** Forwarding message from "David G. Holm" <Harbour@spacemoose.com> on
Fri, 2 Mar 2001 12:17:36 -0500

** Reply to message from Randy Portnoff <randy@palmasdev.com> on Fri,
02 Mar 2001 10:50:48 -0500

All but six HRL and HVM code modules either state that the are public
domain or that they are covered by the Harbour Exception (I did a visual
inspection of all .c, .h, .l, .prg, .slx, and .y modules in all source
directories other than source/compiler, which isn't included in either
the HRL or the HVM, and the include directory).

The siz modules are: macroa.c, macrob.c, macroc.c, and macroslx.c, all
of which are located in the source/macro directory, and dbfcdx1.h and
dbfcdx2.h, both of which are located in the source/rdd/dbfcdx directory.

Hopefully the authors of those modules will update them with the
appropriate notice.

From harbour@lists.harbour-project.org  Fri Mar  2 12:33:11 2001
From: harbour@lists.harbour-project.org (David G. Holm)
Date: Fri Mar  2 12:33:11 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Our current GPL license probably won't do what we want it to do.
In-Reply-To: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKCEBEDKAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>
References: <200103021613.f22GDY502973@thor.parrett.net>
Message-ID: <200103021732.f22HWU510657@thor.parrett.net>

** Reply to message from "Ron Pinkas" <Ron@Profit-Master.com> on Fri, 2
Mar 2001 08:34:16 -0800

> > Total and utter nonsense! It is *impossible* to create an executable
> > from Harbour that is not covered by the Harbour License!
> 
> You might have intended such, but this is no more than wishful thinking,
> because the Exception *does* say:
> 
> "Your use of that executable is in *no* way restricted on
> account of *linking* the HRL and/or HVM code into it."

The Harbour Exception is part of the Harbour License! It does *not*
exclude programs from the Harbour License, it excludes *part* of the
*GPL* from your *use* of the excecutable, which is *still* covered by
the Harbour License.
-- 
David G. Holm, Set Captain and all around
Harbour Project Clipper Compatibility fanatic.

From harbour@lists.harbour-project.org  Fri Mar  2 12:39:02 2001
From: harbour@lists.harbour-project.org (Ron Pinkas)
Date: Fri Mar  2 12:39:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Our current GPL license probably won't do what we want it to do.
In-Reply-To: <008001c0a33c$0ef55be0$1bb49cc3@detti.hu>
Message-ID: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKEEBGDKAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>

1 + 1 = Attila Feher, right?

> I gues, (excuse me for mambling) that even _having_ a license
> forbiding this
> would not prevent people form actually doing it if they want.  I
> guess all U
> can do against it to make Harbour _very_well_ known so people cannot be
> cheated this way. :-((

That is like saying that laws against stealing don't prevent people from
doing so.

1. Most people will not do what they know to be illegal.
2. Without such laws we would have no definition for, what is valid as
oppose to what's not.

> Suppose someone copies a stable version of the Harbour sources,
> changes few
> things to (eg) C++, starts a grep and changes function names etc.  In many
> country (law system) you will not be able to proove it is the same code.
> :-(((  Said, but true!  I mean it, I just know 2 lost cases like this. :-(
>
> FA

We never imagined we could stop illegal actions from taking place. We only
seek to define what is/isn't allowed with regard to taking advantage of
Harbour.

Ron


From harbour@lists.harbour-project.org  Fri Mar  2 12:41:01 2001
From: harbour@lists.harbour-project.org (David G. Holm)
Date: Fri Mar  2 12:41:01 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Our current GPL license probably won't do what we want it to do.
In-Reply-To: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKCEBEDKAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>
References: <200103021613.f22GDY502973@thor.parrett.net>
Message-ID: <200103021740.f22He9511386@thor.parrett.net>

** Reply to message from "Ron Pinkas" <Ron@Profit-Master.com> on Fri, 2
Mar 2001 08:34:16 -0800

> > Which would mean that the program is *not* just a linker, but a linker
> > that is bound to two libraries, with the two bound libraries qualifying
> > as binary distributions, which are covered by the GPL, but *not* by the
> > Harbour Exception.
> 
> No both executables are in "no way restricted on account of linking the HRL
> and/or HVM code into them"!!!

If the linker was written with Harbour and only uses the HRL and HVM to
run the linker, then that is fine and dandy and the linker would be
covered by the Harbour Exception.

But, if the linker *also* includes a binding of the HRL and/or HVM for
inclusion in the programs that it links, then the linker would *not* be
covered by the Harbour Exception, because *this* use of the HRL and/or
HVM would fall under the binary distribution clause of the GPL.

So because your example involves the second use, the linker is *not*
covered by the Harbour Exception, but the programs that it creates would
probably be covered.
-- 
David G. Holm, Set Captain and all around
Harbour Project Clipper Compatibility fanatic.

From harbour@lists.harbour-project.org  Fri Mar  2 12:53:02 2001
From: harbour@lists.harbour-project.org (Ron Pinkas)
Date: Fri Mar  2 12:53:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Our current GPL license probably won't do what we want it to do.
In-Reply-To: <20010302173039.L21816@hagbard.davep.org>
Message-ID: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKOEBHDKAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>

Dave,

> > "Your use of that executable is in *no* way restricted on account of
> > *linking* the HRL and/or HVM code into it."
>
> David is actually correct. The executable *is* covered by the harbour
> licence otherwise it wouldn't be enjoying the benefits of that exception.

The very second the Exception takes effect, *all* liabilities described in
the GPL, become null and void, because we gave an irrevocable right to use
such executable free of *any* *restriction*.

Ron

From harbour@lists.harbour-project.org  Fri Mar  2 13:01:02 2001
From: harbour@lists.harbour-project.org (Ron Pinkas)
Date: Fri Mar  2 13:01:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Our current GPL license probably won't do what we want it to do.
In-Reply-To: <200103021740.f22He9511386@thor.parrett.net>
Message-ID: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKGEBIDKAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>

David,

> > No both executables are in "no way restricted on account of
> linking the HRL
> > and/or HVM code into them"!!!
>
> But, if the linker *also* includes a binding of the HRL and/or HVM for
> inclusion in the programs that it links, then the linker would *not* be
> covered by the Harbour Exception, because *this* use of the HRL and/or
> HVM would fall under the binary distribution clause of the GPL.

I knew this even before asking the advice of my copyright attorney, but he
made it crystal clear. Once the Exception grants the right to use such
executable without *any* *restriction*, you have effectively granted
irrevocable rights which can *not* be legally restricted by the granting
party!!!

> So because your example involves the second use, the linker is *not*
> covered by the Harbour Exception, but the programs that it creates would
> probably be covered.

Both are completely and unconditionally covered. I suggest you seek legal
advice to verify this.

Ron

From harbour@lists.harbour-project.org  Fri Mar  2 13:04:20 2001
From: harbour@lists.harbour-project.org (Dave Pearson)

> else I need would be good (I have read the FAQ, and will further). It
> seems I have to go deep into a problem which also effects OO - something
> about not being able to keep track of PROCNAME...

If you simply want help using harbour then the harbour-users mailing list is
there for that purpose. If you've found a bug in harbour and you want to get
the developers to help you track it down then this is the right mailing list
to use.

From harbour@lists.harbour-project.org  Fri Mar  2 13:10:04 2001
From: harbour@lists.harbour-project.org (Dave Pearson)
Date: Fri Mar  2 13:10:04 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Our current GPL license probably won't do what we want it to do.
In-Reply-To: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKOEBHDKAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>; from Ron@Profit-Master.com on Fri, Mar 02, 2001 at 09:50:48AM -0800
References: <20010302173039.L21816@hagbard.davep.org> <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKOEBHDKAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>
Message-ID: <20010302180950.A31842@hagbard.davep.org>

On Fri, Mar 02, 2001 at 09:50:48AM -0800, Ron Pinkas wrote:
> Dave,
> 
> > > "Your use of that executable is in *no* way restricted on account of
> > > *linking* the HRL and/or HVM code into it."
> >
> > David is actually correct. The executable *is* covered by the harbour
> > licence otherwise it wouldn't be enjoying the benefits of that exception.
> 
> The very second the Exception takes effect, *all* liabilities described in
> the GPL, become null and void, because we gave an irrevocable right to use
> such executable free of *any* *restriction*.

Correct, that's because the exception is in force. The licence does apply,
it's the application of the licence that's protecting the application's
non-free code from the GPL.

If the executable wasn't covered by the harbour licence then the exception
wouldn't be in force and the GPL would come to the forefront.

The licence doesn't cease to act after a link is complete and distribution
has taken place, the licence kicks in to it's fullest extent at that point.
Large parts of the GPL speak about the requirements when you *distribute*
binaries, the exception has to be "working" to separate the licence
requirements of the GPLd code in the binary from the non-free code in the
binary.

Think of the harbour exception as a condom, it only works while it's in use.

-- 
The Harbour Project: A free software Clipper compatible compiler
Home Page..........: http://www.harbour-project.org/
FAQ................: http://www.harbour-project.org/faq/harbour.html
My harbour page....: http://www.davep.org/harbour/

From harbour@lists.harbour-project.org  Fri Mar  2 13:37:02 2001
From: harbour@lists.harbour-project.org (Ron Pinkas)
Date: Fri Mar  2 13:37:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Our current GPL license probably won't do what we want it to do.
In-Reply-To: <20010302180950.A31842@hagbard.davep.org>
Message-ID: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKGEBKDKAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>

Dave,

> > The very second the Exception takes effect, *all* liabilities
> described in
> > the GPL, become null and void, because we gave an irrevocable
> right to use
> > such executable free of *any* *restriction*.

> The licence doesn't cease to act after a link is complete and distribution
> has taken place, the licence kicks in to it's fullest extent at
> that point.

That's totally false!!! Please check with any copyright attorney before
making such baseless claim.

The Exception grants unconditional, irrevocable, rights to use this
executable, free of any restriction what's so ever! This freedom is never
terminated and the GPL never "kicks in" on the account of *any* usage of
this executable.

> Large parts of the GPL speak about the requirements when you *distribute*
> binaries, the exception has to be "working" to separate the licence
> requirements of the GPLd code in the binary from the non-free code in the
> binary.

But all such parts are NULL and VOID, when it comes to this executable.

> Think of the harbour exception as a condom, it only works while
> it's in use.

Which means forever as far as the lifetime of this executable.

Ron


From harbour@lists.harbour-project.org  Fri Mar  2 14:27:02 2001
From: harbour@lists.harbour-project.org (Ron Pinkas)
Date: Fri Mar  2 14:27:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] GPL + Exception -> Legal Interpretation
In-Reply-To: <20010302180950.A31842@hagbard.davep.org>
Message-ID: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKCEBLDKAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>

Dave, David, All,

Here is a [simplified] legal description of the impact of the GPL + the
Harbour Exception on *any* excusable, where its only reliance on Harbour is
the link inclusion of the compiled HVM and/or HRTL (the Executable):

1. The second the link takes place, usage of the resulting Executable, is
subject to the GPL.

2. That very brief of an instant described in paragraph 1. above, the GPL is
being modified by the copyrights holder (Licensor), so as to create a new
license (HGPL). You *must* read this License (HGPL), as if a magic wand (the
Harbour Exception), has erased *any* and *all* language, that reads as a
restriction, while leaving intact everything else.

3. Any and all usage of the Excusable is subject to the HGPL and no other
License (unless such Excusable is relaying on other copyrighted material,
subjecting it to License granted by *other* copyright holder) for the
duration of its life time.

In summary, anyone is free to use any such executable, anyway they see feet,
without having to comply with any restriction (because no such restriction
exists), yet being granted each and every right described in the GPL.

Ron


From harbour@lists.harbour-project.org  Fri Mar  2 14:32:02 2001

> Harbour is

From harbour@lists.harbour-project.org  Fri Mar  2 15:04:02 2001
From: harbour@lists.harbour-project.org (David G. Holm)
Date: Fri Mar  2 15:04:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Our current GPL license probably won't do what we want it to do.
In-Reply-To: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKGEBHDKAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>
References: <200103021732.f22HWU510657@thor.parrett.net>
Message-ID: <200103022003.f22K35524300@thor.parrett.net>

** Reply to message from "Ron Pinkas" <Ron@Profit-Master.com> on Fri, 2
Mar 2001 09:46:53 -0800

> I guess it's my turn to say "Total and utter nonsense"!
> 
> Try convincing a Judge or Jury, that "in no way restricted", does *not*
> fully and completely, relinquish any, and all, rights to claim what is/isn't
> allowed!!!

You are focusing on a small fragment of the Harbour Exception and are
failing to understand how it works in context with the entire Harbour
License. Here is the entire Harbour Exception again:

>  The exception is that if you link the Harbour Runtime Library (HRL)
>  and/or the Harbour Virtual Machine (HVM) with other files to produce
>  an executable, this does not by itself cause the resulting executable
>  to be covered by the GNU General Public License. Your use of that
>  executable is in no way restricted on account of linking the HRL
>  and/or HVM code into it.

You are making the erroneous assumption that the sentence "Your use of
that executable is in no way restricted on account of linking the HRL
and/or HVM code into it" means that there are no restrictions whatsoever
on the use of the executable. But what is *actually* says is that
*merely* linking the HRL and/or HVM code into your executable does not
restrict your use of the executable. It does *not* say, or even *imply*,
that there are no other factors that can restrict your use of the
application. And some of the things that can *still* restrict your use
of the executable include, but are *not* limited to: using the
exectuable to performa a binary distribution of any part of Harbour or
the use of any modified Harbour source code.
-- 
David G. Holm, Set Captain and all around
Harbour Project Clipper Compatibility fanatic.

From harbour@lists.harbour-project.org  Fri Mar  2 20:00:04 2001
From: harbour@lists.harbour-project.org (Brian Hays)
Date: Fri Mar  2 20:00:04 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Fwd: [HarbourUsers] Harbour license restrictions
References: <200103021719.f22HJ2509262@thor.parrett.net> <200103021719.f22HJ2509262@thor.parrett.net> <20010302173850.O21816@hagbard.davep.org> <200103022011.f22KBn525087@thor.parrett.net> <200103022011.f22KBn525087@thor.parrett.net> ; from dholm@jsd-llc.com on Fri, Mar 02, 2001 at 03:11:41PM -0500 <200103022301.f22N1L508310@thor.parrett.net>
Message-ID: <011501c0a37e$052d5e40$921a5e18@bh>

RE CDX:
Don't forget Ryszard is in the middle of extensive work on that; the
existing files may be superfluous depending on what he's done.

Which does raise another question:  If one developer starts a small prg and
puts the standard header on it with his/her copyright, but then another
developer writes 10 yards of code to flesh it out, who gets any copyright?
Especially where the startup has stubs for functions and the second
developer writes all the guts, it can't be designated as "These functions
copyright XYZ".  And what if the first developer's code gets bug-fixed to
where there's nothing left of the original besides function names?  Does a
subsequent developer have the right to simply remove the first developer's
code altogether and replace it with new code and a new copyright?

This is where a "donated" copyright to a legal entity would help...

Brian Hays

From harbour@lists.harbour-project.org  Fri Mar  2 22:30:04 2001
From: harbour@lists.harbour-project.org (Ron Pinkas)
Date: Fri Mar  2 22:30:04 2001
Subject: [Harbour] GPL + Exception -> Legal Interpretation
In-Reply-To: <200103021954.f22Jsk523579@thor.parrett.net>
Message-ID: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKOEBMDKAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>

> > Sorry I neglected to mention that was the legal interpretation of my
> > copyright council.
>

> Exception, or did you just "explain things" to him?

verbatim.

Ron


From harbour@lists.harbour-project.org  Fri Mar  2 23:37:02 2001
From: harbour@lists.harbour-project.org (Ron Pinkas)
Date: Fri Mar  2 23:37:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] GPL + Exception -> Legal Interpretation
In-Reply-To: <20010302224330.X21816@hagbard.davep.org>
Message-ID: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKGEBPDKAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>

Dave,

> > 1. The second the link takes place, usage of the resulting
> Executable, is
> > subject to the GPL.
>
> Usage?

What you might do with an entity such as an executable including but not
limited to distributing, modifying, running, etc., is generically referred
to as usage.

> > 2. That very brief of an instant described in paragraph 1.
> above, the GPL is
> > being modified by the copyrights holder (Licensor), so as to
> create a new
> > license (HGPL).
>
> The GPL has not been modified. The "harbour licence" isn't a modified
> version of the GPL.

You shouldn't make baseless statements like that. *Adding* or *removing*
*any* *language* when applied to a legal document (such as the GPL), is
indeed considered a modification. The Harbour Exception *does* create a new
modified version of the GPL. I would strongly recommend that you consult
with a legal expert before making such statements.

> > 3. Any and all usage of the Excusable is subject to the HGPL
> and no other
> > License (unless such Excusable is relaying on other copyrighted
> material,
> > subjecting it to License granted by *other* copyright holder) for the
> > duration of its life time.
>
> Usage?

Consider Usage a synonym of Activities.

> > In summary, anyone is free to use any such executable, anyway they see
> > feet, without having to comply with any restriction (because no such
> > restriction exists), yet being granted each and every right described in
> > the GPL.
>
> The GPL doesn't generally speak about the *use* of an executable
> so I'm not
> sure what you mean about usage.

The GPL does generally speak about *use*. From GPL (section 0):

"The act of running the Program is not restricted"

Activities (like coping, distributing, and modifying) and/or and actions
(like running) are all considered usage. Further, our Exception is an
integral part of the Harbour License and reads:

"Your use of that executable is in no way restricted"
      ^^^

> Perhaps you're speaking about distribution?

No, I was talking about usage which is a slightly broader term. Most
Software are accompanied by a "User License". Such document aim to described
what usage of the software is valid. The GPL while not labeled "User
License" still is exactly that.

Ron


From harbour@lists.harbour-project.org  Fri Mar  2 23:43:02 2001
From: harbour@lists.harbour-project.org (Ron Pinkas)
Date: Fri Mar  2 23:43:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Our current GPL license probably won't do what we want it to do.
In-Reply-To: <20010302224108.W21816@hagbard.davep.org>
Message-ID: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKMEBPDKAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>

Dave,

> Curious, you're talking about a claim I never made. I'm sure the claim is
> baseless but it isn't a claim I made.

Did *you* not make the following claim?

> The licence doesn't cease to act after a link is complete and
> distribution has taken place, the licence kicks in to it's fullest
> extent at that point.

Ron

From harbour@lists.harbour-project.org  Sat Mar  3 00:22:10 2001
From: harbour@lists.harbour-project.org (Phil Barnett)
Date: Sat Mar  3 00:22:10 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Fwd: [HarbourUsers] Harbour license restrictions
In-Reply-To: <011501c0a37e$052d5e40$921a5e18@bh>
Message-ID: <3AA03914.5893.14032336@localhost>

On 2 Mar 2001, at 17:05, Brian Hays wrote:

> RE CDX:
> Don't forget Ryszard is in the middle of extensive work on that; the
> existing files may be superfluous depending on what he's done.
> 
> Which does raise another question:  If one developer starts a small prg and
> puts the standard header on it with his/her copyright, but then another
> developer writes 10 yards of code to flesh it out, who gets any copyright?
> Especially where the startup has stubs for functions and the second
> developer writes all the guts, it can't be designated as "These functions
> copyright XYZ".  And what if the first developer's code gets bug-fixed to
> where there's nothing left of the original besides function names?  Does a
> subsequent developer have the right to simply remove the first developer's
> code altogether and replace it with new code and a new copyright?

Technically. once code exists and is copyrighted to an entity, all 
subsequent edits of that code are derivative works, regardless of 
the added detail. All derivative works are still copyrighted to the 
original owner.

> This is where a "donated" copyright to a legal entity would help...

Indeed.


-- 
              Phil Barnett  mailto:midnight@the-oasis.net
                       WWW  http://www.the-oasis.net/
                  FTP Site  ftp://ftp.the-oasis.net

From harbour@lists.harbour-project.org  Sat Mar  3 00:33:02 2001

Remember, folks...

Other than getting the GPL + Harbour Exception on those six 
modules, we are not taking any action yet.

My proposal is that Dave and I take all the existing arguments and 
discussions into consideration and draft another license that we 
will come back to the table with.

This will allow the coders to continue concentrating on what they 
are doing while Dave and I hammer out a new proposed license.

I just love how the ideas have flowed in this project.

There are brilliant minds at work here.

Thank you all!

not because they've ceased to be in force.

Here's a different way to consider it, perhaps your legal adviser might like
to ponder it too. If someone decompiles a harbour built executable have they
manager to find a way of removing the GPL from the GPLd source code?

From harbour@lists.harbour-project.org  Sat Mar  3 02:41:43 2001
From: harbour@lists.harbour-project.org (Dave Pearson)
Date: Sat Mar  3 02:41:43 2001
Subject: [Harbour] GPL + Exception -> Legal Interpretation
In-Reply-To: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKGEBPDKAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>; from Ron@Profit-Master.com on Fri, Mar 02, 2001 at 08:34:17PM -0800
References: <20010302224330.X21816@hagbard.davep.org> <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKGEBPDKAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>
Message-ID: <20010303072521.B21816@hagbard.davep.org>

On Fri, Mar 02, 2001 at 08:34:17PM -0800, Ron Pinkas wrote:
> Dave,
> 
> > The GPL has not been modified. The "harbour licence" isn't a modified
> > version of the GPL.
> 
> You shouldn't make baseless statements like that. 

What's up with you Ron Pinkas? Why do you keep trying to tell the world that
I say things for no reason? 

>                                                   *Adding* or *removing*
> *any* *language* when applied to a legal document (such as the GPL), is
> indeed considered a modification. The Harbour Exception *does* create a
> new modified version of the GPL. 

No it doesn't. Show me where we've modified the text of the GPL. Show me
where the GPL is different in harbour than it is anywhere else.

>                                  I would strongly recommend that you
> consult with a legal expert before making such statements.

I don't need to do that Ron, I can see with my own eyes that we've not
modified the GPL. Is your legal advisor telling you this even though you've
not shown him the harbour exception and how it is applied?

You want to show him it all before you go accusing people have making
"baseless" statements. You might also want to apologise for making such
accusations too.

> > The GPL doesn't generally speak about the *use* of an executable so I'm
> > not sure what you mean about usage.
> 
> The GPL does generally speak about *use*. From GPL (section 0):
> 
> "The act of running the Program is not restricted"
> 
> Activities (like coping, distributing, and modifying) and/or and actions
> (like running) are all considered usage. Further, our Exception is an
> integral part of the Harbour License and reads:
> 
> "Your use of that executable is in no way restricted"
>       ^^^

This is why I said "generally". You might have noticed that the GPL is
mostly concerned with distribution of binaries and the making of derivative
works. That's all I was saying.

-- 
The Harbour Project: A free software Clipper compatible compiler

From harbour@lists.harbour-project.org  Sat Mar  3 02:54:02 2001
From: harbour@lists.harbour-project.org (Ron Pinkas)
Date: Sat Mar  3 02:54:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Our current GPL license probably won't do what we want it to do.
In-Reply-To: <20010303072035.A21816@hagbard.davep.org>
Message-ID: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKGECCDKAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>

Dave,

> Here's a different way to consider it, perhaps your legal adviser
> might like
> to ponder it too. If someone decompiles a harbour built
> executable have they
> manager to find a way of removing the GPL from the GPLd source code?

I did already think of that myself too. He explains that while such someone
might try to claim that "Your use of that executable is in no way
restricted", allows such "use", the (U.S.) legal system doesn't consider
decompiling a "use", but rather abuse.

Ron


From harbour@lists.harbour-project.org  Sat Mar  3 03:02:03 2001
From: harbour@lists.harbour-project.org (Dave Pearson)
Date: Sat Mar  3 03:02:03 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Our current GPL license probably won't do what we want it to do.
In-Reply-To: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKGECCDKAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>; from Ron@Profit-Master.com on Fri, Mar 02, 2001 at 11:51:19PM -0800
References: <20010303072035.A21816@hagbard.davep.org> <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKGECCDKAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>
Message-ID: <20010303080149.G21816@hagbard.davep.org>

On Fri, Mar 02, 2001 at 11:51:19PM -0800, Ron Pinkas wrote:
> Dave,
> 
> > Here's a different way to consider it, perhaps your legal adviser might
> > like to ponder it too. If someone decompiles a harbour built executable
> > have they manager to find a way of removing the GPL from the GPLd source
> > code?
> 
> I did already think of that myself too. He explains that while such
> someone might try to claim that "Your use of that executable is in no way
> restricted", allows such "use", the (U.S.) legal system doesn't consider
> decompiling a "use", but rather abuse.

Hmm, although that does give some "protection" it isn't really helpful is
it. It decompilation of an executable that you *own* (as opposed to own a
licence for) really abuse? I find that hard to believe.

Put another way, if I build an application with harbour, loose the source
code, use a harbour decompiler to get *my* source back, why is that seen as
abuse. Also, as a side effect to that, I've also got a load of source that
used to be under the GPL. Is it still under the GPL now that it's been
"washed" by my application and the decompiler? I'd have thought not, it's a
derivative work. If it's still under the copyright of the various harbour
copyright holders it then begs the question: what licence exists for it now?

If the GPL still exists for it it would seem that the licence existed
post-build, and that the exception existed post-build too.

-- 
The Harbour Project: A free software Clipper compatible compiler
Home Page..........: http://www.harbour-project.org/
FAQ................: http://www.harbour-project.org/faq/harbour.html
My harbour page....: http://www.davep.org/harbour/

> to join the harbour project.

He wanted both.

Here is the text he sent. The first paragraph speaks to becoming 
part of GNU, the last paragraph mentions donating the copyright.

I did write back to him and explain that it's not a database 
package, but a language and compiler that can use databases.

***************************
From:           	Richard Stallman <rms@santafe.edu>
To:             	midnight@the-oasis.net
Subject:        	Re: Task List Suggestion.
Send reply to:  	rms@gnu.org
Date: Fri, 18 Aug 2000 19:25:31 -0600 (MDT)
Message-Id: <200008190125.TAA14655@wijiji.santafe.edu>

Would you like to make this database package GNU software?  
Here's an explanation of what it means for a program to be GNU 
software:

=================================================
=====================
Calling a program GNU software means that its developers and the 
GNU project agree that "This program is part of the GNU project, 
released under the aegis of GNU"--and say so in the program.

This means that we normally put the program on ftp.gnu.org 
(although we could instead refer to the developer's choice of ftp 
site) and that we put the official pages describing the program on 
the GNU web server.  (It is ok to have more informal pages about 
secondary issues, such as discussion meant for people who want 
to help develop the package, on some other site.)

It means that the developers agree to pay some attention to 
making the program work well with the rest of the GNU system--
and conversely that the GNU project will encourage other GNU 
maintainers to pay some attention to making their programs fit in 
well with it.

Just what it means to make programs work well together is mainly 
a practical matter that depends on what the program does.  But 
there are a few general principles.  Certain parts of the GNU coding 
standards directly affect the consistency of the whole system.  
These include the standards for configuring and building a program, 
and the standards for command-line options.  It is important to 
make all GNU programs follow these standards, where they are 
applicable.

Another important GNU standard is that GNU programs should 
come with documentation in Texinfo format.  That is the GNU 
standard documentation format, and it can be converted 
automatically into various other formats.

If a GNU program wants to be extensible, it should use GUILE 
(http://www.gnu.org/software/guile/guile.html) as the programming 
language for extensibility--that is the GNU standard extensibility 
package.  If the program doesn't use GUILE today, at least there 
should be a firm plan to support it in the future.

A GNU program should not recommend use of any non-free 
program, and it should not refer the user to any non-free 
documentation for free software.  The need for free documentation 
to go with free software is now a major focus of the GNU project; to 
show that we are serious about the need for free documentation, 
we must not contradict our position by recommending use of 
documentation that isn't free.

Occasionally there are issues of terminology which are important 
for the success of the GNU project as a whole.  So we ask 
maintainers of GNU programs to follow them.  For example, the 
documentation files and comments in the program should speak of 
Linux-based GNU systems or GNU/Linux systems, rather than 
calling the whole system "Linux", and should use the term "free 
software" rather than "open source".

Deciding that a program is GNU software does not necessarily 
require transferring copyright to the FSF; that is a separate 
question.  If you transfer the copyright to the FSF, the FSF will 
enforce the GPL for the program if someone violates it; if you keep 
the copyright, enforcement will be up to you.



-- 
              Phil Barnett  mailto:midnight@the-oasis.net
                       WWW  http://www.the-oasis.net/
                  FTP Site  ftp://ftp.the-oasis.net

From harbour@lists.harbour-project.org  Sat Mar  3 03:25:03 2001

Subject: [Harbour] GPL + Exception -> Legal Interpretation

Dave,

> What's up with you Ron Pinkas? Why do you keep trying to tell the
> world that
> I say things for no reason?

Because you did. You clearly stated:

"The "harbour license" isn't a modified version of the GPL."

That is absolutely false in the legal sense, because the GPL + Harbour
Exception == Modified version of the GPL. If it wasn't modified we could
have used the GPL *without* such exception.

> >                                                   *Adding* or *removing*
> > *any* *language* when applied to a legal document (such as the GPL), is
> > indeed considered a modification. The Harbour Exception *does* create a
> > new modified version of the GPL.
>
> No it doesn't. Show me where we've modified the text of the GPL. Show me
> where the GPL is different in harbour than it is anywhere else.

,--------------------------------------------------------------------
|This program is free software; you can redistribute it and/or modify
|it under the terms of the GNU General Public License as published by
|the Free Software Foundation; either version 2 of the License, or
|(at your option) any later version, with one exception:
|                                    ^^^^ ^^^ ^^^^^^^^^
`---------------------------------------------------------------------

The above legally creates a new License based on the GPL with the addition
of the Exception.

> >                                  I would strongly recommend that you
> > consult with a legal expert before making such statements.
>
> I don't need to do that Ron, I can see with my own eyes that we've not
> modified the GPL. Is your legal advisor telling you this even
> though you've
> not shown him the harbour exception and how it is applied?

I did clearly state that I *did* show him the Exception, why would you
miss-state this fact too?

> You want to show him it all before you go accusing people have making
> "baseless" statements. You might also want to apologise for making such
> accusations too.

I *did* "show it all". I only accused you of doing what you clearly did. You
claimed:

"The "harbour license" isn't a modified version of the GPL."

When in fact it is. I specifically suggested that you seek legal advice
about this very fact, before making such statements.

> > > The GPL doesn't generally speak about the *use* of an
> executable so I'm
> > > not sure what you mean about usage.
> >
> > The GPL does generally speak about *use*. From GPL (section 0):
> >
> > "The act of running the Program is not restricted"
> >
> > Activities (like coping, distributing, and modifying) and/or and actions
> > (like running) are all considered usage. Further, our Exception is an
> > integral part of the Harbour License and reads:
> >
> > "Your use of that executable is in no way restricted"
> >       ^^^
>
> This is why I said "generally". You might have noticed that the GPL is
> mostly concerned with distribution of binaries and the making of
> derivative
> works. That's all I was saying.

No that's *not* *all* you were saying. 3 different times you were
questioning, the use of the term "use". Where as I explained, it is
perfectly appropriate in the context it was used.

> for it now?

copyright protection it claimed at its most recent prior copyright notice.

> If the GPL still exists for it would seem that the licence existed
> post-build, and that the exception existed post-build too.

I'm told the GPL + Exception exists from the moment the executable was
created. Use of this executable is forever subject to terms of this HGPL*.

I also clearly stated, in the sentence prior to that one:

,----
| The GPL has not been modified.
`----

> That is absolutely false in the legal sense, because the GPL + Harbour
> Exception == Modified version of the GPL. If it wasn't modified we could
> have used the GPL *without* such exception.

It isn't a modified version of the GPL. The content of the file COPYING has
in no way been modified. Furthermore, the "harbour licence" uses the pure
GPL in most circumstances. The harbour exception is an agreement between the
copyright holder an a user of that code that absolves them from observing
the GPL for a given "use".

The GPL has not been modified, the "harbour licence" isn't a modified
version of the GPL, the file COPYING is unmolested.

I'm still having a hard time seeing how what I'm saying is "baseless" when
I've actually thought about this and what I'm saying has a basis. Perhaps
you'd be so kind to drop the argumentative tone and actually look at what
I'm writing?

I can see that your legal advisor has given you legal advice and that you
believe his advice. I can also see that the GPL hasn't been modified, these
two facts don't fit, hence the reason I'm pointing this out and asking about
it so we can all learn.

You, on the other hand, seem to want to try and convince the world that I
have no good firm reasons for asking what I'm asking. What purpose does that
serve Ron Pinkas?

> ,--------------------------------------------------------------------
> |This program is free software; you can redistribute it and/or modify
> |it under the terms of the GNU General Public License as published by
> |the Free Software Foundation; either version 2 of the License, or
> |(at your option) any later version, with one exception:
> |                                    ^^^^ ^^^ ^^^^^^^^^
> `---------------------------------------------------------------------
> 
> The above legally creates a new License based on the GPL with the addition
> of the Exception.

I'd have a hard time disagreeing with this. You'll note, however, that it
doesn't say that the GPL has been modified.
