From harbour@lists.harbour-project.org  Sat Mar  3 04:51:01 2001
From: harbour@lists.harbour-project.org (Matthew Collins)
Date: Sat Mar  3 04:51:01 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Licensing discussions
In-Reply-To: <3AA03BAC.26182.140D4375@localhost>; from midnight@the-oasis.net on Sat, Mar 03, 2001 at 12:32:44AM -0500
References: <3AA03BAC.26182.140D4375@localhost>
Message-ID: <20010303093846.A412@janes.demon.co.uk>

On Sat, Mar 03, 2001 at 12:32:44AM -0500, Phil Barnett wrote:
> 
> Remember, folks...
> 
> Other than getting the GPL + Harbour Exception on those six 
> modules, we are not taking any action yet.
> 
> My proposal is that Dave and I take all the existing arguments and 
> discussions into consideration and draft another license that we 
> will come back to the table with.
> 

I seem to have come back in the middle of the discussion here. I'll
summarise the current points that I've seen, can someone please 
correct me if I'm wrong on anything.

1. Currently, changing code like errorsys.prg, getsys.prg will require
   that those portions of code be made available under the GPL, as
   the modified versions are covered under the GPL+Harbour exception.
   This is not desirable.

2. The GPL+Harbour exception is OK for the original purpose (allowing
   people to create non-free programs using Harbour and the Harbour
   libraries) without them having to GPL the code that they are
   compiling, as long as they don't include modified Harbour code.

So what we want, is for people to be able to modify units like
errorsys.prg, getsys.prg without having to GPL their modifications.

So, the questions I have.

Is the existing GPL+Harbour exception OK for the "core" harbour code?

Why don't we identify units that we want people to be able to modify
& include in their own program without them being subject to our 
licence and put them in the public domain? 

Take errorsys.prg. People should be able to modify it and include
it in their programs. There is no problem with putting it in the
public domain, as we don't care if people include it in non-free
software.

Please. Tell me if I'm seeing this too simply. It's hard to see through
Ron & Dave arguments to see if they have found a fundamental flaw in
the harbour exception, or if they are just trying to bend it to allow
units like errorsys to be used in a non-free manner.

--
Matthew Collins

From harbour@lists.harbour-project.org  Sat Mar  3 05:45:03 2001
From: harbour@lists.harbour-project.org (Ron Pinkas)
Date: Sat Mar  3 05:45:03 2001
Subject: [Harbour] GPL + Exception -> Legal Interpretation
In-Reply-To: <20010303092450.M21816@hagbard.davep.org>
Message-ID: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKAECGDKAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>

Dave,

> I also clearly stated, in the sentence prior to that one:
>
> ,----
> | The GPL has not been modified.
> `----

But this is exactly the problem, you make a statement with legal context
based on literal context. This is flawed. From the legal standpoint, (GPL is
a legal document) adding any text which is attached to or applied to a legal
document, effectively modifies such document.

The License which any Harbour Application is covered by, is *not* the GPL,
it is a version of the GPL which is derived from the original GPL *plus* the
Harbour Exception.

> > That is absolutely false in the legal sense, because the GPL + Harbour
> > Exception == Modified version of the GPL. If it wasn't modified we could
> > have used the GPL *without* such exception.
>
> It isn't a modified version of the GPL. The content of the file
> COPYING has
> in no way been modified. Furthermore, the "harbour license" uses the pure
> GPL in most circumstances. The harbour exception is an agreement
> between the
> copyright holder an a user of that code that absolves them from observing
> the GPL for a given "use".
>
> The GPL has not been modified, the "harbour license" isn't a modified
> version of the GPL, the file COPYING is unmolested.

Have you read what you just wrote? "Most cases"?

This is where you keep ignoring what is no more than a simple legal reality.
License X + any additional text, is no longer License X. I don't know how to
repeat it in any clearer terms. Even if the addition text only effected
0.00000000001% of circumstances.

> I'm still having a hard time seeing how what I'm saying is "baseless" when
> I've actually thought about this and what I'm saying has a basis. Perhaps
> you'd be so kind to drop the argumentative tone and actually look at what
> I'm writing?

What has basis in your unqualified opinion does not necessarily qualify as
legal basis. Your difficulty is arising exactly from your willingness to
argue a legal point without the legal qualifications.

> I can see that your legal advisor has given you legal advice and that you
> believe his advice. I can also see that the GPL hasn't been
> modified, these
> two facts don't fit, hence the reason I'm pointing this out and
> asking about
> it so we can all learn.

How is the saying, "If Two conflicting realities appear correct, at least
one of them must be false"?

Your claim that the Harbour License is not a modified version of the GPL is
100% false.

You claim that you "point it out and asking, so that we can all learn", but
yet you decline to accept the professional opinion of a qualified expert as
valid. You have not explained why makes you qualified to refute such
qualified opinion.

The only way you can resolve your conflict, is by seeking professional
advise, that you should be willing to accept. I did suggest this before, and
you continually declined.

> You, on the other hand, seem to want to try and convince the world that I
> have no good firm reasons for asking what I'm asking. What
> purpose does that
> serve Ron Pinkas?

You were not asking, you were making unqualified claims, and definitive
statements which were absolutely false.

It serve the purpose of correcting the wrong impression you insisted on
conveying, even after I tried to provide you with the qualified information,
you should have relied upon.

> > ,--------------------------------------------------------------------
> > |This program is free software; you can redistribute it and/or modify
> > |it under the terms of the GNU General Public License as published by
> > |the Free Software Foundation; either version 2 of the License, or
> > |(at your option) any later version, with one exception:
> > |                                    ^^^^ ^^^ ^^^^^^^^^
> > `---------------------------------------------------------------------
> >
> > The above legally creates a new License based on the GPL with
> the addition
> > of the Exception.

> I'd have a hard time disagreeing with this. You'll note, however, that it

> De momento hay van las pruebas que he realizado:
> 
> Pruebas realizadas al RDD DBFCDX nativo de Harbour
> bajo Harbour Compiler 0.36 (Build 36) (2001.02.20) (Flex)
> -----------------------------------------------------------------------
> 
> Provoca GPF :
> *************
> 
> - Indexar con un nombre de archivo CDX que ya exista
>   ( Normalmente, CA-Clipper "engordaba" re-escribiendo el archivo
>     si no se utilizaba SET AUTOPEN OFF )
>   Es curioso que solamente pasa si el indice se crea por primera vez
>   desde Harbour y se vuelve a crear tambien desde Harbour, en cambio,
>   si la primera vez se crea desde CA-Clipper y luego se crea desde Harbour,
>   ya no ocurre ningun GPF, ya que Harbour NO ESCRIBE DE NUEVO el indice.
>   CA-Clipper SI ESCRIBE DE NUEVO el indice cada vez, sin provocar GPF.
> 
> - Indexar utilizando la clausula FOR
>   p.e. index on first for !deleted()
> 
> - Indexar utilizando un campo numrico
> 
> Funciones que fallan:
> *********************
> 
> - Indexar utilizando un campo tipo fecha provoca un "espectacular" volcado
>   por pantalla del siguiente texto: "hb_cdxTagDoIndex( LPCDXTAG pTag )"
>   cuando se ejecuta un LIST de la DBF despus del indexado.
> 
> - No es posible la apertura de una misma DBF ms de una vez (con alias
>   distintos ). Esto funciona perfectamente en CA-Clipper:
>       use test alias "uno" new
>       use test alias "dos" new
>   En cambio en Harbour: Error DBFCDX/1001  Open error: test.dbf
> 
> - SET FILTER hace que no se detecte nunca un eof()
>   p.e.
>   SET FILTER TO SubStr( Field, 1, 1 ) == "A"
>   Tanto un LIST como un bucle del tipo
>   WHILE !Eof()
>    ? first
>    Skip
>   Enddo
>   provocaran una salida indefinidamente del ultimo registro
> 
> - Parece ser que en OrdScope() hay una operacion no soportada
> 
> hb_cdxTagKeyRead()hb_cdxTagTestRange()hb_cdxTagKeyRead()hb_cdxTagTestRange()
>   Error DBFCDX/0  Operation not supported
>   Called from ORDSCOPE(0)
>   Called from MAIN(10)
>   ce\vm\fm.c:425: HB_TR_ERROR Block 1 (size 24) ORDSCOPE(0)
>   source\vm\fm.c:425: HB_TR_ERROR Block 2 (size 1) ORDSCOPE(0)
> 
> - OrdKeyCount() devuelve 0 (cero) aunque la DBF NO est vaca.
> 
> Seguiremos investigando... !:)
> 


Regards

Luiz Rafael Culik



From harbour@lists.harbour-project.org  Sat Mar  3 15:21:02 2001
From: harbour@lists.harbour-project.org (Marek Paliwoda)
Date: Sat Mar  3 15:21:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] linux version
References: <20010301221940.925.qmail@web12712.mail.yahoo.com>
 <20010301224403.T21816@hagbard.davep.org>
 <001001c0a362$d9314060$9d99e6c3@homejxgdiook8o>
Message-ID: <011b01c0a41c$bbaa17a0$20b572c3@map>

> > On Thu, Mar 01, 2001 at 02:19:40PM -0800, Timur Kh wrote:
> >
> > > Is here anybody, who is busy with linux version of the Harbour?
> > > As I understood you have own rtl for every OS/compiler. Library,
> > > which is linked under linux, gtstd, is almost empty. Is here any other
> > > library for linux under development? If no, I can try to write after
> > > some consultations.
> >
> > GTCRS is the library you want to be looking at for terminal IO under
> > GNU/Linux.
> >
> > If you're running a RedHat based system there's an RPM of 0.36 available
> > for download on the harbour web site. If you don't like binary builds but
>> do have an RPM based system you can grab the SPRM and build it
> > yourself,  it'll do the "right thing" in regards to including the right
> > libraries.
>
> Thanks you. I've finally build it. I would, probably, add -lm -lncurses
> options to gcc command in bin/bld.sh that it could find appropriate
> libraries (As I had to do). I ran some included tests. Some of them, like
> "hello", "box", are OK, while others, like "dirtest", failed. Is this the
> problem with gtcrs or with other code?


It is a problem with implementation of  OutXXX() functions in Unix
environment. Currently to manipulate screen (beter say a terminal)
gt layer uses either curses or slang library which put terminal to a
"raw" mode with no LF translation. In console.c both hb_conOutStd()
and hb_conOutErr() use hb_fsWriteLarge() to write directly to a file
descriptor outside either curses or slang library, so they can not
track all screen writes this way. This leads for example to problems
with Dos CRLF and Unix LF new line markers. Simple lines :

OutStd( " This is a first line " + hb_osNewLine() )
OutStd( " This is a second line " + hb_osNewLine() )

will work ok on Dos but fail on Unix because both line feed and carriage
return will be written to screen on Dos, setting cursor in a proper place,
and on Unix only line feed will be sent moving cursor down and not forcing
it to a begin of line.
Because libraries can not track all screen writes some screen output done
by OutXXX() funcs may be discarded during library refresh screen operations.

Another problem with using screen management libraries (I should
say - with controling terminals) in Unix environment is redirecting output
from stdout and stderr to a file or a pipe. Terminals are controled via
sequences of control characters which are sent to them and these
sequences simply are redirected too, causing redirection unuseable
at all.

Try redirecting simple program :

PROCEDURE Main()
    OutStd( " This is a redirection " + hb_osNewLine() )
RETURN

to a file and see that file. You'll see what I mean.

Marek Paliwoda







From harbour@lists.harbour-project.org  Sat Mar  3 23:51:02 2001
From: harbour@lists.harbour-project.org (Phil Barnett)
Date: Sat Mar  3 23:51:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Licensing discussions
In-Reply-To: <20010303093846.A412@janes.demon.co.uk>
References: <3AA03BAC.26182.140D4375@localhost>; from midnight@the-oasis.net on Sat, Mar 03, 2001 at 12:32:44AM -0500
Message-ID: <3AA18335.24120.190CB088@localhost>

On 3 Mar 2001, at 9:38, Matthew Collins wrote:

> I seem to have come back in the middle of the discussion here. I'll
> summarise the current points that I've seen, can someone please 
> correct me if I'm wrong on anything.
> 
> 1. Currently, changing code like errorsys.prg, getsys.prg will require
>    that those portions of code be made available under the GPL, as
>    the modified versions are covered under the GPL+Harbour exception.
>    This is not desirable.
> 
> 2. The GPL+Harbour exception is OK for the original purpose (allowing
>    people to create non-free programs using Harbour and the Harbour
>    libraries) without them having to GPL the code that they are
>    compiling, as long as they don't include modified Harbour code.
> 
> So what we want, is for people to be able to modify units like
> errorsys.prg, getsys.prg without having to GPL their modifications.
> 
> So, the questions I have.
> 
> Is the existing GPL+Harbour exception OK for the "core" harbour code?
> 
> Why don't we identify units that we want people to be able to modify
> & include in their own program without them being subject to our 
> licence and put them in the public domain? 

While I'm not against this approach, I think it leaves a lot to be 
desired.

> Take errorsys.prg. People should be able to modify it and include
> it in their programs. There is no problem with putting it in the
> public domain, as we don't care if people include it in non-free
> software.

That's one way to get there, and perhaps the most obvios parts 
should be treated this way such as errorsys and getsys.

> Please. Tell me if I'm seeing this too simply. It's hard to see through
> Ron & Dave arguments to see if they have found a fundamental flaw in
> the harbour exception, or if they are just trying to bend it to allow
> units like errorsys to be used in a non-free manner.

Ok, it's a year from now and I'm writing some code to compile with 
Harbour and I want to do something with a part of the RTL that 
hasn't been identified in the list of 'sanctioned code' that I can 
modify.

Now what?

Do I try to find the author and get his permission to modify his work 
without invoking the GPL?

Do I ignore it and break the law?

Do I rewrite the code that I wanted to borrow and modify because 
modification of the code I want to borrow is not sanctioned?

Do I try to get the developers to add my features the to base set?

This is what I was referring to when I requested this conversation 
and asked to not create a list that delineates which modules can 
and which modules can't be modified and included, but instead a 
general rule that identifies them without letting all the cows out of 
the barn at the same time. (getting us ripped off because we 
loosened a huge loophole).

While it may seem convenient to identify a list of source code that 
we are sanctioned to modify and include, we have never before had 
the privilege of having the entire code base at our disposal. (re CA-
Clipper or any other commercial product) This makes it difficult to 
draw the line since we don't have much experience in what will be 
useful to modify and include at some point in the future.

For example, should we allow someone to modify the object 
system? How about the way arrays are populated?

It's going to be really hard to identify just which code should be 
subject to inclusion and modification without invoking the GPL. If 
we create a list of limits, we could be stifling innovation.

This is why I wanted to create a general rule instead of a list.

Something like:

Commonnly modified modules in the Harbour Project source code 
have not been licensed via the GPL license, but were instead 
placed in the public domain. Feel free to modify these and include 
them in in your source code while still maintaining the Harbour 
Exception clause to the GPL license.

You may also include and modify as many as three other RTL and 
VM source code modules without invoking the GPL license.

I'm not even suggesting that this is a solution, but just to illustrate 
the idea of creating a general rule instead of a list. The exception to 
this is that you cannot use this exception to create a commercial 
compiler.


-- 
              Phil Barnett  mailto:midnight@the-oasis.net
                       WWW  http://www.the-oasis.net/
                  FTP Site  ftp://ftp.the-oasis.net

From harbour@lists.harbour-project.org  Sun Mar  4 02:53:05 2001
From: harbour@lists.harbour-project.org (Dave Pearson)
Date: Sun Mar  4 02:53:05 2001
Subject: [Harbour] GPL + Exception -> Legal Interpretation
In-Reply-To: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKAECGDKAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>; from Ron@Profit-Master.com on Sat, Mar 03, 2001 at 02:42:08AM -0800
References: <20010303092450.M21816@hagbard.davep.org> <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKAECGDKAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>

On Sat, Mar 03, 2001 at 02:42:08AM -0800, Ron Pinkas wrote:
> Dave,
> 
> > I'm still having a hard time seeing how what I'm saying is "baseless"
> > when I've actually thought about this and what I'm saying has a basis.
> > Perhaps you'd be so kind to drop the argumentative tone and actually
> > look at what I'm writing?
> 
> What has basis in your unqualified opinion does not necessarily qualify as
> legal basis. Your difficulty is arising exactly from your willingness to
> argue a legal point without the legal qualifications.

I'm not arguing a legal point Ron, I'm simply making a statement of fact.
We've not modified the GPL.

> You claim that you "point it out and asking, so that we can all learn",
> but yet you decline to accept the professional opinion of a qualified
> expert as valid. You have not explained why makes you qualified to refute
> such qualified opinion.

Oh God, here we go again, Ron Pinkas and his inane attempts at bullying.
Ron, can't you begin to understand that I don't have to be qualified, in any
way, shape or form, to see that we've not changed one single word of the
GPL? Can't you see that such an observation, no matter anyone's
qualification, will cause those who are curious to ask for clarification?

What I don't understand is why, if you've got to the trouble of taking legal
advice, you're not willing to share it to it's fully extent and explain why
we have modified the GPL? So far you've simply stated that we have and have
then claimed argument-by-qualification as your reasoning.

I've asked for clarification, I've been honest and polite enough to document
where my confusion may be and you come up with the crap about.

> > You, on the other hand, seem to want to try and convince the world that
> > I have no good firm reasons for asking what I'm asking. What purpose
> > does that serve Ron Pinkas?
> 
> You were not asking, you were making unqualified claims, and definitive
> statements which were absolutely false.

In my native language (English) a question mark means that the preceding
text is a question. Does it mean something different in your native
language?

> You keep insisting on not seeing what is clearly in front of you. I'm
> afraid you'll have to ask others, as I did my best and failed.

If you really did take legal advice I would have thought that your "best"
would have exceeded "because I would told so". If you are not in a position
to explain further then, obviously, you're more than welcome to say that you
can't.

From harbour@lists.harbour-project.org  Sun Mar  4 08:34:02 2001
From: harbour@lists.harbour-project.org (Matthew Collins)
Date: Sun Mar  4 08:34:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Licensing discussions
In-Reply-To: <3AA18335.24120.190CB088@localhost>; from midnight@the-oasis.net on Sat, Mar 03, 2001 at 11:50:13PM -0500
References: <3AA03BAC.26182.140D4375@localhost>; <20010303093846.A412@janes.demon.co.uk> <3AA18335.24120.190CB088@localhost>
Message-ID: <20010304132820.A612@janes.demon.co.uk>

On Sat, Mar 03, 2001 at 11:50:13PM -0500, Phil Barnett wrote:
> 
> Ok, it's a year from now and I'm writing some code to compile with 
> Harbour and I want to do something with a part of the RTL that 
> hasn't been identified in the list of 'sanctioned code' that I can 
> modify.
> 
> Now what?
> 
> Do I try to find the author and get his permission to modify his work 
> without invoking the GPL?
> 
> Do I ignore it and break the law?
> 
> Do I rewrite the code that I wanted to borrow and modify because 
> modification of the code I want to borrow is not sanctioned?
> 
> Do I try to get the developers to add my features the to base set?
> 

Modify the code, and release your modified version of Harbour with the
existing Licence. Then compile your code with the version of Harbour.
That is what the GPL is for. To stop people doing exactly what you are 
Talking about. We don't really want people modifing the core without
making those changes available under the GPL.

> This is what I was referring to when I requested this conversation 
> and asked to not create a list that delineates which modules can 
> and which modules can't be modified and included, but instead a 
> general rule that identifies them without letting all the cows out of 
> the barn at the same time. (getting us ripped off because we 
> loosened a huge loophole).
> 
> While it may seem convenient to identify a list of source code that 
> we are sanctioned to modify and include, we have never before had 
> the privilege of having the entire code base at our disposal. (re CA-
> Clipper or any other commercial product) This makes it difficult to 
> draw the line since we don't have much experience in what will be 
> useful to modify and include at some point in the future.
> 
> For example, should we allow someone to modify the object 
> system? How about the way arrays are populated?
> 

We do allow people to modify the object system, as long as they 
release their changes under the same licence that we use. They are
getting all our work for free, why should they be able to change it
and not let us see their changes.

> It's going to be really hard to identify just which code should be 
> subject to inclusion and modification without invoking the GPL. If 
> we create a list of limits, we could be stifling innovation.
> 

Why not use Ca-Clipper as a guide. Release those units that CA released
with Clipper, and put the in the Public domain.
Anything else that people want to do with Harbour, is most likely 
going to benefit everybody who uses Harbour, so they should be
made available under the GPL.

The GPL does not require you to release your code to everybody. It 
requires you to release your code to whoever you make a binary version
available to. If you are selling an application to somebody, you don't
have to make your changes available to the world, just to the person
you have given your binary to. The only thing you can't do is stop
them passing on the source to whoever they choose. A developer working
closly with a client and writing bespoke software is not going to be
bothered about giving a small portion of their source code to the 
client.

> This is why I wanted to create a general rule instead of a list.
> 
> Something like:
> 
> Commonnly modified modules in the Harbour Project source code 
> have not been licensed via the GPL license, but were instead 
> placed in the public domain. Feel free to modify these and include 
> them in in your source code while still maintaining the Harbour 
> Exception clause to the GPL license.
> 
> You may also include and modify as many as three other RTL and 
> VM source code modules without invoking the GPL license.
>

I can see big problems with this.
 
> I'm not even suggesting that this is a solution, but just to illustrate 
> the idea of creating a general rule instead of a list. The exception to 
> this is that you cannot use this exception to create a commercial 
> compiler.
> 

IMHO, releasing some units that we know will need to be modified 
(like errorsys) into the public domain, and leaving the rest as it
is, would be the best plan. Anything else and you are risking reducing
the freedom of people who want to use Harbour.

E.G. Somebody releases a library that enables the use of a graphical
toolkit on Windows & Linux/*BSD. To do this, they modify a part of the
harbour internals. If a licence like the one you are suggesting is
in force, they could release this "new" part of harbour as binary only.
They could then require you to use their copy of harbour, as it is the
only one that their "new" internal unit will work with.



From harbour@lists.harbour-project.org  Sun Mar  4 11:32:02 2001
From: harbour@lists.harbour-project.org (Dave Pearson)
Date: Sun Mar  4 11:32:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Bug with oError:args as received by an error handler
Message-ID: <20010304163057.G21816@hagbard.davep.org>

I was just having a bit more of a play with Ron's PP.PRG to check that his
latest round of changes worked fine in a harbour built on a GNU/Linux box
and found that it kept crashing if I put in "nonsense" commands. It kept
dying in the error handler.

After a bit of digging it seems that the :args instance variable isn't
getting populated correctly when an error occurs in "harbour space". Take
this code for example:

-- cut here ----------------------------------------------------------------
Function Main()

   errorblock( {|o| MyErrHandler( o ) } )

   ? 2 + NIL
   
Return( NIL )

Function MyErrHandler( o )

   ? valtype( o:args )
   Quit

Return( NIL )
-- cut here ----------------------------------------------------------------

The screen output should be "A", and it is with CA-Clipper. With harbour
however the output is "N". It seems that :args is set to a numeric value (I
get 0 with the above test code) when it should be an array.

Hence the reason that PP.PRG kept dying on this line:

,----[ Line 765 ]
|       FOR Counter := 1 TO Len( oError:Args )
`----

-- 
The Harbour Project: A free software Clipper compatible compiler
Home Page..........: http://www.harbour-project.org/
FAQ................: http://www.harbour-project.org/faq/harbour.html
My harbour page....: http://www.davep.org/harbour/

X-Original-Date: Fri, 5 Jan 2001 12:16:45 +0000
Date: Fri, 5 Jan 2001 12:16:45 +0000

I don't know which C compiler/platform combinations this affects but it's a
problem with GCC on my Linux box and, I guess, GCC on any platform. It might
also be a problem with other compilers too as it's a C symbol name thing.

Take the following fully correct Clipper program:

,----[ foo-bar.prg ]
| ? "Hello, World!"
`----

Note the name, that's the important bit. This compiles, links and runs just
fine with CA-Clipper.

However, with harbour/gcc/Linux it chokes at the C compilation stage, the
reason should be fairly obvious:

,----
| davep@hagbard:~/temp$ gharbour foo-bar
| Harbour Compiler 0.35j (Build 35) (2000.11.30) (Flex)
| Copyright 1999-2000, http://www.harbour-project.org
| Compiling 'foo-bar.prg'...
| Lines 3, Functions/Procedures 1
| Generating C source output to 'foo-bar.c'... Done.
| foo-bar.c:11: parse error before `-'
| foo-bar.c:16: `HB_FUN_FOO' undeclared here (not in a function)
| foo-bar.c:16: `BAR' undeclared here (not in a function)
| foo-bar.c:16: initializer element for `symbols[0].pFunPtr' is not constant
| foo-bar.c:18: parse error before `-'
| foo-bar.c:32: parse error before `-'
| foo-bar.c:46: warning: parameter names (without types) in function declaration
| foo-bar.c:46: conflicting types for `hb_vmExecute'
| /usr/local/include/harbour/hbvmpub.h:85: previous declaration of `hb_vmExecute'
| foo-bar.c:46: warning: data definition has no type or storage class
| foo-bar.c:47: parse error before `}'
`----

the reason being:

,----
| davep@hagbard:~/temp$ grep FOO-BAR foo-bar.c
|        HB_FUNC( FOO-BAR );
| HB_INIT_SYMBOLS_BEGIN( hb_vm_SymbolInit_FOO-BAR )
| { "FOO-BAR", HB_FS_PUBLIC | HB_FS_FIRST, HB_FUNCNAME( FOO-BAR ), NULL },
| HB_INIT_SYMBOLS_END( hb_vm_SymbolInit_FOO-BAR )
|    static HB_$INITSYM hb_vm_auto_SymbolInit_FOO-BAR = hb_vm_SymbolInit_FOO-BAR;
|    #pragma startup hb_vm_SymbolInit_FOO-BAR
| HB_FUNC( FOO-BAR )
`----

You can't have a "-" in a symbol name in C.

--

http://www.davep.org/               |     eg - Norton Guide reader for Linux.
http://www.davep.org/clipper/       |    weg - Norton Guide reader for Windows.
http://www.davep.org/norton-guides/ | dgscan - DGROUP scanner for Clipper.

From harbour@lists.harbour-project.org  Sun Mar  4 12:22:01 2001
From: harbour@lists.harbour-project.org (John Skelton)
Date: Sun Mar  4 12:22:01 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Our current GPL license probably won't do what
 we want it to do.
Message-ID: <200103041221_MC2-C789-4A43@compuserve.com>

"documentation in Texinfo format ...

John.

From harbour@lists.harbour-project.org  Sun Mar  4 12:22:10 2001
From: harbour@lists.harbour-project.org (John Skelton)
Date: Sun Mar  4 12:22:10 2001
Subject: [Harbour] GPL + Exception -> Legal Interpretation
Message-ID: <200103041221_MC2-C789-4A44@compuserve.com>

Ron & Dave,

I think your apparent misunderstanding centres round whether the
Harbour Exception has modified the GPL.

As I see it, it's so obvious that we haven't changed the actual file
(COPYING or whatever) that Ron cannot mean that.  Instead, he / his
lawyer is referring to modification in a legal sense.

It doesn't seem unreasonable that the law in at least some countries
can speak of a modification as being either physical or conceptual
(or both).  A will quite commonly is modified by a codicil (one or
more extra pages, usually added later).  No physical modification
takes place (and indeed such a thing would risk invalidating the
will).

So, I can accept that the Harbour Exception (+GPL) is overall a
modified GPL.

Whether it then operates as the lawyer says is something I've tried
to figure out, too.  I'm extremely unconvinced, but I'm not a lawyer
let alone an American lawyer.

John.

From harbour@lists.harbour-project.org  Sun Mar  4 12:33:02 2001
From: harbour@lists.harbour-project.org (Dave Pearson)
Date: Sun Mar  4 12:33:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] GPL + Exception -> Legal Interpretation
In-Reply-To: <200103041221_MC2-C789-4A44@compuserve.com>; from John_Skelton@compuserve.com on Sun, Mar 04, 2001 at 12:21:08PM -0500
References: <200103041221_MC2-C789-4A44@compuserve.com>
Message-ID: <20010304173219.K21816@hagbard.davep.org>

On Sun, Mar 04, 2001 at 12:21:08PM -0500, John Skelton wrote:

> It doesn't seem unreasonable that the law in at least some countries can
> speak of a modification as being either physical or conceptual (or both).
> A will quite commonly is modified by a codicil (one or more extra pages,
> usually added later). No physical modification takes place (and indeed
> such a thing would risk invalidating the will).

The difference I'm seeing here, and am attempting to get a handle on, is
that the exception itself doesn't appear to modify the GPL, it simply says
when you don't need to apply it (the GPL that is). I'm not convinced that
the GPL is modified in anyway way, be it physically or otherwise.

There's also the small matter of the GPL being under copyright so I'm also
not sure how this talk of modification sits with the fact that we've not
asked the copyright holder of that document if we can "modify" it.

> Whether it then operates as the lawyer says is something I've tried to
> figure out, too. I'm extremely unconvinced, but I'm not a lawyer let alone
> an American lawyer.

You and me both. Perhaps someone with access to legal advice in the US and
who is willing to accept that I'm asking questions out of interest might
want to step forward and satisfy our curiosity?

-- 
The Harbour Project: A free software Clipper compatible compiler
Home Page..........: http://www.harbour-project.org/
FAQ................: http://www.harbour-project.org/faq/harbour.html
My harbour page....: http://www.davep.org/harbour/

From harbour@lists.harbour-project.org  Sun Mar  4 12:59:02 2001
From: harbour@lists.harbour-project.org (Ron Pinkas)
Date: Sun Mar  4 12:59:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] GPL + Exception -> Legal Interpretation
In-Reply-To: <20010304074049.R21816@hagbard.davep.org>
Message-ID: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKKECLDKAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>

Dave,

> > What has basis in your unqualified opinion does not necessarily
> qualify as
> > legal basis. Your difficulty is arising exactly from your willingness to
> > argue a legal point without the legal qualifications.
>
> I'm not arguing a legal point Ron, I'm simply making a statement of fact.
> We've not modified the GPL.

Dave, it is not a statement of fact, it is only your opinion. This argument
will never hold in court of law, because you don't need to literally modify
a legal document, in order to get a modified version of it.

Consider the following, ABC publishes a Version 1.0 of License X, Some time
later, ABC publishes Version 1.1 of License X. It reads as follows:

,-----------
|This is Version 1.1 of License X. All terms and condition of Version 1.0
apply, with the |addition of new section 10. as follows:
|
|10. This is Section 10, we have just modified License X, without ever
touching it. You are |no longer subject to sections 1, 3, and 5, if you own
product Y.
`-----------

Adding the Harbour Exception, created a New (modified) License, which can no
longer be refer d to as the GPL, because it isn't. It is a new License based
on the GPL + some additional text.

> What I don't understand is why, if you've got to the trouble of
> taking legal
> advice, you're not willing to share it to it's fully extent and
> explain why
> we have modified the GPL? So far you've simply stated that we
> have and have
> then claimed argument-by-qualification as your reasoning.

How do you recommend I share more than I did? I did forward clear
statements, indicating, that any addition or removal of text, attached or
applied to a legal document, is in effect modifying it. I did try to
explain, that you don't need to modify or even have access to the original,
in order to create a modified version of such. I did try to explain, that
you seem to insist on the literal meaning of the word modify, which is
indeed different in a legal context.

> In my native language (English) a question mark means that the preceding
> text is a question. Does it mean something different in your native
> language?

Dave, I was referring to the many definitive statements you made ending with
a period, not a question mark. For sake of brevity, I'll not re-quote them
yet again.

> > You keep insisting on not seeing what is clearly in front of you. I'm
> > afraid you'll have to ask others, as I did my best and failed.
>
> If you really did take legal advice I would have thought that your "best"
> would have exceeded "because I would told so". If you are not in
> a position
> to explain further then, obviously, you're more than welcome to
> say that you
> can't.

I did say exactly that.

Ron

Attorney and get some clarifications in return.

Ron


From harbour@lists.harbour-project.org  Sun Mar  4 13:16:02 2001
From: harbour@lists.harbour-project.org (Ron Pinkas)
Date: Sun Mar  4 13:16:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] GPL + Exception -> Legal Interpretation
In-Reply-To: <20010304173219.K21816@hagbard.davep.org>
Message-ID: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKKECMDKAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>

Dave

> The difference I'm seeing here, and am attempting to get a handle on, is
> that the exception itself doesn't appear to modify the GPL, it simply says
> when you don't need to apply it (the GPL that is). I'm not convinced that
> the GPL is modified in anyway way, be it physically or otherwise.

Assume, you are in a court of law, and you are asked under oath:

,----
|Is the Harbour Application subject to the GPL, Yes or No?
`----

I hope you understand, you can *not* answer "Yes", and be truthful, yet you
can't answer "Yes, but..." either. The *only* truthful answer in court of
law, will have to be "No".

That's because the Harbour Application is subject to a modified version of
the GPL, equaling the "sum" of the GPL plus the Harbour Exception.

> There's also the small matter of the GPL being under copyright so I'm also
> not sure how this talk of modification sits with the fact that we've not
> asked the copyright holder of that document if we can "modify" it.

Legal modification, does not equal literal modification.

> > Whether it then operates as the lawyer says is something I've tried to
> > figure out, too. I'm extremely unconvinced, but I'm not a
> lawyer let alone
> > an American lawyer.
>
> You and me both. Perhaps someone with access to legal advice in the US and
> who is willing to accept that I'm asking questions out of interest might
> want to step forward and satisfy our curiosity?

What is your question Dave? I do have access to legal advice in the US and
am willing to forward your question, and advise you of the reply.

Ron

From harbour@lists.harbour-project.org  Sun Mar  4 18:25:03 2001

Subject: [Harbour] GPL + Exception -> Legal Interpretation
In-Reply-To: <20010304202731.L21816@hagbard.davep.org>

Dave,

> > > I'm not arguing a legal point Ron, I'm simply making a statement of
> > > fact. We've not modified the GPL.
> >
> > Dave, it is not a statement of fact, it is only your opinion.
>
> No, what I state there is a fact. COPYING hasn't been modified in any way.
> I'm then working out from there.

Let's go back to my court of law scenario, why won't you answer?

,---------------------------------------------------------------------------
---
|Assume, you are in a court of law, and you are asked under oath:
|
|,----
||Is the Harbour Application subject to the GPL, Yes or No?
|`----
|
|I hope you understand, you can *not* answer "Yes", and be truthful, yet you
|can't answer "Yes, but..." either. The *only* truthful answer in court of
|law, will have to be "No".
|
|That's because the Harbour Application is subject to a modified version of
|the GPL, equaling the "sum" of the GPL plus the Harbour Exception.
`---------------------------------------------------------------------------
---

> > Adding the Harbour Exception, created a New (modified) License,
> which can
> > no longer be refer d to as the GPL, because it isn't. It is a
> new License
> > based on the GPL + some additional text.
>
> So you do agree that the GPL hasn't been modified and that the harbour
> licence isn't a modified GPL? All I'm saying, and seeking clarification
> about, is that we seem to have a set of rules for telling people when the
> unmolested GPL should be applied.

How do you arrive at this, Dave? Let's read again:

,----
| Adding the Harbour Exception, created a New (modified) License,
|                               ^^^^^^^   ^^^  ^^^^^^^^  ^^^^^^^
| which can no longer be referred to as the GPL, because it isn't.
|           ^^ ^^^^^^ ^^ ^^^^^^^^       ^^^ ^^^          ^^ ^^^^^
| It is a new License based on the GPL + some additional text.
|         ^^^ ^^^^^^^ ^^^^^        ^^^ ^
`----

Here is the clarification you seek:

A set of rules (or any other text) when *added* to any agreement,
effectively modifies such agreement. In the court of law this action is
considered a modification.

> I'm not sure why such questions or such a desire for
> clarification would be
> met with such hostile responses.

Can you please point me to where have I been hostile? I can easily point you
to numerous occasions in this exchange, where you accused me of "Ignorance",
"Bullying", used a teacher like, preaching tone "Ron Pinkas", etc.. I was
not hostile for the simple, reason, that your defensiveness have earned my
curiosity, and interest, but no other emotions, I'm aware of.

> I'm especially interested in why you'd go
> shouting "baseless" when even you now seem to be noticing that the GPL
> hasn't been changed.

This is just as baseless a claim, as your original claims. Are *you* willing
to ignore, baseless, claims, on such critical subject?

> You're clearly referring to my words about your legal advisor and those
> words clearly end with a question mark. Are you sure it was brevity that
> caused you to not quote this exchange?

Here are few of your baseless claims, and definitive statements, ending with
period rather than question mark:

This is how it got started Dave:

,---------------------------------------------------------------------------
---
|> The GPL has not been modified. The "harbour licence" isn't a modified
|> version of the GPL.
|                    ^
| You shouldn't make baseless statements like that. *Adding* or *removing*
| *any* *language* when applied to a legal document (such as the GPL), is
| indeed considered a modification. The Harbour Exception *does* create a
new
| modified version of the GPL. I would strongly recommend that you consult
| with a legal expert before making such statements.
`---------------------------------------------------------------------------
---

Later:

,---------------------------------------------------------------------------
---
|> It isn't a modified version of the GPL. The content of the file
|> COPYING has
|> in no way been modified. Furthermore, the "harbour license" uses the pure
|                         ^
|> GPL in most circumstances.
|                           ^
`---------------------------------------------------------------------------
---

More:

,---------------------------------------------------------------------------
---
|> The GPL has not been modified, the "harbour license" isn't a modified
|> version of the GPL, the file COPYING is unmolested.
|                                                    ^
`---------------------------------------------------------------------------
---

More:

,---------------------------------------------------------------------------
---
|> I'd have a hard time disagreeing with this. You'll note, however, that it
|> doesn't say that the GPL has been modified.
|                                            ^
`---------------------------------------------------------------------------
---

Etc., Etc., yes I'm sure it was brevity. I'm also confident that you lost
the ability withdraw, which is long overdue.

Ron

From harbour@lists.harbour-project.org  Mon Mar  5 01:11:02 2001
From: harbour@lists.harbour-project.org (Phil Barnett)
Date: Mon Mar  5 01:11:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Licensing discussions
In-Reply-To: <20010304132820.A612@janes.demon.co.uk>
References: <3AA18335.24120.190CB088@localhost>; from midnight@the-oasis.net on Sat, Mar 03, 2001 at 11:50:13PM -0500
Message-ID: <3AA2E7A0.25215.1E7CF2BD@localhost>

On 4 Mar 2001, at 13:28, Matthew Collins wrote:

> On Sat, Mar 03, 2001 at 11:50:13PM -0500, Phil Barnett wrote:
> > 
> > Ok, it's a year from now and I'm writing some code to compile with 
> > Harbour and I want to do something with a part of the RTL that 
> > hasn't been identified in the list of 'sanctioned code' that I can 
> > modify.
> > 
> > Now what?
> > 
> > Do I try to find the author and get his permission to modify his work 
> > without invoking the GPL?
> > 
> > Do I ignore it and break the law?
> > 
> > Do I rewrite the code that I wanted to borrow and modify because 
> > modification of the code I want to borrow is not sanctioned?
> > 
> > Do I try to get the developers to add my features the to base set?
> > 
> 
> Modify the code, and release your modified version of Harbour with the
> existing Licence. Then compile your code with the version of Harbour.
> That is what the GPL is for. To stop people doing exactly what you are 
> Talking about. We don't really want people modifing the core without
> making those changes available under the GPL.

If I can do this than I can modify Harbour until it is no longer 
recognizable, and it encourages many forks of the Harbour code 
base.
 
> > This is what I was referring to when I requested this conversation 
> > and asked to not create a list that delineates which modules can 
> > and which modules can't be modified and included, but instead a 
> > general rule that identifies them without letting all the cows out of 
> > the barn at the same time. (getting us ripped off because we 
> > loosened a huge loophole).
> > 
> > While it may seem convenient to identify a list of source code that 
> > we are sanctioned to modify and include, we have never before had 
> > the privilege of having the entire code base at our disposal. (re CA-
> > Clipper or any other commercial product) This makes it difficult to 
> > draw the line since we don't have much experience in what will be 
> > useful to modify and include at some point in the future.
> > 
> > For example, should we allow someone to modify the object 
> > system? How about the way arrays are populated?
> > 
> 
> We do allow people to modify the object system, as long as they 
> release their changes under the same licence that we use. They are
> getting all our work for free, why should they be able to change it
> and not let us see their changes.

What if their changes are not need or wanted back into the base 
code?
 
> > It's going to be really hard to identify just which code should be 
> > subject to inclusion and modification without invoking the GPL. If 
> > we create a list of limits, we could be stifling innovation.
> > 
> 
> Why not use Ca-Clipper as a guide. Release those units that CA released
> with Clipper, and put the in the Public domain.
> Anything else that people want to do with Harbour, is most likely 
> going to benefit everybody who uses Harbour, so they should be
> made available under the GPL.

Why not use CA-Clipper as a guide? Because they are a poor 
guidelight for an open source project.
 
> The GPL does not require you to release your code to everybody. It 
> requires you to release your code to whoever you make a binary version
> available to. If you are selling an application to somebody, you don't
> have to make your changes available to the world, just to the person
> you have given your binary to. The only thing you can't do is stop
> them passing on the source to whoever they choose. A developer working
> closly with a client and writing bespoke software is not going to be
> bothered about giving a small portion of their source code to the 
> client.
 
> > This is why I wanted to create a general rule instead of a list.
> > 
> > Something like:
> > 
> > Commonnly modified modules in the Harbour Project source code 
> > have not been licensed via the GPL license, but were instead 
> > placed in the public domain. Feel free to modify these and include 
> > them in in your source code while still maintaining the Harbour 
> > Exception clause to the GPL license.
> > 
> > You may also include and modify as many as three other RTL and 
> > VM source code modules without invoking the GPL license.
> >
> 
> I can see big problems with this.

Like?
  
> > I'm not even suggesting that this is a solution, but just to illustrate 
> > the idea of creating a general rule instead of a list. The exception to 
> > this is that you cannot use this exception to create a commercial 
> > compiler.
> > 
> 
> IMHO, releasing some units that we know will need to be modified 
> (like errorsys) into the public domain, and leaving the rest as it
> is, would be the best plan. Anything else and you are risking reducing
> the freedom of people who want to use Harbour.

How is allowing more freedom a reduction of freedom?
 
> E.G. Somebody releases a library that enables the use of a graphical
> toolkit on Windows & Linux/*BSD. To do this, they modify a part of the
> harbour internals. If a licence like the one you are suggesting is
> in force, they could release this "new" part of harbour as binary only.
> They could then require you to use their copy of harbour, as it is the
> only one that their "new" internal unit will work with.

Yes, that is true, but at the same time, they will have created a 
fork of the code, which is their right. Now, they have a maintenance 
nightmare. The original code base continues to forge ahead and 
theirs get's left behind. Eventually developers will choose the most 
advanced one.

And, if you're not a developer, what's the difference?


-- 
              Phil Barnett  mailto:midnight@the-oasis.net
                       WWW  http://www.the-oasis.net/
                  FTP Site  ftp://ftp.the-oasis.net

suggesting the same thing that I and others have suggested: the list of
sources that were supplied by Nantucket/CA for the CA-Clipper system
libraries are a good guide as to which parts of the HRTL might do well to be
in the public domain (or at least under a more permissive licence).

Assuming the question you say I "won't" answer is the boxed question: my
answer would be "which application are you talking about and where did all
the sources come from that were used to build it". I'd also seek
clarification as to what they meant when they said "harbour application"
(I'd also want to know where in the world this court was and why I was there
and being asked such a question).

I would, however, answer Yes *and* No if we're talking about an application
built using harbour and incorporating the HVM and HRTL. From what you've
said previously about your own opinion and the legal advice you've received
it seems that you'd give exactly the same answer.

Think about the decompilation issue.

> > > Adding the Harbour Exception, created a New (modified) License, which
> > > can no longer be refer d to as the GPL, because it isn't. It is a new
> > > License based on the GPL + some additional text.
> >
> > So you do agree that the GPL hasn't been modified and that the harbour
> > licence isn't a modified GPL? All I'm saying, and seeking clarification
> > about, is that we seem to have a set of rules for telling people when
> > the unmolested GPL should be applied.
> 
> How do you arrive at this, Dave? 

Because you say it's based on the GPL. I wouldn't disagree with that.

> A set of rules (or any other text) when *added* to any agreement,
> effectively modifies such agreement. In the court of law this action is
> considered a modification.

I don't doubt or disagree that the agreement you see at the top of our HVM
files is different from those you see at the top the compiler files (for
example).

fiction of your imagination". Banging on about how what I'd written was

On Mon, Mar 05, 2001 at 03:42:39AM -0500, Phil Barnett wrote:
> On 5 Mar 2001, at 8:12, Dave Pearson wrote:
> 
> > I think you're taking Matthew's suggesting out of context here. He's not
> > suggesting that we take open source hints and guidance from CA, he's
> > suggesting the same thing that I and others have suggested: the list of
> > sources that were supplied by Nantucket/CA for the CA-Clipper system
> > libraries are a good guide as to which parts of the HRTL might do well
> > to be in the public domain (or at least under a more permissive
> > licence).

> reverse engineer the parts they wouldn't give us access to so we could do
> more, get more, stretch edges, etc.

Can you think of a good list of "extras", bits that people needed access to
so they could improve their applications (I don't think hack-libraries like
Clip4Win and FiveW*n count here)?

Personally I can see *large* parts of the RTL would fall into this category.
This suggests that, ideally, the RTL would be much more useful if it had a
far more permissive licence.

> In this light, I think they are a poor example of what to let people
> modify and what not to.
> 
> But, they do present a beginning.

True, harbour already provides more source that can be freely changed (all
of it's source) and some parts, which CA never gave you access to, can be
included, in modified form, in non-free applications without any licence
implications. ACHOICE.PRG, ALERT.PRG and MENUTO.PRG are good examples. Some
really generous individuals were kind enough to donate them to the public
domain, which makes life easier for everyone.

From harbour@lists.harbour-project.org  Mon Mar  5 06:21:02 2001
From: harbour@lists.harbour-project.org (John Skelton)
Date: Mon Mar  5 06:21:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] GPL + Exception -> Legal Interpretation
Message-ID: <200103050620_MC2-C79D-EB4@compuserve.com>

Dave,

"COPYING hasn't been modified in any way. I'm then working out from
there."

I have to say I don't see why, but that's not the point.  COPYING
_has_ been modified from a legal POV, which does not require it to be
a physical mod.

"So you do agree that the GPL hasn't been modified and that the harbour
licence isn't a modified GPL?"

Neither.  It has been modified and it is a modified GPL.  At least, as
a non-lawyer it looks true to me and Ron's lawyer says so.

"All I'm saying, and seeking clarification about, is that we seem to
have a set of rules for telling people when the unmolested GPL should
be applied."

Fine - sounds useful.

John.

From harbour@lists.harbour-project.org  Mon Mar  5 06:21:16 2001

Ron,

"Assume, you are in a court of law, and you are asked under oath:
|Is the Harbour Application subject to the GPL, Yes or No?
I hope you understand, you can *not* answer "Yes", and be truthful, yet y=
ou
can't answer "Yes, but..." either"

IIRC, you can.  I think you've watched too many movies. :-(

You can also turn to the judge and ask to explain why both yes & no
would likely give a false impression.

Er... we really don't want to get into minutiae of each country's
legal systems do we!

John.

From harbour@lists.harbour-project.org  Mon Mar  5 06:21:28 2001
From: harbour@lists.harbour-project.org (John Skelton)
Date: Mon Mar  5 06:21:28 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Licensing discussions
Message-ID: <200103050620_MC2-C79D-EB0@compuserve.com>

Phil,

"What if their changes are not need or wanted back into the base
code?"

No problem.  AFAIK all that matters is that the changes are made
available.

I'm not sure how long they have to be available - it sort of sounds
(reads <g>) like forever, which is obviously daft, especially if the
project didn't take them!  Still, "forever" probably isn't a problem
in practice...

John.

From harbour@lists.harbour-project.org  Mon Mar  5 06:22:02 2001
From: harbour@lists.harbour-project.org (John Skelton)
Date: Mon Mar  5 06:22:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] GPL + Exception -> Legal Interpretation
Message-ID: <200103050620_MC2-C79D-EAD@compuserve.com>

Dave,

"The difference I'm seeing here, and am attempting to get a handle on, is=

that the exception itself doesn't appear to modify the GPL, it simply say=
s
when you don't need to apply it (the GPL that is)."

I expect from a legal POV that's a modification.  It refers to it,
and when it does & doesn't apply.  Probably qualifies (as a mod. from
a legal POV) on all counts.

"I'm not convinced that the GPL is modified in anyway way, be it
physically or otherwise."

I wouldn't say I'm 100% convinced, but enough (98%?) to work on the
basis that it is.

"There's also the small matter of the GPL being under copyright"

Not small.  Well... maybe it is in the sense that it would be a major
oddity for FSF/RMS to be about freedom but not allow the Harbour way,
especially in view of emails with RMS.

A lawyer would probably strongly recommend getting _written_
permission, _signed_ by an authorised (legally, that is)
representative of the copyright owner (FSF).

I'd be happy with what we have, I suppose because it feels (ethically,
morally, whatever) OK and RMS & FSF are "into" that, plus RMS has been
made aware of the Exception, and in addition it's been OK'ed for GUILE.

If we deal more with lawyers and end up convinced that it's not quite
the right Exception, I think we should at least run any revised one
past RMS/FSF. :-)

"I'm also not sure how this talk of modification sits with the fact
that we've not asked the copyright holder of that document if we can
"modify" it."

It's "probably" OK to not physically modify it (i.e. refer to it as is
done).  However, "probably" is not the kind of situation a lawyer
would be likely to recommend one stays in having raised it!

Also see my comments above.

> Whether it then operates as the lawyer says is something I've tried to
> figure out, too. I'm extremely unconvinced, but I'm not a lawyer let al=
one
> an American lawyer.

"You and me both. Perhaps someone with access to legal advice in the US a=
nd
who is willing to accept that I'm asking questions out of interest might
want to step forward and satisfy our curiosity?"

Ron's trying. :-)

And yes, that does have two meanings. :-) :-)

However, I think Ron actually _is_ willing to find out.  We can all
help keep the costs down if we can figure out careful questions to
ask, with explanations (motivation for asking, background info, etc)
I would think.  E.g. I'm less than convinced that the lawyer's views
so far are correct but I'm struggling to come up with the right way
to dig to find why / why not. :-(

Could I (gulp! is this too big a risk?) possibly ask both you and Ron
to drop (better: forget <g>) large parts of this thread?  Y'know: the
ones not entirely on-topic.  Or whatever euphemism I mean.  Both of
you could instead help to figure out the exact questions we should be
asking. :-)

John.

From harbour@lists.harbour-project.org  Mon Mar  5 06:40:04 2001
From: harbour@lists.harbour-project.org (Dave Pearson)
Date: Mon Mar  5 06:40:04 2001
Subject: [Harbour] GPL + Exception -> Legal Interpretation
In-Reply-To: <200103050620_MC2-C79D-EAD@compuserve.com>; from John_Skelton@compuserve.com on Mon, Mar 05, 2001 at 06:19:38AM -0500
References: <200103050620_MC2-C79D-EAD@compuserve.com>
Message-ID: <20010305113856.Z21816@hagbard.davep.org>

On Mon, Mar 05, 2001 at 06:19:38AM -0500, John Skelton wrote:

> "The difference I'm seeing here, and am attempting to get a handle on, is
> that the exception itself doesn't appear to modify the GPL, it simply says
> when you don't need to apply it (the GPL that is)."
> 
> I expect from a legal POV that's a modification. It refers to it, and when
> it does & doesn't apply. Probably qualifies (as a mod. from a legal POV)
> on all counts.

Sure, I can see how it could be seen that way from a legal point of view in
one or more countries. I don't think I've said that it couldn't be seen that
way. All I've been trying to find out and document is my confusion about
this point of view and, also, that we've not actually modified the GPL
itself. My concern about the last bit being the issue that the GPL itself is
a document that is under copyright.

> Could I (gulp! is this too big a risk?) possibly ask both you and Ron to
> drop (better: forget <g>) large parts of this thread? Y'know: the ones not
> entirely on-topic. Or whatever euphemism I mean. Both of you could instead
> help to figure out the exact questions we should be asking. :-)

The moment the attacks stop my defence will stop. Anyone is more than
welcome to attack me via private email.

--

Subject: [Harbour] Licensing discussions
In-Reply-To: <200103050620_MC2-C79D-EB0@compuserve.com>; from John_Skelton@compuserve.com on Mon, Mar 05, 2001 at 06:19:41AM -0500

On Mon, Mar 05, 2001 at 06:19:41AM -0500, John Skelton wrote:
> Phil,
> 
> "What if their changes are not need or wanted back into the base
> code?"
> 
> No problem. AFAIK all that matters is that the changes are made available.

Simply making the changes available doesn't absolve someone from the GPL.
It's the GPL that means they have to make the changes available *if* they
distribute the binary.

From harbour@lists.harbour-project.org  Mon Mar  5 10:28:01 2001
From: harbour@lists.harbour-project.org (Ron Pinkas)
Date: Mon Mar  5 10:28:01 2001
Subject: [Harbour] GPL + Exception -> Legal Interpretation
In-Reply-To: <20010305114014.A21816@hagbard.davep.org>
Message-ID: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKIEDCDKAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>

Dave,

> So Ron's lawyer is, in effect, saying that there are two distinct versions
> of the GPL at play when the exception is in place?

No, my understanding is that there is one license HGPL which is a version of
the GPL excluding all restrictions.

Please note, at this point it appears this is only true for only non
modified HVM & HRL.

I'm told Decompilation, is not an issue, because the source for these
components is freely available. But, such decompiled source is covered by
the GPL but rather than the HGPL, because the exception is only alive for
executables.

Ron

won't you answer.

> decompilation,

From harbour@lists.harbour-project.org  Mon Mar  5 10:55:03 2001
From: harbour@lists.harbour-project.org (Dave Pearson)
Date: Mon Mar  5 10:55:03 2001
Subject: [Harbour] GPL + Exception -> Legal Interpretation
In-Reply-To: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKIEDCDKAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>; from Ron@Profit-Master.com on Mon, Mar 05, 2001 at 07:25:35AM -0800
References: <20010305114014.A21816@hagbard.davep.org> <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKIEDCDKAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>
Message-ID: <20010305155148.K21816@hagbard.davep.org>

On Mon, Mar 05, 2001 at 07:25:35AM -0800, Ron Pinkas wrote:
> Dave,
> 
> > So Ron's lawyer is, in effect, saying that there are two distinct
> > versions of the GPL at play when the exception is in place?
> 
> No, my understanding is that there is one license HGPL which is a version
> of the GPL excluding all restrictions.
> 
> Please note, at this point it appears this is only true for only non
> modified HVM & HRL.

This is still where I'm confused by this modified-GPL business, it seems to
me that creating a derived work of an item of source[1] in the HRTL "wipes"
the exception from the file. Or, at least, it can be interpreted that way,
the idea being that it's the copyright holder who gets to offer the
exception, the author of a derived work can't do that on behalf of the
copyright holder.

So, and this is my confusion, if, legally, in some country or other, the
exception is seen as a modification to the GPL itself, does that mean that
creating a derived work creates yet another licence that happens to be
exactly like the GPL or does it mean that the GPL was always there but the
exception no longer applies?

IOW, from where I'm sat, it strikes me that the harbour "licence" isn't so
much a modified version of the GPL, it's more of an IF.THEN.ELSE statement.

No matter how this is viewed, either in US law or from a layman's point of
view, the important thing I wanted to stress and have been trying to stress
is that we're not changing the wording of the GPL itself and that the GPL is
always there and is the primary licence. The exception is an agreement
between the user who wants to write non-free software and the copyright
holder of any given file in the HVM/HRTL.

> I'm told Decompilation, is not an issue, because the source for these
> components is freely available. But, such decompiled source is covered by
> the GPL but rather than the HGPL, because the exception is only alive for
> executables.

I think there might be a word missing from that last sentence (or perhaps
there's a word or two too many), it seems to be saying that the source is
covered by both the GPL *and* the HGPL[2] but it also says that the
exception only applies to executables (agreed) which suggests that the
"HGPL" doesn't count for the decompiled source.

Regarding "decompiled code doesn't count", the decompiled code wouldn't
generally look anything like the original code, it'd be, in effect, a
translation of the original. Is it correct to say that it doesn't count when
it would appear that it's a derived work? Is it a derived work? Does a
translation have a different status from a derived work?

In the grand scheme of things I guess none of this really matters too much,
but it's nice to try and get a handle on it. I'm still wondering if it'll
really help or if it'll be far too much work and effort to try and tighten
up the exception to defeat MegaEvilNastyCorpIncLtdPLCGmbH when what's
probably more important is that we do everything possible to make life
easier for those who want to modify key parts of the RTL but still
distribute their own code as non-free software.

-----
[1]  Which is under the GPL plus harbour exception, I'm obviously not
thinking of the public domain files here.

[2]  I'm not sure that it's a good idea to start referring to something
called the HGPL, that seems like a possible route to even more confusion.
I've never seen anything calling itself the GGPL when used in connection
with guile for example (although the FSF's licences page doesn't help
matters because it suggests that the GPL plus the guile exception is another
kind of licence but doesn't actually say so, if you follow my meaning).

-- 
The Harbour Project: A free software Clipper compatible compiler
Home Page..........: http://www.harbour-project.org/
FAQ................: http://www.harbour-project.org/faq/harbour.html
My harbour page....: http://www.davep.org/harbour/

On Mon, Mar 05, 2001 at 04:01:31PM +0000, Dave Pearson wrote:

>                                                       Also, where does it
> get it's numeric value from? I'd have thought that if it was a failure to
> populate :args then that instance variable would have been NIL, not a
> numeric value.

Doh! It's obvious when you look in the obvious place (the terror known as
terror). Might someone currently configured with full CVS access be kind
enough to apply the attached patch?

-- 
The Harbour Project: A free software Clipper compatible compiler
Home Page..........: http://www.harbour-project.org/
FAQ................: http://www.harbour-project.org/faq/harbour.html
My harbour page....: http://www.davep.org/harbour/
--X1xGqyAVbSpAWs5A
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Disposition: attachment; filename="terror.diff"

--- /usr/local/src/harbour/source/rtl/terror.prg	Tue Oct  5 23:52:00 1999
+++ terror.prg	Mon Mar  5 16:45:31 2001
@@ -43,7 +43,7 @@
    IF s_oClass == NIL
       s_oClass := TClass():New( "ERROR" )
 
-      s_oClass:AddData( "Args"         , 0 )
+      s_oClass:AddData( "Args"         , NIL )
       s_oClass:AddData( "CanDefault"   , .F. )
       s_oClass:AddData( "CanRetry"     , .F. )
       s_oClass:AddData( "CanSubstitute", .F. )

--X1xGqyAVbSpAWs5A--

From harbour@lists.harbour-project.org  Mon Mar  5 11:51:02 2001

Subject: [Harbour] Licensing discussions
In-Reply-To: <3AA18335.24120.190CB088@localhost>
References: <3AA03BAC.26182.140D4375@localhost> ; from midnight@the-oasis.net on Sat, Mar 03, 2001 at 12:32:44AM -0500<20010303093846.A412@janes.demon.co.uk>

** Reply to message from "Phil Barnett" <midnight@the-oasis.net> on
Sat, 3 Mar 2001 23:50:13 -0500

> You may also include and modify as many as three other RTL and 
> VM source code modules without invoking the GPL license.

No, what we are looking for is more like "You may also include and
modify as many as three other HRL and HVM source code modules while
retaining the protection of the Harbour Exception to the GPL for your
resulting executable." We *never* want to imply that the GPL does not
apply.
-- 
David G. Holm, Set Captain and all around
Harbour Project Clipper Compatibility fanatic.

From: harbour@lists.harbour-project.org (David G. Holm)
Date: Mon Mar  5 12:05:03 2001
Subject: [Harbour] GPL + Exception -> Legal Interpretation
In-Reply-To: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKKECMDKAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>
References: <20010304173219.K21816@hagbard.davep.org>

** Reply to message from "Ron Pinkas" <Ron@Profit-Master.com> on Sun, 4
Mar 2001 10:13:14 -0800

> Assume, you are in a court of law, and you are asked under oath:
> 
> ,----
> |Is the Harbour Application subject to the GPL, Yes or No?
> `----
> 
> I hope you understand, you can *not* answer "Yes", and be truthful, yet you
> can't answer "Yes, but..." either. The *only* truthful answer in court of
> law, will have to be "No".

Actually, the only truthful answer is, "Yes." Because even if the
application qualifies for the Harbour Exception, the exception only
exempts the application from a small section of the GPL.

I cannot fathom why you or your lawyer claim that the Harbour Exception
exempts the appliction from the entire GPL, because that is simply not
the case.
-- 
David G. Holm, Set Captain and all around
Harbour Project Clipper Compatibility fanatic.

From harbour@lists.harbour-project.org  Mon Mar  5 12:30:02 2001
From: harbour@lists.harbour-project.org (David G. Holm)
Date: Mon Mar  5 12:30:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] GPL + Exception -> Legal Interpretation
In-Reply-To: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKIEDCDKAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>
References: <20010305114014.A21816@hagbard.davep.org>
Message-ID: <200103051729.f25HT3515785@thor.parrett.net>

** Reply to message from "Ron Pinkas" <Ron@Profit-Master.com> on Mon, 5
Mar 2001 07:25:35 -0800

> No, my understanding is that there is one license HGPL which is a version of
> the GPL excluding all restrictions.

Actually, the Harbour compiler and all libraries are always covered by
the GPL. The Harbour Exception does not change how the GPL applies to
the source or binary code for any part of Harbour.

> The exception is that if you link the Harbour Runtime Library (HRL)
> and/or the Harbour Virtual Machine (HVM) with other files to produce
> an executable, this does not by itself cause the resulting executable
> to be covered by the GNU General Public License. Your use of that
> executable is in no way restricted on account of linking the HRL
> and/or HVM code into it.

The Harbour Exception only applies to an application that has been
created from Harbour, so that the mere act of linking in the HRL and/or
HVM won't force you to GPL that application (but other things could
still force you to GPL your application).
-- 
David G. Holm, Set Captain and all around
Harbour Project Clipper Compatibility fanatic.

(As I expected) No, because "Yes and No" equals "No".

> Think about the decompilation issue.

All of the files which include the Exception are covered by what I my
attorney referred to as HGPL, which is the GPL + Exception, regardless of
the form. But, this HGPL has language that allows executable form to be
released of restrictions that otherwise apply. The decompiled code is not
dismissed of those restrictions.

From harbour@lists.harbour-project.org  Mon Mar  5 13:36:02 2001
From: harbour@lists.harbour-project.org (Ron Pinkas)
Date: Mon Mar  5 13:36:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] GPL + Exception -> Legal Interpretation
In-Reply-To: <200103051704.f25H4A513331@thor.parrett.net>
Message-ID: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKMEDGDKAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>

David,

> > Assume, you are in a court of law, and you are asked under oath:
> >
> > ,----
> > |Is the Harbour Application subject to the GPL, Yes or No?
> > `----
>
> Actually, the only truthful answer is, "Yes." Because even if the
> application qualifies for the Harbour Exception, the exception only
> exempts the application from a small section of the GPL.

I re-verified, and the GPL + Harbour Exception, legally constitutes a new
license, which can't be referred to as the GPL, because it is not!

> I cannot fathom why you or your lawyer claim that the Harbour Exception
> exempts the appliction from the entire GPL, because that is simply not
> the case.

This is not what he said. He said:

> 2. That very brief of an instant described in paragraph 1. above,
> the GPL is
> being modified by the copyrights holder (Licensor), so as to create a new
> license (HGPL). You *must* read this License (HGPL), as if a
> magic wand (the
> Harbour Exception), has erased *any* and *all* language, that reads as a
> restriction, while leaving intact everything else.

The exception only wave the restrictions, but nothing else. Legally, this is
a new license.

Ron


From harbour@lists.harbour-project.org  Mon Mar  5 14:05:03 2001
From: harbour@lists.harbour-project.org (David G. Holm)
Date: Mon Mar  5 14:05:03 2001
Subject: [Harbour] GPL + Exception -> Legal Interpretation
In-Reply-To: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKMEDGDKAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>
References: <200103051704.f25H4A513331@thor.parrett.net>
Message-ID: <200103051904.f25J4r523556@thor.parrett.net>

** Reply to message from "Ron Pinkas" <Ron@Profit-Master.com> on Mon, 5
Mar 2001 10:33:31 -0800

> > I cannot fathom why you or your lawyer claim that the Harbour Exception
> > exempts the appliction from the entire GPL, because that is simply not
> > the case.
> 
> This is not what he said. He said:

And what exactly do you have left after you remove all of the
restrictions from the GPL?

> > 2. That very brief of an instant described in paragraph 1. above,
> > the GPL is
> > being modified by the copyrights holder (Licensor), so as to create a new
> > license (HGPL). You *must* read this License (HGPL), as if a
> > magic wand (the
> > Harbour Exception), has erased *any* and *all* language, that reads as a
> > restriction, while leaving intact everything else.
> 
> The exception only wave the restrictions, but nothing else. Legally, this is
> a new license.

Which is nonsense, because the Harbour Exception very clearly removes
*one* restriction and *only* one restriction and only under *limited*
circumstances.
-- 
David G. Holm, Set Captain and all around
Harbour Project Clipper Compatibility fanatic.

I was using the one command line cvs but last year when I installed Win2K it
didnt work anymore.
When I searched Sourforge for a cvs for Win32, I found Wincvs and decided to
try it.
It works for me, the setup is easy.
I must also say that the plain cvs command line is not difficult to use.
The main advantage of wincvs is the "visual click&commit" :-)
It's a matter of if she feels more confortable with command line or GUI
tools.

From harbour@lists.harbour-project.org  Mon Mar  5 14:51:01 2001
From: harbour@lists.harbour-project.org (Ron Pinkas)
Date: Mon Mar  5 14:51:01 2001
Subject: [Harbour] GPL + Exception -> Legal Interpretation
In-Reply-To: <200103051904.f25J4r523556@thor.parrett.net>
Message-ID: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKOEDIDKAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>

David,

> > This is not what he said. He said:
>
> And what exactly do you have left after you remove all of the
> restrictions from the GPL?

The rights.

> > The exception only wave the restrictions, but nothing else.
> Legally, this is
> > a new license.
>
> Which is nonsense, because the Harbour Exception very clearly removes
> *one* restriction and *only* one restriction and only under *limited*
> circumstances.

Which *one*?

Please re-read the Exception:

,------------------------
| is in no way restricted
`------------------------

In legal language == "No Restrictions"!

I can assure you after verifying, and re-verifying, the a US legal expert in
the laws of intellectual properties, insists the above is the only valid
legal outlook.

Ron


From harbour@lists.harbour-project.org  Mon Mar  5 15:52:01 2001
From: harbour@lists.harbour-project.org (David G. Holm)
Date: Mon Mar  5 15:52:01 2001
Subject: [Harbour] GPL + Exception -> Legal Interpretation
In-Reply-To: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKOEDIDKAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>
References: <200103051904.f25J4r523556@thor.parrett.net>
Message-ID: <200103052051.f25KpV503992@thor.parrett.net>

** Reply to message from "Ron Pinkas" <Ron@Profit-Master.com> on Mon, 5
Mar 2001 11:48:03 -0800

> > ...the Harbour Exception very clearly removes
> > *one* restriction and *only* one restriction and only under *limited*
> > circumstances.
> 
> Which *one*?

The part that requires that any binary distrubution that uses software
that is covered by the GPL must also be covered by the GPL.

> Please re-read the Exception:

I think I ought to know what the Harbour Exception says. After all, I'm
the one who adapated it from the Guile Exception and typed it into the
doc/hdr_tpl.txt file from which it was later extracted into the
doc/license.txt file by Victor. And I re-read it every time that I paste
it in as a quote. Have you been re-reading it, or just glossing over it?

> ,------------------------
> | is in no way restricted
> `------------------------
> 
> In legal language == "No Restrictions"!
> 
> I can assure you after verifying, and re-verifying, the a US legal expert in
> the laws of intellectual properties, insists the above is the only valid
> legal outlook.

The only way to reach that conclusion is to take the sentence fragment
"is in no way restricted" out of context. Anybody can make a document
seem to say whatever they want it to say by taking fragments of the
document out of context, but that's not how contracts and licences are
interpreted, as your lawyer should well know. Read the whole thing again:

> The exception is that if you link the Harbour Runtime Library (HRL)
> and/or the Harbour Virtual Machine (HVM) with other files to produce
> an executable, this does not by itself cause the resulting executable
> to be covered by the GNU General Public License. Your use of that
> executable is in no way restricted on account of linking the HRL
> and/or HVM code into it.

In other words, it means that just linking in the HRL and/or HVM does
not restrict your use of the executable, but your use of the executable
might still be restricted if your use of it runs afoul of other parts of
the GPL.

But you and your lawyer appear to be reading it as meaning that because
you linked in the HRL and/or HVM, your use of the resulting executable
is exempt from the GPL in its entirety, even though the Harbour
Exception neither states nor implies that.

I challenge you to forward this email, in it's entirety and unedited,
to your lawyer and then post his response, in it's entirety and
unedited, to the list.
-- 
David G. Holm, Set Captain and all around
Harbour Project Clipper Compatibility fanatic.

From harbour@lists.harbour-project.org  Mon Mar  5 17:12:02 2001
From: harbour@lists.harbour-project.org (Luiz Rafael Culik Guimaraes)
Date: Mon Mar  5 17:12:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Harbour and (Microsoft .NET x Java)
Message-ID: <000b01c0a5c1$61a75000$53d4d7c8@culik>

Dear Friends

Some time ago their was as thread asking if Harbour would support the New
microsoft .NET. After reading many magazines about Microsoft .NET and Java,
And also doing research on the internet I`ve come to the Follow.

1 ) Microsoft .NET is noting more then an Tool to try to recover the place
that Java from Sun Microsystem Got.

2 ) Apps created by Microsoft .NET will , in my understand, Do the same
thing that Java do today , as accesssing Databases, commercial apps,

3 ) Java is more solid, Have many years of life. I have seen incredible
websites(Home banking) using Java apps to get  what an client has in his
bank account, to recieve payments of docs, and other things, along that
today has many Java programmer as C programmers.

4 ) If we should choice between one of this too, I`ve choose to say with
java. We already has the java output support ready.

Regards

Luiz Rafael Culik
