Dave,

"MUA's lack of an In-Reply-To header"

It doesn't add one?  Sh*t.  Sorry.  I plan to change it, but that
revolves around BT's promise (now broken!) of ADSL access.

"I thought the concern that Phil was raising is that someone who wants to=

modify parts of the HRTL can't use their modified version in their own
non-free application if they can't get their code accepted by the copyrig=
ht
holder of the file concerned."

I thought that was the issue; I think it's incorrect: i.e. they _can_
use their own changes whether or not they're accepted.  But I think
they _must_ make them available.  (I'm not sure how long for, but at
least as long as they use 'em I'd say.)

"So, I was pointing out (agreeing with you?) that making their changes
available won't allow them to use that code in a non-free application."

Disagreeing, then. :-)  I reckon they can use their own changes (see
above).

I hope.

John.

From harbour@lists.harbour-project.org  Mon Mar  5 18:38:02 2001
From: harbour@lists.harbour-project.org (=?iso-8859-1?Q?Gustavo_A._Gonz=E1lez_M.?=)
Date: Mon Mar  5 18:38:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Bug in the pre-processor
Message-ID: <003201c0a5cd$47196820$6df4c4a1@gustavo>

This is a multi-part message in MIME format.

------=_NextPart_000_002B_01C0A5AB.A01CB340
Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset="iso-8859-1"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 8bit

Hi.

I found a bug in the pre-processor, when any of "[ ]" is missing in a
optional clauses.

In clipper i have the next error: "Error C2066  Unclosed optional clause in
#translate/#command"

In my computer, when try with harbour, is generated a GPF on windows and
can't continue.

*********

Try it:

#xcommand COMANDO ;
                      [ ACCION [ OPCION_A <x1> ] ;
                                         [ OPCION_B <z1> ] ;  // missing ]
                  => ;
                     FunX( <x1>, <z1> )

FUNCTION TEST()

COMANDO ACCION ;
                      OPCION_A 10 ;
                      OPCION_B 20

RETURN

*********

Regards.

--
Gustavo A. Gonzlez M.
gonzalezgustavo@cantv.net
Caracas - Venezuela




------=_NextPart_000_002B_01C0A5AB.A01CB340
Content-Type: application/octet-stream;
	name="X.prg"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Content-Disposition: attachment;
	filename="X.prg"


#xcommand COMANDO ;
                [ ACCION [ OPCION_A <x1> ] ;
                         [ OPCION_B <z1> ] ];
                 => ;
                 FunX( <x1> [, <z1> ] )

FUNCTION TEST()

COMANDO ACCION OPCION_A 10 ;
               OPCION_B 20

RETURN


------=_NextPart_000_002B_01C0A5AB.A01CB340--


From harbour@lists.harbour-project.org  Mon Mar  5 19:07:01 2001
From: harbour@lists.harbour-project.org (John Skelton)
Date: Mon Mar  5 19:07:01 2001
Subject: [Harbour] GPL + Exception -> Legal Interpretation
Message-ID: <200103051905_MC2-C7C4-530F@compuserve.com>

Ron,

> ,------------------------
> | is in no way restricted
> `------------------------
> =

> In legal language =3D=3D "No Restrictions"!

Er... has your lawyer misread the following (from license.txt):

"Your use of that
 executable is in no way restricted on account of linking the HRL
 and/or HVM code into it."

It is vital to note that there is no comma (,) before "on account".
He appears to be reading it as if that missing comma were present.

It's not, but if it were the "on account" would then mean "because"
- which does seem to be the way he's reading it.

He _does_ have a competent knowledge of English, doesn't he?

An alternative: should the above wording be changed to something
which cannot be misread like that?  Perhaps:

"Your use of that
 executable has no extra restrictions placed on it by the linking of
 HRL and/or HVM code into it."

Or:

"Restrictions, if any, applying to that
 executable are unaffected by the linking of HRL
 and/or HVM code into it."

Next, if it's not the above issue, more info please.

John.

From harbour@lists.harbour-project.org  Mon Mar  5 21:46:01 2001
From: harbour@lists.harbour-project.org (Ron Pinkas)
Date: Mon Mar  5 21:46:01 2001
Subject: [Harbour] GPL + Exception -> Legal Interpretation
In-Reply-To: <200103052051.f25KpV503992@thor.parrett.net>
Message-ID: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKAEDLDKAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>

David,

> > > ...the Harbour Exception very clearly removes
> > > *one* restriction and *only* one restriction and only under *limited*
> > > circumstances.
> >
> > Which *one*?
>
> The part that requires that any binary distrubution that uses software
> that is covered by the GPL must also be covered by the GPL.

Ok, so which restrictions does it *not* remove, and where does it say so?

> > Please re-read the Exception:
>
> I think I ought to know what the Harbour Exception says. After all, I'm
> the one who adapated it from the Guile Exception and typed it into the
> doc/hdr_tpl.txt file from which it was later extracted into the
> doc/license.txt file by Victor. And I re-read it every time that I paste
> it in as a quote. Have you been re-reading it, or just glossing over it?

I'm confident you are familiar with its content, I read it dozens of times
too, and didn't see the problem, until when it clicked.


> > ,------------------------
> > | is in no way restricted
> > `------------------------
> >
> > In legal language == "No Restrictions"!
> >
> > I can assure you after verifying, and re-verifying, the a US
> legal expert in
> > the laws of intellectual properties, insists the above is the only valid
> > legal outlook.
>
> The only way to reach that conclusion is to take the sentence fragment
> "is in no way restricted" out of context. Anybody can make a document
> seem to say whatever they want it to say by taking fragments of the
> document out of context, but that's not how contracts and licences are
> interpreted, as your lawyer should well know. Read the whole thing again:
>
> > The exception is that if you link the Harbour Runtime Library (HRL)
> > and/or the Harbour Virtual Machine (HVM) with other files to produce
> > an executable, this does not by itself cause the resulting executable
> > to be covered by the GNU General Public License. Your use of that
> > executable is in no way restricted on account of linking the HRL
> > and/or HVM code into it.

That was exactly the context I understood, and also the one explained by my
attorney. He did explain and I did forward few times, that the Executable,
is "excused" by the Exception, *only* if its exclusive reliance upon Harbour
Code, is the link inclusion of the compiled HVM, and or the HRL. This is
perfectly clear.

> In other words, it means that just linking in the HRL and/or HVM does
> not restrict your use of the executable, but your use of the executable
> might still be restricted if your use of it runs afoul of other parts of
> the GPL.

That's the part where you describe an understanding that is not expressed in
the Exception. The Exception, is saying something to the effect of:

</Loose On>
As long as the only Harbour code used by your executable is the compiled
HVM, or HRL, then this Executable is released from all of the GPL
restrictions.
</Loose Off>

> But you and your lawyer appear to be reading it as meaning that because
> you linked in the HRL and/or HVM, your use of the resulting executable
> is exempt from the GPL in its entirety, even though the Harbour
> Exception neither states nor implies that.

Yes it does, it clearly says that if you "only" linked the HVM or HRL, you
are then and only then, free to use this Executable without any
restrictions.

You should read the "this by itself" portion, as if it says "as long as you
didn't link more then just the HVM and/or HRL"!

> I challenge you to forward this email, in it's entirety and unedited,
> to your lawyer and then post his response, in it's entirety and
> unedited, to the list.

David, it is clear that you don't trust the input I forwarded to be
objective. I suggest you contact an attorney directly, so that you can
appreciate the input you' receive. I will also forward my phone number on
private email, so that we can discuss it more interactively if you wish.

Ron


From harbour@lists.harbour-project.org  Mon Mar  5 21:57:02 2001
From: harbour@lists.harbour-project.org (Ron Pinkas)
Date: Mon Mar  5 21:57:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] GPL + Exception -> Legal Interpretation
In-Reply-To: <200103051905_MC2-C7C4-530F@compuserve.com>
Message-ID: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKKEDLDKAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>

John,

> > ,------------------------
> > | is in no way restricted
> > `------------------------
> >
> > In legal language == "No Restrictions"!
>
> Er... has your lawyer misread the following (from license.txt):
>
> "Your use of that
>  executable is in no way restricted on account of linking the HRL
>  and/or HVM code into it."
>
> It is vital to note that there is no comma (,) before "on account".
> He appears to be reading it as if that missing comma were present.
>
> It's not, but if it were the "on account" would then mean "because"
> - which does seem to be the way he's reading it.

There is no doubt that is exactly how we all read it. It was always
understood and explained to read something to the effect of: <<as long as
you don't use more than just the compiled HVM and HRL>>.

The "evil" scenario I demonstrated did not use more then just the compiled
HVM and HRL.

> He _does_ have a competent knowledge of English, doesn't he?

Absolutely.

> An alternative: should the above wording be changed to something
> which cannot be misread like that?  Perhaps:
>
> "Your use of that
>  executable has no extra restrictions placed on it by the linking of
>  HRL and/or HVM code into it."
>
> Or:
>
> "Restrictions, if any, applying to that
>  executable are unaffected by the linking of HRL
>  and/or HVM code into it."
>
> Next, if it's not the above issue, more info please.

This will not change anything, as this was not the problem. The problem is
that one *can* easily use the above to do more then we intended for it to
allow. We wanted to allow a Harbour application to be released without any
GPL restrictions. But the exception doesn't qualify the executable, beyond
the mere link inclusion of the HVM and/or HRL.

As it is now:

If you linked that HVM and/or HRL, and if you didn't use more of Harbour,
than just linking HVM and/or HRL, the resulting executable is free and clear
from all GPL restrictions.

Ron

On Mon, Mar 05, 2001 at 09:25:25PM +0300, Alexander S.Kresin wrote:

>  He wrote that all tests fills the screen with non-readable symbols

>  output from 'box' - all pseudo-graphics symbols was replaced by
>  something else.

Can you give us more information about his environment and the like? I just
tried this code:

,----[ foo.prg ]
| Function Main()
| 
|    @ 10, 10 to 20, 20
|    inkey( 0 )
|    
| Return( NIL )
`----

and it drew a box with no problems.

What distribution is he using (of both harbour and GNU/Linux)? What version
of that distribution? What version of ncurses? Do other programs that draw
boxes work fine? What sort of terminal is he running this test in?

From harbour@lists.harbour-project.org  Tue Mar  6 03:10:38 2001
From: harbour@lists.harbour-project.org (Dave Pearson)
Date: Tue Mar  6 03:10:38 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Licensing discussions
In-Reply-To: <200103051801_MC2-C7AD-9893@compuserve.com>; from John_Skelton@compuserve.com on Mon, Mar 05, 2001 at 06:01:14PM -0500
References: <200103051801_MC2-C7AD-9893@compuserve.com>
Message-ID: <20010306075521.Z21816@hagbard.davep.org>

On Mon, Mar 05, 2001 at 06:01:14PM -0500, John Skelton wrote:

> "I thought the concern that Phil was raising is that someone who wants to
> modify parts of the HRTL can't use their modified version in their own
> non-free application if they can't get their code accepted by the
> copyright holder of the file concerned."
> 
> I thought that was the issue; I think it's incorrect: i.e. they _can_ use
> their own changes whether or not they're accepted. But I think they _must_
> make them available. (I'm not sure how long for, but at least as long as
> they use 'em I'd say.)

But their own changes fall under the GPL don't they? Furthermore, I'm not
sure that a change doesn't cause the harbour exception to be "removed" from
that file. If we can know for sure that the harbour exception *isn't*
"removed" from a file when a derivative work is created then we don't have a
problem at all.

Or, put another way, if the harbour exception isn't removed from the file
when a derivative work is created what is causing them to make their changes
available? If it is removed, what stops that item of code from requiring
that their code be licenced under a GPL compatible licence and that the
executable as a whole be licenced under the GPL?

-- 
The Harbour Project: A free software Clipper compatible compiler
Home Page..........: http://www.harbour-project.org/
FAQ................: http://www.harbour-project.org/faq/harbour.html
My harbour page....: http://www.davep.org/harbour/

From harbour@lists.harbour-project.org  Tue Mar  6 03:10:54 2001
From: harbour@lists.harbour-project.org (Dave Pearson)
Date: Tue Mar  6 03:10:54 2001
Subject: [Harbour] GPL + Exception -> Legal Interpretation
In-Reply-To: <200103051904.f25J4r523556@thor.parrett.net>; from dholm@jsd-llc.com on Mon, Mar 05, 2001 at 02:04:45PM -0500
References: <200103051704.f25H4A513331@thor.parrett.net> <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKMEDGDKAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com> <200103051904.f25J4r523556@thor.parrett.net>
Message-ID: <20010306074950.Y21816@hagbard.davep.org>

On Mon, Mar 05, 2001 at 02:04:45PM -0500, David G. Holm wrote:
> ** Reply to message from "Ron Pinkas" <Ron@Profit-Master.com> on Mon, 5
> Mar 2001 10:33:31 -0800
>
> > > 2. That very brief of an instant described in paragraph 1. above, the
> > > GPL is being modified by the copyrights holder (Licensor), so as to
> > > create a new license (HGPL). You *must* read this License (HGPL), as
> > > if a magic wand (the Harbour Exception), has erased *any* and *all*
> > > language, that reads as a restriction, while leaving intact everything
> > > else.
> > 
> > The exception only wave the restrictions, but nothing else. Legally,
> > this is a new license.
> 
> Which is nonsense, because the Harbour Exception very clearly removes
> *one* restriction and *only* one restriction and only under *limited*
> circumstances.

I'm with Ron and his legal adviser here. I don't think it's quite nonsense.
I'd agree with you that the intention of the harbour exception is to only
remove one "restriction" from the GPL but I can't agree that it *clearly*
removes it.

The exception clearly states that the act of linking with code licenced
under the "harbour licence" doesn't cause the executable as a whole to fall
under the GPL, although that obviously doesn't affect the GPL'd code (be it
under the harbour exception or not). On top of that the exception finishes
off with:

,----
| Your use of that executable is in no way restricted on account of linking
| the HRL and/or HVM code into it.
`----

which, in the light of what Ron's legal advisor has said, is ambiguous at
best. If anything I'd say the lack of clarity is in "use". The above text
seems to dissolve and not dissolve the GPL, or key parts of it.

It seems to be that the fact of the matter is that if Ron's LA's reading of
the exception is what we've been presented with then we need to think about
making it less ambiguous.

Although making a blanket change to the exception at this late stage might
be difficult at best.

-- 
The Harbour Project: A free software Clipper compatible compiler
Home Page..........: http://www.harbour-project.org/
FAQ................: http://www.harbour-project.org/faq/harbour.html
My harbour page....: http://www.davep.org/harbour/

about people drawing their own conclusions.

It's quite simple, you didn't comprehend the question I was asking (or
perhaps I'd not worded the question well). Instead of acknowledging that

Look Ron Pinkas, it's really simple. I've not got a position to defend or a
point to "make" so I really don't have to cover up being wrong about
anything. Despite the fantasy you seem to be enjoying and trying to share
with others I really don't have a problem being wrong. Far from it, I like
being wrong, it's called learning.

If it turns out that we have to view harbour's licence as a molested GPL
then that's fine by me, I don't have any stake in an alternative point of
view. All I've done is try and ask for more background on why we'd need to
view it this way, the only answers I've had from your are shouts of
"baseless!" and some stuff about "because I asked by legal advisor". They
are not convincing arguments.

No, I don't have a problem with being wrong. You do seem to have a problem
with people wanting to learn and know more.

What I do have a problem with is bullying, dishonest people who seek to
pollute public spaces with their bullying and dishonesty. Even worse are
bullying, dishonest people who, when presented with the evidence of their
own bullying and dishonesty (even when they ask for that evidence, like you
did), simply ignore it rather than face up to it, acknowledge it, learn from
it and move on.

From harbour@lists.harbour-project.org  Tue Mar  6 03:41:05 2001
From: harbour@lists.harbour-project.org (Ron Pinkas)
Date: Tue Mar  6 03:41:05 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Bug with oError:args as received by an error handler
In-Reply-To: <20010306075737.A21816@hagbard.davep.org>
Message-ID: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKMEDODKAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>

Dave,

> > I don't have the discussion in front of me, and yes it was on the list.
>
> I as asking if it was on the list at it's current location,
> this'll tell me
> which archives I need to be looking for.

I think it was on the eGroups list.

--------------------
I just found my message dated Nov-12-2000

We already have hb_errPutArgs(...). It seems very strait forward, to change
hb_errRT_BASE_Subst(...) etc., to receive additional ... arguments and in
turn call hb_errPutArgs(...). Finally it is fairly simple, though time
consuming, to change all hb_err*() calls to include the operands arguments.

I would suggest that hb_errPutArgs() is changed to accept an ARRAY of ITEMs
rather than variable number ITEM parameters. Similarly adding ARRAY of ITEMs
parameter to hb_err*() will make the subsequent call to hb_errPutArgs(...)
much simpler. Generating the ARRAY of operands before calling hb_err*(...)
and passing it to hb_err*() seems quiet simple.

Any comments?

Ron
--------------------

Victor's reply, should be at about no long thereafter.

> > IIRC, I offered adding 1 more parameter to the functions in question,
> > which would be an array populated by the arguments, Victor,
> explained that
> > creating multiple versions, to receive 1,2,3 or N parameters for each of
> > the argument would work better.
>
> I don't think I understand what "the functions in question" are.
> Do you mean
> the functions that throw the errors (hb_vmPlus(), for example) or do you
> mean something else?

See above.

Ron

From harbour@lists.harbour-project.org  Wed Mar  7 09:56:01 2001
From: harbour@lists.harbour-project.org (Brian Hays)
Date: Wed Mar  7 09:56:01 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Bug List
Message-ID: <003601c0a696$f89a2250$921a5e18@bh>

Phil et al:
Here's my buglist.
There are also a few ADS specific bugs that I will take care of so I didn't
incllude them here.

Brian Hays

HARBOUR BUGS
============

GC (Garbage collector) issues
   In a large FiveWin app, hb_gcAll() can cause the app to gpf/disappear

   In reaction to questions on __GetGrip(), Ryszard suggested that a new
   algorithm of managing allocated/deallocated lists of items would be
   better.

   If this is necessary to stabilize memory I would keep it at
   the top of the list!

------------------------------------------------------------------
Symbol searches fail if the symbol has trailing spaces.
   For example,
      use test alias test
      // this would be cVar's value if read from a dbf field
      cVar := "TEST      "
      select(cVar)  --> returns 0
   The discussion on this centered on a desire to not slow down all symbol
   handling (the bug is not only in the select function)


----------------------
Array corruption (GC?)
   Arrays can become nil in a large app after being passed by reference
   and/or not by reference, including as a detached local reference in a
   codeblock.  This has not been reproducible in a test applet.

----------------------
Macro handling of str lengths for numbers
   FUNCTION test ()
      local cVar := "'x'+str(12345678901)+'x'"
      ? 'x'+str(12345678901)+'x'
      ? &cVar
   RETURN Nil
Harbour output has a space for both:
   x 12345678901x
   x 12345678901x

   Clipper does not if it's macro compiled.
   x12345678901x
   x 12345678901x
----------------------

ordKeyVal and others are still in dummy.prg
   I was waiting on implementing those until a decision was made on
   Ryszard's proposed RDD changes.
   Should they go into dbcmd.c ?

----------------------
ord.ch should be coordinated with a new dbInfo.ch
   What are the legal issues of header files looking an awful lot
   like those of another development system?

----------------------
COPY TO is incomplete



Reported by others
----------------------
>From Alejandro Mery Pellegrini <amery@ing.puc.cl>
THE 'SAVE TO' statement doesn't work like clipper's.
   i.e.
   like nom?? works for nom10, but not for nom1




From harbour@lists.harbour-project.org  Wed Mar  7 09:59:01 2001
From: harbour@lists.harbour-project.org (John Skelton)

Message-ID: <200103060626_MC2-C7C9-FC94@compuserve.com>

Ron,

ed

or this "evil" person?

John.

From harbour@lists.harbour-project.org  Wed Mar  7 10:05:01 2001
From: harbour@lists.harbour-project.org (Phil Barnett)
Date: Wed Mar  7 10:05:01 2001
Subject: [Harbour] GPL + Exception -> Legal Interpretation
In-Reply-To: <200103051904.f25J4r523556@thor.parrett.net>
References: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKMEDGDKAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>
Message-ID: <3AA5F8E3.31892.B7F06D6@localhost>

On 5 Mar 2001, at 14:04, David G. Holm wrote:

> > The exception only wave the restrictions, but nothing else. Legally,
> > this is a new license.
> 
> Which is nonsense, because the Harbour Exception very clearly removes
> *one* restriction and *only* one restriction and only under *limited*
> circumstances.

I might agree that it is a dual license, not a modified GPL. You 
have a choice which one you use.

                       WWW  http://www.the-oasis.net/
                  FTP Site  ftp://ftp.the-oasis.net

     ! fixed skipping for some special cases
     + hb_ntxSortKeyAdd()
       * Sorting of keys
     + hb_ntxRootPage()
     + hb_ntxBufferSave()
       * Building index from sorted keys
     + hb_ntxReadBuf()
       * read buffering
     * Index creating is fully rewritten.

       and works faster than before.

Mar 2001 18:42:37 -0800

> Ok, so which restrictions does it *not* remove, and where does it say so?

Quoting from the Harbour Exception, "this does not by itself cause the
resulting executable to be covered by the GNU General Public License."
-- 
David G. Holm, Set Captain and all around
Harbour Project Clipper Compatibility fanatic.

From harbour@lists.harbour-project.org  Wed Mar  7 10:31:12 2001
From: harbour@lists.harbour-project.org (David G. Holm)
Date: Wed Mar  7 10:31:12 2001
Subject: [Harbour] GPL + Exception -> Legal Interpretation
In-Reply-To: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKKEDLDKAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>
References: <200103051905_MC2-C7C4-530F@compuserve.com>
Message-ID: <200103061525.f26FOV519122@thor.parrett.net>

** Reply to message from "Ron Pinkas" <Ron@Profit-Master.com> on Mon, 5
Mar 2001 18:54:41 -0800

> The "evil" scenario I demonstrated did not use more then just the compiled
> HVM and HRL.

Oh, yes it did! Your "evil" scenario not only had the HRL and HVM
linked into the linker program for its use in executing its functions,
but it also had the HRL and HVM bound to it for the purpose of linking
those two libraries to another program. Only the first use is covered by
the Harbour Exception. The second use is a binary distribution of the
libraries themselves, which is *not* covered by the binary distribution.
-- 
David G. Holm, Set Captain and all around
Harbour Project Clipper Compatibility fanatic.

From harbour@lists.harbour-project.org  Wed Mar  7 10:45:02 2001
From: harbour@lists.harbour-project.org (Dave Pearson)
Date: Wed Mar  7 10:45:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] GPL + Exception -> Legal Interpretation
In-Reply-To: <3AA5F8E3.31892.B7F06D6@localhost>; from midnight@the-oasis.net on Wed, Mar 07, 2001 at 09:01:23AM -0500
References: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKMEDGDKAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com> <200103051904.f25J4r523556@thor.parrett.net> <3AA5F8E3.31892.B7F06D6@localhost>
Message-ID: <20010307143857.S5326@hagbard.davep.org>

On Wed, Mar 07, 2001 at 09:01:23AM -0500, Phil Barnett wrote:
> On 5 Mar 2001, at 14:04, David G. Holm wrote:
> 
> > Which is nonsense, because the Harbour Exception very clearly removes
> > *one* restriction and *only* one restriction and only under *limited*
> > circumstances.
> 
> I might agree that it is a dual license, not a modified GPL. You have a
> choice which one you use.

That's an interesting way of looking at it. The obvious question is that if
it's a *dual* licence what are the two licences that you get to choose from?
On the one hand you've got the GPL, anyone electing to use harbour to
develop free software gets to choose a GPL compatible free software licence
and they must distribute the package as a whole under the GPL.

On the other hand there's a "licence" that you need to observe if you're
writing non-free software. What Ron and his legal advisor seem to be saying
is that although the GPL hasn't been modified in any "real world" sense it
is modified in a legal sense and so this is, legally (in the US at least),
presented as a licence in it's own right which is either a modified GPL or
is, at least, based on the GPL (or something, I'm still a bit confused about
what the real case is here).

So, what is the licence on the "other hand"?

-- 
The Harbour Project: A free software Clipper compatible compiler
Home Page..........: http://www.harbour-project.org/
FAQ................: http://www.harbour-project.org/faq/harbour.html
My harbour page....: http://www.davep.org/harbour/

From harbour@lists.harbour-project.org  Wed Mar  7 10:49:18 2001
From: harbour@lists.harbour-project.org (John Skelton)
Date: Wed Mar  7 10:49:18 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Licensing discussions
Message-ID: <200103060626_MC2-C7C9-FC97@compuserve.com>

Dave,

"But their own changes fall under the GPL don't they?"

Right (which is why they have to make them available).

"I'm not sure that a change doesn't cause the harbour exception to
be "removed" from that file."

It's not removed.  Making a change to source code can't alter a
license.  You'd need the license holder's consent to do that.

"If we can know for sure that the harbour
exception *isn't* "removed" from a file when a derivative work is
created then we don't have a problem at all."

Then we don't have a problem. :-)

"if the harbour exception isn't removed from the file when a
derivative work is created what is causing them to make their changes
available?"

Unless the derivative work is an executable, the GPL applies - thus
they have to make their changes available.

"If it is removed, what stops that item of code from requiring that
their code be licenced under a GPL compatible licence and that the
executable as a whole be licenced under the GPL?"

It's not removed. :-)

John.

From harbour@lists.harbour-project.org  Wed Mar  7 10:49:44 2001

On Mon, Mar 05, 2001 at 09:25:25PM +0300, Alexander S.Kresin wrote:

> Yet another report from Uri V. Hnykin, now problems with ncurses.
>  He wrote that all tests fills the screen with non-readable symbols
>  with codes < 32.
>  He sent me one fragment, which was more readable than others - the
>  output from 'box' - all pseudo-graphics symbols was replaced by
>  something else.
>  Any ideas ?

One of the possible reasons could be that he uses a screen font 
prepared for Russian language in which case chars between 128 
and 255 can be whatever they are. 
This was for example true for me when I used badly formed fonts
for polish ISO-8859-2 code page.
Ask him to check if he uses standard 437 code page.

Marek Paliwoda

please quote and I'll attempt to answer if I can. Regardless, the lack of
focus, is in directing attention away from the argued issues, which are:

I have nothing else to argue here. I ask that we focus back our attention to
the above 2 issues. This is far more productive for Harbour, then my

> more crap?
>
> Look Ron Pinkas, it's really simple. I've not got a position to
> defend or a
> point to "make" so I really don't have to cover up being wrong about
> anything. Despite the fantasy you seem to be enjoying and trying to share
> with others I really don't have a problem being wrong. Far from it, I like
> being wrong, it's called learning.

Please let us know if you withdraw your claim that the Harbour License is
not a modified GPL. If you didn't, please don't tell us you have no position
to defend.

> If it turns out that we have to view harbour's licence as a molested GPL
> then that's fine by me, I don't have any stake in an alternative point of
> view. All I've done is try and ask for more background on why we'd need to
> view it this way, the only answers I've had from your are shouts of
> "baseless!" and some stuff about "because I asked by legal advisor". They
> are not convincing arguments.

It's not about stakes, it is about a statement with legal context being
either legally correct, or false, and baseless. Are you still backing your
original claim? *If* you are no longer sure, why would you take offense to
my description of it as being false and baseless? If you still stand behind
your statement why would claim you have no position to defend?

> No, I don't have a problem with being wrong. You do seem to have a problem
> with people wanting to learn and know more.

What would that problem be?

> What I do have a problem with is bullying, dishonest people who seek to
> pollute public spaces with their bullying and dishonesty. Even worse are
> bullying, dishonest people who, when presented with the evidence of their
> own bullying and dishonesty (even when they ask for that
> evidence, like you
> did), simply ignore it rather than face up to it, acknowledge it,

intimidation/persecution/torment/frightning/opression/harrasment did I apply
against poor Dave?

Dishonesty, is much more serious, and far worse accusation! I though we new
how to respect and even enjoy our arguments. Referring to me as "dishonest
people" is beyond the scope of such argument. I hope you will sometime soon
"learn" (like claim you like to), that context is very important to the
tone, and scope of an argument. Individuals like us should be able to argue
without getting so personal, and without resorting to generic unqualified
statements. There is a huge difference between saying, I find your argument
dishonest, to saying you are a dishonest person.

Ron

longer the GPL right?

From harbour@lists.harbour-project.org  Wed Mar  7 12:11:02 2001
From: harbour@lists.harbour-project.org (David G. Holm)
Date: Wed Mar  7 12:11:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] GPL + Exception -> Legal Interpretation
In-Reply-To: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKMEFBDKAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>
References: <200103061522.f26FL0518644@thor.parrett.net>
Message-ID: <200103071709.f27H9x227891@smtp.parrett.net>

** Reply to message from "Ron Pinkas" <Ron@Profit-Master.com> on Wed, 7
Mar 2001 07:36:35 -0800

> Why would you argue this, instead of contacting a copyright expert you can
> trust, and find out the true legal meaning of this exception?

The only thing a "copyright expert" can do is give an *opinion* on what
he or she *thinks* the "true legal meaning" is. And if you ask five
"experts", you're likely to get five different opinions. There can be no
"true legal meaning" until a judge or jury has handed down a verdict in
a specific case involving this particular license in a particular
jurisdiction. And even then, the "true legal meaning" may only apply to
that particular jurisdiction. Or haven't you noticed the contradictory
rulings handed down by different Federal district courts in nearly
identical copyright infringment cases in the US?
-- 
David G. Holm, Set Captain and all around
Harbour Project Clipper Compatibility fanatic.

> or this "evil" person?

What you apparently missed, is that this is no "regular" linker. It links
Harbour *compatible* pcode with *the* Harbour HVM and HRL to produce Harbour
*like* executable, but not being subject to Harbour License, and without
having to give Harbour any credit (even though some 2/3 of this is actually
Harbour).

Ron

will improve one's chances.

From harbour@lists.harbour-project.org  Wed Mar  7 12:34:02 2001
From: harbour@lists.harbour-project.org (David G. Holm)
Date: Wed Mar  7 12:34:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] GPL + Exception -> Legal Interpretation
In-Reply-To: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKEEFCDKAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>
References: <200103061525.f26FOV519122@thor.parrett.net>
Message-ID: <200103071733.f27HXb230496@smtp.parrett.net>

** Reply to message from "Ron Pinkas" <Ron@Profit-Master.com> on Wed, 7
Mar 2001 07:45:56 -0800

> Every executable is a binary distribution!

And the Harbour Exeption *only* applies to a binary distribution that
has linked the HRL and/or HVM into it for the purpose of being executed,
not to one that has them bound to it for the purpose of distributing the
library.

> Our Exception specifically release all restrictions that otherwise apply, if
> the executable in question "only" include compiled versions of the HVM
> and/or HRL.

No, it does not, as I have clearly explained over and over again.

> You never explained how did my "evil" executable, did more than "linking the
> HRL and/or HVM code into it"?

I guess you *missed* reading the part of my message that explains that,
*despite* your having quoted it in your reply!

> Since "this does not by itself cause the resulting executable to be covered
> by the GNU General Public License" what did?

OK, one more time, but with more technical details: When a library is
linked into an executable, you lose all the "library" aspects of the
original library. In order for the linker to link the HRL and/or HVM
into another program, it has to have the HRL and/or HVM in library
format. Which means that it can't use the HRL and/or HVM that were
linked into the linker program itself, because that copy of the HRL
and/or HVM is missing the library information. Which means that in order
to not include the HRL and/or HVM as separate library files with the
binary distribution of the linker, they have to be bound to the linker
in library format, such as by simply appending them to the end of the
original binary of the linker executable. It is *this* use of the HRL
and/or HVM that causes the GPL to apply to this linker, overriding the
*potential* application of the Harbour Exception for the *other* use of
the HRL and/or HVM.
-- 
David G. Holm, Set Captain and all around
Harbour Project Clipper Compatibility fanatic.

From harbour@lists.harbour-project.org  Wed Mar  7 12:39:02 2001
From: harbour@lists.harbour-project.org (David G. Holm)

From harbour@lists.harbour-project.org  Wed Mar  7 12:49:02 2001
From: harbour@lists.harbour-project.org (David G. Holm)
Date: Wed Mar  7 12:49:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] GPL + Exception -> Legal Interpretation
In-Reply-To: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKGEFFDKAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>
References: <200103071709.f27H9k227879@smtp.parrett.net>
Message-ID: <200103071748.f27HmM231929@smtp.parrett.net>

** Reply to message from "Ron Pinkas" <Ron@Profit-Master.com> on Wed, 7
Mar 2001 09:18:48 -0800

> > Just exactly which part of "this does not by itself cause the resulting
> > executable to be covered by the [GPL]" is it that is so difficult for
> > you to understand? The *only* clause that is potentially being released
> > is the *one* clause that is *explicitly* listed!
> 
> Which is?

It's right there in the part that you quoted, so why do you keep acting
as if it isn't there? It's the part that reads "...cause the resulting
executable to be covered by the GNU Public License."

If the HRL and/or HVM did not use the Harbour Exception, then a binary
distribution of the resulting executable would have to be released under
the GPL (or a compatible license). But because the HRL and/or HVM do
have the Harbour Exception, then the resulting executable might not have
to be released under the GPL, if the only thing that was done with the
HRL and/or HVM was to link them into the executable (i.e., include them
for the purpose of executing them).

And that is the *only* clause of the GPL that Harbour code has the
*potential* to be exempted from.
-- 
David G. Holm, Set Captain and all around
Harbour Project Clipper Compatibility fanatic.

From harbour@lists.harbour-project.org  Wed Mar  7 12:51:02 2001
From: harbour@lists.harbour-project.org (Ryszard Glab)
Date: Wed Mar  7 12:51:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Bug with oError:args as received by an error handler
In-Reply-To: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKMEDODKAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>
References: <20010306075737.A21816@hagbard.davep.org>
Message-ID: <3AA6843B.7714.1C69FD5@localhost>

On 6 Mar 2001, at 0:38, Ron Pinkas wrote:

> I would suggest that hb_errPutArgs() is changed to accept an ARRAY of ITEMs
> rather than variable number ITEM parameters. Similarly adding ARRAY of ITEMs
> parameter to hb_err*() will make the subsequent call to hb_errPutArgs(...)
> much simpler. Generating the ARRAY of operands before calling hb_err*(...)
> and passing it to hb_err*() seems quiet simple.
> 
> Any comments?

  I think the the choise is simple: we will have to add either a code to 
create an array of arguments in all places where errors are generated or 
call hb_errPutArgs() with these arguments. The first solution will 
produce bigger executables and will be much more error prone since 
building an array is not a single function call. We can create some macro 
for it but we have hb_errPutArgs() function for this purpose already.

Regards, Ryszard

From harbour@lists.harbour-project.org  Wed Mar  7 12:55:03 2001

David,

> > relying on our unqualified opinions, wouldn't you agree?
>
> Except when the provider of such an opinion has obviously misread the

From harbour@lists.harbour-project.org  Wed Mar  7 13:03:02 2001
From: harbour@lists.harbour-project.org (Ron Pinkas)
Date: Wed Mar  7 13:03:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] GPL + Exception -> Legal Interpretation
In-Reply-To: <200103071733.f27HXb230496@smtp.parrett.net>
Message-ID: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKAEFIDKAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>

David,

> > Since "this does not by itself cause the resulting executable
> to be covered
> > by the GNU General Public License" what did?
>
> OK, one more time, but with more technical details: When a library is
> linked into an executable, you lose all the "library" aspects of the
> original library. In order for the linker to link the HRL and/or HVM
> into another program, it has to have the HRL and/or HVM in library
> format. Which means that it can't use the HRL and/or HVM that were
> linked into the linker program itself, because that copy of the HRL
> and/or HVM is missing the library information. Which means that in order
> to not include the HRL and/or HVM as separate library files with the
> binary distribution of the linker, they have to be bound to the linker
> in library format, such as by simply appending them to the end of the
> original binary of the linker executable. It is *this* use of the HRL
> and/or HVM that causes the GPL to apply to this linker, overriding the
> *potential* application of the Harbour Exception for the *other* use of
> the HRL and/or HVM.

1. Our exception does *not* qualify what is "bound" as opposed to link.

2. I'm not a linker expert, but, I can't agree that linking will necessarily
"lose the library aspects". As an example, most of us already agreed that a
DLL is considered an executable, didn't we? Is there anything stopping our
"evil" from distributing the HVM and HRL in DLL form, to serve its Harbour
compatible pcode?

Ron


From harbour@lists.harbour-project.org  Wed Mar  7 13:04:02 2001

> It is not very wise to assume, that an expert has "obviously misread"

Except that in this case, it is. Your expert appears to be reading the
Harbour Exception as if there were a comma present in it at one point,
where there clearly is no comma, and by taking an out of context
fragment to be the the overriding scope of the Harbour Exception, which
it clearly isn't.

From harbour@lists.harbour-project.org  Wed Mar  7 13:47:02 2001
From: harbour@lists.harbour-project.org (David G. Holm)
Date: Wed Mar  7 13:47:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] GPL + Exception -> Legal Interpretation
In-Reply-To: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKAEFIDKAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>
References: <200103071733.f27HXb230496@smtp.parrett.net>
Message-ID: <200103071846.f27Ik1205772@smtp.parrett.net>

** Reply to message from "Ron Pinkas" <Ron@Profit-Master.com> on Wed, 7
Mar 2001 10:00:55 -0800

> 1. Our exception does *not* qualify what is "bound" as opposed to link.

It says "...if you link..." and to link means to include for purpose of
execution.

> 2. I'm not a linker expert, but, I can't agree that linking will necessarily
> "lose the library aspects". As an example, most of us already agreed that a
> DLL is considered an executable, didn't we? Is there anything stopping our
> "evil" from distributing the HVM and HRL in DLL form, to serve its Harbour
> compatible pcode?

If the linker only contains the unmodified HRL and HVM for the linker
to execute, then it would in all likelyhood not have to be distributed
under the GPL. If distributing just the the HVM and HRL in library form
is even allowed under the GPL, then the libraries would probably have to
be distributed under the GPL *without* the Harbour Exception, which I
expect would mean that using the non-GPL linker together with the GPL
library would cause any resulting executable to have to be placed under
the GPL (or compatible license).

But would it still be the case if someone were to download the non-GPL
linker and also download the same version of Harbour that was used in
the creation of the linker, and use the HRL and HVM from the Harbour
distribution with the linker to create a new executable? Well, I for one
don't really care, because at that point, it is obvious that the linker
and Harbour are separate products and what we are mainly trying to
prevent is someone from passing off Harbour as their own work.
-- 
David G. Holm, Set Captain and all around
Harbour Project Clipper Compatibility fanatic.

On Wed, Mar 07, 2001 at 12:33:35PM -0500, David G. Holm wrote:
> ** Reply to message from "Ron Pinkas" <Ron@Profit-Master.com> on Wed, 7
> Mar 2001 07:45:56 -0800
> 
> > Every executable is a binary distribution!
> 
> And the Harbour Exeption *only* applies to a binary distribution that has
> linked the HRL and/or HVM into it for the purpose of being executed, not
> to one that has them bound to it for the purpose of distributing the
> library.

Or, to put it another way, it (the exception) speaks to binary data that is
linked to the file in such a way that it is callable and executable from
other code, not linked such that it is simply some cargo or a non-executable
resource. Right?

> resource. Right?

That's the intent, but it's looking like we may have to reword the
exception to ensure that the intent doesn't get lost when the exception
is read by someone with a legalistic mind-set.

In-Reply-To: <200103071803.f27I3F201070@smtp.parrett.net>; from dholm@jsd-llc.com on Wed, Mar 07, 2001 at 01:03:14PM -0500
References: <200103071738.f27HcY231010@smtp.parrett.net> <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKEEFHDKAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com> <200103071803.f27I3F201070@smtp.parrett.net>

Hi, gang.

May I suggest we delegate someone to contact FSF for a referral to an
attorney who can help us with these questions?

It's possible that we could even do this without cost, if said attorney
is particularly friendly to the Free Software movement.

I don't doubt the competence of the lawyer Ron contacted, but the GPL
is an oddity even in the realm of intellectual property law, and we are
unavoidably (not Ron's fault) getting a "filtered" version of what this
lawyer heard and said.

It's an important discussion, but it doesn't have to be a big controversy.

Aren't we all on the same side?

David,

> > 1. Our exception does *not* qualify what is "bound" as opposed to link.
>
> It says "...if you link..." and to link means to include for purpose of
> execution.

Which is what my proposal seeks to clarify, right?

> > 2. I'm not a linker expert, but, I can't agree that linking
> will necessarily
> > "lose the library aspects". As an example, most of us already
> agreed that a
> > DLL is considered an executable, didn't we? Is there anything
> stopping our
> > "evil" from distributing the HVM and HRL in DLL form, to serve
> its Harbour
> > compatible pcode?
>
> If the linker only contains the unmodified HRL and HVM for the linker
> to execute, then it would in all likelyhood not have to be distributed
> under the GPL. If distributing just the the HVM and HRL in library form
> is even allowed under the GPL, then the libraries would probably have to
> be distributed under the GPL *without* the Harbour Exception, which I
> expect would mean that using the non-GPL linker together with the GPL
> library would cause any resulting executable to have to be placed under
> the GPL (or compatible license).
>
> But would it still be the case if someone were to download the non-GPL
> linker and also download the same version of Harbour that was used in
> the creation of the linker, and use the HRL and HVM from the Harbour
> distribution with the linker to create a new executable? Well, I for one
> don't really care, because at that point, it is obvious that the linker
> and Harbour are separate products and what we are mainly trying to
> prevent is someone from passing off Harbour as their own work.

David, what about the HVM + HRL in DLL form? Didn't we intend to allow it
(in the context of running an Harbour application)?

Don't you see that if we don't qualify it, anyone can distribute DLL form of
HVM and/or HRL without subjecting such, to GPL terms? He won't even have to
"credit" Harbour at all. If he managed to create Harbour compatible pcode
compiler, he now has complete Harbour like package (2/3 of which is actually
Harbour), and none of this is subject to any GPL terms, if he so chooses.

Ron

From harbour@lists.harbour-project.org  Wed Mar  7 14:29:02 2001
From: harbour@lists.harbour-project.org (Dave Pearson)
Date: Wed Mar  7 14:29:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Licensing discussions
In-Reply-To: <200103060626_MC2-C7C9-FC97@compuserve.com>; from John_Skelton@compuserve.com on Tue, Mar 06, 2001 at 06:25:51AM -0500
References: <200103060626_MC2-C7C9-FC97@compuserve.com>
Message-ID: <20010307181047.D5326@hagbard.davep.org>

On Tue, Mar 06, 2001 at 06:25:51AM -0500, John Skelton wrote:
> Dave,
> 
> "I'm not sure that a change doesn't cause the harbour exception to
> be "removed" from that file."
> 
> It's not removed. Making a change to source code can't alter a license.
> You'd need the license holder's consent to do that.

Agreed, you obviously need the copyright holder's consent to modify a
licence. The ambiguity I'm concerned about is that it could be seen that the
exception isn't "transferable" when a derived work is made. If what Ron's
legal advisor says is true for all "reasonable" countries then the point is
moot anyway. This is why I'm actually very interested in what Ron's legal
advisor has might have said, if it does turn out that we can and have to
view what we've got here as a licence that doesn't change when a derived
work is made it means we don't actually have a problem with ERRORSYS and
friends either (as, if you're reading this David, you suspected bet we were
both worried about any possible ambiguity).

> "If we can know for sure that the harbour exception *isn't* "removed" from
> a file when a derivative work is created then we don't have a problem at
> all."
> 
> Then we don't have a problem. :-)

It would begin to appear so. This is good news.

> "if the harbour exception isn't removed from the file when a derivative
> work is created what is causing them to make their changes available?"
> 
> Unless the derivative work is an executable, the GPL applies - thus they
> have to make their changes available.

Ahh, hmm, now I see an ambiguity. Or perhaps not. This is another reason for
me wanting to be totally sure about what Ron's legal advisor has said and
wondering how applicable it is in general, if we only have once licence, not
a "choice", then the GPL wouldn't appear to be "there".

That is, I can see how we'd like this to work and I can see how most people
would intend it to work, I'm just concerned that the implications of what
Ron's LA has said might work for us one way but against us another.

-- 
The Harbour Project: A free software Clipper compatible compiler

FAQ................: http://www.harbour-project.org/faq/harbour.html
My harbour page....: http://www.davep.org/harbour/

From harbour@lists.harbour-project.org  Wed Mar  7 14:30:07 2001
From: harbour@lists.harbour-project.org (Dave Pearson)
Date: Wed Mar  7 14:30:07 2001
Subject: [Harbour] ChangeLog 2001-03-04 16:40 UTC-0800 Ron Pinkas <ron@profit-master.com>
In-Reply-To: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKKECODKAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>; from Ron@Profit-Master.com on Sun, Mar 04, 2001 at 04:54:56PM -0800
References: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKCECODKAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com> <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKKECODKAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>
Message-ID: <20010306143628.D5326@hagbard.davep.org>

--mxv5cy4qt+RJ9ypb
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Disposition: inline

On Sun, Mar 04, 2001 at 04:54:56PM -0800, Ron Pinkas wrote:
> 2001-03-04 16:40 UTC-0800 Ron Pinkas <ron@profit-master.com>
>    * contrib/dot/pp.prg
>      * Modified rest of Error Handlers to check type of :Args (Harbour bug).

Those type checks attempted to check the type of a variable that didn't
exist (a typo of oError), so the recursive error call problem still existed
but for a different reason.

Attached is a patch to fix this.

-- 
The Harbour Project: A free software Clipper compatible compiler
Home Page..........: http://www.harbour-project.org/
FAQ................: http://www.harbour-project.org/faq/harbour.html
My harbour page....: http://www.davep.org/harbour/
--mxv5cy4qt+RJ9ypb
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Disposition: attachment; filename="pp.diff"

--- /usr/local/src/harbour/contrib/dot/pp.prg	Mon Mar  5 10:24:50 2001
+++ pp.prg	Tue Mar  6 14:31:46 2001
@@ -775,7 +775,7 @@
 
    LOCAL Counter, xArg, sArgs := ""
 
-   IF ValType( oErr:Args ) == 'A'
+   IF ValType( oError:Args ) == 'A'
       sArgs := " - Arguments: "
 
       FOR Counter := 1 TO Len( oError:Args )
@@ -826,7 +826,7 @@
 
    LOCAL Counter, xArg, sArgs := ""
 
-   IF ValType( oErr:Args ) == 'A'
+   IF ValType( oError:Args ) == 'A'
       sArgs := " - Arguments: "
 
       FOR Counter := 1 TO Len( oError:Args )

--mxv5cy4qt+RJ9ypb--

From harbour@lists.harbour-project.org  Wed Mar  7 18:21:02 2001
From: harbour@lists.harbour-project.org (John Skelton)
Date: Wed Mar  7 18:21:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] GPL + Exception -> Legal Interpretation
Message-ID: <200103071819_MC2-C7EE-D5A@compuserve.com>

Ron,

> Every executable is a binary distribution!

Yes, but it may still be subject to GPL.  Your example linker is,
because it includes the LIBs in a form where they do _not_ qualify
for the Harbour Exception.

> Our Exception specifically release all restrictions that otherwise appl=
y, if
> the executable in question "only" include compiled versions of the HVM
> and/or HRL.

It does _not_ release all restrictions in the way you say.

> how did my "evil" executable, did more than "linking the
> HRL and/or HVM code into it"?

It also includes the HRL/HVM code in a LIB (or equivalent) form, in
what is a blatant attempt to bypass the license.  Courts can deal
with such abuses.

> Since "this does not by itself cause the resulting executable to be cov=
ered
> by the GNU General Public License" what did?

Including those LIBs.

John.

From harbour@lists.harbour-project.org  Wed Mar  7 18:21:18 2001
From: harbour@lists.harbour-project.org (John Skelton)
Date: Wed Mar  7 18:21:18 2001
Subject: [Harbour] GPL + Exception -> Legal Interpretation
Message-ID: <200103071819_MC2-C7EE-D5E@compuserve.com>

Ron,

> this is no "regular" linker. It links Harbour *compatible* pcode
> with *the* Harbour HVM and HRL to produce Harbour *like* executable,
> but not being subject to Harbour License, and without having to give
> Harbour any credit (even though some 2/3 of this is actually Harbour).

Yes, it so links, but I believe that doesn't have the effect you/your
lawyer claimed.  As others have said, you're linking some extra stuff
in what is clearly an attempt to get around the license.  That's just
an abuse, something courts are generally quite good at dealing with.

John.

------- Forwarded message follows -------
From:           	"Victor Szakats" <vector@mail.matav.hu>
To:             	<harbour@lists.harbour-project.org>
Subject:        	Re: [Harbour] HBTest
Organization:   	Szelvesz Bt.
Send reply to:  	harbour@lists.harbour-project.org
	<mailto:harbour-request@lists.harbour-
project.org?subject=subscribe>
	<mailto:harbour-request@lists.harbour-
project.org?subject=unsubscribe
>
Date sent:      	Sun, 12 Nov 2000 22:05:39 +0100

[ Double-click this line for list subscription options ] 

Ron,


> I would suggest that hb_errPutArgs() is changed to accept an 
ARRAY of ITEMs
> rather than variable number ITEM parameters. Similarly adding 
ARRAY of ITEMs
> parameter to hb_err*() will make the subsequent call to 
hb_errPutArgs(...)
> much simpler. Generating the ARRAY of operands before calling 
hb_err*(...)
> and passing it to hb_err*() seems quiet simple.
> 
> Any comments?

I think that passing an array of items needs a relatively complex
preparation, 
and cosidering the large number of hb_err() calls, the fact that
this
call is 
not part of the actual functionality of the caller, and that my main
goal till 
now was to make the error launching call a one-liner, which is as
simple 
as possible and which doesn't require any stack space from the 
caller
side. 
Because of these I think that the array approach doesn't fit here.

My implementation would include a hb_err() functionl which would 
accept two arguments (which is one of the most common), one 
which 
would accept one (which is the other most common), perhaps one 
which would accept three (should check if it's worth), and finally
one
with a variable number of parameters, for the rest of the cases.

As a small statistic here are the current hb_err() calls with :arg:
1 parameter: 83
2 parameter: 154
3 parameter: 16
4 parameter: 2
Total of: 255 (83+154+16+2)

Two more notes:
1) Only BASE error types need the :arg feature currently.
2) For easy calling, the caller should pass the original ITEM
pointer
to the hb_err() function (not a copy of the ITEM)

Victor Szakats

G.J. Doornink <dkg@xs4all.nl>

From: harbour@lists.harbour-project.org (Bill Schuler)
Date: Wed Mar  7 18:34:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Palm  Extended Systems, (Advantage Database Server)
Message-ID: <60026F9F4AE1D41180E600508B550E2917841C@postal.extendsys.com>

After yesterdays announcement we have had a number of phone calls. To help
answer some of the questions we posted the follow message on our news group.
I thought that everyone on the Harbour Team should be aware of this as well.
I hope this will answer everyone's questions.  If you would like more
information please feel free to contact me and I will be happy to help you.

We are pleased to announce to Advantage Partners/users yesterday's
definitive agreement by Palm to acquire Extended Systems.  This is great
news for both Advantage and its business partners, who will benefit from
Palm's keen interest in application developers.  As Extended Systems'
President and CEO Steve Simpson said, "Together, we significantly strengthen
our ability to serve the needs of the explosive enterprise market.   It's a
win-win for customers, employees and stockholders."  Extended Systems will
become part of Palm's Enterprise business unit, which will be based in
Boise, Idaho and headed by Steve Simpson.

For the Advantage Team, it's business as usual.  Our partner relationships
will remain in effect and we will continue to develop and market Advantage
Database Server with a broadened set of resources and partners. We hope to
leverage this fast-growing and profitable software business opportunity and
we're very enthusiastic about our shared vision and prospects with Palm.

Not only are our companies' products highly complementary, but our cultures
are as well.  We share an intense customer focus.  We both emphasize speed
to market, agility, and teamwork to keep pace with customer needs and stay
ahead of the curve.

As an Advantage Partner, you will continue to hear a lot more from us about
the exciting prospects for the business in the next few months.  As always,
you will continue to receive regular updates from us on new developments
with Advantage.  We remain dedicated to providing the quality products,
customer service, and support that you have come to expect from Extended
Systems.

For more detailed information on the Palm acquisition, visit
www.extendedsystems.com.  If you have any further questions, feel free to
contact your Advantage Sales Representative.

We look forward to continuing to serve your data management needs and
appreciate your ongoing support and feedback.

Best regards,

The Advantage Team

From harbour@lists.harbour-project.org  Wed Mar  7 23:27:36 2001
From: harbour@lists.harbour-project.org (Phil Barnett)
Date: Wed Mar  7 23:27:36 2001
Subject: [Harbour] GPL + Exception -> Legal Interpretation
In-Reply-To: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKMEFCDKAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>
References: <3AA5F8E3.31892.B7F06D6@localhost>
Message-ID: <3AA6C39B.6571.E96E58E@localhost>

On 7 Mar 2001, at 7:54, Ron Pinkas wrote:

> Phil,
> 
> > > Which is nonsense, because the Harbour Exception very clearly removes
> > > *one* restriction and *only* one restriction and only under *limited*
> > > circumstances.
> >
> > I might agree that it is a dual license, not a modified GPL. You
> > have a choice which one you use.
> 
> Not so!
> 
> 1. The Exception does not mention any choice (other then the effective
> Version No. of the GPL).
> 2. Even if it did, this new multiple choice agreement, would have been
> legally considered a new modified License.
> 
> When you say:
> 
> ,-----------------------
> | This program is free software; you can redistribute it and/or modify
> | it under the terms of the GNU General Public License as published by
> | the Free Software Foundation; either version 2 of the License, or
> | (at your option) any later version, with one exception:
> `------------------------             ^^^^ ^^^ ^^^^^^^^^
> 
> You just created a new modified license! Surely you must understand it is no
> longer the GPL right?
> 
> Phil, I trust people will not doubt your objectivity, any chance you
> yourself might check this with a legal expert?

I think I have read enough copyright background on software to 
make a relatively well educated statement, and I don't have time or 
money to persue what would no doubt be expensive legal copyright 
expertise.

Anything that is not GPL does not necessarily meand it's a 
modified GPL.

But it's something. A second license where you can ignore the 
GPL for specific instances if you so wish.

The fact is that you are not required to use the exception unless 
you choose to do so, so the real GPL is in force and unmodified if 
you so choose.

That's why I think we should be thinking towards a dual license 
situation.

1. The result of Harbour compiler output in executable form is GPL 
if you wish.

2. The result if Harbour compiler in executable form is not GPL if 
you wish ... if and only if certain rules are followed.

To me, that is not a modified GPL, it's a choice between a very 
restrictive license (GPL) and a very non restrictive license (Harbour 
License) that has no bearing on the first choice and does nothing 
to negate that choice.


-- 
              Phil Barnett  mailto:midnight@the-oasis.net
                       WWW  http://www.the-oasis.net/
                  FTP Site  ftp://ftp.the-oasis.net

From harbour@lists.harbour-project.org  Wed Mar  7 23:27:56 2001
From: harbour@lists.harbour-project.org (Phil Barnett)
Date: Wed Mar  7 23:27:56 2001
Subject: [Harbour] GPL + Exception -> Legal Interpretation
In-Reply-To: <20010307143857.S5326@hagbard.davep.org>
References: <3AA5F8E3.31892.B7F06D6@localhost>; from midnight@the-oasis.net on Wed, Mar 07, 2001 at 09:01:23AM -0500
Message-ID: <3AA6C39A.885.E96E462@localhost>

On 7 Mar 2001, at 14:38, Dave Pearson wrote:

> On Wed, Mar 07, 2001 at 09:01:23AM -0500, Phil Barnett wrote:
> > On 5 Mar 2001, at 14:04, David G. Holm wrote:
> > 
> > > Which is nonsense, because the Harbour Exception very clearly removes
> > > *one* restriction and *only* one restriction and only under *limited*
> > > circumstances.
> > 
> > I might agree that it is a dual license, not a modified GPL. You have a
> > choice which one you use.
> 
> That's an interesting way of looking at it. The obvious question is that if
> it's a *dual* licence what are the two licences that you get to choose from?
> On the one hand you've got the GPL, anyone electing to use harbour to
> develop free software gets to choose a GPL compatible free software licence
> and they must distribute the package as a whole under the GPL.
> 
> On the other hand there's a "licence" that you need to observe if you're
> writing non-free software. What Ron and his legal advisor seem to be saying
> is that although the GPL hasn't been modified in any "real world" sense it
> is modified in a legal sense and so this is, legally (in the US at least),
> presented as a licence in it's own right which is either a modified GPL or
> is, at least, based on the GPL (or something, I'm still a bit confused about
> what the real case is here).
> 
> So, what is the licence on the "other hand"?

The 'Harbour Exception' license, which states that under certain 
specific circumstances, you can elect to not inherit the GPL.


-- 
              Phil Barnett  mailto:midnight@the-oasis.net
                       WWW  http://www.the-oasis.net/
                  FTP Site  ftp://ftp.the-oasis.net

From harbour@lists.harbour-project.org  Wed Mar  7 23:28:16 2001

From harbour@lists.harbour-project.org  Thu Mar  8 00:15:03 2001
From: harbour@lists.harbour-project.org (Phil Barnett)
Date: Thu Mar  8 00:15:03 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Mailing List backup.
Message-ID: <3AA6CEF0.11349.EC32B97@localhost>

Ok, with three long established members holding a usable copy of the mailing list, I feel that we have this covered. This should be used in the 
case of minor failure to contact everyone and let them know we know about the problem, or catastrophic failure to rebuild the membership on a 
new list server. (let's hope that's never necessary)

This script runs 1am, USA EST, Sunday morning, weekly.

Cron entry:

0 1 * * 0 /root/leaplist_grab_mail

Script:

#!/bin/bash

cd /home/mailman/bin
./list_members leaplist | mail -s "Leaplist membership weekly export" exec@lists.leap-cf.org
./list_members harbour | mail -s "Harbour membership weekly export" davep@davep.org
./list_members harbour | mail -s "Harbour membership weekly export" bhays@abacuslaw.com
./list_members harbour | mail -s "Harbour membership weekly export" catfood@underflap.com


-- 
              Phil Barnett  mailto:midnight@the-oasis.net
                       WWW  http://www.the-oasis.net/
                  FTP Site  ftp://ftp.the-oasis.net

From harbour@lists.harbour-project.org  Thu Mar  8 00:16:04 2001
From: harbour@lists.harbour-project.org (Ron Pinkas)
Date: Thu Mar  8 00:16:04 2001
Subject: [Harbour] GPL + Exception -> Legal Interpretation
In-Reply-To: <3AA6C39B.17298.E96E520@localhost>
Message-ID: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKOEGGDKAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>

Phil,

> I think I have read enough copyright background on software to
> make a relatively well educated statement, and I don't have time or
> money to persue what would no doubt be expensive legal copyright
> expertise.
>
> Anything that is not GPL does not necessarily meand it's a
> modified GPL.

Of course not.

> But it's something. A second license where you can ignore the
> GPL for specific instances if you so wish.

Regardless of the number of choices one is given, any software is only
covered by one License. The compounded sum of all the terms is referred to
as the Software License.

> The fact is that you are not required to use the exception unless
> you choose to do so, so the real GPL is in force and unmodified if
> you so choose.

There is no wording in the Exception that describes such a choice.

> That's why I think we should be thinking towards a dual license
> situation.
>
> 1. The result of Harbour compiler output in executable form is GPL
> if you wish.

We don't have to do this. Any one can distribute what ever software he owns
as GPL. If one is not "forced" to use GPL, he has the right to do so,
without us having to say so.

> 2. The result if Harbour compiler in executable form is not GPL if
> you wish ... if and only if certain rules are followed.

Right, we "just" need to define those rules...

> To me, that is not a modified GPL, it's a choice between a very
> restrictive license (GPL) and a very non restrictive license (Harbour
> License) that has no bearing on the first choice and does nothing
> to negate that choice.

The sum of (global/whole/composite) Harbour License is *not* the GPL. My
attorney referred to it as a "modified GPL", because it is based on the GPL
but it is not *the* GPL. He actually called "amended GPL".

Ron

From harbour@lists.harbour-project.org  Thu Mar  8 00:20:02 2001
From: harbour@lists.harbour-project.org (Ron Pinkas)
Date: Thu Mar  8 00:20:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Bug with oError:args as received by an error handler
In-Reply-To: <3AA6843B.7714.1C69FD5@localhost>
Message-ID: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKGEGHDKAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>

Ryszard, Dave,

After re-reading Victor's input and Ryszard's input, it seems we can take
advantage of all the input as follows:

1. Create a new hb_MakeArray() based on hb_errPutArgs() as follows:

//-------------------------------------------------------------//
PHB_ITEM hb_MakeArray( USHORT uiArgCount, ... )
{
   PHB_ITEM pArray;
   USHORT uiArgPos;
   va_list va;

   HB_TRACE(HB_TR_DEBUG, ("hb_MakeArray(%hu, ...)", uiArgCount));

   pArray = hb_itemArrayNew( uiArgCount );

   /* Build the array from the passed arguments. */

   va_start( va, uiArgCount );
   for( uiArgPos = 1; uiArgPos <= uiArgCount; uiArgPos++ )
      hb_itemArrayPut( pArray, uiArgPos, va_arg( va, PHB_ITEM ) );
   va_end( va );

   return pArray;
}
//-------------------------------------------------------------//

2. Change hb_errRT_BASE() to accept 5th PHB_ITEM parameter, so that we call
it as follows:

  hb_errRT_BASE( EG_STROVERFLOW, 1209, NULL, "+", hb_MakeArray( 2, pItem1,
pItem2 ) );

3. hb_errRTBASE() will also be modified to forward the array to
hb_errRT_New(), and later release the Array Item.

This should address all concerns, regarding ease of use, size,
susceptibility to errors, caller stack requirements, and it is still a one
liner. Best of all we don't have to create multiple versions of
hb_errRT_BASE() and hb_errRT_New().

Ron

>   I think the the choise is simple: we will have to add either a code to
> create an array of arguments in all places where errors are generated or
> call hb_errPutArgs() with these arguments. The first solution will
> produce bigger executables and will be much more error prone since
> building an array is not a single function call. We can create some macro
> for it but we have hb_errPutArgs() function for this purpose already.
>
> Regards, Ryszard


From harbour@lists.harbour-project.org  Thu Mar  8 00:46:02 2001
From: harbour@lists.harbour-project.org (Ron Pinkas)
Date: Thu Mar  8 00:46:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] GPL + Exception -> Legal Interpretation
In-Reply-To: <3AA6C39B.17298.E96E520@localhost>

> > 2. I'm not a linker expert, but, I can't agree that linking will
> > necessarily "lose the library aspects". As an example, most of

> > agreed that a DLL is considered an executable, didn't we? Is there
> > anything stopping our "evil" from distributing the HVM and HRL in DLL
> > form, to serve its Harbour compatible pcode?
>
> Well, the long hand name for a DLL is Dynamically Linked
> LIBRARY, so I can't see how it would be considered an
> executable. It has no bootstrap.

1. I have some recollection of us referring to DLLs as executable (we
wouldn't be the first).
2. I have some recollection of us talking about allowing the HVM + HRL as a
DLL.
3. If we didn't allow it at all (non GPL), wouldn't it be too harsh a
restriction?

Ron

From harbour@lists.harbour-project.org  Thu Mar  8 01:10:03 2001
From: harbour@lists.harbour-project.org (Phil Barnett)
Date: Thu Mar  8 01:10:03 2001
Subject: [Harbour] GPL + Exception -> Legal Interpretation
In-Reply-To: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKAEGIDKAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>
References: <3AA6C39B.17298.E96E520@localhost>
Message-ID: <3AA6DBCD.29946.EF56ABC@localhost>

On 7 Mar 2001, at 21:43, Ron Pinkas wrote:

> Phil,
> 
> > > 2. I'm not a linker expert, but, I can't agree that linking will
> > > necessarily "lose the library aspects". As an example, most of
> > us already
> > > agreed that a DLL is considered an executable, didn't we? Is there
> > > anything stopping our "evil" from distributing the HVM and HRL in DLL
> > > form, to serve its Harbour compatible pcode?
> >
> > Well, the long hand name for a DLL is Dynamically Linked
> > LIBRARY, so I can't see how it would be considered an
> > executable. It has no bootstrap.
> 
> 1. I have some recollection of us referring to DLLs as executable (we
> wouldn't be the first).
> 2. I have some recollection of us talking about allowing the HVM + HRL as a
> DLL.
> 3. If we didn't allow it at all (non GPL), wouldn't it be too harsh a
> restriction?

What .DLL's do isn't up to us to decide.

A library is a block of objects ready for a linker to include when 
referenced.

A DLL is a block of objects ready for dynamic linking at runtime.

What has this got to do with the Harbour Exception except 
_when_?

We don't have a 'when clause', do we?


-- 
              Phil Barnett  mailto:midnight@the-oasis.net
                       WWW  http://www.the-oasis.net/
                  FTP Site  ftp://ftp.the-oasis.net

From harbour@lists.harbour-project.org  Thu Mar  8 01:17:02 2001
From: harbour@lists.harbour-project.org (Ron Pinkas)
Date: Thu Mar  8 01:17:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] GPL + Exception -> Legal Interpretation
In-Reply-To: <3AA6C39B.17298.E96E520@localhost>
Message-ID: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKOEGIDKAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>

Phil,

> > 2. I'm not a linker expert, but, I can't agree that linking will
> > necessarily "lose the library aspects". As an example, most of
> us already
> > agreed that a DLL is considered an executable, didn't we? Is there
> > anything stopping our "evil" from distributing the HVM and HRL in DLL
> > form, to serve its Harbour compatible pcode?
>
> Well, the long hand name for a DLL is Dynamically Linked
> LIBRARY, so I can't see how it would be considered an
> executable. It has no bootstrap.

BTW, our exception reads "if you link" not "if you [static] link", it read
"on account of linking" not "on account of static linking". I believe it's
fait to say that Dynamic Linking an executable is still nothing more than
linking, and that a DLL in this configuration is an integral part of this
executable.

Ron

From harbour@lists.harbour-project.org  Thu Mar  8 05:34:02 2001
From: harbour@lists.harbour-project.org (John Skelton)
Date: Thu Mar  8 05:34:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] GPL + Exception -> Legal Interpretation
Message-ID: <200103080532_MC2-C811-C2EB@compuserve.com>

Ron,

> I never said I link anything extra, I said the exact opposite

Then you failed to make yourself clear throughout a very long thread
of many messages. :-(

> Take instead the DLL scenario

If only you'd raised it sooner. :-)

> This DLL is still excused by the Exception, right?

I don't know for sure.  The license doesn't define executable.  A DLL
is not in some senses an executable, yet in other senses it is.  But
it's mainly a Library (the final L in DLL).  I believe people here
intended to allow a DLL, in which case the "evil" linker _may_ be
allowed.  I think it's not, because of this:

In the case where HVM/HRL is/are in a DLL, the executable is _not_
the DLL, it is instead the combination of the non-DLL _and_ the DLL.

The "evil" linker would be performing actions (joining Harbour
compiler output to the DLL) to create an executable, and those actions
are (as before with a LIB) clearly being done in an attempt to bypass
the license, and so it's still an abuse with which a court should be
able to deal.

John.

From harbour@lists.harbour-project.org  Thu Mar  8 05:34:18 2001
From: harbour@lists.harbour-project.org (John Skelton)
Date: Thu Mar  8 05:34:18 2001
Subject: [Harbour] GPL + Exception -> Legal Interpretation
Message-ID: <200103080532_MC2-C811-C2ED@compuserve.com>

Ron,

> I never stated the LIBs linked to my example linker, are in any
> specific form.

It doesn't matter what form - they're GPL (_not_ Harbour Exception).

> > It does _not_ release all restrictions in the way you say.

> It doesn't matter, what I, or you, say or think, in this matter.

After a vast number of messages from many people you say that!  Well,
if it was factually accurate that would be bad because it would mean
so many people have wasted their time, but fortunately I don't see it
as being accurate.  At least, it's as true about us as it is about
your lawyer.  In a sense it could be said that all that would matter
would be a court's (possibly appealed, re-appealed etc) decision.  And
even then no doubt any specific action would have specific details so
that it might take many cases, in each of many jurisdictions, before
we really know.  Until then, your comment above strikes me as
pointless.

> > It also includes the HRL/HVM code in a LIB (or equivalent) form, in
> > what is a blatant attempt to bypass the license.  Courts can deal
> > with such abuses.

> Again, I never specified any form, neither does our exception.

The exact form doesn't matter.  Especially to a court, where the
issues would have to be explained.

> > > Since "this does not by itself cause the resulting executable
> > to be covered
> > > by the GNU General Public License" what did?
> >
> > Including those LIBs.

> Which is the exact opposite of the Exception text.

So?  That's what I said: the "evil" linker is an obvious abuse.  A
court could deal with that.  _We_ could deal with it in NGs etc by
exposing the "evil" person.  We probably could _not_ afford the court
case, however. :-(

John.

[Re-sent]

Ron,

> 1. Expert, does not need to be in quotes, he is an experienced attorney=

> specializing in intellectual properties, thus expert in this context.

Er... there are many types of intellectual properties.  Is he
specifically an expert on _software_ _copyright_?  (That's copyright in
the context of software.)

> 2. Assuming he "obviously misread" is unwise, regardless of the number =
of
> the unqualified individuals disagreeing with his opinion.

He appears to have misread (inserting a comma that isn't there).  You
say he says he hasn't so misread, but have not provided any details
of how the license can be construed the way he says.  So, at the
moment he looks wrong.  I'm open to persuasion if you'll post his
explanation of how he can interpret that sentence the way he does,
bearing in mind that the comma concerned is absent.

If his explanation is along the lines of the comma not needing to be
there from a legal POV (for whatever reason), please at the same time
ask him how to change that sentence to mean what it means in English
(which is where the comma would make a vital difference).

John.

From harbour@lists.harbour-project.org  Thu Mar  8 11:20:04 2001
From: harbour@lists.harbour-project.org (David G. Holm)
Date: Thu Mar  8 11:20:04 2001
Subject: [Harbour] GPL + Exception -> Legal Interpretation
In-Reply-To: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKOEGIDKAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>
References: <3AA6C39B.17298.E96E520@localhost>
Message-ID: <200103081619.f28GJ6a10819@smtp.parrett.net>

** Reply to message from "Ron Pinkas" <Ron@Profit-Master.com> on Wed, 7
Mar 2001 22:14:35 -0800

> BTW, our exception reads "if you link" not "if you [static] link", it read
> "on account of linking" not "on account of static linking". I believe it's
> fait to say that Dynamic Linking an executable is still nothing more than
> linking, and that a DLL in this configuration is an integral part of this
> executable.

The intent of the Harbour Exception to allow both static and dynamic
linking, which is why the type of linking is not specified.
-- 
David G. Holm, Set Captain and all around
Harbour Project Clipper Compatibility fanatic.

From harbour@lists.harbour-project.org  Thu Mar  8 11:48:02 2001

Subject: [Harbour] GPL + Exception -> Legal Interpretation
In-Reply-To: <200103081619.f28GJ6a10819@smtp.parrett.net>
Message-ID: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKKEGMDKAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>

David,

> > BTW, our exception reads "if you link" not "if you [static] 
> link", it read
> > "on account of linking" not "on account of static linking". I 
> believe it's
> > fait to say that Dynamic Linking an executable is still nothing 
> more than

> > executable.
> 
> The intent of the Harbour Exception to allow both static and dynamic
> linking, which is why the type of linking is not specified.

Do you now see the validity of my "evil" scenario concern?

Ron

From harbour@lists.harbour-project.org  Thu Mar  8 11:49:02 2001
From: harbour@lists.harbour-project.org (Ron Pinkas)
Date: Thu Mar  8 11:49:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] GPL + Exception -> Legal Interpretation
In-Reply-To: <200103081056_MC2-C821-28A0@compuserve.com>
Message-ID: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKMEGMDKAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>

> > 1. Expert, does not need to be in quotes, he is an experienced attorney
> > specializing in intellectual properties, thus expert in this context.

> Er... there are many types of intellectual properties.  Is he
> specifically an expert on _software_ _copyright_?  (That's copyright in
> the context of software.)

Yes he specializes in software copyright. He negotiated my Software License
Agreement with SEARS who uses my software in all there US Carpet Cleaning
Operations. I have been using his excellent services for about 3 years.

> number of
> > the unqualified individuals disagreeing with his opinion.
