From harbour@lists.harbour-project.org  Thu Mar  8 12:35:02 2001
From: harbour@lists.harbour-project.org (David G. Holm)
Date: Thu Mar  8 12:35:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] GPL + Exception -> Legal Interpretation
In-Reply-To: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKKEGMDKAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>
References: <200103081619.f28GJ6a10819@smtp.parrett.net>
Message-ID: <200103081734.f28HY5a19347@smtp.parrett.net>

** Reply to message from "Ron Pinkas" <Ron@Profit-Master.com> on Thu, 8
Mar 2001 08:45:07 -0800

> > The intent of the Harbour Exception to allow both static and dynamic
> > linking, which is why the type of linking is not specified.
> 
> Do you now see the validity of my "evil" scenario concern?

No, because regardless of how the "evil linker" and the HRL/HVM
libraries are distributed, either the linker or the HRL/HVM libraries
will have to be distributed under the GPL (or a compatible license),
because even if the HRL/HVM is distributed only as a single set of DLLs,
which both the "evil linker" and the programs that it links will use,
the DLLs are serving a dual purpose, one of which is a binary
distribution, so the Harbour Exception would not apply to the DLLs and
they would have to be distributed under the GPL (o.a.c.l.). So if the
linker and the DLLs were distributed together, then the linker would
also have to be distributed under the GPL (o.a.c.l.). I'm not sure if
the GPL would allow those DLLs to be released as a standalone
distribution, so if the author of the "evil linker" doesn't want to
release the linker under the GPL (o.a.c.l.), he will probably have to
make available a binary distribution of Harbour that contains the DLLs,
so there would be no doubt as to what free software the "evil linker"
author is legally using.
-- 
David G. Holm, Set Captain and all around
Harbour Project Clipper Compatibility fanatic.

From harbour@lists.harbour-project.org  Thu Mar  8 12:51:00 2001
From: harbour@lists.harbour-project.org (Ron Pinkas)
Date: Thu Mar  8 12:51:00 2001
Subject: [Harbour] GPL + Exception -> Legal Interpretation
In-Reply-To: <200103081734.f28HY5a19347@smtp.parrett.net>
Message-ID: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKMEGNDKAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>

David,

> > Do you now see the validity of my "evil" scenario concern?
>
> No, because regardless of how the "evil linker" and the HRL/HVM
> libraries are distributed, either the linker or the HRL/HVM libraries
> will have to be distributed under the GPL (or a compatible license),
> because even if the HRL/HVM is distributed only as a single set of DLLs,
> which both the "evil linker" and the programs that it links will use,
> the DLLs are serving a dual purpose, one of which is a binary
> distribution, so the Harbour Exception would not apply to the DLLs and
> they would have to be distributed under the GPL (o.a.c.l.). So if the
> linker and the DLLs were distributed together, then the linker would
> also have to be distributed under the GPL (o.a.c.l.). I'm not sure if
> the GPL would allow those DLLs to be released as a standalone
> distribution, so if the author of the "evil linker" doesn't want to
> release the linker under the GPL (o.a.c.l.), he will probably have to
> make available a binary distribution of Harbour that contains the DLLs,
> so there would be no doubt as to what free software the "evil linker"
> author is legally using.

I can't see how you arrive at this, and my attorney specifically explained,
that if we don't qualify "if you link" and "on account of linking" then it
is simply left open.

The exception specifically allows (non GPL) distribution of the HVM and HRL,
*if* this distribution is in the form of "linking it with other files to
produce an executable". My scenario falls neatly under this allowance.

This double purpose you talk about has no support, in the Exception. My
"Evil" did *no* *more* then "linking it with other files to produce an
executable". Our Exception does *not* say how many purposes such link is
allowed to have.

Ron

From harbour@lists.harbour-project.org  Thu Mar  8 13:18:00 2001
From: harbour@lists.harbour-project.org (David G. Holm)
Date: Thu Mar  8 13:18:00 2001
Subject: [Harbour] GPL + Exception -> Legal Interpretation
In-Reply-To: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKMEGNDKAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>
References: <200103081734.f28HY5a19347@smtp.parrett.net>
Message-ID: <200103081817.f28IHea24043@smtp.parrett.net>

** Reply to message from "Ron Pinkas" <Ron@Profit-Master.com> on Thu, 8
Mar 2001 09:48:30 -0800

> I can't see how you arrive at this, and my attorney specifically explained,
> that if we don't qualify "if you link" and "on account of linking" then it
> is simply left open.

But it *is* qualified, by the fragment that reads, "this does not by
itself", which means that other factors could restrict the resulting
executable.

And the sentence that reads "Your use of that executable is in no way
restricted on account of linking the HRL and/or HVM code into it," does
not mean that if you link the HRL and/or HVM code into your executable,
your executable is not restricted by any terms of the GPL. What it
actually means is that linking the HRL and/or HVM code into your
executable does not invoke the GPL restrictions on what you can do with
the executable.

Seeing as how your attorney has misread the Harbour Exception, it is
quite likely that some other attorneys will also misread it. This means
that we need to reword the Harbour Exception. Not in order to change
what it means, but to try to reduce the possibility that folks with a
legalistic mind-set will read into it things that it most definitely
does not say.
-- 
David G. Holm, Set Captain and all around
Harbour Project Clipper Compatibility fanatic.

From harbour@lists.harbour-project.org  Thu Mar  8 13:20:02 2001

> What it actually means is that linking the HRL and/or HVM code into your
> executable does not invoke the GPL restrictions on what you can do with
> the executable.

But other things still could...

David G. Holm, Set Captain and all around

From harbour@lists.harbour-project.org  Thu Mar  8 14:53:00 2001
From: harbour@lists.harbour-project.org (David G. Holm)
Date: Thu Mar  8 14:53:00 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Proposed Rewording of the Harbour License
Message-ID: <200103081951.f28Jpua01849@smtp.parrett.net>

As it turns out, the Harbour Exception consist of only a small
section of the actual Guile Exception to the GNU GPL. I have
just today obtained a full copy of the Guile License, which I
have adapted to refer to Harbour and the Harbour Project and
would become the new content of doc/license.txt, if approved
(and would also be included in doc/hdr_tpl.txt, minus the
first paragraph):

The license of Harbour consists of the GNU GPL plus a special statement
giving blanket permission to link with non-free software.  This is the
license statement as found in any individual file that it applies to:

 This program is free software; you can redistribute it and/or modify
 it under the terms of the GNU General Public License as published by
 the Free Software Foundation; either version 2, or (at your option)
 any later version.

 This program is distributed in the hope that it will be useful,
 but WITHOUT ANY WARRANTY; without even the implied warranty of
 MERCHANTABILITY or FITNESS FOR A PARTICULAR PURPOSE.  See the
 GNU General Public License for more details.

 You should have received a copy of the GNU General Public License
 along with this software; see the file COPYING.  If not, write to
 the Free Software Foundation, Inc., 59 Temple Place, Suite 330,
 Boston, MA 02111-1307 USA (or visit the web site http://www.gnu.org/).

 As a special exception, the Harbour Project gives permission for
 additional uses of the text contained in its release of Harbour.

 The exception is that, if you link the Harbour libraries with other
 files to produce an executable, this does not by itself cause the
 resulting executable to be covered by the GNU General Public License.
 Your use of that executable is in no way restricted on account of
 linking the Harbour library code into it.

 This exception does not however invalidate any other reasons why
 the executable file might be covered by the GNU General Public License.

 This exception applies only to the code released by the Harbour
 Project under the name Harbour.  If you copy code from other
 Harbour Project or Free Software Foundation releases into a copy of
 Harbour, as the General Public License permits, the exception does
 not apply to the code that you add in this way.  To avoid misleading
 anyone as to the status of such modified files, you must delete
 this exception notice from them.

 If you write modifications of your own for Harbour, it is your choice
 whether to permit this exception to apply to your modifications.
 If you do not wish that, delete this exception notice.
-- 
David G. Holm, Set Captain and all around
Harbour Project Clipper Compatibility fanatic.

From harbour@lists.harbour-project.org  Thu Mar  8 19:06:01 2001

Subject: [Harbour] GPL + Exception -> Legal Interpretation
Message-ID: <200103081904_MC2-C82E-51C9@compuserve.com>

Ron,

> he specializes in software copyright

Did you say exactly that at the start?

> > He appears to have misread (inserting a comma that isn't there).  You=

> > say he says he hasn't so misread, but have not provided any details
> > of how the license can be construed the way he says.  So, at the
> > moment he looks wrong.  I'm open to persuasion if you'll post his
> > explanation of how he can interpret that sentence the way he does,
> > bearing in mind that the comma concerned is absent.

> John, please excuse me for saying so, but I really don't think you are
> qualified to evaluate the correctness of his legal ability. I said nume=
rous
> times already, that he never considered a comma, that *you* think needs=
 to
> be there for him to be right.

I don't see the explanation I asked for. :-(

Let's get this straight.  For normal English that comma matters.  I do
hope neither you nor he disagrees.  That leads on to what I wrote
before, i.e. asking how it can be read that way from a legal POV and
how to fix it (see below).

> Please clarify what specific portion of his description you don't agree=

> with, and I'll try to get a clarification.

You've just repeated it!  Also, that a DLL is not in itself an
executable.

I don't _really_ want a "clarification".  I want the license fixing if
it's broken. :-)

> > If his explanation is along the lines of the comma not needing to be
> > there from a legal POV (for whatever reason), please at the same time=

> > ask him how to change that sentence to mean what it means in English
> > (which is where the comma would make a vital difference).

> I'm not sure what meaning you think it has.

What it says.  It's not complex; what did you not understand in it,
especially bearing in mind I've explained this more than once and you
appeared to understand it.

I see no point in carrying on the way we are.  The whole process is
a bit like the Harbour team made a PRG which works for all of them,
then someone (you) took it to an expert in another Xbase dialect (your
lawyer).  He compiled it with his Xbase dialect but it goes wrong in
some way.  He doesn't say exactly what and we can only find out hints
(at best) through you.  He may or may not have a fix but has not said.
Frankly it's no way to diagnose a bug let alone fix it.

I've explained that a DLL is not an executable.  I've explained the
English meaning of the license in the absence of that comma.  I've
asked how it is that it can be read to mean something else.  I've
asked for a rewording of the license by your lawyer so it means what
we meant (and what I read it to mean already - using English, but we
need legalese).  Now it's time your lawyer addressed these issues so
that we get the license we thought we had.

Failing that, I see no way forward and we should drop the thread.  If
we do that, at worst it appears the license is too free; let's try to
live with it.  Better to be too open than too closed.

John.

From harbour@lists.harbour-project.org  Thu Mar  8 22:13:02 2001
From: harbour@lists.harbour-project.org (Ron Pinkas)
Date: Thu Mar  8 22:13:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] GPL + Exception -> Legal Interpretation
In-Reply-To: <200103081904_MC2-C82E-51C9@compuserve.com>
Message-ID: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKIEHBDKAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>

John,

> > he specializes in software copyright
>
> Did you say exactly that at the start?

Sorry, no one asked what he specializes in (before you did). I assumed that
was clear from the fact that he was my attorney and deals with IP. I
wouldn't have seek his advise if that was not his field.

> Let's get this straight.  For normal English that comma matters.  I do
> hope neither you nor he disagrees.  That leads on to what I wrote
> before, i.e. asking how it can be read that way from a legal POV and
> how to fix it (see below).

John, the problem you find with his interpretation is not related to the use
of a comma.

I really am not sure why you think that reading the Exception "in English"
should yield different understanding. Let me try and go over the paragraph
and explain his input one final time:

 * The exception is that if you link the Harbour Runtime Library (HRL)
 * and/or the Harbour Virtual Machine (HVM) with other files to produce
 * an executable, this does not by itself cause the resulting executable
 * to be covered by the GNU General Public License. Your use of that
 * executable is in no way restricted on account of linking the HRL
 * and/or HVM code into it.

The first sentence "if you link ... this doesn't by itself ...", reads in
English:

,----------------------------------------------
| as long as your executable does not borrow
| more than the specified excluded components,
| it is not covered by the GPL.
`----------------------------------------------

The 2nd, sentence, "Your use ... is in mo way restricted on account of ..."
reads in English:

,----------------------------------------------
| if your executable does not borrow any other
| code outside of the excluded components, then
| your use of the executable is not restricted
| in any way.
`----------------------------------------------

Do you claim that these "interpretations" are not consistent with the
English Language?

> > Please clarify what specific portion of his description you don't agree
> > with, and I'll try to get a clarification.
>
> You've just repeated it!  Also, that a DLL is not in itself an
> executable.

Dynamic Linking is a form of linking, and the linked DLL becomes integral
part of the executable by means of the link. Obviously the executable is not
complete without the linked DLL.

> I don't _really_ want a "clarification".  I want the license fixing if
> it's broken. :-)

It depends on our definition for broken. I believe that the Exception,
should make it clear that we allow the HVM and/or HRL to be excluded
(excused from forcing GPL), *only* if the executable is indeed an Harbour
application. This can easily be fixed.

> > > If his explanation is along the lines of the comma not needing to be
> > > there from a legal POV (for whatever reason), please at the same time
> > > ask him how to change that sentence to mean what it means in English
> > > (which is where the comma would make a vital difference).

I hope it's now clear the problem has nothing to do with the comma. The
problem is with the lack of any qualification on what "deserves" to be
linked with the HVM and/or HRL and still be excused from the GPL.

> > I'm not sure what meaning you think it has.
>
> What it says.  It's not complex; what did you not understand in it,
> especially bearing in mind I've explained this more than once and you
> appeared to understand it.

Sorry for upsetting you. If you don't agree with the above interpretation,
we might still be at the exact same point, and I could ask you the exact
same question :-(. I sure hope this is not the case.

Ron

From harbour@lists.harbour-project.org  Fri Mar  9 05:48:02 2001
From: harbour@lists.harbour-project.org (John Skelton)
Date: Fri Mar  9 05:48:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] GPL + Exception -> Legal Interpretation
Message-ID: <200103090547_MC2-C839-F8E4@compuserve.com>

Ron,

> the problem you find with his interpretation is not related to the use
> of a comma.

It's taken a long time to find that out. :-(

> The first sentence "if you link ... this doesn't by itself ...", reads =
in
> English:
> =

> | as long as your executable does not borrow
> | more than the specified excluded components,
> | it is not covered by the GPL.

I don't agree, but I think maybe it turns on the word "link".  I think
the H.proj. meant it in the sense of what a linker does.  Unfortunately
it can have the wider English meaning.

Using the intended meaning (bear with me) I think your re-write is
incorrect.  If so, (part of) the fix is (*) to make clear what "link"
meaning is intended.

(*) may be; see what others here say and what your lawyer says

IAC, strictly your version and the original are different (because
yours only covers a subset) but I'm pretty sure that difference is
not your point and is just an outcome of "translating" the word "link".

> The 2nd, sentence, "Your use ... is in mo way restricted on account of =
..."
> reads in English:
> =

> | if your executable does not borrow any other
> | code outside of the excluded components, then
> | your use of the executable is not restricted
> | in any way.

Strictly, as before, it doesn't mean that.  That diff. matters but
let's work on "link"/"linking".

> Do you claim that these "interpretations" are not consistent with the
> English Language?

Yes.

> Dynamic Linking is a form of linking, and the linked DLL becomes integr=
al
> part of the executable by means of the link. Obviously the executable i=
s not
> complete without the linked DLL.

Quite.

> > I don't _really_ want a "clarification".  I want the license fixing i=
f
> > it's broken. :-)

> I believe that the Exception, should make it clear that we allow the
> HVM and/or HRL to be excluded (excused from forcing GPL), *only* if
> the executable is indeed an Harbour application. This can easily be
> fixed.

I'm not sure it can.  The "evil" linker looks like a Harbour app.

> I hope it's now clear the problem has nothing to do with the comma.

If you (& your lawyer <g>) say not, fine.

> The problem is with the lack of any qualification on what "deserves"
> to be linked with the HVM and/or HRL and still be excused from the
> GPL.

Given my comments above, I don't see any such problem.  We probably
have to define what "link" means, that's all.

> Sorry for upsetting you.

I'm not upset - sorry if it seems so.  "Frustrated" would be a better
word - due to slow (almost no!) progress despite the flood of messages.

Er... even so, I hope we could be "upset" from time to time but not
bear any grudges. :-)  You know: fall out 3 times a day but not on a
permanent basis. :-) :-)

> If you don't agree with the above interpretation

Basically I don't, but I think the "link" issue is the main one.

In view of people's differing shades of meanng about DLLs / shared
libs (and there are prob. other names, too) it might be useful to
clarify that such a thing is not by itself an executable.  And perhaps
(probably?) also in what context an HVM/HRL lib can be used (which is
probably only with a Harbour compiler-derived executable).

John.

From harbour@lists.harbour-project.org  Fri Mar  9 09:00:04 2001
From: harbour@lists.harbour-project.org (Juan Agustin Barriga)
Date: Fri Mar  9 09:00:04 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Fw: Copy to Problem
References: <005401c0a819$9216f240$f5d4d7c8@culik>
Message-ID: <000901c0a8a8$eba20590$c06410ac@jharrier>

Well... as I have been stating since I wrote APPEND FROM/COPY TO, the latter
is NOT creating the output file. This is because I think we need an RDDNode
level function to check file existance. UNLESS COPY TO should just go out
and create the table, even if it exists..., but then we neen a DropTable
which is not available. All this takes me back to my proposal (which has
never been commented) on adding to the RDDNode level three "virtual"
functions (that each RDD shoul provide), namely : CreateTable, DropTable &
TableExists.
With this functionality everythisng should work fine on enviroments where
tables are abstract entities and not files. I also commented that the
current implementation of dbCreate() (and Clipper's) is a hack on dbOpen()
and not an independent functionality.

Anybody has something to say?
Regards
Harrier

John,

> > The first sentence "if you link ... this doesn't by itself
> ...", reads in
> > English:
> >
> > | as long as your executable does not borrow
> > | more than the specified excluded components,
> > | it is not covered by the GPL.
>
> I don't agree, but I think maybe it turns on the word "link".  I think
> the H.proj. meant it in the sense of what a linker does.  Unfortunately
> it can have the wider English meaning.
>
> Using the intended meaning (bear with me) I think your re-write is
> incorrect.  If so, (part of) the fix is (*) to make clear what "link"
> meaning is intended.
>
> (*) may be; see what others here say and what your lawyer says

I don't understand, what is the intended meaning in your opinion? Can you
please provide a small interpretation like I did? I have no clue how it can
be interpreted to say anything other than what it clearly does.

What meaning of link my interpretation was using, that is different than
what link is? My Interpretation could easily read:

,--------------------------------------------
| as long as your executable does not link in
| more than the specified excluded components,
| it is not covered by the GPL.
`--------------------------------------------

Now that the word link is not interpreted, does it change my interpretation?
What would be wrong with the above interpretation? Actually I used borrow
because it has wider scope than link. My attorney used the term "rely". He
said as long as the Executable, doesn't rely on other Harbour code.

> IAC, strictly your version and the original are different (because
> yours only covers a subset) but I'm pretty sure that difference is
> not your point and is just an outcome of "translating" the word "link".

John, please believe me I have no clue what difference you are talking
about. If I describe only a subset, it means I dropped something, what did I
drop?

> > The 2nd, sentence, "Your use ... is in mo way restricted on
> account of ..."
> > reads in English:
> >
> > | if your executable does not borrow any other
> > | code outside of the excluded components, then
> > | your use of the executable is not restricted
> > | in any way.
>
> Strictly, as before, it doesn't mean that.  That diff. matters but
> let's work on "link"/"linking".

I don't understand how can you read "on account of", or "this doesn't by
itself", to mean anything other then, "more is needed (to violate) - this
much is allowed"!!! If you agree with this, than what is "more" in this
context, of what *is* allowed?

> > I believe that the Exception, should make it clear that we allow the
> > HVM and/or HRL to be excluded (excused from forcing GPL), *only* if
> > the executable is indeed an Harbour application. This can easily be
> > fixed.
>
> I'm not sure it can.  The "evil" linker looks like a Harbour app.

No it isn't, Harbour Application involves the HVM executing pcode, compiled
by the Harbour compiler.

> > I hope it's now clear the problem has nothing to do with the comma.
>
> If you (& your lawyer <g>) say not, fine.

Do you still think we are reading some non existing comma?

> > The problem is with the lack of any qualification on what "deserves"
> > to be linked with the HVM and/or HRL and still be excused from the
> > GPL.
>
> Given my comments above, I don't see any such problem.  We probably
> have to define what "link" means, that's all.

Sorry I don't understand.

> > Sorry for upsetting you.

No. Software that is placed under the GNU GPL is *required* to include
a copy of the GNU GPL COPYING file. We haven't so far, which surprised
me, which is why I committed it. It still needs to be added to the
procedure that builds the source and binary distributions...

From harbour@lists.harbour-project.org  Fri Mar  9 14:03:02 2001
From: harbour@lists.harbour-project.org (Brian Hays)
Date: Fri Mar  9 14:03:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Fw: Copy to Problem
References: <005401c0a819$9216f240$f5d4d7c8@culik> <000901c0a8a8$eba20590$c06410ac@jharrier>
Message-ID: <005e01c0a8cc$5ea96b50$921a5e18@bh>

Harrier:
Actually there was one post by Bruno regarding that function.  At the time I
wasn't that familiar with the RDD and didn't know what to add.  But it seems
to me the cl*pper implementation used the Trans and TransRec methods to
transfer data between two different RDDs, and this was the gist of Bruno's
comment.  It would seem that it is the target RDD's responsibility to deal
with file creation.

The default behavior SHOULD always create a new file/table and destroy the
existing one; this is the documented behavior of COPY TO.  It expects that
the target is NOT in an open RDD workarea, and probably throws a sharing
error if it is.

If you want an option to move records to an open table, there will need to
be some parameter or global flag to allow that behavior.  Perhaps it would
be better to add a new command MOVE TO for this?  Or an extra clause in the
header to indicate that an ALIAS is being passed instead of a "file".  This
would make it clear that the programmer wants to move data between open
aliases instead of creating a new table.  If you want to append to an
existing but unopened file, then there needs to be a mechanism to call Open
instead of Create.  This could perhaps be as simple as handling a new
parameter in __dbCopy to create or open as necessary. The current code just
calls rddMoveRecords( ), but wouldn't it make sense to handle the table
opening before calling that?

Brian

From harbour@lists.harbour-project.org  Fri Mar  9 14:28:02 2001
From: harbour@lists.harbour-project.org (Juan Agustin Barriga)
Date: Fri Mar  9 14:28:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Fw: Copy to Problem
References: <005401c0a819$9216f240$f5d4d7c8@culik> <000901c0a8a8$eba20590$c06410ac@jharrier> <005e01c0a8cc$5ea96b50$921a5e18@bh>
Message-ID: <003901c0a8d6$be619db0$c06410ac@jharrier>

I partially agree. Trans & TransRec are NOT mandatory on RDD implementation
(I never did them on Clipper) so I assume they do the GETVALUE/PUTVALUE
(rddMoveRecords could be the default). But that is not the point. Allthough
now I get the clarification that COPY TO should copy to a newly created
file, still we have the problem of not having an RDD level (abstract) to
check if a table exists, to delete it if it does, and to create a new one
(without calling Open). So my proposal to add these three functions to the
RDDNode so every RDD can put it's implementation there. The actual dbCreate
shoud be derived to that function and out of a hacjed Open.

Regards
Harrier

----- Original Message -----
From: "Brian Hays" <bhays@abacuslaw.com>

> Harrier:

I
> wasn't that familiar with the RDD and didn't know what to add.  But it
seems
> to me the cl*pper implementation used the Trans and TransRec methods to
> transfer data between two different RDDs, and this was the gist of Bruno's
> comment.  It would seem that it is the target RDD's responsibility to deal
> with file creation.
>
> The default behavior SHOULD always create a new file/table and destroy the
> existing one; this is the documented behavior of COPY TO.  It expects that
> the target is NOT in an open RDD workarea, and probably throws a sharing
> error if it is.
>
> If you want an option to move records to an open table, there will need to
> be some parameter or global flag to allow that behavior.  Perhaps it would
> be better to add a new command MOVE TO for this?  Or an extra clause in
the
> header to indicate that an ALIAS is being passed instead of a "file".
This
> would make it clear that the programmer wants to move data between open
> aliases instead of creating a new table.  If you want to append to an
> existing but unopened file, then there needs to be a mechanism to call
Open
> instead of Create.  This could perhaps be as simple as handling a new
> parameter in __dbCopy to create or open as necessary. The current code
just
> calls rddMoveRecords( ), but wouldn't it make sense to handle the table
> opening before calling that?
>
> Brian
>
> ----- Original Message -----
> From: "Juan Agustin Barriga" <harrier@topconnect.cl>
> To: <harbour@lists.harbour-project.org>
> Sent: Friday, March 09, 2001 6:54 AM
> Subject: Re: [Harbour] Fw: Copy to Problem
>
>
> > Well... as I have been stating since I wrote APPEND FROM/COPY TO, the
> latter
> > is NOT creating the output file. This is because I think we need an
> RDDNode
> > level function to check file existance. UNLESS COPY TO should just go
out
> > and create the table, even if it exists..., but then we neen a DropTable
> > which is not available. All this takes me back to my proposal (which has
> > never been commented) on adding to the RDDNode level three "virtual"
> > functions (that each RDD shoul provide), namely : CreateTable, DropTable
&
> > TableExists.
> > With this functionality everythisng should work fine on enviroments
where
> > tables are abstract entities and not files. I also commented that the
> > current implementation of dbCreate() (and Clipper's) is a hack on
dbOpen()
> > and not an independent functionality.
> >
> > Anybody has something to say?
> > Regards
> > Harrier

From harbour@lists.harbour-project.org  Fri Mar  9 20:37:02 2001
From: harbour@lists.harbour-project.org (Brian Hays)
Date: Fri Mar  9 20:37:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] NetErr()
Message-ID: <001401c0a903$7ef3d940$921a5e18@bh>

When a USE fails for an existing file, it is not supposed to throw an error,
but instead set NetErr.

Currently, the value for NetErr is a static in dbcmd.c that is only accessed
by HB_FUNC( NETERR ).
But every RDD that opens files has to be able to set that value.  For the
moment, I have added
   s_bNetError = TRUE;
in dbcmd.c (not yet posted) whenever the SELF_OPEN fails.  It would be more
accurate for each rdd to set it only under actual sharing errors, but this
would require either another set/get function or calling NetErr() with the
vmPush stuff, which doesn't seem right.

Is this good enough for government work, or should we implement that static
differently?  Should it perhaps be a member of the area structure (my vote)
??


Brian Hays



From harbour@lists.harbour-project.org  Fri Mar  9 22:35:03 2001

----- Original Message -----
From: "Horacio Roldn" <horacioroldan@usa.net>
To: <harbour@lists.harbour-project.org>
Sent: Friday, March 09, 2001 3:46 AM
Subject: RE: [Harbour] GPL + Exception -> Legal Interpretation

I wanted to put my bit tho this Gbs about license :-)

1) About the issues of a modified GPL:
Dave's interpretation of the IF ELSE ENDIF form of the harbour license (HL)
is not wrong, I guess the confusion is saying that FSF/GPL license applies
in Harbour.
Say this: Peter wrote a well known accounting app, after that I take his
code and do the following:
if day()=13 and dow()=6 // Friday
  wipe the hard disk
else
  execute Peter's code
endif
Users of my app could say (regarding what they see on screen everyday) that
it's Peter app, but that's wrong. My app is using lots of his code (all) but
the executable is a new one build my me.
The HL is a new one that includes the terms (not the license as an entity)
described in the GPL. (indeed it may be thought as a derived work! :-) )
It could be easily expressed as:
if (conditions for harbour exception)
  the developer is not bound to the terms of the GPL on account of Harbour
code
else
  copy of the terms of the GPL (actually a reference to them)
endif

2) Freedom to change the code
It was said that changing (forking, etc) the code will erase the harbour
exception, it was also said that it won't.
I'm not sure about this, I guess that the terms of the GPL about a derived
work may force a GPL license into such work. If so and if it's harbour wish
the HL could have one other addition:

NOTE: Wherever the terms of the GPL forces a derived work of Harbour to be
GPL'ed, we allow it to have the HL instead (read the meaning not the words:
English is not my native language !)

By the way: I was wondering if a programmer changes some harbour code,
rebuilds harbour and use it to develop and distribute his apps . Must he
publish his changes?
He's not distributing the modified Harbour compiler, nor the libraries. He's
only distributing the linked libraries and this is covered by the Harbour
exception.
If this it's true then we don't have any problem with the matters about
errorsys.prg and the others.

3) Abuse of Harbour work
In regard of "Ron's" linker (the one that use DLL to work and for use of
it's linked app)
Ron, I think you missed what John pointed out about the distribution of the
DLL. If the evil's linked app must use the harbour's DLLs then we can think
that the linker is actually distributing the libraries for this purpose.
(The linker has them to work but if it links another app to them we can
speak about distribution)

I'll put another evil enviroment that don't require to distribute nothing: a
runner.
A runner could execute Harbour compatible pCode without having an extra copy
of the libraries and that would be the use as it is said in:
"Your use of that
 executable is in no way restricted on account of linking the HRL
 and/or HVM code into it."

I remember (not very well) the license of a commercial C compiler several
years ago that allowed you to build any app you like with the exception of a
another C compiler.

I think that we shoud have that in mind in order to difference the freedom
of the Harbour compiled executables. If they are meant to do what harbour
does by including verbatim code from harbour (compiler, rtl, vm) then they
shoul be out of the harbour exception.

I hope I did not bother you with this :-)

Best regards

Ron,

> what is the intended meaning in your opinion?

It's your / your lawyer's view that disagrees with what the license
means, but without giving reasons or enough detail or a fix.

I was trying to make the (obvious I thought) point that in English
(and probably legalese) "link" does not only mean what it means in
the context of a computer software linker.  But: let's stop.  I feel
my para above says it all.  We're wasting vast amounts of time and
effort.

For what it's worth, if your lawyer's right the current license looks
to give at most a slight extra amount of freedom than was intended.
I don't care enough to debate about it any more.

John.

From harbour@lists.harbour-project.org  Sat Mar 10 13:04:02 2001
From: harbour@lists.harbour-project.org (Brian Hays)
Date: Sat Mar 10 13:04:02 2001
Subject: Fw: [Harbour] Fw: Copy to Problem
Message-ID: <003a01c0a98d$5fb5b280$921a5e18@bh>

(Re-Sent)

Harrier:
OK, I'm seeing the issues better now.  Can we clarify all of them?
I wouldn't expect rdd-level code (in rddMoveRecords for example) to call the
prg-level dbCreate. But it does need to accomplish the same thing, so the
guts of dbCreate really should be abstracted out so the functionality is
available to C code as well as dbCreate itself.   Is this the right starting
point??  Or should __dbCopy just duplicate what pieces are needed to call
SELF_CREATE, etc., to handle it?

Additionally, the old dbCreate did not leave open the target, but this was a
Harbour extension to make that an option, right?
But it takes a parameter to handle this, so that shouldn't be a problem,
should it?

The idea of adding TableExistence methods sounds good, but do we want to
require all RDDs to implement them for core functionality like COPY TO?
And how important is it to implement the option to append to existing
instead of overwriting?

Thanks,

Brian

From harbour@lists.harbour-project.org  Sat Mar 10 17:22:02 2001

From harbour@lists.harbour-project.org  Sat Mar 10 18:23:02 2001
From: harbour@lists.harbour-project.org (Brian Hays)
Date: Sat Mar 10 18:23:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] How to get the Database Handle in RDD ADS
References: <007401c0a9b0$99af13a0$18d4d7c8@culik>
Message-ID: <007001c0a9b9$d9f12f80$921a5e18@bh>

Luiz:

dbInfo(DBI_FULLPATH) gives the full path to the file.

Are you/Manuel talking about the actual file handle for the open dbf?
Since the goal of ADS is to use the remote server, that won't ever be
available.  Because of this, I doubt the Local Server DLLs make the file
handle available either (I couldn't find it in the help file, and since the
DLL opens the files I'm not completely sure it could share it with the EXE
if it wanted.)  At any rate, even if it did, any code written for it would
fail when using the Remote Server since that's another process on another
machine, so I think Manuel will have to find a different way to do what he
wants.  Have him forward the actual goal, and I'll see if there's another
way to handle it.

Brian Hays

From harbour@lists.harbour-project.org  Sun Mar 11 21:18:01 2001
From: harbour@lists.harbour-project.org (Juan Agustin Barriga)
Date: Sun Mar 11 21:18:01 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Fw: Copy to Problem
References: <003a01c0a98d$5fb5b280$921a5e18@bh>
Message-ID: <003b01c0aaa2$65326800$c06410ac@jharrier>

I've been hacking around Harbour code (debugging) and now I also have things
more clear... The virtual functions table is in the place I would expect, so
that makes things simpler. I see the extra parameter on dbCreate that allows
the file to be also opened or not (on Clipper it was always expected it to
be, so that is a good thing, does this mean that my rddCreate function will
be able to get this information? How? I found an ISLOG( 4 ) on DBCREATE
(dbcmd.c), how this can be passed to the RDD?

On the COPY to issue, I think that a DBOEXIST functionality is VERY useful,
at least TOPConnect programmers make heavy use of it as to create the needed
tables at run time, I also think that it should not be difficult to
implement on the DBF file based RDDs. I plan to allow Index existence test
as well. I also find a missing an DBDROP functionality. Maybe all of them
were non important when dealing with DBF files, where you could always go to
the operating system file functions to check & delete a table, but this is
not the case on a "really" abstract RDD layer, where you just cannot know
what a table really is, or, in other words, you the dine the functionality
of such an entity, not it's physical existence.

You are right on the issue of dbCreate being a prg-level routine, but
rddMoveRecords can happily call SELF_CREATE as DBCRATE does filling the
proper arguments (not too much code). After experimenting with a Clipper
program I see that COPY TO will delete an existing target table and create a
new one. Is this behavior what Clipper-heads want? Making this
deletion/creation is not possible on an RDD as TOPConnect without the
DBEXIST functionality.Maybe the flag that you talk about is the best
solution as to append records to an existing table is a good choice. Another
flag that would be nice is  to enable by-field-name-copy, this can be very
useful when moving data between the ever changing record layouts.

I have just downloaded the latest CVS and will have time this week to make
my proposal. I will not change to the TRANS/TRANSREC functionality because,
to remain abstract, the Put/GetValue are the only methods that are mandatory
to the RDD and do the work, another level of functions in the middle seems
more complicated (I like MIS) and affects performance as well.

Ill keep you (all) posted, unless the list says something on the contrary.

Harrier

From harbour@lists.harbour-project.org  Mon Mar 12 03:03:28 2001
From: harbour@lists.harbour-project.org (Alexander S.Kresin)
Date: Mon Mar 12 03:03:28 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Re: NetErr()
In-Reply-To: <007001c0a9b9$d9f12f80$921a5e18@bh>
References: <007401c0a9b0$99af13a0$18d4d7c8@culik>
 <007001c0a9b9$d9f12f80$921a5e18@bh>
Message-ID: <1403636360.20010312094825@belacy.belgorod.su>

On 09.03.2001 20:37, Brian Hays <bhays@abacuslaw.com> wrote:

BH>
BH> Currently, the value for NetErr is a static in dbcmd.c that is only accessed
BH> by HB_FUNC( NETERR ).
BH> But every RDD that opens files has to be able to set that value.  For the
BH> moment, I have added
BH>   s_bNetError = TRUE;
BH> in dbcmd.c (not yet posted) whenever the SELF_OPEN fails.  It would be more
BH> accurate for each rdd to set it only under actual sharing errors, but this
BH> would require either another set/get function or calling NetErr() with the
BH> vmPush stuff, which doesn't seem right. Is this good enough for government work, or should we implement that static
BH> differently?  Should it perhaps be a member of the area structure
BH> (my vote) ??

 In this case NetErr() will take the result from current workarea and
 in this case:

  select a
  use test  // failed
  select b
  ? neterr()

  will return .f. .
  So I suggest to have it as a member of the workarea structure and
  keep the existing static s_bNetError. RDD will set the value of the
  variable from the workarea and appropriate function in dbcmd will
  check it and set s_bNetError . In this case we could add new
  function ( AreaNetErr() ? ), which will return the error status for
  the selected workarea.

Best regards,
 Alexander
http://members.xoom.com/alkresin/

From harbour@lists.harbour-project.org  Mon Mar 12 07:14:02 2001
From: harbour@lists.harbour-project.org (Patrick Mast)
Date: Mon Mar 12 07:14:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Bugreport
In-Reply-To: <3AACAEB2.805A4040@corevia.com>
Message-ID: <NCBBJKNMIDPJNLJCHCHICEKHGAAA.harbour@winfakt.com>

This is a messega I got from Jose Gimenez:

I'm working on accesing COM interfaces for Harbour (it's almost finished)
and I've found a BUG in Harbour.
You can verify it running this little program:

----------------------------------------------------------------------------
----

#include "Fivewin.ch"

PROCEDURE main()

   LOCAL o, n := 1

   MsgInfo( n, "Before change" )  // result: 1
   o:=test():new()
   o:change( @n )                 // Passed by reference
   MsgInfo( n, "After change" )   // result: Clipper: 1234
                                  //         Harbour: 1
RETURN


STATIC PROCEDURE ChangeNum( x )
   x := 1234
RETURN


CLASS test
METHOD new() CONSTRUCTOR
METHOD change( n ) INLINE ChangeNum( @n ) // Passed by reference
ENDCLASS


METHOD new() CLASS test
RETURN Self

----------------------------------------------------------------------------
----

As you can see, if a parameter is passed by reference to a inline method of
a class, this parameter is dereferenced.

I've modified only 1 line (1980) in CLASSES.C from VM directory and now it's
working fine.

Regards,

Patrick Mast
www.Patrick.Be.kz (By Bekz.net)

From harbour@lists.harbour-project.org  Mon Mar 12 10:52:02 2001
From: harbour@lists.harbour-project.org (Juan Agustin Barriga)
Date: Mon Mar 12 10:52:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Re: NetErr()
References: <007401c0a9b0$99af13a0$18d4d7c8@culik> <007001c0a9b9$d9f12f80$921a5e18@bh> <1403636360.20010312094825@belacy.belgorod.su>
Message-ID: <003701c0ab0c$14651520$c06410ac@jharrier>

Currently, my RDD has the following code, when the Open fails, and it works
fine:

    SHORT  RetVal;
    pError = hb_errNew();

    hb_errPutGenCode( pError, ErrNro );
    hb_errPutSubCode( pError, 0 );

    hb_errPutSeverity( pError, ES_WARNING );

    hb_errPutFlags( pError, EF_CANDEFAULT );
    hb_errPutDescription( pError, aErrMsg[14] );  <-- this is my message

    RetVal = SUPER_ERROR( (AREAP)pArea, pError );
    hb_errRelease( pError );
    return ( RetVal );

After this, NetErr() is True.

Harrier

From harbour@lists.harbour-project.org  Mon Mar 12 12:38:02 2001
From: harbour@lists.harbour-project.org (Juan Agustin Barriga)
Date: Mon Mar 12 12:38:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] COPY implementation
References: <003a01c0a98d$5fb5b280$921a5e18@bh> <003b01c0aaa2$65326800$c06410ac@jharrier>
Message-ID: <007901c0ab1b$019c96c0$c06410ac@jharrier>

Now that Im going into the code to implement COPY TO with table
overwritting, I understand what Brian said about DBCREATE being at the
prg-level as opossed to the C-level code. But my question goes beyond; I see
DBCREATE completely mixed up with DBOPEN, as a matter of fact it builds up a
DBOPENINFO structure to pass to the RDD. Why is this so? Did the
Clipper-heads think that table creation was a "kind of" table opening? It
has to create a new WorkArea and all the stuff... I see this very twisted.
In my opinion DBCREATE should receive the structure and pass it to the RDD
for table creation WITHOUT a WorkArea involved! As I see, ALL virtual
functions have an asociated AREAP as it's first parameter, why? I pretend
the DBEXIT, DBDROP & DBEXIST functions wich operate with no WorkArea at all,
as they are Database level (as DBCREATE should be), not table instance ones.

Any comments?

Harrier

From harbour@lists.harbour-project.org  Mon Mar 12 15:53:02 2001

Date: Mon Mar 12 15:53:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] How to install harbour linux
In-Reply-To: <001a01c0ab36$57f60ae0$0400a8c0@sala_04.compex-ba.com.br>
Message-ID: <200103122052.f2CKqEU05384@smtp.parrett.net>

** Reply to message from "Compex Informatica - Jose Augusto Junior"
<compex@mma.com.br> on Mon, 12 Mar 2001 17:51:28 -0300

> I have already got the source rpm. Do i need to get any library or not?

No. You just need to export the shell variables identified in the file
doc/gmake.txt and then run "make -r" to build Harbour and the libraries.
You can also export the various HB_*_INSTALL shell variables (also
identified in the file doc/gmake.txt) and run "make -r install" to
install the binaries and libraries to the directories of your choice.

There is also a make_gnu.sh shell script that you can use.
-- 
David G. Holm, Set Captain and all around
Harbour Project Clipper Compatibility fanatic.

From harbour@lists.harbour-project.org  Mon Mar 12 16:15:02 2001
From: harbour@lists.harbour-project.org (Dave Pearson)

From harbour@lists.harbour-project.org  Mon Mar 12 16:15:23 2001
From: harbour@lists.harbour-project.org (Dave Pearson)
Date: Mon Mar 12 16:15:23 2001
Subject: [Harbour] How to install harbour linux
In-Reply-To: <200103122052.f2CKqEU05384@smtp.parrett.net>; from dholm@jsd-llc.com on Mon, Mar 12, 2001 at 03:52:10PM -0500
References: <001a01c0ab36$57f60ae0$0400a8c0@sala_04.compex-ba.com.br> <200103122052.f2CKqEU05384@smtp.parrett.net>
Message-ID: <20010312211248.Z5326@hagbard.davep.org>

On Mon, Mar 12, 2001 at 03:52:10PM -0500, David G. Holm wrote:
> ** Reply to message from "Compex Informatica - Jose Augusto Junior"
> <compex@mma.com.br> on Mon, 12 Mar 2001 17:51:28 -0300
> 
> > I have already got the source rpm. Do i need to get any library or not?
> 
> No. You just need to export the shell variables identified in the file
> doc/gmake.txt and then run "make -r" to build Harbour and the libraries.
> You can also export the various HB_*_INSTALL shell variables (also
> identified in the file doc/gmake.txt) and run "make -r install" to install
> the binaries and libraries to the directories of your choice.

None of that is necessary if he's got the source RPM. All that's required
with the source RPM is:

,----
| rpm --rebuild harbour-0.36-1.src.rpm
`----

and a binary RPM will be produced. He can then install the binary RPM with:

,----
| rpm -i harbour-0.36-1.i386.rpm
`----

then read /usr/doc/harbour-0.39/README.RPM.

-- 
The Harbour Project: A free software Clipper compatible compiler
Home Page..........: http://www.harbour-project.org/
FAQ................: http://www.harbour-project.org/faq/harbour.html
My harbour page....: http://www.davep.org/harbour/

From harbour@lists.harbour-project.org  Mon Mar 12 18:43:02 2001
From: harbour@lists.harbour-project.org (Juan Agustin Barriga)
Date: Mon Mar 12 18:43:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] COPY implementation 2
References: <003a01c0a98d$5fb5b280$921a5e18@bh> <003b01c0aaa2$65326800$c06410ac@jharrier> <007901c0ab1b$019c96c0$c06410ac@jharrier>
Message-ID: <001501c0ab4d$f153db10$c06410ac@jharrier>

As I advance on the implementation of COPY TO with table overwritting, I'm
looking at more weird stuff... DBEXIT, DBDROP & DBEXISTS were easy, even on
dbf1.c (which uses fsDelete & fsFile for the purpose), but DBCREATE... it's
completely out of place! I'm beginning to think that the Clipper-heads that
designed the RED architecture were no OOP wizards, had only a partial idea
of abstraction a less yet about "separation of concerns". Take the dbInfo()
example, many of the asked items have no connection to a particular instance
of a table, they refer to the Database properties. Did they put a WorkArea
pointer on every function just to have access to the virtual table function
on SELF_ stuff?, but that table is known to the RDD! Why SUPER_ goes
directly, but SELF_ doesn't?. Okay, functions at the DataBase level are very
few, but that's not an argument. And dbCreate IS at the DatBase level , not
a table instance one. The bad news is that putting this straight would break
every RDD's code (what I've done up to now has no impact). I need the
Harbour crew to get the point & agree on doing it, I can of course change
the RDD's under SOURCE/RDD, but that's not enough. My proposal is that
dbCreate receives a DBCREATEINFO with the needed information (table name,
fields and whatever), and that it does it's job without any connection to
dbOpen.

Comments please.
Harrier

Not quite. Ron and I were talking about what's needed and what could be done
just a few days ago. Check the archives.

However, while you're at it, the attached patch could do with being applied
to TERROR.PRG.

-- 
The Harbour Project: A free software Clipper compatible compiler
Home Page..........: http://www.harbour-project.org/
FAQ................: http://www.harbour-project.org/faq/harbour.html
My harbour page....: http://www.davep.org/harbour/
--81JctsDUVPekGcy+
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Disposition: attachment; filename="terror.diff"

--- /usr/local/src/harbour/source/rtl/terror.prg	Tue Oct  5 23:52:00 1999
+++ terror.prg	Mon Mar  5 16:45:31 2001
@@ -43,7 +43,7 @@
    IF s_oClass == NIL
       s_oClass := TClass():New( "ERROR" )
 
-      s_oClass:AddData( "Args"         , 0 )
+      s_oClass:AddData( "Args"         , NIL )
       s_oClass:AddData( "CanDefault"   , .F. )
       s_oClass:AddData( "CanRetry"     , .F. )
       s_oClass:AddData( "CanSubstitute", .F. )

--81JctsDUVPekGcy+--

From harbour@lists.harbour-project.org  Mon Mar 12 20:36:02 2001
From: harbour@lists.harbour-project.org (Luiz Rafael Culik Guimaraes)
Date: Mon Mar 12 20:36:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] make lib files
References: <007401c0a9b0$99af13a0$18d4d7c8@culik> <007001c0a9b9$d9f12f80$921a5e18@bh> <1403636360.20010312094825@belacy.belgorod.su> <003701c0ab0c$14651520$c06410ac@jharrier> <000e01c0ab1b$56b14a20$080000bc@terminalx>
Message-ID: <002001c0ab5e$07434ae0$03d4d7c8@sl.conex.net>

Noberto


> Hi to all
>
> I am starting testing with Fhw+harbour and need convert my functions , in
> clipper i do :
>
> clipper filefunc /m/n/a/w
> clipper filefunc1 /m/n/a/w
> lib filelib +filefunc +filefunc1
>
> how make this with harbour+FWH ? harbour generate an obj to link ?

You can use
Set HI=c:\harbour\include
harbour filefunc /m /n /i%HI% | bcc32 -c -O2 -I%HI% filefunc.c |echo
+-filefunc.obj & >>lib.rsp

Btw in few days Ill finish the library support for the hbmake utility

Regards

Luiz  Rafael Culik

> 
> clipper filefunc /m/n/a/w
> clipper filefunc1 /m/n/a/w
> lib filelib +filefunc +filefunc1
> 
> how make this with harbour+FWH ? harbour generate an obj to link ?

   * contrib/dot/pp.prg
   * contrib/dot/rp_run.ch
      + Added support for initializers for PRIVATE, PUBLIC, LOCAL, STATIC
      + Added support for Declared Parameters and PARAMETERS.
      + Added support for STATIC Procedures & Functions (will not be seen by
modules called by DO <filename>.prg and vice-versa.
      + Added support for INIT and EXIT procedures.

Good Morning,

  This program always give an Open error with harbour but not when 
compiled wit clipper, the DBF FPT and CDX file exist. My problem 
is Hberror.log didn't give wich Open error number !

  Do I forget to do something ??

  Sylvain 



 


     Sylvain Robert
     srobert@logava.com

     Les Logiciels Avantage
     www.logava.com


--Message-Boundary-19539
Content-type: text/plain; charset=US-ASCII
Content-transfer-encoding: 7BIT
Content-description: Text from file 'Test.prg'

// Socket server connection sample

#include "FiveWin.ch"

//------------------------------------------------------------------------//

function Main()
   Local Drive:="F"
   Textget:=""
   SET(_SET_AUTOPEN,.f.)
   RDDSETDEFAULT("DBFCDX")
   Set exclusive off
   Set deleted on
   Select A
   IF ALLTRIM(NETNAME()) == "MRROBERT"
     Drive:="H"
   ELSEIF ALLTRIM(NETNAME()) == "SRVNT_AVANTAGE"
     Drive:="D"
   endif

   use (Drive)+":\enregis\client" index (Drive)+":\enregis\cnum",(Drive)+":\enregis\cnat";
       ,(Drive)+":\enregis\cdet" alias CLIENT
Return nil

--Message-Boundary-19539
Content-type: text/plain; charset=US-ASCII
Content-disposition: inline

From harbour@lists.harbour-project.org  Tue Mar 13 12:18:27 2001
From: harbour@lists.harbour-project.org (Alexander S.Kresin)
Date: Tue Mar 13 12:18:27 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Re: DBFCDX problem
In-Reply-To: <3AADF9DC.15015.DDC814@localhost>
References: <3AADF9DC.15015.DDC814@localhost>
Message-ID: <1856569808.20010313201056@belacy.belgorod.su>

On  Tuesday, March 13, 2001, 18:43 Sylvain Robert  <srobert@logava.com> wrote:

SR>   This program always give an Open error with harbour but not when 
SR> compiled wit clipper, the DBF FPT and CDX file exist. My problem 
SR> is Hberror.log didn't give wich Open error number !

SR>   Do I forget to do something ??

 Since DBFCDX isn't default RDD, you should insert these two lines:

   request _DBFCDX
   rddRegister( "DBFCDX", 1 )

   before
     RDDSETDEFAULT("DBFCDX") .

Best regards,
 Alexander
http://members.xoom.com/alkresin/



From harbour@lists.harbour-project.org  Tue Mar 13 12:25:04 2001
From: harbour@lists.harbour-project.org (Ron Pinkas)
Date: Tue Mar 13 12:25:04 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Proposed Rewording of the Harbour License
In-Reply-To: <200103131650.f2DGoMU28222@smtp.parrett.net>
Message-ID: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKKEIIDKAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>

David,

I do care, and still want to us to address the problem I raised regarding
the lack of qualification on what kind of Executables can link HVM/HRL, and
still be excused from GPL.

It makes no sense, that we will allow a 3rd. party to develop just the
compiler front end, and ship a full fledge package utilizing the HVM & HRL,
without having to disclose this fact.

This is especially true, since, you and few others think that the current
text [already] does not allow it, and yet a copyright expert claims it does.
It only makes sense to clear such reported ambiguity.

What do you think about adding to the Exception:

,----------------------------------------------------------------
| as long as the HVM and/or HRL are not supporting code generated
| by a NON FREE (NON GPL?) Harbour compatible compiler.
`----------------------------------------------------------------

We also have to address the issue of applying the Exception to modified
HVM/HRL.

Ron

> So, does the fact that nobody commented on the proposed Harbour
> Exception rewrite from the full text of the Guile Exception mean that
> nobody cares what the license is or that nobody objects to the rewrite?
> --
> David G. Holm, Set Captain and all around
> Harbour Project Clipper Compatibility fanatic.

Content-type: text/plain; charset=US-ASCII

// Socket server connection sample

#include "FiveWin.ch"

//------------------------------------------------------------------------//

function Main()
   Local Drive:="F"
   Textget:=""
   request _DBFCDX
   rddRegister( "DBFCDX", 1 )
   SET(_SET_AUTOPEN,.f.)
   RDDSETDEFAULT("DBFCDX")
   Set exclusive off
   Set deleted on
   Select A
   IF ALLTRIM(NETNAME()) == "MRROBERT"
     Drive:="H"
   ELSEIF ALLTRIM(NETNAME()) == "SRVNT_AVANTAGE"
     Drive:="D"
   endif

   use (Drive)+":\enregis\client" index (Drive)+":\enregis\cnum",(Drive)+":\enregis\cnat";
       ,(Drive)+":\enregis\cdet" alias CLIENT
Return nil

to *how* we'd change the exception.

From harbour@lists.harbour-project.org  Tue Mar 13 12:48:28 2001
From: harbour@lists.harbour-project.org (Dave Pearson)
Date: Tue Mar 13 12:48:28 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Proposed Rewording of the Harbour License
In-Reply-To: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKKEIIDKAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>; from Ron@Profit-Master.com on Tue, Mar 13, 2001 at 09:21:59AM -0800
References: <200103131650.f2DGoMU28222@smtp.parrett.net> <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKKEIIDKAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>
Message-ID: <20010313174144.R5326@hagbard.davep.org>

On Tue, Mar 13, 2001 at 09:21:59AM -0800, Ron Pinkas wrote:

> It makes no sense, that we will allow a 3rd. party to develop just the
> compiler front end, and ship a full fledge package utilizing the HVM &
> HRL, without having to disclose this fact.

Seeking to stop such a thing would be the opposite of the harbour exception
wouldn't it? That is, wouldn't we be seeking to add *more* restrictions as
opposed to removing them (which is what the harbour exception does)?

> This is especially true, since, you and few others think that the current
> text [already] does not allow it, and yet a copyright expert claims it
> does. It only makes sense to clear such reported ambiguity.

Unless I've totally missed the gist of the discussions that have taken place
the thing that people said wasn't allowed had nothing to do with non-free
compilers making use of the HVM and HRTL. I thought the example that was
being discussed was the "evil linker using HVM/HRTL as binary cargo", which
is quite different.

> What do you think about adding to the Exception:
> 
> ,----------------------------------------------------------------
> | as long as the HVM and/or HRL are not supporting code generated
> | by a NON FREE (NON GPL?) Harbour compatible compiler.
> `----------------------------------------------------------------

There's a huge hole in this that could cause problems: who gets to decide
the definition of "free"? Another hole in the wording of the above is that
there's every chance the HRL would be supporting code generated by a
non-free compiler, some C compilers are non-free and the HRL provides the
extend system.

-- 
The Harbour Project: A free software Clipper compatible compiler
Home Page..........: http://www.harbour-project.org/
FAQ................: http://www.harbour-project.org/faq/harbour.html
My harbour page....: http://www.davep.org/harbour/

From harbour@lists.harbour-project.org  Tue Mar 13 13:30:04 2001
From: harbour@lists.harbour-project.org (Ron Pinkas)
Date: Tue Mar 13 13:30:04 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Proposed Rewording of the Harbour License
In-Reply-To: <20010313174144.R5326@hagbard.davep.org>
Message-ID: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKEEIKDKAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>

Dave,

> > It makes no sense, that we will allow a 3rd. party to develop just the
> > compiler front end, and ship a full fledge package utilizing the HVM &
> > HRL, without having to disclose this fact.
>
> Seeking to stop such a thing would be the opposite of the harbour
> exception
> wouldn't it? That is, wouldn't we be seeking to add *more* restrictions as
> opposed to removing them (which is what the harbour exception does)?

No, it simply further qualifies what kind of Executable *is* entitled to the
removal of these restrictions, or "deserves" the relief of the Exception.

> > This is especially true, since, you and few others think that
> the current
> > text [already] does not allow it, and yet a copyright expert claims it
> > does. It only makes sense to clear such reported ambiguity.
>
> Unless I've totally missed the gist of the discussions that have
> taken place
> the thing that people said wasn't allowed had nothing to do with non-free
> compilers making use of the HVM and HRTL. I thought the example that was
> being discussed was the "evil linker using HVM/HRTL as binary
> cargo", which
> is quite different.

I suggest that the "evil" scenario was just on example of how the Exception
could be abused.

> > What do you think about adding to the Exception:
> >
> > ,----------------------------------------------------------------
> > | as long as the HVM and/or HRL are not supporting code generated
> > | by a NON FREE (NON GPL?) Harbour compatible compiler.
> > `----------------------------------------------------------------
>
> There's a huge hole in this that could cause problems: who gets to decide
> the definition of "free"? Another hole in the wording of the above is that
> there's every chance the HRL would be supporting code generated by a
> non-free compiler, some C compilers are non-free and the HRL provides the
> extend system.

1. This is why I put (NON GPL?). I', not sure what the legal term is.
2. Please note it doesn't say NON FREE Compiler, it says NON FREE *Harbour*
*compatible* compiler.

Ron

From harbour@lists.harbour-project.org  Tue Mar 13 14:18:02 2001
From: harbour@lists.harbour-project.org (Patrick Mast)
Date: Tue Mar 13 14:18:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Harbour with FiveWin and ADO
In-Reply-To: <003201c0abef$c76ac2d0$921a5e18@bh>
Message-ID: <NCBBJKNMIDPJNLJCHCHIOELIGAAA.harbour@winfakt.com>

Hi,

I'm testing this great TOleAuto class from Jose Giminez.
We can do this now:

,------------------
|Function TestADO()
|   LOCAL oCO, oRS, cFieldName
|   LOCAL Conn := "Provider=Advantage OLE DB Provider; " + ;
|                 "Data Source=.; " + ;
|                 "ServerType=ADS_LOCAL_SERVER; TableType=ADS_CDX;"
|
|   oCO := TOleAuto():New( "ADODB.Connection" )
|
|   IF Ole2TxtError() != "S_OK"
|      MsgAlert("No ADODB connection available.", "Error")
|   ELSE
|      oCO:Open( Conn )
|
|      MsgInfo( "SELECT * FROM prueba" )
|      oRS := oCO:Execute("Select * from PRUEBA")
|      oRS:MoveFirst()
|
|      DO WHILE .NOT. oRS:Eof()
|         cFieldName := oRS:Fields(0):Name
|         MsgInfo( cFieldName + ": " + ;
|                  cValToChar( oRS:Fields( cFieldName ):Value ) )
|         oRS:MoveNext()
|      Enddo
|
|      MsgInfo( "Grabar como .XML" )
|      IF FILE( "Prueba.xml" )
|         FERASE( "Prueba.xml" )
|      ENDIF
|      oRS:Save( "Prueba.xml", 1)
|
|      oRS:End()
|      oCO:End()
|
|   ENDIF
|
|RETURN
`--------------------
Is this great or what? ;-))

Regards,

Patrick Mast
www.Patrick.Be.kz (By Bekz.net)

From harbour@lists.harbour-project.org  Tue Mar 13 14:48:03 2001
From: harbour@lists.harbour-project.org (Dave Pearson)
Date: Tue Mar 13 14:48:03 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Proposed Rewording of the Harbour License
In-Reply-To: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKEEIKDKAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>; from Ron@Profit-Master.com on Tue, Mar 13, 2001 at 10:27:32AM -0800
References: <20010313174144.R5326@hagbard.davep.org> <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKEEIKDKAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>
Message-ID: <20010313194723.U5326@hagbard.davep.org>

On Tue, Mar 13, 2001 at 10:27:32AM -0800, Ron Pinkas wrote:
> Dave,
> 
> > > It makes no sense, that we will allow a 3rd. party to develop just the
> > > compiler front end, and ship a full fledge package utilizing the HVM &
> > > HRL, without having to disclose this fact.
> >
> > Seeking to stop such a thing would be the opposite of the harbour
> > exception wouldn't it? That is, wouldn't we be seeking to add *more*
> > restrictions as opposed to removing them (which is what the harbour
> > exception does)?
> 
> No, it simply further qualifies what kind of Executable *is* entitled to
> the removal of these restrictions, or "deserves" the relief of the
> Exception.

I'm not sure I follow what you're driving at here and above. In the above
you seem concerned with some form of disclosure while here you seem more
concerned with how and when the exception can be applied. I'm not sure that
I can see how the two are related.

> > Unless I've totally missed the gist of the discussions that have taken
> > place the thing that people said wasn't allowed had nothing to do with
> > non-free compilers making use of the HVM and HRTL. I thought the example
> > that was being discussed was the "evil linker using HVM/HRTL as binary
> > cargo", which is quite different.
> 
> I suggest that the "evil" scenario was just on example of how the
> Exception could be abused.

As you may recall I could see some merit in your "evil" example. However,
writing a non-free compiler that produces output that can be used with the
HVM and HRTL isn't the same thing is it?

> > > What do you think about adding to the Exception:
> > >
> > > ,----------------------------------------------------------------
> > > | as long as the HVM and/or HRL are not supporting code generated
> > > | by a NON FREE (NON GPL?) Harbour compatible compiler.
> > > `----------------------------------------------------------------
> >
> > There's a huge hole in this that could cause problems: who gets to
> > decide the definition of "free"? Another hole in the wording of the
> > above is that there's every chance the HRL would be supporting code
> > generated by a non-free compiler, some C compilers are non-free and the
> > HRL provides the extend system.
> 
> 1. This is why I put (NON GPL?). I', not sure what the legal term is.

I think requiring the GPL would be a bad idea. That is to say, there are
other free software licences available (and other free software licences are
still waiting to be written).

> 2. Please note it doesn't say NON FREE Compiler, it says NON FREE *Harbour*
> *compatible* compiler.

Ahh, yes, I missed that. I can see that defining "harbour compatible" could
be an interesting exercise.

-- 
The Harbour Project: A free software Clipper compatible compiler
Home Page..........: http://www.harbour-project.org/
FAQ................: http://www.harbour-project.org/faq/harbour.html
My harbour page....: http://www.davep.org/harbour/

From harbour@lists.harbour-project.org  Tue Mar 13 14:52:02 2001
From: harbour@lists.harbour-project.org (Dave Pearson)
Date: Tue Mar 13 14:52:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] How to install harbour linux
In-Reply-To: <005301c0abf4$b065b7c0$0400a8c0@sala_04.compex-ba.com.br>; from compex@mma.com.br on Tue, Mar 13, 2001 at 04:34:56PM -0300
References: <005301c0abf4$b065b7c0$0400a8c0@sala_04.compex-ba.com.br>
Message-ID: <20010313195153.V5326@hagbard.davep.org>

On Tue, Mar 13, 2001 at 04:34:56PM -0300, Compex Informatica - Jose Augusto Junior wrote:

> I have installed harbour and now it works. But i have a doubt: How to
> export a shell variable to say harbour where to find include files, like
> SET INCLUDE and SET LIB of clipper.

You can tell harbour where to find include files:

,----
| davep@hagbard:~$ harbour | grep include
|           -i<path>         #include file search path
`----

Telling your "linker" where your library files are is a GCC issue. If you've
got the RPM installed (I seem to recall that you have) you can have a look
at /usr/bin/harbour-link for some ideas on how this is done.

BTW, your questions are much better suited to the harbour-users mailing
list.

-- 
The Harbour Project: A free software Clipper compatible compiler
Home Page..........: http://www.harbour-project.org/
FAQ................: http://www.harbour-project.org/faq/harbour.html
My harbour page....: http://www.davep.org/harbour/

different issue (that's the issue that Ron and I were discussing).

From harbour@lists.harbour-project.org  Tue Mar 13 17:06:02 2001
From: harbour@lists.harbour-project.org (David G. Holm)
Date: Tue Mar 13 17:06:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Proposed Rewording of the Harbour License
In-Reply-To: <200103131556_MC2-C8AC-FC39@compuserve.com>
Message-ID: <200103132205.f2DM5C102213@smtp.parrett.net>

** Reply to message from John Skelton <John_Skelton@compuserve.com> on
Tue, 13 Mar 2001 15:56:02 -0500

> It never reached me. :-(  Due to the DNS problems?
> 
> Maybe post it again.

OK:

As it turns out, the Harbour Exception consist of only a small
section of the actual Guile Exception to the GNU GPL. I have
just today obtained a full copy of the Guile License, which I
have adapted to refer to Harbour and the Harbour Project and
would become the new content of doc/license.txt, if approved
(and would also be included in doc/hdr_tpl.txt, minus the
first paragraph):

The license of Harbour consists of the GNU GPL plus a special statement
giving blanket permission to link with non-free software.  This is the
license statement as found in any individual file that it applies to:

 This program is free software; you can redistribute it and/or modify
 it under the terms of the GNU General Public License as published by
 the Free Software Foundation; either version 2, or (at your option)
 any later version.

 This program is distributed in the hope that it will be useful,
 but WITHOUT ANY WARRANTY; without even the implied warranty of
 MERCHANTABILITY or FITNESS FOR A PARTICULAR PURPOSE.  See the
 GNU General Public License for more details.

 You should have received a copy of the GNU General Public License
 along with this software; see the file COPYING.  If not, write to
 the Free Software Foundation, Inc., 59 Temple Place, Suite 330,
 Boston, MA 02111-1307 USA (or visit the web site http://www.gnu.org/).

 As a special exception, the Harbour Project gives permission for
 additional uses of the text contained in its release of Harbour.

 The exception is that, if you link the Harbour libraries with other
 files to produce an executable, this does not by itself cause the
 resulting executable to be covered by the GNU General Public License.
 Your use of that executable is in no way restricted on account of
 linking the Harbour library code into it.

 This exception does not however invalidate any other reasons why
 the executable file might be covered by the GNU General Public License.

 This exception applies only to the code released by the Harbour
 Project under the name Harbour.  If you copy code from other
 Harbour Project or Free Software Foundation releases into a copy of
 Harbour, as the General Public License permits, the exception does
 not apply to the code that you add in this way.  To avoid misleading
 anyone as to the status of such modified files, you must delete
 this exception notice from them.

 If you write modifications of your own for Harbour, it is your choice
 whether to permit this exception to apply to your modifications.
 If you do not wish that, delete this exception notice.
-- 
David G. Holm, Set Captain and all around
Harbour Project Clipper Compatibility fanatic.
