From harbour@lists.harbour-project.org  Wed Mar 14 12:20:02 2001
From: harbour@lists.harbour-project.org (Marek Paliwoda)
Date: Wed Mar 14 12:20:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Re: Harbour/Linux again
Message-ID: <003c01c0acaa$e441a8e0$55b572c3@map>

This is a multi-part message in MIME format.

--Boundary_(ID_RUcyWT5qgGaVXkDpljbCTw)
Content-type: text/plain; charset=iso-8859-2
Content-transfer-encoding: 7BIT

Alexander,

...snip....

> MP> One of the possible reasons could be that he uses a screen font
> MP> prepared for Russian language in which case chars between 128
> MP> and 255 can be whatever they are.
>
>  I'm sure he use it. I use such a font too, but haven't that problem.
>  And he has that problem only with Harbour. Other console programs
>  which uses pseudo-graphics and Russian texts works Ok for him
>  ( including the Clip applications ).
>
> MP> Ask him to check if he uses standard 437 code page.
>
>  I'm sure that he use the standard KOI-8r code page, as most of
>  Russian Linux users.

So maybe the problem is different ?

Could You please ask Your friend to compile attached ascii.c program 
and run it redirecting output to a file then send this file to my 
private address ? Maybe this can help me to see what is wrong.

>  That guy is quite experienced Unix user and he wrote me that ncurses
>  and slang isn't a good choice for terminal library because of the
>  problems with national code pages and pseudo-graphics.

I think that there are much more problems with terminal handling under
Unix environment other than national code pages and pseudo-graphics.
One of a most important is keyboard handling even on standard 437 code
page. To my knoledge there is no possibility to provide all that
CTRL+SpecialKeys and ALT+Keys Dos funcionality under Unix in general
meaning (I mean hundreds of different terminals, most of them with
very limited properties ). Yet another problem is displaying characters
with code less than 32. There are many usefull chars in Dos there, but
due to the fact that such chars are control chars under Unix, either for
system and for terminals, I don't think they can be displayd properly
in all Unixes and all terminals. All these problems and some more were
described in gtslang.txt by me.

So generally I wouldn't expect 100% compatibility with Clipper under
Unix. We can reach better compatibility in some environments but not
in all cases.

I made an attempt to solve these problems by developing a gt driver
based on X11 library. It works in XWindows and emulates a text console
with 437 code page. Although it solves problems with chars less than
32, pseudo-graphics chars, keyboard handling and screen resizing
( currently not with other code pages ) when a proper font is used,
unfortunately it introduces new incompatibilities with Clipper. Because
it is not a full terminal emulation, it is not possible to run other
programs from within Harbour programs directly. Instead it is necessary
to run them thru something like :

RUN "xterm -e <other unix program>"

It also has the same problem with Harbour OutXXX() functions as ncurses
and slang drivers have (which I described in one of my previous posts)
and possibly, other currently unknown to me problems (code pages ?), so
I think it also is not a good solution too.

I think a discussion should be started to find a proper solution, but
I don't think we have more choices than ncurses and slang  under Unix
( and maybe X11 ???? - but it needs more work in current time ).

In my opinion the future is a GUI layer based on a portable library
which will slowly force moving old aplications to a new environment.
Being inspired by Antonio's FWH, I am currently playing with Harbour 
and GTK library under Linux and Win98 and I am trying to play with 
QT library as well.

>  BTW, could you check the difference between slang 1.3 and 1.4
>  versions and fix the gtsln ( now it doesn't compiles with 1.4 ) ?

I am suprised here.

I successfully compiled slang driver with a following environment :

   Slang 1.22  RedHat 6.0
   Slang 1.38  Mandrake 6.1
   Slang 1.40  RedHat 7.0
   Slang 1.41  RedHat 7.0
   Slang 1.44  RedHat 7.0
   Slang 1.22  Dos+Djgpp

and had no problems. This of course does not mean there are no
problems at all, but I can not figure them ! Is there anyone who
had similar problems with compilation of slang driver too ?

What is Your configuration when You compile gtsln ?
Does <slang include files> are in a proper place ?
The driver expects them in a  /usr/include/slang/ dir.
Could You send me a short errlog from compilation to my
private address as well as script You used to compile ?
Could You send your slang.h to my private address too ?
And could You also privately describe me shortly KOI-8r
code page ? Maybe I am missing something obvious.

I would be appreciate.

And about the differencies.

If we are talking about terminal handling part of Slang library
(not all Slang library) there is no big difference between at least
Slang 1.38 and Slang 1.44. Only bug fixes and small enhancemets
(up to my knowledge of course). And even Slang 1.22 does not differ
much in this part.

And finally I would like to say my appologies yet another time,
that I did not respond to Your mail in a proper time. It really
was not my fault. Only because of a lucky case I downloaded mail
archives and founded Your mail. Sorry again.

Best Regards
Marek Paliwoda



--Boundary_(ID_RUcyWT5qgGaVXkDpljbCTw)
Content-type: application/octet-stream; name=Ascii.c
Content-disposition: attachment; filename=Ascii.c
Content-transfer-encoding: quoted-printable

=0A=
#include <stdio.h>=0A=
#include <curses.h>=0A=
=0A=
#define myaddch( x ) addch( x )=0A=
#define XSHFT 0=0A=
=0A=
int main()=0A=
  {=0A=
  int i,j,c;=0A=
=0A=
  initscr();=0A=
  raw();=0A=
  nonl();=0A=
  noecho();=0A=
  meta(stdscr, TRUE);=0A=
  keypad(stdscr, TRUE);=0A=
=0A=
  move(3, 0);=0A=
  printw(" 00   01   02   03   04   05   06   07   08   09   0A   0B   =
0C   0D   0E   0F");=0A=
=0A=
  for (i=3D0; i<8; i++)=0A=
    {=0A=
    move(5+i, 0);=0A=
    /* printw("%x", 128+i*16); */=0A=
=0A=
    for (j=3D0; j<16; j++)=0A=
      {=0A=
      move(5+i, (j*5)+XSHFT);=0A=
      if( ((i*16)+j) > 31 )=0A=
            myaddch( (chtype)(    (i*16)+j) );=0A=
      else=0A=
            myaddch( (chtype)(    42 ) );=0A=
=0A=
      move(5+i, (j*5)+XSHFT+1);=0A=
      if( ((i*16)+j) > 31 )=0A=
            myaddch( ( (chtype)(    (i*16)+j) ) | A_ALTCHARSET );=0A=
      else=0A=
            myaddch( (chtype)(    42 ) );=0A=
=0A=
      move(5+i, (j*5)+XSHFT+2);=0A=
      myaddch( (chtype)(128+(i*16)+j) );=0A=
=0A=
      move(5+i, (j*5)+XSHFT+3);=0A=
      myaddch( ( (chtype)(128+(i*16)+j) ) | A_ALTCHARSET );=0A=
      }=0A=
    }=0A=
=0A=
  move(18,0);=0A=
  addch(ACS_ULCORNER);=0A=
  addch(ACS_HLINE);=0A=
  addch(ACS_URCORNER);=0A=
  addch(ACS_LLCORNER);=0A=
  addch(ACS_VLINE);=0A=
  addch(ACS_LRCORNER);=0A=
=0A=
  refresh();=0A=
  /* c =3D getch(); */=0A=
=0A=
  endwin();=0A=
  return(0);=0A=
  }=0A=

--Boundary_(ID_RUcyWT5qgGaVXkDpljbCTw)--

From harbour@lists.harbour-project.org  Wed Mar 14 14:28:01 2001
From: harbour@lists.harbour-project.org (Brian Hays)
Date: Wed Mar 14 14:28:01 2001
Subject: [Harbour] COPY implementation 2
References: <003a01c0a98d$5fb5b280$921a5e18@bh> <003b01c0aaa2$65326800$c06410ac@jharrier> <007901c0ab1b$019c96c0$c06410ac@jharrier> <001501c0ab4d$f153db10$c06410ac@jharrier>
Message-ID: <004701c0acbd$ad4b6610$921a5e18@bh>

Harrier:
A minor point on your comments re Trans being optional:
There is a function __dbTrans() that is currently stubbed out in dummy.prg.
I have never used it, but I did some scanning around and there are 3rd party
libs that have called it from PRG code.  Ultimately it seems we should have
this function, which I presume is a front end for the Trans rdd methods.

I was previously unfamiliar with these functions, and you obviously knew
about them,
so if you think it's more efficient to go straight to Get/PutValue for
append and CopyTo, that's probably OK.  But it appears that the "Trans"
level of abstraction would handle some issues for To/From Delimited and SDF
as well as the related codeblocks for scoping and filtering.

So I guess this msg gets down to:  do we lose any functionality by not
having copyTo/AppendFrom use Trans?  And even if not,  am I correct in
concluding that Harbour's base RDD needs to implement it anyway to support
other existing code?

Thanks,
Brian


From harbour@lists.harbour-project.org  Wed Mar 14 16:01:02 2001
From: harbour@lists.harbour-project.org (Juan Agustin Barriga)
Date: Wed Mar 14 16:01:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] COPY implementation 2
References: <003a01c0a98d$5fb5b280$921a5e18@bh> <003b01c0aaa2$65326800$c06410ac@jharrier> <007901c0ab1b$019c96c0$c06410ac@jharrier> <001501c0ab4d$f153db10$c06410ac@jharrier> <004701c0acbd$ad4b6610$921a5e18@bh>
Message-ID: <001001c0acc9$9db28420$c06410ac@jharrier>

You are quite right, but I still think that DBAPPEND & COPY TO will get far
more complicated if it has to build up the Trans stuff and use it, not to
say we should implement them. I don't rely know the internals of the Trans
functionality... It seem to me that it's a short cut on record moving when
you KNOW IN ADVANCE the layout of them, which is not the case on copy
functions. I will investigate the issue. If someone has more Info about it I
will appreciate.

Regards
Harrier

From harbour@lists.harbour-project.org  Wed Mar 14 16:09:02 2001
From: harbour@lists.harbour-project.org (Juan Agustin Barriga)
Date: Wed Mar 14 16:09:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] COPY TO finished
References: <003a01c0a98d$5fb5b280$921a5e18@bh> <003b01c0aaa2$65326800$c06410ac@jharrier> <007901c0ab1b$019c96c0$c06410ac@jharrier> <001501c0ab4d$f153db10$c06410ac@jharrier> <004701c0acbd$ad4b6610$921a5e18@bh>
Message-ID: <001d01c0acca$ae8029a0$c06410ac@jharrier>

This is a multi-part message in MIME format.

------=_NextPart_000_0016_01C0ACA9.22BF0B50
Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset="iso-8859-1"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

I've finished the implementation of DBAPPEND and DBCOPY, I've try it with
the default RDD and it works fine (Until I got read of the memory leaks,
what a hell!). Now COPY TO deletes the target table and recreates it, as
Clipper does. I left the option of adding a parameter in the future to allow
for appending. I also addeed the DBEXIT (for RDD cleanup), DBDROP (for table
deleting) and DBEXISTS (for table/index verification), this two last ones I
implemented them on DBF1.C, though I didn't know where to get the Index
extension, so that has to be completed. I have seen no impact on the rest of
Harbour, so you tell me. I have incorporated to DBCMD.C the code previously
on RDDCPY.C.

One thing that I had to do was to bring up, to hbapirdd.h the RDDNODE
definition, this was to implement the three new functions that do not relay
on a table instance. I would have liked to put into this category dbCreate,
but that would break all the code, so I need the input from the other RDD
gurus to make such a change. I have given my reasons why this should be so
on previous messages.

I'm attaching a zip with the harbour directory structure containing the
files that were modified.

Anyone for a try?

Regards
Harrier

	name="harbour.zip"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: base64
Content-Disposition: attachment;
	filename="harbour.zip"

From harbour@lists.harbour-project.org  Wed Mar 14 16:53:02 2001
From: harbour@lists.harbour-project.org (Brian Hays)
Date: Wed Mar 14 16:53:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] garbage collector
Message-ID: <000901c0acd1$e8709ad0$921a5e18@bh>

Ryszard:
Would it help the GC issues if there were a PRG-callable function to destroy
arrays or codeblocks for real once the programmer is sure he/she is done
with it?
    _KillItem(bBlock)

There are lots of situations (closing of a window, for example) where many
items could get cleaned up directly rather than waiting for an idle state of
some sort.  In the case of large arrays this would give some control over
when the memory can be recovered.

Or would this create two many hard-to-debug problems when the wise
programmer forgets it was embedded in a codeblock somewhere?

Brian Hays



From harbour@lists.harbour-project.org  Wed Mar 14 17:15:03 2001
From: harbour@lists.harbour-project.org (Juan Agustin Barriga)
Date: Wed Mar 14 17:15:03 2001
Subject: [Harbour] COPY TO finished
References: <003a01c0a98d$5fb5b280$921a5e18@bh> <003b01c0aaa2$65326800$c06410ac@jharrier> <007901c0ab1b$019c96c0$c06410ac@jharrier> <001501c0ab4d$f153db10$c06410ac@jharrier> <004701c0acbd$ad4b6610$921a5e18@bh> <001d01c0acca$ae8029a0$c06410ac@jharrier>
Message-ID: <003501c0acd3$e05752b0$c06410ac@jharrier>

A thing I forgot to mention is that I "fixed" the mess with
DBOPENINFO.abName. As it was, this field was being x_grabbed on DBUSEAREA
and the the pointer copied to the WorkAreas FileName. I changed this so each
WorkArea x_grabs the space and the copies the contents to it. Of couse I
added the x_free to dbfClose and DBUSEAREA. It seems to me that each level
shoud deal with its own grab/free issues.

Regards
Harrier

> Gimnez)

Regards,

Patrick Mast
www.Patrick.Be.kz (By Bekz.net)


From harbour@lists.harbour-project.org  Thu Mar 15 02:44:02 2001

Subject: [Harbour] Re: Harbour/Linux again
In-Reply-To: <003c01c0acaa$e441a8e0$55b572c3@map>

From harbour@lists.harbour-project.org  Thu Mar 15 06:23:02 2001
From: harbour@lists.harbour-project.org (John Skelton)
Date: Thu Mar 15 06:23:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] garbage collector
Message-ID: <200103150621_MC2-C8EC-4454@compuserve.com>

Brian,

> Or would this create two many hard-to-debug problems when the wise
> programmer forgets it was embedded in a codeblock somewhere?

Probably. :-(

Calls such as these sound fairly safe:
1. immediate full GC run - IIRC this is HB_GCALL()
2. disable GC (*)
3. (re-)enable GC
4. internal data structure consistency (validity) check
5. re-alloc/move as many things as possible (so pointers change)
   - might as well call #4 next!

(*) presumably the app will eat memory until #3 is used (and GC runs)

#2 is risky in more than the obvious way (possibly huge memory usage),
in that if an app fails without it and works with it it's then very
easy to blame the GC, whereas it may well just be that an old pointer
had not been properly cleaned up (or set NULL or ...).

I failed to persuade CA to do these. :-(  I think the idea is that
programmers either don't make pointer/logic errors or find them so
soon that they're not important.  If only.

John.

From harbour@lists.harbour-project.org  Thu Mar 15 12:21:01 2001
From: harbour@lists.harbour-project.org (David G. Holm)
Date: Thu Mar 15 12:21:01 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Proposed Rewording of the Harbour License
In-Reply-To: <20010313174719.S5326@hagbard.davep.org>
References: <200103081951.f28Jpua01849@smtp.parrett.net> <200103131650.f2DGoMU28222@smtp.parrett.net>
 <200103131650.f2DGoMU28222@smtp.parrett.net> ; from dholm@jsd-llc.com on Tue, Mar 13, 2001 at 11:50:10AM -0500
Message-ID: <200103151720.f2FHKoS06089@smtp.parrett.net>

** Reply to message from Dave Pearson <davep@davep.org> on Tue, 13 Mar
2001 17:47:19 +0000

> the second was to ask if you'd mind annotating what you
> think the harbour version of this actually says.

OK. Following is a copy of the proposed Harbour Exception with my
annotations of what I think that it is actually saying.

>  As a special exception, the Harbour Project gives permission for
>  additional uses of the text contained in its release of Harbour.

The above part appears to be simply a successful attempt to increase
the verbosity of the exception, but is probably there for some specific
legal reason...

>  The exception is that, if you link the Harbour libraries with other
>  files to produce an executable, this does not by itself cause the
>  resulting executable to be covered by the GNU General Public License.
>  Your use of that executable is in no way restricted on account of
>  linking the Harbour library code into it.

The above paragraph is essentially identical to the one that has been
beaten to death on this very mailing list. The only difference is that
I've replaced the overly verbose references to the HRL and the HVM with
"libraries".

The reason why is that the exception only applies to binary code
created from source code that includes the Harbour Exception. So it is
sufficient to reference "libraries" instead of specifying *which*
libraries. For example, the Pre-Processor isn't technically part of
either the HRL or the HVM, but it *is* covered by the Harbour Exception,
which means that an executable created from Harbour that includes the PP
library would not be automatically excluded from the Harbour Exception,
even if the exception only specifically mentioned the HRL and the HVM.
(Harbour itself *is* excluded from the Harbour Exception, because core
components of the source code used to build the compiler do *not*
include the exception.)

>  This exception does not however invalidate any other reasons why
>  the executable file might be covered by the GNU General Public License.

The above paragraph explicitly voids the claim by Ron's lawyer that
just linking in the libraries exempts the executable from any and all
clauses of the GNU GPL.

>  This exception applies only to the code released by the Harbour
>  Project under the name Harbour.  If you copy code from other
>  Harbour Project or Free Software Foundation releases into a copy of
>  Harbour, as the General Public License permits, the exception does
>  not apply to the code that you add in this way.  To avoid misleading
>  anyone as to the status of such modified files, you must delete
>  this exception notice from them.

The above paragraph means that, for example, if someone were to add
Guile to Harbour and release it on their own instead of committing the
changes back to the Harbour Project CVS, then the Harbour Exception
would not apply to the Guile code, but would still apply to the Harbour
code and the Guile Exception would still apply to the Guile code, so the
net result would be that the derivative "Harbour with Guile" would be
covered by both the Harbour Exception and the Guile Exception.

However, if someone were to add code from a pure GNU GPL project to
Harbour, then the code from the other project would *not* inherit the
Harbour Exception, which would mean that the Harbour Exception would not
apply to any executable created from this derivative Harbour.

>  If you write modifications of your own for Harbour, it is your choice
>  whether to permit this exception to apply to your modifications.
>  If you do not wish that, delete this exception notice.

The above paragraph means that if you modify Harbour independently of
the Harbour Project, then you can remove the exception from any source
code that you modify (but you can't *add* it to any source code and you
*can't* remove it from source code that you *haven't* modified). The net
result would be that executables created from your derivative version of
Harbour would *not* be covered by the Harbour Exception if the resulting
executable included code from modules that you modified and removed the
Harbour Exception from.

For example, if you modify source/rtl/trim.c and remove the Harbour
Exception, then if I use your derivative version of Harbour, but don't
use any of the functions from the trim.c module and that module does
*not* get linked into my executable, then my resulting executable might
*still* be eligible for the Harbour Exception. But, if the trim module
*were* to be linked in (for example, if I used "REQUEST TRIM" somewhere
in my source code), then my executable would *not* be eligible for the
Harbour Exception, because it now includes code that was built from
source that no longer contained the exception.
-- 
David G. Holm, Set Captain and all around
Harbour Project Clipper Compatibility fanatic.

>        deleting) and DBEXISTS (for table/index verification).

www.Patrick.Be.kz (By Bekz.net)

From harbour@lists.harbour-project.org  Thu Mar 15 13:53:00 2001
From: harbour@lists.harbour-project.org (Juan Agustin Barriga)
Date: Thu Mar 15 13:53:00 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Re: COPY TO finished
References: <NCBBJKNMIDPJNLJCHCHIEENIGAAA.harbour@winfakt.com>
Message-ID: <005001c0ad80$e618d4a0$c06410ac@jharrier>

NO, dbExit will only be called if defined. See hb_rddShutDown( void ) on
DBCMD.C . The RDDs must change their RDDFUNCS table, anyhow, to include the
new slots, allthough dbExit can be NULL. DBEXISTS & DBDROP should be
implemented for COPY TO to work.

Regards
Harrier

From harbour@lists.harbour-project.org  Thu Mar 15 14:16:02 2001
From: harbour@lists.harbour-project.org (Ryszard Glab)
Date: Thu Mar 15 14:16:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Re: COPY TO finished
In-Reply-To: <005001c0ad80$e618d4a0$c06410ac@jharrier>
Message-ID: <3AB122CA.3325.175FB76@localhost>

On 15 Mar 2001, at 14:51, Juan Agustin Barriga wrote:

> NO, dbExit will only be called if defined. See hb_rddShutDown( void ) on
> DBCMD.C . The RDDs must change their RDDFUNCS table, anyhow, to include
> the new slots, allthough dbExit can be NULL. DBEXISTS & DBDROP should be
> implemented for COPY TO to work.

  I think that we should add a single RDD entry only named for example 
'rddCall'. This should accept a numeric index into an extension function, 
similar to ordInfo and dbInfo. This way only a single new entry will be 
needed in RDD table and this will allow to support RDD specific calls 
without rebuilding virtual tables in drivers that doesn't support a given 
function.
  At least this is what I have done in the new RDD version that I am 
working on.

Regards, Ryszard

H:H:\enregis\.
  
  Just create a File with a FPT and you'll see !

Content-type: text/plain; charset=US-ASCII
Content-transfer-encoding: 7BIT
Content-description: Text from file 'test2.prg'

#include "fivewin.ch"
Set Exclusive off
Set deleted on
function Main()
   Local Drive:="F"
   request _DBFCDX
   rddRegister( "DBFCDX", 1 )
   SET(_SET_AUTOPEN,.f.)
   RDDSETDEFAULT("DBFCDX")
   Select A
   use (Drive)+":\enregis\client"
Return nil


--Message-Boundary-30530--

if dbexists( "MYFILE", "", "MY_RDD" )

endif

From harbour@lists.harbour-project.org  Thu Mar 15 17:02:01 2001
From: harbour@lists.harbour-project.org (David G. Holm)
Date: Thu Mar 15 17:02:01 2001
Subject: [Harbour] ChangeLog 2001-03-15 17:00 UTC-0500 David G. Holm
Message-ID: <200103152201.f2FM1RS01779@smtp.parrett.net>

2001-03-15 17:00 UTC-0500 David G. Holm <dholm@jsd-llc.com>

  * contrib/libmisc/Makefile
  * contrib/libmisc/makefile.bc
  * contrib/libmisc/makefile.vc
    + Added twirler.prg

  + contrib/libmisc/twirler.prg
    + New class provides twirler functionality with optional title
      and smoothing (by specifying a minimum time between updates).

  + Makefile
    + Added the new twirl.prg module to BAD_PRG_SOURCES, because
      it uses the LIBMISC library (to build this program, you'll
      have to add "CONTRIBS=LIBMISC" ahead of "LIBS=\").

  + tests/twirl.prg
    + New module to test the twirler class using seven twirlers.
-- 
David G. Holm, Set Captain and all around
Harbour Project Clipper Compatibility fanatic.

One more observation about the web site. The "See latest ChangeLog" link is
probably better as:

http://cvs.sourceforge.net/cgi-bin/cvsweb.cgi/~checkout~/harbour/ChangeLog?cvsroot=harbour-project

Currently it points to the change details of the ChangeLog, not the content
of the ChangeLog. The link above gives the user access to the *content* of
the current ChangeLog.

Hi,

  Sorry for this one I finally found the problem, for whom that didn't 
use Ilink32 and BC5.5 before: 
 
 The first object after the C0?32.obj must be your starting program

  Sorry if I disturb Harbour developper with this one ! ;(, but I think 
this information will be usefull for Clipper user. I didn't touch any 
other language and Linker since Clipper Winter 85 !

  One error still remain the one related for FPT file ! Any clue ?

  Thank you,

  Sylvain

From harbour@lists.harbour-project.org  Fri Mar 16 10:31:02 2001
From: harbour@lists.harbour-project.org (Ryszard Glab)
Date: Fri Mar 16 10:31:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] ChangeLog 2001-03-16 16:10 UTC+0100
Message-ID: <3AB240CC.26315.1839D67@localhost>

    *doc/en/garbage.txt
    *include/hbapi.h
    *source/vm/garbage.c
    *source/vm/itemapi.c
        * new functions: hb_gcGripGet() and hb_gcGripDrop() for dynamic
        allocation/deallocation of items
        * added redefinition of _getGrip/_dropGrip to use 
        hb_gcGripGet/hb_gcGripDrop
        * items allocated with hb_itemNew() or direct _getGrip() calls are
        maintained properly by the Garbage Collector - there is no need
        to locking/unlocking such items.
        * removed no longer needed hb_gcLockItem/hb_gcUnlockItem    

    *source/rdd/dbcmd.c
    *source/rdd/workarea.c
    *source/rdd/dbfntx/dbfntx1.c
    *source/rtl/errorapi.c
    *source/rtl/idle.c
    *source/rtl/setkey.c
        * removed no longer needed calls for 
hb_gcLockItem/hb_gcUnlockItem    
        
NOTE: there is no hb_gcLockItem/hb_gcUnlockItem functions - please remove
    calls for these functions from your code.

Regards, Ryszard

From harbour@lists.harbour-project.org  Fri Mar 16 11:37:02 2001
From: harbour@lists.harbour-project.org (David G. Holm)
Date: Fri Mar 16 11:37:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] ChangeLog 2001-03-15 17:00 UTC-0500 David G. Holm
In-Reply-To: <000301c0ad9d$1df8f6e0$0f2aa8c0@antonio>
References: <200103152201.f2FM1RS01779@smtp.parrett.net>
Message-ID: <200103161636.f2GGaDS13334@smtp.parrett.net>

** Reply to message from "Antonio Linares" <alinares@fivetech.com> on
Thu, 15 Mar 2001 23:13:08 +0100

> What is it a twirler ?

It sequentially displays various characters in the same screen location
to indicate progress. Also known as a spinner. The twirler uses the
characters |, /, -, and \ by default. The test program (tests/twirl.prg)
shows other variations, including a throbber, that uses the characters,
., o, O, and o.
-- 
David G. Holm, Set Captain and all around
Harbour Project Clipper Compatibility fanatic.

From harbour@lists.harbour-project.org  Fri Mar 16 14:08:56 2001
From: harbour@lists.harbour-project.org (Marek Paliwoda)
Date: Fri Mar 16 14:08:56 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Re: Harbour/Linux again
References: <003c01c0acaa$e441a8e0$55b572c3@map>
 <1514602912.20010315095731@belacy.belgorod.su>
Message-ID: <001201c0ae4c$8e9d60c0$c3b372c3@map>

Alexander,

... snip ...

> MP> So generally I wouldn't expect 100% compatibility with Clipper under
> MP> Unix. We can reach better compatibility in some environments but not
> MP> in all cases.
>
>  Yes, in case of work from the remote terminal there is a lot of
>  possible problems and they can be solved only by tuning of appropriate
>  software, termcaps, etc.
>  But we can expect, I think, that if we work from the console, it
>  should be Ok, isn't it ?

When we are talking about *LINUX* console - probably yes.

But there are oher Unixes in a world and things are stil very complicated.
For example I have an access to Sco OpenServer with its console set on
a PC (exactly like in linux) but this console is rather limited too. In fact,
tricks must be done to force it work good.
And what about such Unixes like HP - based on non PC computers ? They
usualy have a console set on a terminal by default (and it could be the same
for linux, Sco and others, when working in a specific environments). I have
an access to HPUX and can say that even administrative work I try to do
from a terminal emulation, not from console, because I find it very unusable .

So I still think the compatibility is a big problem. But of course I fully
agree that EVERYTHING SHOULD BE DONE to reach maximum point
of compatibility, at least in LINUX.


Regards
Marek Paliwoda





From harbour@lists.harbour-project.org  Fri Mar 16 15:27:01 2001
From: harbour@lists.harbour-project.org (David G. Holm)
Date: Fri Mar 16 15:27:01 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Potential NTX and CDX problems?
Message-ID: <200103162026.f2GKQ5r04042@smtp.parrett.net>

I get the following warnings with RSXNT:

First for NTX:

> gcc -I. -I../../../../../include -Zwin32 -Wall  -c ../../dbfntx1.c -odbfntx1.o
> ../../dbfntx1.c: In function `hb_ntxIndexCreate':
> ../../dbfntx1.c:1655: warning: unknown conversion type character `*' in format
> ../../dbfntx1.c:1655: warning: too many arguments for format

That's for this sprintf call:

> sprintf( szBuffer, "%0*.0*f", pTag->KeyLength,
>        pTag->KeyDec, hb_numRound( hb_itemGetND( pItem ),
>        pTag->KeyDec ) );

And:

> ../../dbfntx1.c:1663: warning: unknown conversion type character `*' in format
> ../../dbfntx1.c:1663: warning: too many arguments for format

Which is for this sprintf call:

> sprintf( szBuffer, "%0*.0*f", pTag->KeyLength,
>        pTag->KeyDec, hb_itemGetND( pItem ) );

Based in the compiler not complaining about sprintf calls that use
"%0*li", I am assuming that the problem is with the "*f" part of the
"%0*.0*f" format specifier.

Then for CDX:

> gcc -I. -I../../../../../include -Zwin32 -Wall  -c ../../dbfcdx1.c -odbfcdx1.o
> ../../dbfcdx1.c:169: warning: initialization from incompatible pointer type

This turns out to be due to the DBFCDX code not having table entries
for 
DBENTRYP_I0, DBENTRYP_I1, or DBENTRYP_I2, which are supposed to appear
ahead of DBENTRYP_SVP, which is the last entry in the table.

The remaining warnings don't appear to be critical:

> ../../dbfcdx1.c: In function `hb_cdxSortStuffKey':
> ../../dbfcdx1.c:3256: warning: suggest parentheses around + or - inside shift
> ../../dbfcdx1.c: In function `hb_cdxSortGetNode':
> ../../dbfcdx1.c:3303: warning: suggest parentheses around + or - inside shift
> ../../dbfcdx1.c:3355: warning: suggest parentheses around + or - inside shift
> ../../dbfcdx1.c: In function `hb_cdxOrderCreate':
> ../../dbfcdx1.c:3679: warning: int format, long int arg (arg 2)
> ../../dbfcdx1.c:3681: warning: int format, long int arg (arg 2)
> ../../dbfcdx1.c: At top level:
> ../../dbfcdx1.c:1326: warning: `hb_cdxKeyGetItem' defined but not used
-- 
David G. Holm, Set Captain and all around
Harbour Project Clipper Compatibility fanatic.

From harbour@lists.harbour-project.org  Sat Mar 17 14:22:01 2001
From: harbour@lists.harbour-project.org (Alexander S.Kresin)

Subject: [Harbour] Re: Potential NTX and CDX problems?
In-Reply-To: <200103162026.f2GKQ5r04042@smtp.parrett.net>

Message-ID: <1172354774.20010317215925@belacy.belgorod.su>

On  Friday, March 16, 2001, 23:25 David G. Holm <dholm@jsd-llc.com> wrote:

DGH> I get the following warnings with RSXNT:

DGH> First for NTX:

>> gcc -I. -I../../../../../include -Zwin32 -Wall  -c ../../dbfntx1.c -odbfntx1.o
>> ../../dbfntx1.c: In function `hb_ntxIndexCreate':
>> ../../dbfntx1.c:1655: warning: unknown conversion type character `*' in format
>> ../../dbfntx1.c:1655: warning: too many arguments for format

DGH> That's for this sprintf call:

>> sprintf( szBuffer, "%0*.0*f", pTag->KeyLength,
>>        pTag->KeyDec, hb_numRound( hb_itemGetND( pItem ),
>>        pTag->KeyDec ) );

 As it seems, some compilers doesn't accept the second '0' in
 "%0*.0*f" ( it is Ok with BC ).
 Now fixed - changed to "%0*.*f" - and, what is interesting, with BC
 it gives the same result, as the old format string.

 Alexander
http://members.xoom.com/alkresin/

From harbour@lists.harbour-project.org  Sun Mar 18 02:37:03 2001
From: harbour@lists.harbour-project.org (Brian Hays)
Date: Sun Mar 18 02:37:03 2001
Subject: [Harbour] ScopeValue passed to RDDs
Message-ID: <000f01c0af7f$0640eec0$921a5e18@bh>

ordScope() was originally coded to only accept a string.  Since several data
types are valid, I fixed the parameter checking, but we need a decision on
what gets passed to SELF_SETSCOPE.

Do we convert everything to a string value in ordscope and always set
sInfo.scopeValue to this string (which would work OK with ADS but doesn't
seem most flexible), OR do we change ordScope to always pass down the item,
and have all RDDs responsible for converting item contents to appropriate
values?

BTW, what is the best way to convert a numeric item (potentially int or
double) to a string representation?

Brian Hays

From harbour@lists.harbour-project.org  Sun Mar 18 03:09:03 2001
From: harbour@lists.harbour-project.org (Dave Pearson)
Date: Sun Mar 18 03:09:03 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Creating Msvc Build
In-Reply-To: <006c01c0af7f$61a2f1f0$b6122a0a@chasechevy>; from ptucker@sympatico.ca on Sun, Mar 18, 2001 at 02:45:19AM -0500
References: <006c01c0af7f$61a2f1f0$b6122a0a@chasechevy>
Message-ID: <20010318080823.L5326@hagbard.davep.org>

On Sun, Mar 18, 2001 at 02:45:19AM -0500, Paul Tucker wrote:

> Ok I am getting caught up just enough to do a build, then I get on a plane
> in a few hours.
> 
> I downloaded the source and it is from Feb 20th and says it's 0.35j.
> 
> Where do I get a non linux flavour of the source for version 0.36?

[There's not really a "Linux flavour" of the source, but...] You can get
DOS/WinTel formatted source code from the same place that you can get Un*x
formatted source code: <URL:http://www.harbour-project.org/download.htm>.
Grab the source ZIP file.

Note that if you want to be playing with source from a development point of
view (you posted this to the developers mailing list so I'm guessing you do)
then you'd probably do better to grab the latest source from the CVS server.
The harbour FAQ contains lots of information on how to get anonymous CVS
access working on your machine.

--

server.

> access working on your machine.

Subject: [Harbour] Re: ScopeValue passed to RDDs
In-Reply-To: <000f01c0af7f$0640eec0$921a5e18@bh>
References: <000f01c0af7f$0640eec0$921a5e18@bh>
Message-ID: <9219073162.20010319140156@belacy.belgorod.su>

On 18.03.2001 10:42, Brian Hays <bhays@abacuslaw.com> wrote:

BH> ordScope() was originally coded to only accept a string.  Since several data
BH> types are valid, I fixed the parameter checking, but we need a decision on
BH> what gets passed to SELF_SETSCOPE.

BH> Do we convert everything to a string value in ordscope and always set
BH> sInfo.scopeValue to this string (which would work OK with ADS but doesn't
BH> seem most flexible), OR do we change ordScope to always pass down the item,
BH> and have all RDDs responsible for converting item contents to appropriate
BH> values?

 I think, the second is better.

BH> BTW, what is the best way to convert a numeric item (potentially int or
BH> double) to a string representation?

 Don't know, is it the best way, but I used for it the sprintf()
 function - see dbfntx1.c, ntxIndexCreate() .

 Alexander

From harbour@lists.harbour-project.org  Wed Mar 21 06:27:02 2001
From: harbour@lists.harbour-project.org (Dave Pearson)
Date: Wed Mar 21 06:27:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Re: What happens ?
In-Reply-To: <18314385727.20010321125346@belacy.belgorod.su>; from alex@belacy.belgorod.su on Wed, Mar 21, 2001 at 12:53:46PM +0300
References: <18314385727.20010321125346@belacy.belgorod.su>
Message-ID: <20010321112616.H5326@hagbard.davep.org>

[Caution: There's guesswork in this email, believe it at your own peril <g>]

On Wed, Mar 21, 2001 at 12:53:46PM +0300, Alexander S.Kresin wrote:
> > Are you able to "see" lists.harbour-project.org?
> 
>  No, only www.harbour-project.org ( I used tracert for checking ).
>  But I think that I didn't see it before too, because my mailer never
>  could resolve lists.harbour-project.org and deliver the message
>  directly - only via my ISP system.

The reason I ask is that the internet is a less trusting place these days,
mostly thanks to the efforts of those who think that UCE is a good method of
advertising goods and services. Some MTAs will silently drop any email that
has an envelope that comes from an unresolvable location.

There's a chance that an MTA between Phil's machine and your machine is
doing exactly this to try and make sure that the amount of UCE you received
is reduced. The downside of this is that if it can't resolve the envelope
sender of harbour list mails it's going to treat them exactly the same.

I was hit by this when I reworked my local network so that all the machines
internally used davep.org in their names (hagbard.davep.org, rama.davep.org,
eris.davep.org, darwin.davep.org, and so on). Messages were being sent out
with an envelope from davep@hagbard.davep.org. Some people received such
email, others didn't (most notably people at Compu$erve (Hi John!)). Once
I'd fixed the configuration of sendmail on hagbard so that the envelope was
masqueraded as just davep.org (not hagbard.davep.org) every worked fine.

Note that in all of this no bounce messages could or would have been
produced because the domain mentioned in the envelope wasn't resolvable so
there was nowhere to return the bounce to.

What is interesting is that you can't see lists.harbour-project.org. Has
this always been the case or is it a recent thing (I note that you say
"never" but I feel compelled to double check with you)? Patrick's changes to
DNS the other week resulted lists.harbour-project.org disappearing for some
of us but it's back now. Did it disappear recently? If so perhaps there's a
broken name server near you?

>  But, as you see, I'm still able to write to the list - only have no
>  feedback.

Hmm, this would almost suggest that your ISP has no problems but that it's
your machine that's silently ignoring mails from domains that can't be
resolved. Are you running any kind of UCE protection on your own machine?

-- 
The Harbour Project: A free software Clipper compatible compiler
Home Page..........: http://www.harbour-project.org/
FAQ................: http://www.harbour-project.org/faq/harbour.html
My harbour page....: http://www.davep.org/harbour/

From harbour@lists.harbour-project.org  Wed Mar 21 12:15:04 2001
From: harbour@lists.harbour-project.org (Marek Paliwoda)
Date: Wed Mar 21 12:15:04 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Harbour GPF in ac_test.exe in MingW32 environment
Message-ID: <001e01c0b22a$a45b6ec0$2db572c3@map>

Hi,

    I am getting random GPFs in ac_test.exe program created 
under MingW32 environment, when it ends. 

The trace log is as follow :

(gdb) bt
#0  0x412fb6 in hb_codeblockDelete ()
#1  0x40d032 in hb_itemClear ()
#2  0x41ebd7 in hb_errExit ()
#3  0x4020df in hb_vmQuit ()
#4  0x401e94 in main ()
#5  0x4011b1 in __mingw_CRTStartup ()
#6  0x4011cf in mainCRTStartup ()
#7  0xbff8b560 in _size_of_stack_reserve__ ()
#8  0xbff8b412 in _size_of_stack_reserve__ ()
#9  0xbff89dd5 in _size_of_stack_reserve__ ()

Is it possible that this error is related to recent GC changes ? 

Seems to me it can be. In errorapi.c

    static HB_ITEM s_errorBlock;

is declared and filled thru hb_itemCopy(), so it can be released 
by GC too ealier ( or I am missing something ).

After I locally fixed errorapi.c by changing it from

    static HB_ITEM s_errorBlock;
to
    static HB_ITEM_PTR s_errorBlock;,

and assigning it a new item from hb_itemNew( NULL ), and also 
changing all references to s_errorBlock acording to that modification,
a problem disapeared.

The funny thing is that under Djgpp and Linux I could not 
reproduce it.

Marek Paliwoda

Message-ID: <3AB91C42.21692.2299B83@localhost>

    *include/hbapi.h
    *source/vm/codebloc.c
    *source/vm/memvars.c
        * fixed possible loop during a codeblock releasing called
        by the garbage Collector

    *source/rtl/errorapi.c
        *replaced 'static HB_ITEM' to 'static HB_ITEM_PTR' to make it
        the GC friendly

Hi Ron,

I can't understand what could be wrong, but having (re) tryed many 
hours to fully recompile Harbour 0.36 with Simplex, I always have 
the same problem I was having with 0.35.

I can compile Harbour.exe bich correctly indicate 0.36 (Simplex) 
but this version seem to loop on some Prg, rendereing the Lib 
creation impossible (Ctrl-C is the only way to abort the looping). 
The BC 5.5 version (Simplex) as the VC++ Flex are perfectly 
working here. I don't see any debug action I could try. If you want, I 
cant send you the Bad Harbour.exe and even as many exe as you 
could need (with traces or wathever you could need) to you by 
direct E-mail.

Just for Info, this is my what my VC++ compiler say when running.

>>
Microsoft (R) 32-bit C/C++ Optimizing Compiler Version 
12.00.8168 for 80x86
Copyright (C) Microsoft Corp 1984-1998. All rights reserved.

From harbour@lists.harbour-project.org  Wed Mar 21 23:14:02 2001
From: harbour@lists.harbour-project.org (Ron Pinkas)
Date: Wed Mar 21 23:14:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] RON: Always having problem with VC++ and Simplex version
In-Reply-To: <200103212223.f2LMN8t16559@ev6.be.wanadoo.com>
Message-ID: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKEELDDKAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>

Hello J.F.,

Attached is a zip file with my hb_slex.vc and the resulting make_vc.log.
Please compare with your make_vc.log.

As you can see from the LOG file, I had no problem building VC++ SimpLex
build.

Can you please try with the attached make file and let me know?

Please note, I used:

----------
Microsoft (R) 32-bit C/C++ Optimizing Compiler Version 13.00.9030 for 80x86
Copyright (C) Microsoft Corp 1984-2000. All rights reserved.

usage: cl [ option... ] filename... [ /link linkoption... ]
----------

and

----------
Microsoft (R) Macro Assembler Version 6.15.9030
Copyright (C) Microsoft Corp 1981-2000.  All rights reserved.

usage: ML [ options ] filelist [ /link linkoptions]
Run "ML /help" or "ML /?" for more info
----------

You might have to change AS (line 86) from ML to MASM and check this line
(594):

$(AS) /c /Fo$@ $<

If you still fail, I will suggest you try UNCOMMENTing lines (30-31) in
harbour.slx:

//#define SHOW_LEX_TOKENS
//#define DEBUG_LEX

This will generate TRACE info from Lexer, that might explain your problem.

Ron

From harbour@lists.harbour-project.org  Thu Mar 22 02:19:02 2001
From: harbour@lists.harbour-project.org (Phil Barnett)
Date: Thu Mar 22 02:19:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Re: What happens ?
In-Reply-To: <1335608764.20010321102731@belacy.belgorod.su>
Message-ID: <3AB960FF.300.484A3E84@localhost>

On 21 Mar 2001, at 10:27, Alexander S.Kresin wrote:

> > It seems unlikely that this is the cause, considering your email
> > addredd, but competition makes strange bedfellows, so one never
> > knows... http://www.msnbc.com/news/546689.asp?0nm=C14R&cp1=1
> 
>   I don't think so, because the url above tell about lost messages
>   from EarthLink users to AOL, but I haven't any relation to these
>   companies.
>   I still don't receive any messages from Harbour lists - yours I read on
>   matrixlist.com .

You'd have to look through your headers to see if your mail is 
routed through AOL somewhere before you would know. There is 
lots of peering going on right now...  

I'm beginning to think that in todays climate, we'd be better off if we 
made the replyto address of our list harbour@matrixlist.com and 
that way, things would trace, reverse lookups to the PTR record 
would work, etc.

It's really simple for me to change this. It wouldn't effect anything 
negatively (except the image that our list belongs to our domain).

Everyone's opinion?


--

   * hb_slex.vc
     * Minor corrections.

   * include/hbapi.h
     + extern PHB_ITEM hb_paramError( int iParam ); /* Returns either the
generic parameter or a NIL item if param not provided */
     + extern PHB_ITEM hb_arrayFromStack( USHORT uiLen ); /* Creates and
returns an Array of n Elements from the Eval Stack - Does NOT pop the items.
*/
     + extern PHB_ITEM hb_arrayFromParams( void ); /* Creates and returns an
Array of current Generic Parameters. */

   * include/hbapierr.h
     * extern USHORT   hb_errRT_BASE           ( ULONG ulGenCode, ULONG
ulSubCode, char * szDescription, char * szOperation, USHORT uiArgCount,
... );
     * extern USHORT   hb_errRT_BASE_Ext1      ( ULONG ulGenCode, ULONG
ulSubCode, char * szDescription, char * szOperation, USHORT uiOsCode, USHORT
uiFlags, USHORT uiArgCount, ... );
     * extern PHB_ITEM hb_errRT_BASE_Subst     ( ULONG ulGenCode, ULONG
ulSubCode, char * szDescription, char * szOperation, USHORT uiArgCount,
... );
     * extern void     hb_errRT_BASE_SubstR    ( ULONG ulGenCode, ULONG
ulSubCode, char * szDescription, char * szOperation, USHORT uiArgCount,
... );
       + Added support for variable number of Error Arguments.

   * source/rtl/errorapi.c
     * hb_errRT_BASE           ( ULONG ulGenCode, ULONG ulSubCode, char *
szDescription, char * szOperation, USHORT uiArgCount, ... );
     * hb_errRT_BASE_Ext1      ( ULONG ulGenCode, ULONG ulSubCode, char *
szDescription, char * szOperation, USHORT uiOsCode, USHORT uiFlags, USHORT
uiArgCount, ... );
     * hb_errRT_BASE_Subst     ( ULONG ulGenCode, ULONG ulSubCode, char *
szDescription, char * szOperation, USHORT uiArgCount, ... );
     * hb_errRT_BASE_SubstR    ( ULONG ulGenCode, ULONG ulSubCode, char *
szDescription, char * szOperation, USHORT uiArgCount, ... );
       + Added support for variable number of Error Arguments.

   * source/vm/arrays.c
     + PHB_ITEM hb_arrayFromStack( USHORT uiLen )
     + PHB_ITEM hb_arrayFromParams( void )

   */

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Fri Mar 23 02:19:01 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Phil Barnett)
Date: Fri Mar 23 02:19:01 2001
Subject: [Harbour] List address changes, location remains same.
Message-ID: <3ABAB271.28715.4D7089AE@localhost>

Because of mail filtering policies in place around the world today, it 
becomes increasingly important to have an address that will do a 
reverse lookup.  

lists.harbour-project.org does not, and was an alias for 
matrixlist.com, which will do reverse lookups.  

Therefore I have changed this mailing list replyto address to  

harbour@matrixlist.com as of today.  



-- 
              Phil Barnett  mailto:midnight@the-oasis.net
                       WWW  http://www.the-oasis.net/
                  FTP Site  ftp://ftp.the-oasis.net

either lost or denied delivery.

Messages that made it to the list but didn't get distributed to 
everyone are available in the archives.

that's obviously missing and move on.

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Fri Mar 23 03:56:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Brian Hays)
Date: Fri Mar 23 03:56:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] CHANGELOG: 2001-03-23 00:45 UTC-0800
Message-ID: <002a01c0b377$eb58a830$921a5e18@bh>

2001-03-23 00:45 UTC-0800 Brian Hays <bhays@abacuslaw.com>
   * contrib/rdd_ads/ads1.c
      * added unique index creation support
      * tweaked SELF_OPEN to return FAILURE only for probable sharing
         errors, but throw a real error for everything else.
         This way you get the information at runtime for things like
         failure to find a server or other useful ADS error#s

   * contrib/rdd_ads/adsfunc.c
      * minor error handling in ADSGETAOFOPTLEVEL

   * source/rdd/dbcmd.c
      * fixed handling of fourth IsScoped parameter in dbSetRelation

   + contrib/rdd_ads/adsmgmnt.c
      + added wrappers for most Management functions, including statistics
         on connections, comm success rates,
         # of open tables/indexes/users, etc.
         (( work in progress ))

   + contrib/rdd_ads/testmg.prg
      + simple test for management functions

   * contrib/rdd_ads/Makefile
   * contrib/rdd_ads/makefile.bc
   * contrib/rdd_ads/makefile.vc
      * added adsmgmnt.c to build

   >>> I only use Borland; someone please check the other make files!

2001-03-23 00:55 UTC-0800 Brian Hays <bhays@abacuslaw.com>
   * contrib/rdd_ads/testmg.prg
      * fixed header

Brian Hays



From harbour@matrixlist.com  Fri Mar 23 09:21:03 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Sylvain Robert )
Date: Fri Mar 23 09:21:03 2001
Subject: [Harbour] DBFCDX problem
Message-ID: <3ABAF2A4.24825.192ECE@localhost>

--Message-Boundary-24368
Content-type: text/plain; charset=US-ASCII
Content-transfer-encoding: 7BIT
Content-description: Mail message body

Good Morning,

  I reported an error with DBFCDX and FPT last week !

  To help developer to see and solve the problem I wrote a little 
sample.

  Just compile and executed and see wich error Harbour Give !

  Any comment will be appreciated

  Thank you,

  Sylvain 


--Message-Boundary-24368
Content-type: text/plain; charset=US-ASCII
Content-transfer-encoding: 7BIT
Content-description: Text from file 'test2.prg'

// FPT Problem !
// When opening the FPT File it seem's that the (drive) reference is added
// again to the filespec.
function Main()
   Local Drive:="C",Astruct:=Array(1,4)

   Set exclusive off
   Set deleted on

   astruct[1]:={"test1","M",10,0}
   request _DBFCDX
   rddRegister( "DBFCDX", 1 )
   SET(_SET_AUTOPEN,.f.)
   RDDSETDEFAULT("DBFCDX")
   DBCREATE("test2",astruct,"DBFCDX")
   Select A
   use (Drive)+":\"+ALLTRIM(CURDIR())+"\test2"
   close Database
Return nil


--Message-Boundary-24368--

Hi J.F.

> >>
>    * source/vm/classes.c
>      + Added 0 arguments (J.F. can you please decide what should
> be the arguments! ) >>
>
> Sorry if this is a dumb question, but could you explain me a bit
> more what exactly you expect ? I was a bit busy those last month,
> so I have not read all treads and perhaps I'm missing some thing :-
> ((((

I added support for passing the variable number of Arguments of an Error
operations. You should review classes.c and decides which arguments to pass
for the different errors.

So just search for RT_BASE and simply change the ", 0 )" to ",N ,Arg1, ...,
ArgN )", when needed.


BTW, did you get my reply about SimpLex and VC++?

Ron

> >    Set deleted on

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Tue Mar 27 11:17:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (David G. Holm)
Date: Tue Mar 27 11:17:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Traffic slow since change.
In-Reply-To: <20010327165237.A15895@hagbard.davep.org>
References: <20010327134118.G16262@hagbard.davep.org> <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKKEMKDKAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>
 <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKKEMKDKAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com> ; from Ron@Profit-Master.com on Tue, Mar 27, 2001 at 07:22:46AM -0800
Message-ID: <200103271613.f2RGDp203392@smtp.parrett.net>

** Reply to message from Dave Pearson <davep@davep.org> on Tue, 27 Mar
2001 16:52:37 +0100

> This is my concern, we don't seem to be fixing anything. That is, sure,
> replying to matrixlist.com is a useful short term method of getting email to
> the list but it seems to me there's a deeper problem here. It might be worth
> us getting to the bottom of that.

The deeper problem has already been explained by the owner of the
domains involved, in a message to the list with the subject "Re: What
happens?": "I'm beginning to think that in todays climate, we'd be
better off if we made the replyto address of our list
harbour@matrixlist.com and that way, things would trace, reverse lookups
to the PTR record would work, etc."

In other words, harbour@lists.harbour-project.org could not be traced
and reverse lookups on it would fail. This was causing some SMTP
servers, such as my ISP's SMTP server, to refuse to deliver mail to the
list. The following reason was given:

> ----- The following addresses had permanent fatal errors -----
> harbour@lists.harbour-project.org
>     (reason: 553 sorry, that domain isn't in my list of allowed rcpthosts (#5.7.1))

What the message means is that my ISP's SMTP server couldn't do a
reverse lookup of the domain name in the delivery address and that the
domain name was not in its list of domains that don't require a reverse
lookup. This *is* the deeper problem that is being solved by changing
the return address for the list from one that can't be resolved via
reverse lookup to one that can...
-- 
David G. Holm, Set Captain and all around
Harbour Project Clipper Compatibility fanatic.

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Tue Mar 27 11:45:04 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Brian Hays)
Date: Tue Mar 27 11:45:04 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Alpha .37
References: <3AC03486.5816.B9DA523@localhost>
Message-ID: <004601c0b6de$29538bf0$921a5e18@bh>

Phil:
Some of the bugs I reported are fairly innocuous, but this one can affect a
lot of things:

------------------------------------------------------------------
Symbol searches fail if the symbol has trailing spaces.
   For example,
      use test alias test
      // this would be cVar's value if read from a dbf field
      cVar := "TEST      "
      select(cVar)  --> returns 0
   The discussion on this centered on a desire to not slow down all symbol
   handling (the bug is not only in the select function)
------------------------------------------------------------------

I also have a standing question re SetScope which only Alexander replied to,
but I can make the change if we agree:  The problem is numeric Scopes fail.
My proposed fix is that the scope be passed to SELF_ as the original Item
for parsing, whereas now it is checked in ordScope and only the value is
passed.

Should we send down the item instead??


Brian
----- Original Message -----
From: "Phil Barnett" <midnight@the-oasis.net>
>
> So, what are we missing for .37?
>

To further illustrate this point:

,----
| davep@hagbard:~$ host lists.harbour-project.org
| lists.harbour-project.org mail is handled (pri=30) by matrixlist.com
|
| davep@hagbard:~$ telnet matrixlist.com smtp
| Trying 206.132.232.90...
| Connected to matrixlist.com.
| Escape character is '^]'.
| 220 taz2.fiberhosting.com ESMTP
| mail from: davep@davep.org
| 250 ok
| rcpt to: <harbour@lists.harbour-project.org>
| 553 sorry, that domain isn't in my list of allowed rcpthosts (#5.7.1)
| quit
| 221 taz2.fiberhosting.com
| Connection closed by foreign host.
`----

David, if you're reading this, can you double check your reading of the
bounce message you got? I suspect you might have misread what it was telling
you.

Phil, if you're reading this, why is the machine that is the mail host for
lists.harbour-project.org refusing mail for lists.harbour-project.org? Is
this simply a postfix configuration error? Do your admin logs show any
changes to the postfix configuration on or about the time that people
reported the current mail problems?

Because the matrixlist.com SMTP server told my ISP's SMTP server that
it was a problem.

> Why can't that problem be fixed?

Because the problem is not at my ISP's end of the pipe.

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Tue Mar 27 13:03:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (David G. Holm)
Date: Tue Mar 27 13:03:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Traffic slow since change.
In-Reply-To: <20010327173927.D15895@hagbard.davep.org>
References: <20010327134118.G16262@hagbard.davep.org> <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKKEMKDKAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>
 <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKKEMKDKAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com> <20010327165237.A15895@hagbard.davep.org>
 <200103271613.f2RGDp203392@smtp.parrett.net> <200103271613.f2RGDp203392@smtp.parrett.net>
 ; from dholm@jsd-llc.com on Tue, Mar 27, 2001 at 11:16:15AM -0500
Message-ID: <200103271800.f2RI08i15511@smtp.parrett.net>

** Reply to message from Dave Pearson <davep@davep.org> on Tue, 27 Mar
2001 17:39:27 +0100

> I'm still not clear why matrixlist.com is seen as "good" but harbour's lists
> "host" is seen as bad.

Probably because 'nslookup matrixlist.com' succeeds, but 'nslookup
lists.harbour-project.org' fails, which either has to do with the type
of record needed to do a mail map of lists.harbour-project.org to
matrixlist.com, or is because the mapping has been removed. Either way,
matrixlist.com is the domain that actually manages all of the Harbour
mailing lists and it is more reliable to deal directly with the final
domain than to deal with a domain that is mail mapped. Don't ask *me*
why, because I don't know. But people that I trust that do mail hosting
have told me that certain types of mail mapping DNS records can be
problematic.
-- 
David G. Holm, Set Captain and all around
Harbour Project Clipper Compatibility fanatic.

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Tue Mar 27 13:04:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (David G. Holm)
Date: Tue Mar 27 13:04:02 2001

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Tue Mar 27 13:32:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Ryszard Glab)
Date: Tue Mar 27 13:32:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] ChangeLog 2001-03-27 20:05 UTC+0100
Message-ID: <3AC0F9A8.16738.3C15BA@localhost>

    Changes from Marek Paliwoda. Thanks Marek :)
    
    *doc/en/gtslang.txt
    *source/rtl/gtsln/gtsln.c
    *source/rtl/gtsln/kbsln.c
    *source/rtl/gtsln/keytrans.c
     - added support for displaying and entering national characters 
				(see gtslang.txt for details)
     - improved keyboard support for linux text console. Almost all
				ALT/CTRL+ SpecialKeys should work well. Note that You have to
				work using true /dev/tty[1-12] device. This means You can't
				benefit from it when You run Harbour programs from within
				Midnight Commander for example, because MC uses pseudoterminals.
     - prepared for other Unix text consoles (SCO) (not tested)
     - removed support for DOS. It was totally not needed due its
				limitations

Regards, Ryszard

On Tue, Mar 27, 2001 at 01:03:31PM -0500, David G. Holm wrote:

> 2001 18:11:36 +0100
> 
> > David, if you're reading this, can you double check your reading of the
> > bounce message you got? I suspect you might have misread what it was
> > telling you.
> 
> I don't doubt that at all.

But as I've just demonstrated, the error message is coming from Phil's
machine. not from anyone's "SMTP server" (AKA SMTP relay AKA smart host).
Your reading of it said:

,----
| What the message means is that my ISP's SMTP server couldn't do a
| reverse lookup of the domain name in the delivery address and that the
| domain name was not in its list of domains that don't require a reverse
| lookup.
`----

As you'll have seen from my test, which generated exactly the same error, no
ISP SMTP servers were involved, only Phil's machine. Also, as you'll see
from Ron's bounce message, the error was generated by Phil's machine, not by
his ISP's SMTP server.

If you doubt your reading of the error is wrong would you be so kind as to
show how my tests demonstrate that it's a reverse DNS lookup problem
involving an SMTP relay?

Right, that's one apology due to misreading that I owe you now. I didn't see
the "don't" in the above. ;>

As an aside, and to atone for my misreading <g>, I've been doing some more
hunting and found <URL:http://www.palomine.net/qmail/relaying.html> (Phil
appears to be using qmail these days, I thought he was a postfix user).

It would appear that for some reason Phil's machine has decided to refuse to
do relaying for all of us when we want to send mail to lists.h-p.org.
Possible further evidence that this is the case is:

,----
| davep@hagbard:~$ ssh oasis
| Last login: Tue Mar 27 14:34:35 2001 from hagbard.demon.co.uk
|
| davep@taz2:~$ telnet 0 smtp
| Trying 0.0.0.0...
| Connected to 0.
| Escape character is '^]'.
| 220 taz2.fiberhosting.com ESMTP
| mail from: davep@davep.org
| 250 ok
| rcpt to: <harbour@lists.harbour-project.org>
| 250 ok
| quit
| 221 taz2.fiberhosting.com
| Connection closed by foreign host.
`----

The evidence here been that taz2's SMTP server is happy to accept mail for
lists.h-p.org from within Phil's universe, but not from without.

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Tue Mar 27 18:40:03 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (April)
Date: Tue Mar 27 18:40:03 2001
Subject: [Harbour] 'contrib' app hooks into harbour
Message-ID: <3AC12610.99C6D496@mail.rosecom.ca>

I've been hitting my head with an indeterminant bug in the btree contrib
I want to make.

But that is not the issue of this email...

If a contrib needs some early initialization or termination cleanup, how
would a contrib .lib/.o do it?

When I adapted the setkey code to .c, someone suggested that I add a
call to the init & term inside one of the harbour vm files, and this
worked well... for setkey.

I know that a .prg-based contrib can use init/term procedures, but is
there any means to identify a .c file as such?

(if this has been discussed or covered, my apologies :-)

ttfn
April



From harbour@matrixlist.com  Tue Mar 27 19:09:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (David G. Holm)
Date: Tue Mar 27 19:09:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] 'contrib' app hooks into harbour
In-Reply-To: <3AC12610.99C6D496@mail.rosecom.ca>
Message-ID: <200103280005.f2S05bi21946@smtp.parrett.net>

** Reply to message from April <awhite@mail.rosecom.ca> on Tue, 27 Mar
2001 18:45:20 -0500

> If a contrib needs some early initialization or termination cleanup, how
> would a contrib .lib/.o do it?

I don't recall this having been discussed, but one way to do it would
be to look at the generated C source code for a program file that uses
INIT PROC and then reduce that to the minimum code needed. I did that
just now and came up with the following code skeleton:

/*
 * Harbour Compiler, 0.36  (Build 36) (2001.02.20) (Flex)
 * Generated C source code
 */

#include "hbvmpub.h"
#include "hbinit.h"


static HB_FUNC( STARTUP );


HB_INIT_SYMBOLS_BEGIN( hb_vm_SymbolInit_T )
{ "STARTUP", HB_FS_INIT | HB_FS_FIRST, HB_FUNCNAME( STARTUP ), NULL },
HB_INIT_SYMBOLS_END( hb_vm_SymbolInit_T )
#if defined(_MSC_VER)
   #if _MSC_VER >= 1010
      #pragma data_seg( ".CRT$XIY" )
      #pragma comment( linker, "/Merge:.CRT=.data" )
   #else
      #pragma data_seg( "XIY" )
   #endif
   static HB_$INITSYM hb_vm_auto_SymbolInit_T = hb_vm_SymbolInit_T;
   #pragma data_seg()
#elif ! defined(__GNUC__)
   #pragma startup hb_vm_SymbolInit_T
#endif

static HB_FUNC( STARTUP )
{
   /* This is where the generated PCode would normally be,
      followed by a call to the virtual machine runtime,
      but you can put whatever you want in here. */
}
-- 
David G. Holm, Set Captain and all around
Harbour Project Clipper Compatibility fanatic.

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Wed Mar 28 00:39:40 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Phil Barnett)
Date: Wed Mar 28 00:39:40 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Traffic slow since change.
In-Reply-To: <200103271800.f2RI08i15511@smtp.parrett.net>
References: <20010327173927.D15895@hagbard.davep.org>
Message-ID: <3AC1329C.3171.F7E3ABA@localhost>

On 27 Mar 2001, at 13:02, David G. Holm wrote:

> ** Reply to message from Dave Pearson <davep@davep.org> on Tue, 27 Mar
> 2001 17:39:27 +0100
> 
> > I'm still not clear why matrixlist.com is seen as "good" but harbour's lists
> > "host" is seen as bad.
> 
> Probably because 'nslookup matrixlist.com' succeeds, but 'nslookup
> lists.harbour-project.org' fails, which either has to do with the type
> of record needed to do a mail map of lists.harbour-project.org to
> matrixlist.com, or is because the mapping has been removed. Either way,
> matrixlist.com is the domain that actually manages all of the Harbour
> mailing lists and it is more reliable to deal directly with the final
> domain than to deal with a domain that is mail mapped. Don't ask *me*
> why, because I don't know. But people that I trust that do mail hosting
> have told me that certain types of mail mapping DNS records can be
> problematic.

The only thing that changed around this time is that thousands of 
machines changed their DNS version to avoid being exploited.

It is my opinion that several mail systems started rejecting mail for 
addresses that were indirect.

I updated my DNS on or about that time, but the basic DNS 
configuration records didn't change at all.

I heard that lots of other mailing lists that were doing MX redirection 
were also having problems.

That is why I suggested going to the direct address.


-- 
              Phil Barnett  mailto:midnight@the-oasis.net
                       WWW  http://www.the-oasis.net/
                  FTP Site  ftp://ftp.the-oasis.net

On 27 Mar 2001, at 8:51, Brian Hays wrote:

> Phil:
> Some of the bugs I reported are fairly innocuous, but this one can affect a
> lot of things:
> 
> ------------------------------------------------------------------
> Symbol searches fail if the symbol has trailing spaces.
>    For example,
>       use test alias test
>       // this would be cVar's value if read from a dbf field
>       cVar := "TEST      "
>       select(cVar)  --> returns 0
>    The discussion on this centered on a desire to not slow down all symbol
>    handling (the bug is not only in the select function)
> ------------------------------------------------------------------
> 
> I also have a standing question re SetScope which only Alexander replied to,
> but I can make the change if we agree:  The problem is numeric Scopes fail.
> My proposed fix is that the scope be passed to SELF_ as the original Item
> for parsing, whereas now it is checked in ordScope and only the value is
> passed.
> 
> Should we send down the item instead??

I think a couple of replies stated that they thought that would be 
the correct course of action. Have you tried it?

That was the cause of the problem, nothing to do with DNS at all:

,----
| davep@hagbard:~$telnet matrixlist.com smtp
| Trying 206.132.232.90...
| Connected to matrixlist.com.
| Escape character is '^]'.
| 220 taz2.fiberhosting.com ESMTP
| mail from: davep@davep.org
| 250 ok
| rcpt to: harbour@lists.harbour-project.org
| 250 ok
| quit
| 221 taz2.fiberhosting.com
| Connection closed by foreign host.
`----

You should be able to safely switch back to lists.harbour-project.org now.

delayed (and wasn't visible in the archives either, but is now):

    Host                            Date received (local)   Lag       Total lag
 1. Date:                            2001-03-28  07:11:29   00:00:00   00:00:00
 2. hagbard.davep.org                2001-03-28  07:11:29   00:00:00   00:00:00

 6. ns.dios.net                      2001-03-28  16:50:31   09:12:38   09:39:02
 7. (unknown)                        2001-03-28  16:50:31   00:00:00   09:39:02
 8. haybaler.sackheads.org           2001-03-28  17:18:17   00:27:46   10:06:48

11. hagbard.davep.org                2001-03-28  17:32:31   00:13:53   10:21:02

The sticking point appears to have been ns.dios.net. Anyone know who or what
dios.net are/is (well, I can guess what it is from the host name but I'm
wondering what it is in it's role as a mail relay)? I don't believe that it
has anything to do with mail routing to davep.org so that would suggest that
it has something to do with taz.fiberhosting.com (Phil's machine).

References: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKKENCDKAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com> <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKAENEDKAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com> <20010328174630.K19556@hagbard.davep.org> <20010328181114.L19556@hagbard.davep.org>

On Wed, Mar 28, 2001 at 06:11:14PM +0100, Dave Pearson wrote:

> The sticking point appears to have been ns.dios.net. Anyone know who or
> what dios.net are/is (well, I can guess what it is from the host name but
> I'm wondering what it is in it's role as a mail relay)?

Pah! I wasn't thinking. traceroute is my friend:

,----
| davep@hagbard:~$ traceroute matrixlist.com | tail -2
| 12  GTW002e0.BLT.MD.dios.net (208.178.160.2)   [SNIP]
| 13  taz.fiberhosting.com (206.132.232.90)  [SNIP]
`----

So I'm guessing that *.dios.net is where Phil's machine is located and that
ns.dios.net is some mail relay for Phil's machine and it decided to hold
onto some messages for upwards of nine hours.

source\vm\fm.c:425: HB_TR_ERROR Block 2 (size 0) ASIZE(0)
source\vm\fm.c:425: HB_TR_ERROR Block 3 (size 0) ASIZE(0)
source\vm\fm.c:425: HB_TR_ERROR Block 4 (size 0) ASIZE(0)
source\vm\fm.c:425: HB_TR_ERROR Block 5 (size 0) ASIZE(0)
source\vm\fm.c:425: HB_TR_ERROR Block 6 (size 0) ASIZE(0)

Ron

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Thu Mar 29 10:54:01 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (David G. Holm)
Date: Thu Mar 29 10:54:01 2001
Subject: [Harbour] 'contrib' app hooks into harbour
In-Reply-To: <3AC32114.44C3B7D3@mail.rosecom.ca>
References: <200103280328_MC2-CA56-EDDD@compuserve.com>
Message-ID: <200103291551.f2TFpEk17102@smtp.parrett.net>

** Reply to message from April <awhite@mail.rosecom.ca> on Thu, 29 Mar
2001 06:48:36 -0500

> I only have access of DJGPP, but would not some parts of the init/term
> procs be compiler dependant?

Harbour does *not* generate different C code based on what compiler you
used to create Harbour. All of the dependencies are in the two include
files and in the generated C code.

> Dave, can you send me the .prg you built your example from?  OR maybe I'll
> write one and get other team members to compile with assorted compilers
> and send me the source code...

Having people send you the generated C code from various Harbour
compilers would just be a waste of everybody's time...
-- 
David G. Holm, Set Captain and all around
Harbour Project Clipper Compatibility fanatic.

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Thu Mar 29 21:39:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (April)
Date: Thu Mar 29 21:39:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] 'contrib' app hooks into harbour
References: <200103280328_MC2-CA56-EDDD@compuserve.com> <200103291551.f2TFpEk17102@smtp.parrett.net>
Message-ID: <3AC3F2EA.BA40247F@mail.rosecom.ca>

"David G. Holm" wrote:

> Harbour does *not* generate different C code based on what compiler you

Thank you for politely pointing out my mistake.  I had believed that a harbour
produced with a C compiler would generate C code particular to that
compiler.

> Having people send you the generated C code from various Harbour
> compilers would just be a waste of everybody's time...

Again you are correct.  I have been experimenting with a small include
file, but I could use some pre-processor advice.

I know I cannot use a macro expansion - the macro would contain preprocessor
directives.

I have been experimenting with defining three values: init proc name, exit
proc name, and the c file name, and then including the .h file.  This has been
working fine except that :

#define THB_FUNC( n ) HB_FUNC( n )
#define THB_FUNCNAME( n ) HB_FUNCNAME(n)

#define ASSTRING( n ) n

#define SYMBOLNAME( n ) hb_vm_SymbolInit_##n
#define AUTOSYMBOLNAME( n ) hb_vm_auto_SymbolInit_##n

HB_INIT_SYMBOLS_BEGIN(SYMBOLNAME(INITCNAME))
{ ASSTRING( INITNAME ), HB_FS_INIT, THB_FUNCNAME( INITNAME ), NULL },
{ ASSTRING( EXITNAME ), HB_FS_EXIT, THB_FUNCNAME( EXITNAME ), NULL }
HB_INIT_SYMBOLS_END(SYMBOLNAME(INITCNAME))

becomes:

static HB_SYMB symbols[] = {
{   first    , ( ( HB_SYMBOLSCOPE ) 0x08 ) , HB_FUN_first      , 0  },
{   second    , ( ( HB_SYMBOLSCOPE ) 0x10 ) , HB_FUN_second      , 0  }
}; static void __attribute__ ((constructor))  hb_vm_SymbolInit_INITCNAME   (
void ) { hb_vmProcessSymbols( symbols, sizeof( symbols ) / sizeof( HB_SYMB ) );
}

all of the elements are preprocessed properly except the first element of the
array structurs: it should have quotes around the names 'first' and 'second'

If I change:
#define ASSTRING( n ) n
to
#define ASSTRING( n ) #n

static HB_SYMB symbols[] = {
{ "INITNAME" , ( ( HB_SYMBOLSCOPE ) 0x08 ) , HB_FUN_first      , 0  },
{ "EXITNAME" , ( ( HB_SYMBOLSCOPE ) 0x10 ) , HB_FUN_second      , 0  }
};

I guess since the init/exit procs cannot be called directly, would there be any
problem with this field of the structure being a constant value?

Sincerly,

April
